webTitle: Lights go out for the Lightning

fields.headline: Lights go out for the Lightning
fields.standfirst:
Yorkshire Phoenix 225-5
Lancashire Lightning 138
Yorkshire win by 69 runs under D/L method
fields.trailText:
Yorkshire Phoenix 225-5
Lancashire Lightning 138
Yorkshire win by 69 runs under D/L method
fields.body:
The lights went out on Lancashire's hopes of retaining their National League title last night - in more ways than one.

This defeat leaves Lightning next to bottom of the table with eight points from six games, 16 points behind the leaders Worcestershire and in relegation danger. But Lancashire were also embarrassed for the second year running against Yorkshire when one of the temporary floodlights failed, causing a 20-minute delay - hugely frustrating for the players and an 11,850 crowd.

The only difference it made to the course of the game was to make an uphill task for Lancashire even steeper. When the light failed they were 96 for four in the 27th over, needing another 130 off 19. The deliberations of Duckworth and Lewis left them requiring 112 off less than 14, and despite John Crawley's first National League half-century of the season they ended 69 short.

This was a valuable win for Yorkshire, who had been sucked into relegation danger themselves after two weekend defeats. Lancashire sorely missed the injured Peter Martin and Ian Austin, with Mike Smethurst conceding 23 runs in four overs.

Matthew Wood was bowled around his legs by Chris Schofield, but Darren Lehmann dominated the remainder of the innings, sharing a second-wicket stand of 85 with Gary Fellows before the 21-year-old went for a tidy 57, and going on to a 65-ball half-century of his own.

Chris Silverwood, who was dropped for Yorkshire's weekend games and has seen Matthew Hoggard leapfrog him for an England place, then fired out Mark Chilton and Sourav Ganguly in a slippery opening burst, and when the equally impressive Paul Hutchison bowled Neil Fairbrother, Lancashire were 22 for three.

Crawley and Graham Lloyd threatened to make a game of it but Gavin Hamilton had Lloyd leg-before to extinguish their hopes.

 Neil Johnson followed his century against Somerset on Sunday with 81 not out off 114 balls as Zimbabwe beat Durham by eight wickets with 9.4 of their 50 overs to spare.

fields.headline: Letter
fields.standfirst: Charles Kennedy
fields.trailText: 28 June: I wouldn't wear a dinner jacket to Glastonbury
fields.body:
Whilst I know most politicians are totally out-of-touch, I would like to reassure your readers that even I wouldn't wear a dinner jacket to the Glastonbury Festival, as your reporter so outrageously suggested (Record number jump the fence, June 26). I know denim jackets are not at the cutting edge of today's street style - but then again, neither am I!
Charles Kennedy MP

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.trailText: Tom Lawson, 30 head of development funding
fields.body:
Tom Lawson, 30 head of development funding

When I worked for a charity, I was invited to lunch by a couple of parliamentary lobbyists. They took me to a swish restaurant and we didn't talk business until the last seven minutes of a three-hour lunch. I told them what I wanted, they said yes and the deal was done. It was all down to the fact that we got on so well. I learned from this that business lunches are as much about building relationships as deals and there's no point stopping the flow of conversation to blunder in with business talk. You have to see if a relationship will develop first, then discuss work later.

Chris Reynolds, 35 managing director

When I got my first big promotion, I asked a very important businesswoman in the organisation out to lunch because I was ambitious and I wanted to make good contacts. It all got rather embarrassing, though, because she clearly thought I'd organised lunch for personal rather than professional reasons and she kept flirting with me while I tried to steer her towards work issues. I learned that it's best to state at the start of a lunch why you've arranged it and that it's not a bad idea to send a letter of confirmation beforehand, mentioning the points you wish to discuss.

Peter Harris, 34 design consultant

I once had a bizarre lunch with a potential client. He was a millionaire, and my boss and I wanted to impress him by going somewhere terribly expensive, but he spotted the £7.50 special offer on the menu and thought we'd brought him there because it was such a bargain. We got his business because he was impressed with how we used our expense accounts! He thought if we were that good with the company's money, we'd be the same with his. Since then, I've always sounded out a potential client's secretary about where he or she likes to eat. That way you can get an idea of someone's tastes.

Sarah Green, 23 IT consultant

I had a three-month contract at one company and was invited out to a birthday lunch. There was a power struggle between the head of the department and his deputy, so all the deputy's cronies sat at one end of the table and all the head's cronies sat at the other. I chose a chair in between the two factions and chatted amiably with everyone because I'm freelance and can't afford to take sides. Where you sit at a lunch is as important as what you eat - and it's a bad idea to order alcohol or a pudding when no one else does. It raises questions of one's self-control.

Alison Parker, 38 chief executive

I remember inviting the MD of a big organisation to lunch once and waiting and waiting for him to arrive. His secretary said he'd left on time, but he turned up an hour and a quarter late, absolutely livid. I work in a big building where it's difficult to find your way around. I'd sent detailed directions but neither this chap nor his chauffeur had read them properly. As a result, lunch was a rushed disaster. Often there are lots of people involved in the working life of an important person and you have to make sure everyone knows the situation.

webTitle: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes

fields.headline: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: I have a weakness for nuns. I was educated in part by 70s sisters in habits of double-knit polyester and chunky shoes.
fields.body:
I have a weakness for nuns. I was educated in part by 70s sisters in habits of double-knit polyester and chunky shoes. They were lovely on the whole, so I'm feeling uneasy about my case this week. Mary, my client, was a secretary at a Catholic school. She was unmarried and obviously pregnant (seven months) when the school sacked her. This should be an obvious case of sex discrimination, except the nuns are denying that they knew Mary was pregnant. They are saying she was dismissed for "pilfering".

We have photos of Mary at the time she was sacked. She is five feet tall and looks like a children's book drawing of a worm that has swallowed an apple. The evidence of pilfering comes from an ancient sister who thought she may have left her rosary on Mary's desk. Or in the garden. Or under her bed.

I can tell the tribunal panel are uncomfortable. The chair does lots of hearty heh-hehing. "I don't need to ask whether you'll be wanting to swear on the Bible," he joshes Sister Veronica with crushing levity.

The school's barrister has been smirking continuously. When I ran into him before the tribunal in the Crumbly Muffin (as he was tucking into a full English breakfast), he said: "I'm looking forward to you reminding the sisters they're on oath." I refrained from telling him he had egg yolk on his tie.

Sister Veronica has a bland soft face like fallen dough, lightly whiskered in the sunlight falling on the witness table. After she gives her evidence-in-chief, another nun beetles up and whispers in her ear. This is a big no-no.

Me: "Uhh, excuse me, you're not meant to talk to Sister Veronica while she's giving evidence."

Nun: "I was just telling her that our prayers were with her to give her strength in the ordeal ahead."

An epidemic of smirking breaks out. I commence the ordeal. Sister Veronica is resolute that she "never notices that sort of thing" (pregnancy bumps), her mind being on other (higher) matters. I am reduced to: "Well, what about pictures of the Virgin Mary before she gives birth to the baby Jesus? It must have struck you that her figure is somewhat altered."

A wily smile plays over Sister Veronica's lips. "Oh, but you see, dear, I would be looking at her face, at her expression of exaltation, the sublime meekness with which she accepted her role" and so forth. The tribunal panel says it will give its decision in writing. I don't blame them. I don't think I could tell Sister Veronica to her face that she was lying either.

fields.headline: Regaining Latin links
fields.standfirst:
Cubanismo
Jazz Cafe, London
***
fields.trailText:
Cubanismo
Jazz Cafe, London
***
fields.body:
Cubanismo are a great dance band who have recorded best-selling albums but never enjoyed the massive acclaim of those more elderly Cuban veterans, the Buena Vista Social Club, though they come from the same roots. Band leader Jesus Alemany started out, as a teenager, playing trumpet in the revivalist son band Sierra Maestra, who helped popularise early Cuban styles and led the way for the Buena Vista project. After moving to London, he assembled his own band of leading Cuban musicians, who may not be able to match the Buena Vista stars in terms of personality, but can't be faulted for energy, musicianship, even bravery.

Inevitably, the band is dominated by the brass section, led by Alemany's own tight, energetic trumpet work. Dressed in a gold velvet shirt, he looked as if he could have become the Cuban equivalent of Hugh Masekela, but at the Jazz Cafe he never pushed himself forward, taking no lead vocals and remarkably few solos. Instead, he punctuated the songs with slick arrangements, driving on a 14-piece band who played full tilt through much of the set but still sounded fresh after two and a half hours.

With four slick percussionists, good keyboard, bass and tres (Cuban guitar) players, and up to five of the band joining in the chanting vocals, they could have kept going for much of the night. They may have concentrated on rapid-fire dance styles, but this is a band clearly keen to develop new Cuban fusions and establish links across the Caribbean. They demonstrated their clash of Cuban son and Jamaican reggae with an inspired Latin treatment of Bob Marley's Could You Be Loved, and when previewing their next album, which intriguingly sets out to re-establish the old musical links between Havana and New Orleans.

Mardi Gras Mambo, which will be released in August, is a collaboration between Cubanismo and New Orleans musicians; the result is a gloriously cheerful mixture of Cuban styles with R&B, Mardi Gras chanting and even rap - just the sort of album that wins a Grammy. The Cubans and Americans, including singer John Boutte and members of the Yockamo All-Stars, will get together again for a tour after its release, but even on their own, Cubanismo showed they have the skill to ease into New Orleans jazz, then back to those Cuban roots.

fields.headline: Gripped by a storyteller
fields.standfirst:
Richard Thompson
Fairfield Halls, Croydon
****
fields.trailText:
Richard Thompson
Fairfield Halls, Croydon
****
fields.body:
According to Richard Thompson, he loves having Sandy Dillon on tour with him because she "makes me sound cheerful". Dillon is strange, to say the least. With her straight dark hair, pharaoh make-up and thin, elongated body, she looks as if she haunts grave yards at the witching hour, looking for buried inspiration. Her songs are dark and heavy, not least Too Rough, a cacophony of random noise and ironic rock'n'roll postures. When she sings, her voice swoops unnervingly between Betty Boop and John Lee Hooker.

Despite his veteran status, Richard Thompson can still surprise and unsettle too. Armed only with his acoustic guitar, with a fetishistic Vincent Black Lightning motorcycle parked onstage beside him for dramatic effect, he ripped through a potent selection from his bottomless back catalogue.

Dressed in a baggy dark suit and black beret, Thompson bantered matily with the audience, mocking his own meagre record sales and joking facetiously about his lack of superstar status. But when he sings, a deeper, stranger Thompson emerges. His guitar playing is deft and decisive, whether he's piling on the powerchord-strum of Feel So Good or fingerpicking his way with bleak precision through Cold Kisses. Where his speaking voice is diffident and throwaway, he sings with a stridency and power which make you wonder why he ever felt he needed a backing band. In I Misunderstood, he managed to sound both wounded and vengeful; in Shoot Out the Lights, the force of his performance made him seem two feet taller.

He has always stuck fast to his roots in classic folk music, and he has become a gripping story-teller. He apologised for adding new biker-friendly verses to his Vincent Black Lightning saga, a classic tale of love, death and loyalty. In God Loves a Drunk, a dirge in 3/4 time, he shone a redemptive light on the squalid details of his tale. And if that's not enough, Thompson is the only performer I've ever seen who can change a broken guitar string while ad libbing his way through Twist and Shout. That's worth a Grammy, at least.

Richard Thompson plays the Playhouse, Oxford (01865 798600), tomorrow.

fields.headline: In the company of women
fields.standfirst:
Stop Kiss
Soho Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Stop Kiss
Soho Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
New York plays tend to come in two kinds: the harshly tough or the wistfully tender. Diana Son's Stop Kiss is very much one of the latter: a gentle study of slow-burning love between two women that soothes and caresses without ruffling any feathers.

Callie is a traffic reporter for a local New York radio station: Sara is a gauche newcomer from St Louis who is teaching third grade in a Bronx public school. They meet through mutual friends and Callie offers both to shepherd Sara round the city and look after her cat.

But, through a jump forward in time, we know that they are jointly assaulted one dawn in the West Village and that Sara suffers life-threatening abrasions.

Despite the concern shown by their ex-boyfriends we sense that the attack is somehow prompted by their intimate closeness.

Son has a shrewd eye for the sexual tentativeness of the physically shy. Callie and Sara bond instantly, swap secrets and are clearly drawn to each other; but some natural inhibition stops them lunging at each other as they clearly long to.

Even when they share a bed they remain as impeccably chaste as Laurel and Hardy. And if the play has any wider point to make, it is about the ruinousness of restraint: it is precisely because they are unable to express their passion in private that Callie and Sara risk disaster by exchanging a public kiss.

The play is tender, compassionate, sincere: my only complaint is that it courts sentimentality by making its putative lovers so exhaustingly nice.

Sara does not just teach in the Bronx but is adored by everyone in her class; and, although Callie is stuck in a dead-end job, she naturally wins a prize for best traffic reporter. Even Callie's boyfriend is deeply understanding, and an investigating cop exhibits exemplary patience. Is this New York, I kept wondering, or Brigadoon?

But, sugar-coated though it is, Son's 90-minute play slips down easily. And Abigail Morris's production catches exactly the dual heroines' mix of wariness and longing. Though she looks more like a Wasp princess than a one-time klutz, Holly Aird excellently conveys the suppressed yearning of the cautious Callie, and Georgia Mackenzie is all brooding dark-eyed watchfulness as her would-be lover.

Scott Fitzgerald said there are no second acts in American lives. Now there are no second acts in American plays either. But this one, though it has a touch of the fairytale, makes its point about the danger of closeted lesbian love with pleasantly economical compassion.

Until July 22. Box office: 020 7478 0100. This review appeared in some editions of yesterday's Guardian.

webTitle: WorldCom-Sprint merger near collapse after US goes to law

fields.headline: WorldCom-Sprint merger near collapse after US goes to law
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The £76bn merger of telephone groups WorldCom and Sprint was on the verge of collapse after global regulators yesterday said they would block the deal.
fields.body:
The £76bn merger of telephone groups WorldCom and Sprint was on the verge of collapse after global regulators yesterday said they would block the deal.

The US department of justice said it would file a lawsuit to block the merger of long distance operator Sprint with its bigger rival.

US attorney general Janet Reno said: "This merger threatens to undermine the competitive gains achieved since the [justice] department challenged AT&T's monopoly of the telecommunications industry 25 years ago."

European competition commissioner Mario Monti said this week that neither company had provided solutions to competition concerns and he would recommend against approving the deal in its present form.

The European commission was expected to make a ruling on the merger today. However, last night both companies withdrew their merger proposals from the EC review.

WorldCom and Sprint rank second and third respectively in the American long-distance telephone market, behind AT&T. The three companies control about 80% of the market and regulators are concerned that the union of Sprint and WorldCom could lead to dominance in long-distance and internet markets, and to higher pricing for services.

The US justice department's lawsuit says: "For millions of residential and business customers throughout the nation, the merger will lead to higher prices, lower service quality and less innovation."

WorldCom runs the biggest internet backbone in the US, carrying about 37% of data traffic. Sprint operates the second-biggest network, accounting for about 16%.

WorldCom yesterday said it would "promptly review its options with Sprint".

Sprint said: "We are disappointed that we have been unable to convince the justice department that the merger is in the best interest of the Ameri can public and would advance competition."

Analysts predicted yesterday that WorldCom would abandon the deal unless it could strike an agreement to purchase only a portion of Sprint's operations, such as its mobile unit.

Both companies have already offered to divest f Sprint's internet operations. However, the justice department is understood to have said that was not enough and any proposal must also include Sprint's long-distance and local telephone operations.

Yet the European competition commission has reservations about such a break-up of Sprint, citing the failings two years ago of the deal between WorldCom and MCI.

The merger of WorldCom and MCI was approved on the condition that MCI's internet business was sold.

Cable & Wireless bought the business and later sued WorldCom, claiming the company poached customers and withheld support staff.

If a scenario occurred where Sprint's long-distance and internet businesses were put up for sale, Deutsche Telekom has been tipped as a likely buyer.

The German telecommunications group has been looking for a way to enter the US long-distance market to achieve its desire for a global network.

fields.bodyText: The £76bn merger of telephone groups WorldCom and Sprint was on the verge of collapse after global regulators yesterday said they would block the deal. The US department of justice said it would file a lawsuit to block the merger of long distance operator Sprint with its bigger rival. US attorney general Janet Reno said: "This merger threatens to undermine the competitive gains achieved since the [justice] department challenged AT&T's monopoly of the telecommunications industry 25 years ago." European competition commissioner Mario Monti said this week that neither company had provided solutions to competition concerns and he would recommend against approving the deal in its present form. The European commission was expected to make a ruling on the merger today. However, last night both companies withdrew their merger proposals from the EC review. WorldCom and Sprint rank second and third respectively in the American long-distance telephone market, behind AT&T. The three companies control about 80% of the market and regulators are concerned that the union of Sprint and WorldCom could lead to dominance in long-distance and internet markets, and to higher pricing for services. The US justice department's lawsuit says: "For millions of residential and business customers throughout the nation, the merger will lead to higher prices, lower service quality and less innovation." WorldCom runs the biggest internet backbone in the US, carrying about 37% of data traffic. Sprint operates the second-biggest network, accounting for about 16%. WorldCom yesterday said it would "promptly review its options with Sprint". Sprint said: "We are disappointed that we have been unable to convince the justice department that the merger is in the best interest of the Ameri can public and would advance competition." Analysts predicted yesterday that WorldCom would abandon the deal unless it could strike an agreement to purchase only a portion of Sprint's operations, such as its mobile unit. Both companies have already offered to divest f Sprint's internet operations. However, the justice department is understood to have said that was not enough and any proposal must also include Sprint's long-distance and local telephone operations. webTitle: Posters and T-shirts lead the way to victory

fields.headline: Posters and T-shirts lead the way to victory
fields.trailText: Standard Life's staff turned up for work yesterday in T-shirts proclaiming "keep Standard Life mutual", while shopkeepers in the Scottish capital posted stickers on their windows with similar messages.
fields.body:
Standard Life's staff turned up for work yesterday in T-shirts proclaiming "keep Standard Life mutual", while shopkeepers in the Scottish capital posted stickers on their windows with similar messages.

While the people of Edinburgh may have been keen to show their concern about the impact of the insurance group losing its mutual status on jobs and the city's economic prosperity, others were as mesmerised by the outcome of yesterday's crucial vote.

If the carpetbaggers had won and voted in favour of demutualisation, this would have been widely regarded as the death knell for the entire mutual sector.

Few of the other remaining mutuals were expected to survive if Standard Life, Europe's largest mutual, had not resisted the pressure.

However, the City, deprived of a stock market flotation of as much as £18bn, still believes that the insurer has no time to be complacent. "It needs to communicate better with its members and really demonstrate the benefits of mutuality," Jonathan Sheehan, insurance analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson said yesterday.

The local concerns about jobs may only serve to reinforce the sentiment among some listed rivals that mutuals are over staffed and far from efficient, hiding the truth about the products they have on offer.

Despite this, the pro-mutual campaigners were proclaiming victory yesterday.

Nationwide Building Society, which fought off its own carpetbaggers, welcomed the news. Chief executive, Brian Davis, said: "I have to say I am really pleased. It seems people have understood that a windfall is not a free handout."

The Building Societies Association, which has watched its membership shrink, said: "This landmark vote is testament to its members' belief that the organisation served them well as a mutual, and will continue to do so in the future."

fields.headline: Take a break
fields.standfirst: Going on a summer holiday? Or are you one of the 60% of Brits who are too busy, too scared or simply too disorganised to take their full holiday entitlement?  Stefan Stern  reports
fields.trailText: Going on a summer holiday? Or are you one of the 60% of Brits who are too busy, too scared or simply too disorganised to take their full holiday entitlement? Stefan Stern reports
fields.body:
Cliff Richard may have confounded the critics with the length of his pop career, but one Cliff number that has failed the test of time is "We're all going on a summer holiday". The fact is, we're not. If online recruiters totaljobs.com can be believed, an astonishing 60% of British workers are failing to take their full holiday entitlement. As summer arrives and many people's thoughts turn to beaches, bars and complete relaxation, the once-skiving British worker is apparently clocking on for an extra shift. And, according to the totaljobs.com survey, half of us even feel guilty when - if - we finally do get away.

Paid leave, like health and safety legislation, equal pay and equal opportunities, represents one of the great achievements of the modern workplace. Since last October, thanks to the Working Time Directive, British employees are entitled to four weeks paid leave a year, by statute. Law-abiding employers have to put this legislation into practice. It's what we used to call progress. But all over the country, it appears, "free" employees can be heard calling for chains. Why?

Britain's long working hours culture has been well charted in these pages and, at its simplest, not taking holiday is simply the latest manifestation of this wider trend. Some people stay at work under the (usually misguided) impression that they are indispensable. Others just don't trust their colleagues to carry out even simple tasks in their absence. And, worst of all, some are simply too scared to ask for what is rightfully theirs - a full holiday entitlement. The spectre of a domineering boss or a muscular competitor makes a holiday seem an unaffordable luxury.

It is a complicated picture. "Some people set themselves very high standards," says Nick Isles, spokesman for the Institute of Personnel and Development (IPD). "They find it difficult to let go, and don't want to let the company down. This latest statistic has more to do with employee choice than some people might realise."

But the IPD is under no illusions about the main cause of the non-holidaying culture. "Pressure from employers - especially in smaller businesses - may be keeping a lot of people at work for longer," says Isles. When there is healthy growth in the economy and rising demand for goods and services, these pressures are likely to increase. If the firm's survival apparently depends on meeting that big new order, who are you to swan off while your colleagues stay late and keep you in a job? Will your team understand when you explain it's the boss's fault for not hiring enough staff?

There is another reason for our apparent willingness to forgo the beach. Britain, situated as it is between the US and mainland Europe, looks both ways when it comes to working practices. Look one way, towards the tough, lean American model, with its minimal holidays, fierce competition and low unemployment, and we feel lucky to have any days off at all; look towards Europe, with greater employee protection, less "flexibility" and long siestas, and we feel aggrieved. Who should we be emulating?

But maybe there doesn't have to be an explicit choice. Mike Johnson, co-author of the recently published Workaholism - How to Get a Life in the Killing Fields of Work (Naomi Roth Publishing, £9.95), sees a great deal of convergence in attitudes to employee terms and conditions around the British middle ground.

"The French are getting a little less generous, while in the US things are getting a little more generous," says Johnson, an American by birth. The idea that American's take two weeks holiday a year is something of an exaggeration, he says, as holiday entitlement often builds up the longer you stay with a company.

None-the-less, Johnson adds, organising your time to be able to take even the minimum four weeks off a year requires planning and thought. That is one of the biggest causes of people failing to take all their holiday. The psychological challenge - simply staying sane while trying to do a hard job well, and take the necessary holiday to be able to keep up that level of work - is enormous. We are not helped in this challenge by bullying, unscrupulous or disingenuous managers, who play on our better natures and exert moral pressure on us to stay around.

But at a time when all companies tell us that their people are their biggest asset, we should be on our guard, too, against senior managers bearing gifts. The leading US academic Arlie Hochschild spoke recently at an Industrial Society seminar of the dangers of what she called "the absorptive workplace - the company that feels like a village".

According to Hochschild's analysis, some of us are not using up all our holidays because we've be hoodwinked into feeling that we've been away already. Absorbtive companies provide so many services to you as an employee, and spend so much energy in building pseudo-communities at work, that the message is: "You can get away while you're here."

Support structures exist to wash your clothes, "look after" your children, bring you food: life is "outsourced", and the company gets all your energies. At its worst, Hochschild suggested, this tendency leads companies to exploit our very human concern to work well and be productive, creating "workaholic cults" where work is the only option and holiday or leisure almost an irrelevance.

Meanwhile, the sun is shining, you've been working too long, you need a holiday. For Janet Williamson at the TUC, there is a fairly obvious solution to all this: "Good managers encourage workers to take all their holiday. They will be more productive, and it is good for family life. It's a sign of poor work organisation if holiday isn't being taken." Nick Isles at the IPD agrees, pointing to the evidence of long-term damage to health when employees don't get the holiday they need.

And for anyone out there who still can't bear to walk away, Mike Johnson has a final warning: "People think they are getting brownie points for working long and late, and for not taking holiday. That's quite wrong. It shows you're inefficient, it actually reveals that you've got problems. When the next downsizing comes, don't think you'll be spared just because you didn't take your holiday!"

 Stefan Stern is features editor of Management Today magazine.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 shorts
fields.trailText: • Paolo Maldini is doubtful for Italy's semi-final against Holland on Thursday after straining his left thigh in the quarter-final win over Romania on Saturday. The left-back has been told to rest his leg until tomorrow.
fields.body:
 Paolo Maldini is doubtful for Italy's semi-final against Holland on Thursday after straining his left thigh in the quarter-final win over Romania on Saturday. The left-back has been told to rest his leg until tomorrow.

Antonio Conte, who will miss the rest of the tournament after suffering torn ligaments in a late challenge from Gheorghe Hagi in the same game, has said that Romania's captain was trying to break his leg.

"We professionals know well when there is the desire to hurt someone," the midfielder said. "Hagi wanted to break my leg and for this I didn't accept his apology at the end of the match."

Internazionale's Luigi di Biagio is likely to replace Conte in the side to face Holland.

 France's Christophe Dugarry is likely to be fit for tomorrow's semi-final against Portugal despite suffering a broken nose during Sunday's quarter-final win over Spain. France's only other injury concern is the midfielder Emmanuel Petit, who has missed the last two matches after damaging knee ligaments.

 Italy's Stefano Fiore is auctioning off his team's shirts in a bid to raise money to help the fight against child abuse. The 25-year-old Udinese midfielder is organising the sale on his personal web site, www.stefanofiore.com. The proceeds are going to a telephone hotline in Italy called Telefono Azzurro.

"This comes from the deepest of my heart," Fiore said. "We soccer players have an obligation to help those who suffer. It's not enough just to score a goal or play a great match to justify your existence."

 Dutch police detained 30 people in Rotterdam for lighting forbidden flares and fireworks, drunkenness, possession of knives, vandalism and troublemaking after Holland's 6-1 quarter-final win over Yugoslavia.

Two others were arrested after a fight involving 15 people broke out in the stands of the De Kuip stadium where the match was played. Police made two other arrests in The Hague and were forced to clear the main square following the match, when they considered fans were becoming dangerously agitated.

 Total attendances for the tournament will rise above one million after the semi-finals. A total of 955,150 spectators have watched the first 28 matches, an average of 34,113 per match.

 Sweden's Anders Frisk has been chosen to referee the final on Sunday in Rotterdam. Frisk, a 37-year-old insurance claims manager, was the referee for England's 3-2 defeat against Portugal and for Holland's win over France by the same scoreline.

Austria's Günter Benko will take charge of tomorrow's semi-final in Brussels between France and Portugal and Germany's Markus Merk was awarded Thursday's semi-final between Holland and Italy in Amsterdam.

webTitle: Rioch the new man at Wigan

fields.headline: Rioch the new man at Wigan
fields.trailText: Bruce Rioch yesterday assumed control at Second Division Wigan Athletic six months after walking out on Norwich City claiming that the East Anglian club was unable to match his sense of personal ambition.
fields.body:
Bruce Rioch yesterday assumed control at Second Division Wigan Athletic six months after walking out on Norwich City claiming that the East Anglian club was unable to match his sense of personal ambition.

Rioch has been invited to help fulfil the Wigan chairman Dave Whelan's dream of bringing Premiership football to his club's state-of-the-art JJB stadium. He replaces John Benson, who opted to undertake a more administrative role after Wigan had been beaten by Gillingham in last month's Second Division play-off final at Wembley.

Wigan becomes Rioch's seventh club in a managerial career which has included spells at Torquay, Middlesbrough, Millwall, Bolton, Arsenal and Norwich.

His appointment is something of a surprise as it had been assumed that the former Sheffield Wednesday manager Danny Wilson, who was born in Wigan, would be asked to succeed Benson. Instead Wilson will be unveiled as the new manager of Second Division Bristol City this afternoon.

Although in the past Whelan has insisted that his managers work without a contract, he confirmed yesterday that Rioch would sign a deal which would cover at least the next three years.

"This does represent a great challenge for me," said Rioch. "This is a very tough industry but I have joined an ambitious and forward-thinking club. I am really happy to be back in management."

The Celtic striker Mark Viduka last night agreed to join Leeds after several days of negotiations conducted over the internet.

The Australian international is currently in the Far East but his advisors have negotiated a five-year contract worth £22,000 a week by email. Viduka will complete the deal after undergoing a medical at Elland Road on Friday.

Nick Barmby will see the Everton manager Walter Smith this morning to discuss his future at Goodison Park. Although Everton have refused to concede defeat in their fight to hang on to the England international, it is clear he wishes to move on.

Several clubs have expressed an interest in Barmby but the likelihood is he will be most enthusiastically pursued by Chelsea. Barmby has 12 months remaining on his contract and Smith must sanction his sale now or run the risk of losing him on a free transfer next summer.

Meanwhile Everton should complete the £3m transfer of the Italian full-back Alessandro Pistone from Newcastle later this week.

Liverpool's Cameroon international full-back Rigobert Song has opened talks with Marseille over a £3.5m transfer to the French club. Another Anfield full-back, Stig Inge Bjornebye, has completed his £300,000 move to Blackburn.

Chelsea's Chris Sutton has held preliminary talks with the Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson over a £6m transfer to Teesside while Rangers have completed the £2m signing of the Hibernian striker Kenny Miller.

The Argentinian forward Daniel Cordone will fly to England later this week to undergo a medical prior to completing a £500,000 switch to Newcastle. The 26-year-old Racing Club man will sign a 12-month contract with an option on a two-year extension and will join his fellow Argentinian Christian Bassedas at St James' Park.

webTitle: Final four have 2000 lessons for England

fields.headline: Final four have 2000 lessons for England
fields.trailText: Freedom, within a framework of discipline, has underpinned the semi-finalists' success.
fields.body:
Des Lynam had a funny old feeling that Holland might go out to Yugoslavia on Sunday night. And, although he may not thank me for reminding him, I'm delighted to say he couldn't have been more wrong.

The great news is that we are left not just with the four best teams but with four teams whose philosophy shows England the way ahead. They have a basis of defensive strategy and, to varying degrees, use a fluid system that allows the best players to go out and express themselves.

Only the Dutch play with any sort of strict formation and, with Dennis Bergkamp floating, it is hardly set in cement. You'd be hard-pressed to state what the Portuguese system is because people like Luis Figo get everywhere. Against Turkey he started on the left and set up two goals from the right.

The French are also very fluid and the Italians are the same in the top part of the field. They have a rigid three at the back but it's difficult to say where Stefano Fiore, Francesco Totti and Antonio Conte play. They don't govern any one area. And that freedom, within a framework of discipline, has underpinned these teams' success.

It gives them a creativity, an unpredictability and an expressiveness that England lacked. We have got good players but I think we have to get them to perform in a refreshing manner.

I'd like to see David Beckham as the playmaker, surrounded by people like Kieron Dyer, Steve McManaman and Paul Scholes, who would be told: "There's the football. Just go out and kick it between you." So what if at first we lose? We're losing anyway, only in an ugly manner. Let's dare them to show us some skill.

I will never forget Jimmy Hogan, one of my coaches when I was a youngster at Aston Villa. He had coached the Hungarians of the Puskas era and the Austrians before that and he wanted us all to be comfortable on the ball.

Of course I'm not talking about having centre-halves playing up the wings. You need disciplined people and a few who can not only win challenges but move things on. The Dutch, for instance, have Edgar Davids and Philip Cocu, who are not just hammer-throwers who win tackles. They can play and will keep movements going. The same goes for Patrick Vieira, who has come in and looked an established international for France. Christophe Dugarry, who I didn't think could trap a ball, has also shown some great tricks.

One of the things that has been lacking is surprises. I thought there might be a hiccup - there always is - but the four expected to win their quarter-finals have done so. The only giantkilling of the tournament was Norway's win over Spain, which ultimately counted for nothing. But that is not to say everything is too predictable. Not too many fancied Portugal before the tournament began.

They have been great but I think their journey will end tomorrow. Even though France have gone off the boil a bit, perhaps feeling the pressure of being favourites, I think they will have too much power.

fields.headline: Cullinan phoned 33 times, inquiry told
fields.standfirst:
New evidence puts Cronje's team-mates in the spotlight
Condon to clean up cricket
More about the corruption of cricket
fields.trailText: The Johannesburg sweet-shop owner and bookmaker's go-between Hamid Cassim repeatedly telephoned several South African players - including Daryll Cullinan, Paul Adams and Lance Klusener - during last winter's triangular tournament involving England and Zimbabwe, the King Commission revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
The Johannesburg sweet-shop owner and bookmaker's go-between Hamid Cassim repeatedly telephoned several South African players - including Daryll Cullinan, Paul Adams and Lance Klusener - during last winter's triangular tournament involving England and Zimbabwe, the King Commission revealed yesterday.

According to evidence presented to the inquiry in Cape Town, "Banjo" Cassim rang Cullinan 33 times, with the batsman twice returning his call. He placed 30 calls to Adams, 28 to Klusener, 11 to Jonty Rhodes, six to the former seamer Fanie de Villiers, three to the new captain Shaun Pollock and 18 to the team manager Goolam Rajah - none of whom had previously been implicated in match-fixing.

The opener Herschelle Gibbs, left out of next month's tour of Sri Lanka, received 14 calls and rang Cassim himself three times.

Judge Edwin King adjourned the inquiry yesterday after two weeks of hearings. But the latest revelations are likely to see Cullinan, Gibbs and others take the stand again when the inquiry reopens, probably in three months.

The commission also heard that Cassim rang Hansie Cronje an astonishing 180 times, with the former captain returning his call on 11 occasions. But the 46-year-old Cassim, who first introduced Cronje to the London-based bookmaker Sanjay Chawla, denied any involvement in match-fixing.

"It is my nature to phone all the players all the time," said Cassim, who is famed for giving the dried meat biltong to the South African players.

He told the inquiry that he saw Cronje accept money from Chawla in a Durban hotel two nights before South Africa's surprise one-day defeat by Zimbabwe on February 2. "They talked about match forecasting, pitch conditions, team selections and the conditions upon winning the toss.

"I then saw Sanjay take an envelope containing money and hand it to Mr Cronje. I was surprised that Cronje took it. Chawla said: 'Keep this and we'll talk later'."

King now has until Friday to present an interim report to South Africa's national president Thabo Mbeki. His findings will be crucial to the future of Cronje, whose admission in April that he had accepted money from bookmakers triggered the inquiry.

Cronje has been promised immunity from criminal prosecution if he is deemed to have been completely honest with the inquiry but it is unclear how King will judge certain aspects of Cronje's evidence - particularly his failure to identify other players involved in rigging matches.

"I don't suppose there's a pub in the country where people haven't discussed how to eradicate match-fixing," King concluded. "I would welcome suggestions from the public."

Cronje, meanwhile, begged yesterday for forgiveness. "I have let the board, the team, the fans and the game down," he said. "I am bitterly sorry."

fields.headline: Condon to clean up cricket
fields.standfirst:
Cullinan phoned 33 times, inquiry told
More about the corruption of cricket
fields.trailText: The former commissioner of the Metropolitan police Sir Paul Condon has been appointed as the first director of the International Cricket Council's independent Anti-Corruption Investigation.
fields.body:
The former commissioner of the Metropolitan police Sir Paul Condon has been appointed as the first director of the International Cricket Council's independent Anti-Corruption Investigation.

His post, which is for a minimum of three years up to and including the 2003 World Cup in South Africa, was ratified at yesterday's full meeting of the ICC at Lord's. If there was any opposition to an Englishman delving into the murky world of cricket corruption, given its links into Asia, then no one was admitting it.

"I am satisfied that there is a critical mass of support" is all that Condon would say on the matter, apart from stressing that no one was above suspicion. He did, however, state that he had no policing powers and was not instigating a criminal investigation.

It is only in the past few days that Condon was even considered a candidate. He may not be the forty-something, thrusting young barrister envisaged by the incoming ICC president Malcolm Gray but he is only 53, recently retired and his credentials for the job are immense - not least with his own lengthy efforts to rid the Met of corruption during his seven-year term of office.

As commissioner, Condon withstood calls to resign over the Macpherson report into the Stephen Lawrence inquiry. But perhaps his strongest suit is his close and extensive worldwide network of senior police colleagues, and his appointment was "not unconnected with this".

Gray said Condon would be the last important cog in the wheel to stamp out corruption from the game. His terms of reference have yet to be finalised but it was confirmed that he will operate independently of the ICC, reporting only to Lord Griffiths, chairman of the ICC's code of conduct commission.

"I had to be satisfied on three counts," Condon said yesterday. "Firstly, that there was real resolve in the ICC to tackle the problem, and from the good discussion at the meeting I am satisfied.

"Secondly, that I would have the total independence that would be necessary to have any real impact on cricket. Thirdly, I had to be confident that the investigation would be properly resourced.

"I have been assured on all counts and will be setting up the unit over the next few weeks and months. I shall be drawing on any expertise necessary, which could include investigators, financial and legal experts and cricket people who can point out where the opportunities for malpractice are."

Condon himself will not be full-time, though he will devote a considerable part of his time to the task and will employ a full-time staff.

"It is a real challenge," he said, "which I hope will bring benefit to the game. I am confident of the full cooperation of all the countries. There has to be real resolve. It is in the interest of everyone to get this right. The alternative is unthinkable."

Early issues for Condon to address include the Qayyum Report, currently under consideration by Lord Griffiths, and the findings of the King Commission in Cape Town, particularly Ali Bacher's allegations that two World Cup matches were fixed last summer and that the umpire Javed Akhtar was involved in fixing the final test against England in 1998.

Condon is also likely to seek the News of the World tapes and transcripts which allegedly incriminate Pakistan and Australian players. He is not yet clear how retrospective his inquiry needs to be. "I need to understand what the opportunities were but I also need to put the mechanism in place to ensure malpractice does not happen in the future."

fields.headline: Davies, 15, set to make history
fields.trailText: Leanne Davies is on target to become the youngest player ever in international women's cricket, at 15 years 33 days, when England try to build on their 2-1 series lead over South Africa in tomorrow's fourth match at Taunton.
fields.body:
Leanne Davies is on target to become the youngest player ever in international women's cricket, at 15 years 33 days, when England try to build on their 2-1 series lead over South Africa in tomorrow's fourth match at Taunton.

The Rochdale seamer is on standby for Laura Newton, who is suffering knee problems. If Davies plays she will beat the record held by the Cook Islander Manukoa Tanupopo, who was 15 years 357 days when she first played for New Zealand against England in February.

While older heads such as Wasim Akram, Alec Stewart and even Arjuna Ranatunga are enjoying a new lease of life in the men's game, the young brigade are taking all before them in women's cricket. Davies is vying for the honour of becoming England's youngest ever player with the 16-year-old Somerset off-spinner Laura Harper.

 Jarrod Englefield's 72 carried New Zealand A to victory over Worcestershire by four wickets yesterday. Two days earlier he was fined for throwing down his bat after being run out against West Indies.

fields.headline: New media deal brings bonanza
fields.trailText: World cricket has been handed a cash bonanza by the ICC with the negotiations for a media partnership that will extend to the 2007 World Cup in the Caribbean and bring in a minimum of £360m.
fields.body:
World cricket has been handed a cash bonanza by the International Cricket Council with the negotiations for a media partnership that will extend to the 2007 World Cup in the Caribbean.

The partnership, with the World Sports Group and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, will bring the ICC a minimum of $550m (£360m) in exchange for the right to negotiate media deals, but it could amount to much more, with any surplus after operating costs being divided on an 80-20 percentage basis in favour of the ruling body.

According to the ICC's chief executive David Richards, it had been decided to go for the bundling of rights rather than selling individual tournaments - included are the 2003 and 2007 World Cups, the ICC Knockout in Nairobi in October and the ICC Trophy in Canada next year as well as other smaller tournaments - simply because it has secured a much higher figure.

It is far and away the largest sum ever negotiated for the game and represents a move away from individual host countries negotiating their own broadcasting rights for global tournaments.

One immediate effect, in the light of allegations of impropriety against those who did the negotiating on a previous ICC tournament in Bangladesh, and the new resolve for openness, will be the publishing of ICC accounts for the first time.

Bangladesh, however, was celebrating last night having learnt that 26 years after their country was first accepted as an associate member of the ICC they have been granted full test status, making them the 10th test playing nation.

They were given one-day international status in 1997 but fears that the quality of their cricket did not meet the standards required - their limited-overs record is uninspired - were allayed and there is no doubting the quality of the infrastructure in the country and the suitability of the stadium, in Dhakar, which is outstanding, nor the supporters' fervent enthusiasm for the game.

"Test cricket has today embraced and welcomed 130 million people to its fold," said the president of the Bangladesh Cricket Board, Saber Chowdhury yesterday.

"Test cricket has today embraced and welcomed 130 million people to its fold," said the president of the Bangladesh Cricket Board, Saber Chowdhury yesterday.

fields.headline: Community at the core
fields.standfirst: The Lloyds/TSB Teaching Awards continue this week with gongs in four more regions
fields.trailText: The Lloyds/TSB Teaching Awards continue this week with gongs in four more regions
fields.body:
It's no secret that the teacher of the year award meets a cool reception in some staffrooms, where the concept of "pot-hunting" is seen as damaging to teamwork.

The view is often strongest in areas where "community" is a word with real meaning and where a local tradition of cooperation has potential candidates thinking: "An award just for me? No way."

The north-east is one of the strongholds of these values, and its tally of entries is lower than elsewhere; but the awards ceremony in Newcastle upon Tyne offered good reasons for persuading the reluctant to join in.

Not only did the Lord Mayor, Peter Thomson, make teamwork his whole theme. But also Lisa Byrom made a very particular point.

The word "special" in her school's case has nothing to do with special needs; when she joined the staff at Bransty primary near Whitehaven, the school was in special measures. It had just been given a very poor Ofsted report and appeared to be the very opposite of the high-flying, where's-the-next-gong? type of place.

Newly qualified, Lisa brought a couple of distinctions to her job that were not officially on the teacher-training curriculum: permanent enthusiasm and a belief in aiming high. She was asked to coordinate two failing areas noted by Ofsted: numeracy and special needs, and she did so with vim.

"She's an absolutely brilliant teacher, our children are so lucky to be taught by her," said one of the parental fan club from a place which, as Lisa says, "tends to drop off the map of Britain".

Tom Baker, butt of many classroom jokes about daleks and Dr Who, also made the community point, with huge applause when he took the north-east lifetime achievement in teaching award. On top of 34 years at Red Rose primary in Chester le Street, County Durham, he has run the town's boys' football team for three decades as well as the county primaries' FA. "There can be very few lives in Chester le Street which haven't been touched by this extraordinary man," read his citation; and no one was contradicting.

 Martin Wainwright

Football also flitted in and out of the speeches at the south-east region teaching awards ceremony. Sean O'Regan, winner of the Leadership Trust for school leadership, had it on his mind as he explained how his school in King's Cross was Edith Neville primary - "remember the name" - rather than Phil Neville, the player who had given away the penalty that caused England's downfall.

In many ways the event was the perfect antidote: a different sort of tears, and everybody got a jolly good cheering up.

The audience of 450 at the Café Royal in London heard how Sean O'Regan was plucked from the classroom to become acting head after his predecessor resigned in 1996. In the first week, the school was closed due to subsidence; within eight working days he found a temporary local site and the school was up and running again.

The school prospered, coming through an imminent Ofsted with flying colours. All the more remarkable, then, that O'Regan didn't apply to become head first of all, thinking it was too hard and wanting to get back to the classroom; only when the post wasn't filled did he allow his arm to be twisted.

 Will Woodward

Andrea Wyganowski is so dedicated to her job that she is often at her desk at Hyde Technology School at 7am. She jokes that she and the head have a race every day to see who can be at work the earliest. Her commitment to her job as senior maths teacher has seen her promoted six times in 11 years and now she has won the Guardian award for the secondary teacher of the year for the north-west, presented at Liverpool town hall.

 Helen Carter

fields.headline: Unlocking e-commerce
fields.standfirst: Mark Tran takes a look at the latest Keywords technology aimed at boosting online sales
fields.trailText: Mark Tran takes a look at the latest Keywords technology aimed at boosting online sales
fields.body:
The novelty of searching and browsing the net has worn off. People are in hurry and want to find what they are looking for without having to click their way through a company's entire site.

RealNames, a California company founded in 1997, believes it has developed the technology to make e-commerce quick and painless. Known as the Internet Keywords system, this click-cutting device is being backed financially by, among others, Microsoft, as part of the software giant's new strategy to put itself at the centre of the internet for consumers and businesses.

"Surfing was two years ago, now we're looking for e-commerce solutions. We look at Internet Keywords as a way for people to go straight to the products," explains John Tomany, vice president of business development RealNames Europe.

Several companies have turned to Keywords, including eBay, the hugely-successful online auctioneer, and Panasonic, the Japanese electronics consumer giant. The "deep brand-navigation" devised by RealNames allows a company to shepherd customers directly to products, using key phrases.

Say a customer wants to buy a digital video player (DVD) from Panasonic; typing "Panasonic DVDs" in the address field of their browser will take them straight to a list of Panasonic DVDs, cutting out the company's home page and navigation. Ford recently used Keywords technology to push sales of its Explorer cars. Instead of trawling through the Ford site, customers who typed in the words "Ford Explorer" were taken directly to the relevant pages.

For companies keen to exploit e-commerce, such directness can be a boon. Typically, the Keyword system is used in conjunction with a promotion campaign through posters, print or TV ads. Once a company has generated interest in a product, potential customers have the option of following up that interest online.

"It's all about convergence of the offline and online experience," says Mr Tomany.

RealNames claims there has been overwhelming interest in its Keywords technology, which may be mostly hype, but since Microsoft - which has already taken a 20% stake in the company - has today committed itself to Keywords for its Internet Explorer browser and MSN Search, deep brand-navigation could be the shopping tool of the very near future.

About two million Keywords are currently in use in the US and Europe, with between 250,000 and 300,000 of those being based on this side of the Atlantic. A company typically pays RealNames about £2,000 a year for the use of a Keyword and the evidence so far is that companies are willing to give Keywords a go as a means of boosting sales.

webTitle: It's not what you know but where you're from

fields.headline: It's not what you know but where you're from
fields.standfirst: Law firms are getting choosy - pick the 'wrong' university and you may regret it, warn   Alison Rees  and  Phil Thomas
fields.trailText: Law firms are getting choosy - pick the 'wrong' university and you may regret it, warn Alison Rees and Phil Thomas
fields.body:
"Well-paid legal jobs available: only suitable candidates need apply." But who is a "suitable candidate" ? With salaries of £20,000+ on offer for trainee solicitors in City of London law firms, applications for law degree courses stand at almost 16,000 for some 11,000 places.

Universities aware of the high demand and comparatively low cost of tuition, have either raised their law student intake or opened new faculties.

Today, more than 120 institutions offer the LLB degree. In turn, the buoyant economy has increased the demand for solicitors' services. The number of registered, two-year solicitor training contracts exceeds the number of students starting their vocational year at licensed law faculties and other training establishments.

This seems encouraging, although not necessarily good news for all law students with sights set on a career as a solicitor. While the Law Society of England and Wales aims to widen its recruitment base, evidence suggests it faces serious obstacles. Your chance of getting a job in some sectors of the profession, notably the big City firms, may be blocked by something as simple as where your law degree is from.

Clifford Chance, a "global" law firm with 1,996 fee earners, recently advised law students that to get a training contract in the City they should just go to a good university, get a 2:1 and have a fantastic personality.

What then is a "good university"? There has always been an informal league table, semi-officially recognised through the creation of the Russell Group of elite, research-led universities and publication of the Research Assessment Exercises. Now, major divisions exist within this league and an institution's ranking affects the marketplace value of its law degree.

Students applying to law school need to be aware of the training, career and financial implications of where they study. Solicitors' recruitment policies differ but some may well reject applicants simply because they are from "new" universities.

City of London firms offer 30% of all training contracts - essentially big players offering big salaries, recruiting from "good" universities. The average salary for a City trainee is £20,000 as against £11,500 for a trainee in Wales. In London as a whole, 5% of trainees are paid at or below the Law Society's recommended minimum salary; in Wales that figure is 54%.

Students not destined to join a big City firm look to medium-sized, provincial firms and small, high street practices for training contracts. Statistics recently released by the Law Society show these firms are falling in numbers. For many students unable to secure a training contract, their first taste of the legal workplace will be as a para-legal. Invariably paid below the recommended minimum trainee salary, they do similar work to trainee solicitors and hope their contract will later be converted to that of a trainee solicitor.

Different law schools attract different types of students. Recent research* in the five Welsh law schools highlights radically different recruitment patterns. Aberystwyth, say, gets half its students through clearing, 70% are from outside Wales and 97% are under 21. Meanwhile, Swansea Institute of Higher Education was first UCAS choice for 70% of its students, 83% are from Wales and half are mature students with an average age of 26.

Some law schools, particularly in "new" universities, appeal to certain types of students: the mature, students with access qualifications or lower A-level grades or those with domestic commitments forcing them to study locally. As increasing tuition fees and the disappearance of maintenance grants encourage a growth in home-based students, these law schools may face increasing demand for places from students previously outside their usual range of applicants. "Local students will feel obliged to study close to home to save money," said a Glamorgan University student.

The factors students consider when applying are changing. A good social life and the chance to live away from home are no longer paramount. Saving on rent by living at home and availability of part-time work are having more influence on where they study.

Is it reasonable to reject applicants on the basis of where they studied? Entry requirements for law are high, especially at "good" universities. Some students fail to fulfil their potential at A level because, for example, they attend a "poor" school. Lord Dearing highlighted this issue stating "Whatever their innate ability [some students], if they are attending poor schools, tend to get left behind".

And surely all 2:1 law degrees are equal? Nigel Bastin, head of training at the Bar Council, challenges this: "The standards of law degrees from a few universities may be questioned."

On average, newly qualified solicitors in Welsh high street practices earn £17,000. Base salaries for their counterparts in leading City firms start at £40,000+ with some London-based US firms offering £100,000. The question is whether City firms will widen their recruitment net to acknowledge that for an increasing number of talented students and potential first-rate lawyers studying at a "good" university is not an option.

*Law Students: Investing in the Future, by Professor Phil Thomas and Alison Rees, £25, Cardiff Law School, Box 427, Cardiff CF10 1XD.

webTitle: Blunkett pledges more funds for basic learning

fields.headline: Blunkett pledges more funds for basic learning
fields.standfirst: The last word on literacy?
fields.trailText: The government is to spend more money improving basic literacy and numeracy skills among adults after the national skills taskforce released figures showing that one in five adults is functionally illiterate.
fields.body:
The government is to spend more money improving basic literacy and numeracy skills among adults after the national skills taskforce released figures showing that one in five adults is functionally illiterate.

The extra funds, announced today by the education secretary, David Blunkett, will also be earmarked for an increase in spending on schooling for post GCSE pupils, with thousands of pupils to be paid to continue their education.

Mr Blunkett made the announcement after addressing a conference in London at which the taskforce presented figures showing that 7m adults are deemed to be less literate than an average 11-year-old.

He could not specify the exact amount, but said that the government would make learning and skills the top priority in the three-year comprehensive spending review to be unveiled next month by the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

"There is an absolute recognition that we really need to face these challenges," Mr Blunkett said. "I don't remember in 30 years whether a government has come out and said, 'one of our priorities is tackling basic skills.' I think you will find that will be the case in July."

Under the new plans, thousands of teenagers will be paid by the government to stay on at school after their GCSEs following a successful experiment in which 16-year-olds in 15 areas in England had been paid to stay on at school or college.

The education maintenance allowance scheme is to be extended to include more than a third of local education authorities from September this year. Pupils will be paid between £5 and £30 a week to stay on and Mr Blunkett said double the numbers had chosen to do so in the pilot areas.

The education secretary also unveiled a £3m advertising campaign with the slogan "Don't Quit Now" that will run over the summer in an attempt to persuade more children not to leave school at 16.

The report was carried out over two years by the taskforce, which advises the government on the skills available to the economy. It suggests that the UK's skills shortage is costing the country billions of pounds in productivity.

Mr Blunkett also announced reforms to modern apprenticeships, a review of adult learning and a £2.5m "challenge fund" to raise skills among staff.

Meanwhile the schools watchdog, Ofsted, today questioned whether local education authorities were helping in the drive to raise standards in schools and called for a radical overhaul of their size and role.

In its first overview of LEA performance, Ofsted said almost 40% of those it had inspected were "seriously deficient, often in many respects". And, in a move likely to antagonise town halls around England, it said LEAs must "submit themselves to market disciplines", retain just a core of highly paid professionals and only offer services that schools wanted to buy.

webTitle: Lord Alli damns white domination of Whitehall

fields.headline: Lord Alli damns white domination of Whitehall
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A close ally of the prime minister, Tony Blair, last night damned the civil service for its white domination.
fields.body:
A close ally of the prime minister, Tony Blair, last night damned the civil service for its white domination.

Lord Alli said progress among senior mandarins was so slow that it would take nearly two centuries for ethnic minorities to be fairly represented at the top of the civil service.

Giving the annual Greenwich Lecture in London in memory of three murdered black students, including Stephen Lawrence, Lord Alli said senior civil servants prided themselves on being meritocratic. "But they are to a man - and woman - white," said the millionaire business man. "Put at its clearest - and bluntest - 0% of the very top civil servants are black.

"There are no black permanent secretaries. There are no black ambassadors. Is this a reflection of the world we live in?"

Lord Alli said the time had come for Britain to have its first black ambassador and called for a "step change" in the slow progress in promoting black talent.

Just 1.7% of the top 3,000 civil servants are black or Asian, compared to over 5% of the working population.

Lord Alli said: "At the current rate it will take 190 years before our communities are fairly represented in the most senior ranks of the civil ser vice. We cannot wait that long."

He added: "My challenge now to government ministers - black and white - is to take the action needed to deliver what we promised. Put the undoubted energy and intelligence of your senior civil servants into seeking out black talent.

"And if you cannot find a suitable candidate to be Britain's first black ambassador or permanent secretary, let us help you find the right people to do these jobs."

Recent Cabinet Office figures show that the proportion of black and Asian top civil servants fell between from 1.8% in 1989 to 1.7% in 1999.

The government has vowed to double the number by 2005 to 3.2% amid allegations that the "old boy network" is hampering progress.

The government figures showed that black and Asian staff were paid up to £3,500 less than white colleagues, and were more likely to resign.

A Cabinet Office spokeswoman would not respond directly to Lord Alli's attack but said: "We have a strong commitment to equal opportunities and we value the diversity of our staff.

"We fully recognise that people from ethnic minorities are underepresented at senior levels, that is why a key part of the programme to modernise the civil service is to achieve a dramatic increase in diversity and to tackle under representation.

"We therefore set challenging targets to double the representation of ethnic minorities in the senior civil service by 2005."

Lord Alli also attacked the Conservative leader, William Hague, over his demands for tougher asylum and immigration policies. He suggested he was worse than Enoch Powell.

Lord Alli also called for a new "contract" between the black population in London and the Metropolitan police.

This would involve the Met giving commitments to the black community and, in return, receiving more encouragement for young blacks to join the force.

Lord Alli also attacked the Conservative leader, William Hague, over his demands for tougher asylum and immigration policies. He suggested he was worse than Enoch Powell. Lord Alli also called for a new "contract" between the black population in London and the Metropolitan police. This would involve the Met giving commitments to the black community and, in return, receiving more encouragement for young blacks to join the force.

fields.headline: Labour tells sheriffs to modernise
fields.standfirst:
Ministers argue that ancient office suffers from institutional racism and is unrepresentative of today's Britain

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The government has set itself on collision course with the high sheriffs of England and Wales after insisting they reform or risk being consigned to the history books in which many of their powers already reside.
fields.body:
The government has set itself on collision course with the high sheriffs of England and Wales after insisting they reform or risk being consigned to the history books in which many of their powers already reside.

Amid private government concerns that the so-called "shrievalty" is suffering from institutional racism, the body representing the 55 high sheriffs has been warned that its members are mostly white, male and too rich to properly represent a new Britain in which taxes are collected by the inland revenue rather than local despots.

The prime statutory role of today's sheriffs is the enforcement of civil writs, with most emerging into the glare of the media only when they serve papers blocking the activities of eco-warriors attempting to impede the building of roads such as the Newbury bypass in Berkshire.

This year six high sheriffs are women, a number that is set to rise to nine in the year 2002-2003. To ministers' frustration, there has never been a black or Asian high sheriff, though Greater London and Leicestershire are both understood to be about to appoint one.

The government has given the Shrievalty Association, which represents the sheriffs, until next year to increase the number of women and representatives of ethnic minorities holding the office, though it has stopped short of setting quotas.

At present, there is no ethnic or gender monitoring of candidates or post holders, leaving ministers to guess from names the number of women and members of ethnic minorities.

In an article in the association's newsletter, Alex Galloway, clerk of the privy council, which administers the sheriffs' appointments process, wrote: "In terms of representativeness, the shrievalty scores pretty badly, with a very low percentage of women among high sheriffs, even fewer (if any) members of ethnic minorities, and a very limited social range."

He added: "Thoughtful sheriffs should be... looking to see how they might make the process of selecting their successors as inclusive as possible."

A new approach is needed to broaden the field, Mr Galloway warned, risking the fury of more traditional current and past postholders - including one who claimed that "white males are not welcome as sheriffs".

Arguing that sheriffs must not "limit the search to people of traditional background", he proposed using advertisements in local newspapers to publicise the selection process, or asking the public to nominate candidates as they now do for honours.

The post of high sheriff is one of the oldest secular offices and dates back to the turn of the 11th century. They are chosen annually by the Queen from a list drawn up by the incumbent and narrowed to two or three candidates by a tribunal.

Anyone is eligible to be appointed as long as they hold land in the county. Peers, clergy, officers in active service, barristers and solicitors cannot hold the office, and poverty is also grounds for exemption.

Their powers are mainly ceremonial now, but once high sherriffs held responsibility for both judicial and administra tive matters within their bailiwick. They were formerly responsible for the safety of judges within the county and were liable for the safe custody of prisoners as well as the preparation of jury panels for assizes.

Margaret Beckett, leader of Commons, pushed for reform of selections shortly after taking up her post, which also carries the title of president of the privy council office.

One government source said: "The problem of lack of balance is effectively self-perpetuating because the existing sheriffs nominate the next lot."

Duties and functions 'still count for a lot'

Paul Kelso

The first high sheriff of Suffolk took the job in 1199. Some 801 years later, John Clement, 68, who was chairman of the Unigate group, is proud to hold an office that he believes still has a role to play in 21st century Britain.

While some powers have faded into disuse over the centuries, Mr Clement still has a raft of official and unofficial duties he undertakes, all voluntarily.

"There is no renumeration, and if there are any benefits I haven't discovered them. Actually it's worse than that, because you can't set off any of the costs against tax."

As well as signing and serving civil writs and eviction orders Mr Clement is also the returning officer at elections, and liaises with circuit crown court judges about accommodation and travel arrangements.

"We used to be responsible for the judges' safety when they were on the circuit, but the days when we had to ride round with a loaded revolver have long gone," he said.

Mr Clement, elder brother of TV comedy writer Dick Clement, believes the real value of his post resides in the ceremonial work.

"Last week the frigate HMS Grafton was granted the freedom of Ipswich, and I attended the service. This week I have got two school governors' board meetings to attend and speech days to prepare for."

Later in the summer he will host a garden party for "the unrecognised heroes" of the community.

"We invite a range of people who wouldn't otherwise be recognised, for instance the coxwain of the local lifeboat.

"And as we've gone to the effort of putting up a marquee, we will use the whole lot two days later for a British Liver Trust fundraiser."

fields.headline: CRE conference 'badly bungled'
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Serious failings in financial and management controls lay behind the collapse of an international conference organised by the commission for racial equality and backed by Tony Blair that was supposed to showcase the government's anti-racist achievements, according to an official inquiry report published last night.
fields.body:
Serious failings in financial and management controls lay behind the collapse of an international conference organised by the commission for racial equality and backed by Tony Blair that was supposed to showcase the government's anti-racist achievements, according to an official inquiry report published last night.

Tory MPs last night described the report by the new CRE chairman, Gurbux Singh, as identifying a "devastating catalogue of incompetence and mismanagement" within the CRE, the Home Office and GCDC 2000 Ltd, the company set up to run the global cultural and diversity congress which was to be held in Cardiff in March this year.

Several senior CRE figures including the acting chairman, a commissioner, its chief executive and its chief press officer, are among the directors of the company. The congress had been planned to coincide with the first anniversary of the Lawrence inquiry report and Nelson Mandela had been invited to speak alongside government ministers from Australia, Canada and China.

Mr Singh said the collective responsibility for its collapse only a month before it was scheduled is shared between the company, CRE and the Home Office.

He said: "Many factors con tributed to the final outcome: limited assessment of the risks facing the congress and GCDC, over-optimistic projections about income; cashflow and other resourcing difficulties; poor financial challenge and oversight; the inexperience of key staff; and a lack of systems or failing to apply correctly the systems that did not exist."

Mr Singh said the CRE should now appoint a finance director to strengthen its financial controls and ensure appropriate Home Office oversight of its management.

Among the basic failings identified by the Singh report was the appointment of Diane Morley as congress director without any proper consideration of whether she had any suitable experience.

At one point the board was told 1,200 delegates had pre-registered during 1999 but these turned out to only be expressions of interest by people who had no idea they faced a delegate fee of £595 each.

In the Commons yesterday, the Conservative home affairs spokesman, David Lidington, said it was not adequate to say nobody was responsible for a the devastating catalogue of incompetence.

But while the Home Office minister, Mike O'Brien, confirmed there would be losses as a result of the collapse of the congress, he insisted there was no evidence of impropriety.

It is thought the losses could be as high as £750,000.
