webTitle: Mowlam tempts fate with monarchy views

fields.headline: Mowlam tempts fate with monarchy views
fields.standfirst:
The Cabinet Office minister is risking her political future with her comments about rehousing the royals, says her biographer Julia Langdon
Mowlam calls for royals to be rehoused
fields.trailText:
27 June, 4.45pm: The Cabinet Office minister is risking her political future with her comments about rehousing the royals, says her biographer Julia Langdon.
Special report
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam has discovered the meaning of real political power. The Cabinet Office minister is the one member of the Labour government who can say exactly what she thinks and get away with it.

She has the power of her personal popularity to shore her up and - this side of the next general election, anyway - it would be almost impossible for the prime minister, Tony Blair, to get rid of her.

The fact that she has chosen to repeat a point of view about the royal family that caused controversy when she first expressed it six years ago is a measure of the extent to which she couldn't give a damn.

Her views are radical, but well thought-out. But the political point is that she ought to have kept them to herself if she wanted to keep in with the party's officially-approved orthodoxy.

However, since her return to mainland politics after two years as Northern Ireland secretary, Ms Mowlam has been in an odd and anomalous position. She was appointed to the post of Cabinet Office minister last autumn against her will and has made little secret of the extent to which she is unhappy there.

She has also done little to make the job matter. While she knew that the time had come to move back to Britain, she would have preferred something rather more in the mainstream.

The trouble for Mr Blair is that sacking her from his administration would rebound badly on the "new" Labour image. Ms Mowlam is one of the success stories of his government and has an opinion poll rating that has outstripped his own.

He is also very well aware of the fact that the Labour party needs to pay attention to its support from women voters and there would be an outcry if she was moved against her will. Even so, she is tempting fate.

webTitle: Mowlam calls for royals to be rehoused

fields.headline: Mowlam calls for royals to be rehoused
fields.trailText: The Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam, has called for the royal family to be moved out of Buckingham Palace and rehoused in a modern building.
fields.body:
The Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam, has called for the royal family to be moved out of Buckingham Palace and rehoused in a modern building.

In an interview with Saga magazine, Ms Mowlam suggested that old palaces could be used as public museums and galleries. "I don't suggest that the royal family should close down and shut up shop, but if people want a monarch of the new century they should have a palace of the new century, in line with the architecture you see around London," she said.

Ms Mowlam also predicts a constitutional change for the monarchy. "I am not a great fan of the monarchy, even though I like Prince Charles and I like Princess Anne, and exchanges I have had with the Queen have been very pleasant," she said.

"But in terms of constitution, I would support a change. The public aren't of a like mind yet, so it won't happen yet. But it will come. It will evolve. I think the Queen realises this. That is why Prince Charles is becoming a potential leader of the people."

It is not the first time Ms Mowlam - who is believed to be being sidelined by the prime minister, Tony Blair - has made controversial remarks about the monarchy. Before Labour came to power she called for Buckingham Palace and Windsor Castle to be sold off and for the royal family to be housed in a purpose-built palace.

The Cabinet Office would not comment on the report.

Ms Mowlam said today that she had been asked by Saga magazine to confirm that she had made comments about the modernisation of the royal family six years ago.

"I don't feel that strongly about it," she told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. "It is something that I think is now in context and is part of what I think will be an evolutionary change for the monarchy in the 21st century.

"Evolutionary change is what I thought then would happen and what I think now is happening. It is a personal view and not a government view. I just put my personal views on the record six years ago. I am not reneging on them. I said it.

"I still think that modernisation and change is the way forward and I made this as a suggestion for the 21st century. I didn't intend to make it a major news story."

webTitle: Internet deals, Internal disagreements and Interested defender

fields.headline: Internet deals, Internal disagreements and Interested defender
fields.trailText: LAST-MINUTE GLITCH CAUSES PLAYER SWITCH HITCH
fields.body:
LAST-MINUTE GLITCH CAUSES PLAYER SWITCH HITCH

How come busy Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale is looking so radiant at the moment? Hasn't he been working twenty-four-seven to secure the signature of Celtic striker Mark Viduka, a deal he's described as "singularly the most complex and difficult transfer I have been involved in"? Well, yes. But instead of jetting from smoky boardroom to smoky boardroom in order to thrash out a deal with the Australian international, laid-back Peter has put the finishing touches to Viduka's five-year contract from the comfort of his desk, simply by sending a few emails. "Everything has been sorted out on the internet," trilled a relaxed Ridsdale this morning.

But sadly for Peter (and investors in his new start-up hptpt/://::internet.knowledge.cash.com.uk.co) it appears this afternoon that the e-deal won't go through as smoothly as expected. "His work permit will not be automatically rubber stamped," sighed Ridsdale earlier as he wearily picked fluff from the ball in his mouse. "Mark has not played at the highest level for his country over the past two years," he continued, "but I'm confident that we will win our appeal and that Mark will soon be a Leeds player."

Ridsdale's assured stance (if you can take a stance whilst draped over a chaise longue) has convinced all at Elland Road of Viduka's imminent arrival. Which is why David O'Leary O'Leeds isn't concerned about tempting fate. "At £6m we have landed a player who has a proven track record," he said this afternoon. "Mark has really done the business in Scotland. Now I want Mark to do a Michael Bridges and score 20 plus goals in his first season." Even if the deal falls through and Viduka ends up signing for a team Leeds draw in Big Cup?

LOTHAR'S LAST WOBBLE

Say what you like about the Germans, but they've got a great sense of humour (hang on a second - Fiver racial stereotypes ed.). A week after crashing out of Euro 2000, the players are still joshing with each other about the manner of their defeat. Or it could be that they're washing their dirty linen in public. Either way, it's pretty laughable.

"They stormed up to me and said we have to get rid of Ribbeck before the tournament," a wide-eyed Lothar Matthaus told Bild newspaper today, revealing the details of a failed coup in camp Deutschland. "They said I should take over the job and train the team." The nasty men were none other than Lothar's teammates Markus Babbel, Dietmar Hamann and Jens Jeremies, but good upstanding Lothar was having none of it. "I never shoot a coach down. It was thus clear that I would not do it," said the famously subordinate sweeper.

So in case you didn't quite catch the gist: Lothar = good; Babbel = bad. Unless, of course, you're Markus Babbel. The Liverpool-bound full-back wasted no time today in offering his opinion on lovely Lothar. "To blame one single thing is too simple," Babbel insisted - before blaming Lothar. "If Lothar had a character, he would not have played in the first game, when he realised he was only 80 percent fit," he said. "The fact that he did not do it showed a weakness in character." Much like bitching about your teammates in the press, the Fiver supposes.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I lived in a small village and all the labourers came to see me run." Marc Overmars reveals the height of entertainment in rural Holland.

BORO BREAKOUT

"Wormwood Scrubs? Don't make me laugh. Alcatraz? That's for wimps. You're in Middlesbrough now, sonny, and the only way out is if I'm sacked." And with words similar to these, Big Daddy Robson picked up the rumours hinting that Christian Ziege was to join Liverpool and squashed them into a rather unedifying pulp. "There's not one player at this football club that's got a clause in his contract that lets him out in any way or form," Robson barked as his conscripts sat cowering in the corner. "As far as I'm concerned, Christian Ziege has got three years left on his contract and he'll be a Middlesbrough player for those three years."

Impressive talk. But with discipline like that, is it any wonder that top footballers are queueing up to avoid Robbo's lair? First it was Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, then it was Dani - and now even Chris Sutton could shun the north-east in favour of Celtic. "Chris is quite impressed with the area and the set-up of the football club," said Robson a little bit desperately. "I hope he'll look forward to the challenge of playing with Middlesbrough and maybe find it more appealing than playing in the Scottish league," he added, throwing the last of his dice.

But before Robbo gets too despondent, it appears there's one player who might be willing to sign for Boro (and stay). German defender Holger Greilich, who plays for 1860 Munich and has taken the Boro manager's fancy, is sending the right signals to the frustrated Boro boss. "This is a big honour to me," said Greilich, much to Robson's delight. "And I didn't even have a great season!" Just pretend you didn't hear that last bit, Bryan.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal have signed Corinthians attacking midfielder Edu for £6m, according to Planet Football. Although Arsenal are staying tight-lipped at the moment, the 22-year-old has apparently signed a five-year deal.

Newcastle are ready with a £6m bid for Norwich's highly-rated Welsh striker Craig Bellamy.

Davor Suker will complete a free transfer to West Ham on Thursday once work permit formalities are sorted out.

Juventus have reportedly signed French striker David Trezeguet. Monaco have accepted a £14.6m bid, and Trezeguet only needs to pass a medical to wrap up his move to Turin.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Uefa have confirmed there is no possibility of another European ban for English football following the violent scenes at Euro 2000. Uefa general secretary Gerhard Aigner said: "I insist on saying loud and clear that we must not exclude English clubs or England international teams because when there is an international competition held in England there is never the slightest problem. It's curious, isn't it? I think rather we must work in depth with the FA and the English government. It will be long hard work but we must give ourselves the means of eradicating hooliganism. We can't just continue like that just making idle threats."

Danny Wilson is the new manager of Bristol City. The 40-year-old former Sheffield Wednesday and Barnsley manager, who has been given a 12-month rolling contract, has said he has no plans to bring his own backroom staff to the club at present.

Bolton defender Jimmy Phillips has signed a new one-year contract with the club.

Hibernian have signed out-of-contract St Johnstone midfielder John O'Neil. The Edinburgh club have also landed Dunfermline keeper Ian Westwater, who will take up a coaching role at the club.

Nigel Worthington has joined Norwich as assistant to manager Bryan Hamilton.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

British Eurosport: The Spirit of Euro 2000 (10.15pm)

Get off your face on footy.

The nasty men were none other than Lothar's teammates Markus Babbel, Dietmar Hamann and Jens Jeremies, but good upstanding Lothar was having none of it. "I never shoot a coach down. It was thus clear that I would not do it," said the famously subordinate sweeper. So in case you didn't quite catch the gist: Lothar = good; Babbel = bad. Unless, of course, you're Markus Babbel. The Liverpool-bound full-back wasted no time today in offering his opinion on lovely Lothar. "To blame one single thing is too simple," Babbel insisted - before blaming Lothar. "If Lothar had a character, he would not have played in the first game, when he realised he was only 80 percent fit," he said. "The fact that he did not do it showed a weakness in character." Much like bitching about your teammates in the press, the Fiver supposes. QUOTE OF THE DAY "I lived in a small village and all the labourers came to see me run." Marc Overmars reveals the height of entertainment in rural Holland. BORO BREAKOUT "Wormwood Scrubs? Don't make me laugh. Alcatraz? That's for wimps. You're in Middlesbrough now, sonny, and the only way out is if I'm sacked." And with words similar to these, Big Daddy Robson picked up the rumours hinting that Christian Ziege was to join Liverpool and squashed them into a rather unedifying pulp. "There's not one player at this football club that's got a clause in his contract that lets him out in any way or form," Robson barked as his conscripts sat cowering in the corner. "As far as I'm concerned, Christian Ziege has got three years left on his contract and he'll be a Middlesbrough player for those three years." Impressive talk. But with discipline like that, is it any wonder that top footballers are queueing up to avoid Robbo's lair? First it was Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, then it was Dani - and now even Chris Sutton could shun the north-east in favour of Celtic. "Chris is quite impressed with the area and the set-up of the football club," said Robson a little bit desperately. "I hope he'll look forward to the challenge of playing with Middlesbrough and maybe find it more appealing than playing in the Scottish league," he added, throwing the last of his dice. But before Robbo gets too despondent, it appears there's one player who might be willing to sign for Boro (and stay). German defender Holger Greilich, who plays for 1860 Munich and has taken the Boro manager's fancy, is sending the right signals to the frustrated Boro boss. "This is a big honour to me," said Greilich, much to Robson's delight. "And I didn't even have a great season!" Just pretend you didn't hear that last bit, Bryan. THE RUMOUR MILL Arsenal have signed Corinthians attacking midfielder Edu for £6m, according to Planet Football. Although Arsenal are staying tight-lipped at the moment, the 22-year-old has apparently signed a five-year deal. Newcastle are ready with a £6m bid for Norwich's highly-rated Welsh striker Craig Bellamy. Davor Suker will complete a free transfer to West Ham on Thursday once work permit formalities are sorted out. Juventus have reportedly signed French striker David Trezeguet. Monaco have accepted a £14.6m bid, and Trezeguet only needs to pass a medical to wrap up his move to Turin. NEWS IN BRIEF Uefa have confirmed there is no possibility of another European ban for English football following the violent scenes at Euro 2000. Uefa general secretary Gerhard Aigner said: "I insist on saying loud and clear that we must not exclude English clubs or England international teams because when there is an international competition held in England there is never the slightest problem. It's curious, isn't it? I think rather we must work in depth with the FA and the English government. It will be long hard work but we must give ourselves the means of eradicating hooliganism. We can't just continue like that just making idle threats." Danny Wilson is the new manager of Bristol City. The 40-year-old former Sheffield Wednesday and Barnsley manager, who has been given a 12-month rolling contract, has said he has no plans to bring his own backroom staff to the club at present. Bolton defender Jimmy Phillips has signed a new one-year contract with the club. Hibernian have signed out-of-contract St Johnstone midfielder John O'Neil. The Edinburgh club have also landed Dunfermline keeper Ian Westwater, who will take up a coaching role at the club. Nigel Worthington has joined Norwich as assistant to manager Bryan Hamilton. TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO British Eurosport: The Spirit of Euro 2000 (10.15pm) Get off your face on footy.

fields.headline: Handle with kid gloves
fields.standfirst: It has long been assumed that children don't feel pain as severely as adults. Specialists now believe the opposite could be true, says  Claire Phipps
fields.trailText: It has long been assumed that children don't feel pain as severely as adults. Specialists now believe the opposite could be true, says Claire Phipps
fields.body:
If we are in pain, we do something about it. We take painkillers, moan to a friend or go to a doctor. But what about those who can only express a reaction to pain with a grimace or tears? According to latest thinking on the subject, children, so often thought to be less susceptible to pain than adults, may be more sensitive to pain and its treatments than doctors had previously thought.

"The big advantage with adults is that doctors can ask them about their pain and they can then describe it. With children, the use of language is not so developed. They don't have these ways of explaining their pain," explains Dr Ann Goldman, specialist in children with chronic pain at Great Ormond Street Hospital. She is one of the organisers of the International Symposium on Children's Pain, which last week attracted 450 specialists to the Institute of Child Health in London.

"The whole medical fraternity has now realised that children are different," says Richard Howard, consultant in anaesthetics and pain management at Great Ormond Street, and, with Goldman, a director of the Children Nationwide Pain Research Centre. "In the past 10 years or so, neuro-biological research has shown that children, particularly newborn babies, experience pain in a different way to adults."

At Great Ormond Street, one innovation is to use a scale of faces, from smiling to distressed, to help young patients express the degree of pain. "It's more sophisticated than it seems," says Goldman. "We have to ensure that the child understands it in the way we think they do."

Specialists no longer assume that all humans feel pain in the same way. Research released in February this year by Jeffrey Mogil, professor of psychology at the University of Illinois, concluded that men and women experience pain differently. Could drugs aimed specifically at infants be the next step?

Goldman thinks not. "We'll be using the same drugs as for adults, but in a different way," she says. "In the past, children were not given as many painkilling drugs, proportionately, as adults for the same operations. If anything, it seems that they might need more." Young babies, in particular, can suffer: their developing central nervous system can often overreact to painful intervention, such as injections.

The same problems, however, apply to the administering of drugs to treat such pain. In babies, the enzymes in the liver that metabolise drugs are not fully developed. Incidences of mistakes in the treatment of young patients have highlighted the problems of using standard, adult, drugs to treat tiny bodies. In April last year, a junior doctor was acquitted of serious professional misconduct after miscalculating a morphine dose that resulted in the death of a premature baby.

Conversely, a teenage patient can present the opposite problem: drugs can be dealt with by the body more efficiently and make their way out of the bloodstream more quickly, which means that doctors may need to increase the level of analgesics.

Howard also challenges the assumption that very young children have no memory of pain, citing research in Canada - where, unlike in Britain, babies are routinely circumcised without anaesthetic - in which groups of circumcised and non-circumcised babies were tested for their reactions when receiving vaccinations. Those who had been circumcised displayed much stronger reactions than those who had not. Proof, says Howard, that "the earlier experience had influenced their future reactions to pain".

Great Ormond Street is soon to start a study that will follow children who have been treated with painkilling drugs - their input will be crucial in understanding the effects of pain, both long and short-term. Scientists, doctors, anaesthetists, nurses and psychologists, as well as the parents of children suffering acute pain, will all have their say. "We've realised that we really need to be able to understand this," says Howard. "Pain in children sounds very emotive, but it's only now that we've been able to make it a top priority."

webTitle: What to do if summer gets up your nose

fields.headline: What to do if summer gets up your nose
fields.standfirst: It's the worst time of year for hay-fever. Numbers of sufferers are increasing but they can take steps to limit the misery.  Esther Addley reports
fields.trailText: It's the worst time of year for hay-fever. Numbers of sufferers are increasing but they can take steps to limit the misery. Esther Addley reports
fields.body:
Summer begins in early March in Jill Richardson's house. It may not be particularly sunny outside, but she'll wear sunglasses when she leaves the house, and she monitors weather reports with an almost religious observance. But Richardson, unlike the rest of the nation, is not hoping for sunny days. She's praying for rain.

Richardson suffers from hay fever. Not the occasional sneeze and sniffle, but painful, miserable, relentless irritation. Like thousands of other sun-starved Brits, she and her partner and their four-year-old daughter Amy spent the heatwave weekend earlier this month at the seaside. She hoped the pollen count would be lower because of the sea breeze, but woke up with infuriatingly itchy eyes and throat, and didn't stop sneezing all day.

Her partner also has hay fever, and they believe Amy has developed the disease. The family returned home feeling exhausted, headachey and utterly miserable. "You get to the stage when you are weighing up whether it's worth leaving the house at all," she says.

Hay fever, like the common cold, is one of those seasonal diseases we have to muddle through as best we can, hoping for a change in the weather. Where it differs from colds and flu is that only part of the population is vulnerable to it, those who have a specific allergy to pollen. That proportion, however, is increasing every year. In the past 20 years the number of GP consultations for hay fever has quadrupled.

Up to a fifth of Britons may now have the allergy, many of them probably known only to their long-suffering colleagues and families and their local pharmacist. As British summers hot up and our nasal tracts get increasingly pollen-sensitive, hay fever could soon overtake the weather as the nation's favourite summertime gripe.

For that unfortunate 20%, we are in prime griping season. Late June is the peak grass pollen season in the south of England - Wimbledon fortnight, ironically, is the worst time to be around grass. And this has been the worst year for a generation. "With pollen counts over 50 grains per cubic metre, virtually every person with hay fever will be feeling the effects," says Professor Jean Emberlin, director of the national pollen research unit at Worcester university, which compiles the pollen count figures published in the media: 150, she says, is considered high. Last Monday Derby had a pollen count of 683, the highest since 1968.

We tend to assume that environmental extremes are necessarily our fault, but while global warming may have had a part to play in muddling up flowering seasons, pollution does not cause hay fever. It may aggravate the symptoms and irritate an already streaming nose, but it's not the trigger.

So what's to blame? Doctors themselves confess to being unsure as to what prompts the allergy. "We think it's to do with the western lifestyle," says Dr Stephen Durham, professor of allergy and respiratory medicine at the Royal Brompton hospital in London. "Things like immunisation and, ironically, hygiene, have been implicated.

"If you are a snotty-nosed kid running around with 10 siblings who all catch coughs and colds, you are probably more likely to be protected from hay fever in later life." Mollycoddling immune systems when we are children produces softies too enfeebled to fight off pollen allergies in their teens and 20s, the disease's peak years.

The key to coping with hay fever, says Durham, is understanding how it works. Despite the name, grass pollen is not the only trigger - a minority of sufferers are affected by tree pollen or, most commonly, birch.

Tree pollen allergy can be linked to asthma, and sufferers often experience a cross reaction when they eat apples and stone fruits like peaches. Because tree pollen peaks earlier, those who suffer symptoms in March and April are likely to have this type of allergy. "Lots of councils plant birch trees because they are pretty," says Emberlin, "but they don't realise that this has a big role in promoting hay fever."

Sufferers also may not realise that their parents may be to blame. Before concerned mums and dads start rolling their toddlers in grime and pushing them out the door to catch a few colds and grow up hardy, they should pause to check if their own noses need wiping. The best thing you can do to avoid developing hay fever, says Durham, is choose your parents. The child of two parents who are sufferers has a 70-90% chance of developing the disease, which falls to 50% with one parent, and less than 20% if neither has the allergy. Nice thought, if hardly practical advice for the millions of sufferers.

But there are steps you can take to avoid the disease. Maternal smoking during pregnancy and passive smoking as a child are known to contribute to the allergy's development in later life. Wearing sunglasses, keeping car windows shut and fitting a pollen filter to your car can also help, as can staying indoors in late afternoon, when the pollen count is at its highest - " it's the last set of the day at Wimbledon that's going to set your hay fever off," says Durham.

Emberlin counsels watching the pollen forecast carefully - her unit can supply information of counts on certain days. Useful if, for instance, you have suffered badly on the day of an A-level paper and want to appeal to the exam board. If all else fails, says Durham, try to take a holiday abroad or by the coast in the last two weeks in June.

The reason for this year's record highs, ironically, is that the weather has been good but not good enough. Extended periods of very hot, dry weather suppress the pollen-releasing mechanism in plants, while wet drizzly weather dampens it down. It's when the weather is hot in bursts, then cool and damp for a few days, that pollen is at its worst. Just like this summer.

Jill Richardson confesses to looking forward to September, when her six-month season of medication and misery finally comes to an end. At least she'll have a few months of respite before it all begins again. But the millions for whom the annual battle with pollen is a wearying one can at least console themselves that the most successful cure for hay fever is time. Hang on in there; it should start to fade when you reach middle age.

What happens when you have hay fever?

Pollen grains in the air land on the inside of the nose, which is lined with mast cells. These cells have a "trigger" antibody, which in some people is directed against pollen. The allergic reaction causes the cells to release histamine, a chemical which prompts the sneezing and itching impulse. Blood also flows to the nose, which causes blockage, and the mucus producing glands may also be activated.

How do I know what type of pollen I am allergic to?

Doctors can carry out a simple test. It may also help to keep a diary of your symptoms and compare this to published pollen counts.

How should I treat it?

It depends on the type and severity of your allergy, but the main treatments fall into four types:

Antihistamines
These can be very effective for occasional symptoms, and are taken by mouth or by nasal spray. It is important to use the spray properly - nasal cavities go backwards not upwards! Newer drugs are non-drowsy: some of the older brands like Piriton can cause serious drowsiness equivalent to having a couple of pints and so should not be used before driving.

Corticosteroid nasal spray.
For those with severe symptoms, or if the main problem is blockage. This works by suppressing the mast cells themselves, but should ideally be taken before symptoms start, and takes a few days to work. It is important to use the spray regularly - intermittent use is ineffective.

The "anti-hay fever" injection
A one-off injection given at the start of the pollen season into the bottom, many doctors have significant reservations about this treatment. It works by giving a large and uncontrolled dose of steroids at once, and can cause a sunken area at the site of the injection. Has also been associated with psychological problems such as irritability and depression.

Desensitisation
This is the most effective form of long-term treatment, but is extremely labour-intensive. Small doses of pollen extract are injected weekly for 12 weeks and then monthly for three years. But the results are impressive - a 50-60% reduction in symptoms and an 80% reduction in medication. The effects are also long-lasting - this is the closest thing we have to a "cure" for hay fever.

 For more information you should consult your GP or pharmacist. The Royal Brompton hospital is keen to see patients with hay fever to help with their research into the disease. Call 0207 351 8994 if you want to help.

fields.headline: 'Why should I hide away?'
fields.standfirst: We value beauty so highly that living with disfigured features can be unbearable.  Angela Neustatter  talks to two people about how they cope - and about how a new charity is tackling the prejudice
fields.trailText: We value beauty so highly that living with disfigured features can be unbearable. Angela Neustatter talks to two people about how they cope - and about how a new charity is tackling the prejudice
fields.body:
The left-hand side of Henry de Lotbiniere's face is a wreck. What was once an angular cheek meeting chiselled jaw, is now concave. There is a protuberant flesh covered lump in the place where his eye used to be. When he lifts the dark forelock of hair which hangs low over his brow you see a crater-like hole where half his forehead has been removed.

This is the legacy of the 15 surgical operations that de Lotbiniere has undergone in the past 12 years, since a cancerous tumour was first discovered in the roof of his mouth followed by one on the optic nerve behind the left eye.

"He was a handsome man," says Iain Hutchison, consultant oral and facial surgeon at St Bartholomew's and the Royal London Hospitals, of his patient. "But he had to have a succession of operations each more horrific than the last." So what prompted the 54-year-old to put his face on public display?

De Lotbiniere was one of 70 patients who agreed to sit for Mark Gilbert, artist in residence at St Bartholomews and the Royal London Hospitals. Gilbert's vivid, finely detailed portraits of faces during and after treatment form a unique exhibition to mark the launch of Saving Faces, a charity set up by Hutchison to raise funds for the prevention and treatment of oral and facial diseases. One million people need hospital treatment for facial injury annually, Hutchison points out, and although oral cancer is more common than cervical cancer it receives one 20th of the funding.

In a culture that puts such emphasis on conventional beauty and where, as research has demonstrated, people not deemed good looking are also seen to have less desirable personal characteristics, why did the subjects choose to expose themselves in this way?

"I was luckier than many people because my cancer occurred when I was in my 40s," de Lotbiniere explains. "I was already established in my career. I had a wife who didn't take fright and run off at the sight of me but who has been wonderfully supportive, and although my children were just reaching their teens when I had the first operation, my appearance doesn't appear to have worried them.

"But I am sure the effect of having this wrecked face would have been far harder if I had been at that age when the aim of life is looking for friends, a wife, a job," he adds. "I feel passionately that it is important to face the world and say that I am the same person I always was, even though my face is altered." A medical barrister, de Lotbiniere chose to be painted in his wig and robes because he continues to go into court in his very public profession.

Mark Gilbert explains that he wanted to depict the humanity in his subjects. "Whereas a photograph shows just one quick image of a person, which can be very stark, portraits are an opportunity to show a person in more depth, to emphasise what is interesting and charismatic about them."

Paul Farrant, psychologist at St Bartholomew's and the Royal London hospitals, has been evaluating the effect on the patients of being painted: "Mark said that while they were sitting for him people began talking about their feelings and saying it was helpful. We set up a study, which has shown that the paintings are making it easier for people having problems to come to terms with their new appearance."

Because Gilbert painted his subjects at home, with their families, and in some cases wearing the clothes that are integral to their professions, they began to see themselves as more than just the face they have been focusing on. They began to see themselves as people living more rounded lives.

"One man who has facial cancer now produces a photo of his portrait whenever a person says something about his face," says Farrant. "He engages them in a surgical narrative of where he was and what has happened. It means he is not a hostile outsider - which is how people with deformities are so often regarded - but somebody with a story and a means by which to talk to people."

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.trailText: Diabetes fear
fields.body:
Diabetes fear

Q If I eat more than a small amount of anything containing a lot of refined sugar, such as sweets, I experience the classic symptoms of hypoglycaemia (as opposed to hyperglycaemia). With all the recent publicity about the dangers of undetected diabetes, I have been wondering whether I ought to be worried. I'm 42, fit and not overweight.

A When we eat a large sugar load the rising blood sugar level releases insulin from the pancreas. The insulin brings blood sugar levels back down to normal, and sometimes even a little below normal. Diabetics don't produce enough insulin and therefore run high sugar levels, which isn't good for blood vessels and organs. As you've experienced, the rapidly falling blood sugar level after insulin release can make some individuals feel rather shaky, sweaty, weak and hungry - all signs that diabetics get when their blood sugar falls too low (hypoglycaemia) because they've had too much insulin or anti diabetes drugs. I'm sure your GP would gladly check urine and blood for diabetes to reassure you, but I'd cut out sugar loads anyway.

Meningitis jab safety

Q My child is due for her meningitis vaccination next week. I'm worried by reports of serious side effects. Is there any risk of her developing meningitis?

A The meningitis C vaccine isn't a live vaccine and can't cause meningitis or septicaemia (blood poisoning). It's made by combining the bacteria's sugar coating with a protein. The injection, which is safe for babies from two months upwards, gives long-lasting immunity. The jab can't kill your child but the infection can; 60,000 doses have been given worldwide without serious reactions and it's thought that 200 children's lives have been saved this year in the UK because of the vaccination campaign. If your daughter has a high temperature on the day or has had a previous serious reaction to any jab she shouldn't have one. You should discuss it first with your GP. Around 24% of children who have the jab have redness and swelling of the arm, and about 10% get a headache. Call the 24 hour helpline for information: 0845 600 0800

Termination truths

Q I am going to see a gynaecologist for some tests. Is there any way that he/she will be able to tell that I have had an abortion? I didn't go through my own GP for the termination and would prefer that it remains private.

A In general, a gynaecologist couldn't tell for certain. I would advise anyone to be truthful, because it may be relevant in the future. For instance, if you and your partner want to have a baby and find it takes a while, it will be highly relevant that you have already "proved" your fertility. Most GPs and gynaecologists don't bat an eyelid when someone says they've had a termination. I would urge you to give a full and complete history so you get a better service from them.

Breast cancer risks

Q My mother developed breast cancer when she was only 42. Thankfully, she is still alive and well today. I'm now in my 30s and becoming increasingly worried that I'm going to get it too. What tests can I have and when?

A I think you'll find statistics more comforting than platitudes. All UK women without breast cancer in the family carry a 1 in 11 chance of developing it - usually in old age. Our risk of getting breast cancer in our 40s is 1 in 100. With one relative like your mother, who was over 40 when diagnosed, your risk goes up to a maximum of 1 in 8 over your lifetime, and a 1 in 50 chance in your 40s. That's definitely odds against, so you are far more likely not to get breast cancer than to get it, and you are considered to be at low risk. Mammograms from 35, and referral to a specialist genetics clinic are recommended for high risk groups, such as women with two relatives diagnosed in their 30s. You'll obviously want to be aware of your own breasts by checking them regularly and will be invited for regular mammograms from 50, like the rest of us.

Defeating dandruff

Q What works best for dandruff? My wife's always brushing my shoulders and buying me new shampoos from the chemist. It can be very embarrassing.

A Two shampoos available over the counter are worth a try; Selsun and Nizoral. They work in different ways so try one first and switch if you have no joy. If your dandruff is accompanied by scaly skin patches, you may have psoriasis. It's worth a visit to your GP to discuss options.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

webTitle: Hitchhiker's Guide movie is holding out for a hero

fields.headline: Hitchhiker's Guide movie is holding out for a hero
fields.trailText: The long-awaited film version of Douglas Adam's cult novel The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy is finally underway, with a script penned by Adams himself, which he is "extremely pleased with"
fields.body:
As we reported several months ago, the long-awaited film version of Douglas Adam's cult novel The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, is finally underway, with a script penned by Adams himself, which he is "extremely pleased with".

Douglas Adams spoke last week to Slashdot about the problems the project has come up against in Hollywood.

"I suspect there is a cultural divide at work here. In England we celebrate our defeats and our withdrawals [But in the] US you cannot make jokes about failure. It's like cancer, it just isn't funny at any level. In England, though, for some reason it's the thing we love most. So Arthur [Dent, hero of HHG] may not seem like much of a hero to Americans ­ he doesn't have any stock options, he doesn't have anything to exchange high fives about round the water-cooler. But to the English, he is a hero. Terrible things happen to him, he complains about it a bit ­ quite articulately, so we can really feel it along with him - then calms down and has a cup of tea. My kind of guy!

"I've hit a certain amount of difficulty over the years in explaining this in Hollywood. I'm often asked 'Yes, but what are his goals?' to which I can only respond, 'Well, I think he'd just like all this to stop, really.' It's been a hard sell. In the current, latest version of the screenplay, I think that Arthur's non-heroic heroism is now absolutely preserved, and I'm pleased with the way he works out.

"In respect of the screenplay, I'd just mention a couple of things. I finished and delivered this new draft last week, and it's suddenly really working in a way that no previous version really did. It's a very hard circle to square ­ that it should on the one hand be true to the spirit of Hitchhiker, and that on the other hand it should work as a structured movie with a beginning, a middle and an end, and character motivation and so on. Well, I think we've finally got there, after all these years. The new script is my script and I'm extremely pleased with it."

fields.headline: Nigeria fines Shell £26m for 1970 spill
fields.trailText: A Nigerian court has fined Shell 4bn naira (£26m) for a 30-year-old oil spill that contributed directly to the Ogoni uprising against the company which in turn led to the death of Ken Saro-Wiwa and other environmental activists.
fields.body:
A Nigerian court has fined Shell 4bn naira (£26m) for a 30-year-old oil spill that contributed directly to the Ogoni uprising against the company which in turn led to the death of Ken Saro-Wiwa and other environmental activists.

A high court in Port Harcourt has ordered that the corporation's Nigerian subsidy, Shell Petroleum Development Corp, pay the money directly to the Ejamaa Ebubu community, for the 1970 oil spill. A Shell spokesman said the company had lodged an appeal but declined to comment further.

Ogoni leaders yesterday said the case, which has been in the courts for nine years already, might not be resolved for years. "It may go on for another 10, even 20 years", said Ledum Mittee, elected leader of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni Peoples, in London yesterday.

"Shell's strategy is to appeal at every turn and draw out the process. The people who were affected will have died before any money is paid."

Shell has long disputed the spill, arguing that it had left the area and suspended operations during the 1967-1970 Biafran war. But the community of fishers and farmers argued forcefully that the war had ended and that the spill occurred from a corroded pipeline which has since been removed. The court accepted this version of events.

Neither party disputes that thousands of gallons of oil were spilt on rich agricultural land and that the the rivers were badly polluted. A sizeable area is still unusable with the polluted land fenced off. The oil, which penetrated the ground many metres, still pollutes the water courses during the rainy season, says the community.

Shell said yesterday that its efforts to clean up the area were ended in 1993 when opposition by Ogoni activists caused it to suspend its operations in Ogoniland.

webTitle: RIP bill no match for technology

fields.headline: RIP bill no match for technology
fields.standfirst: Wily web users will easily be able to circumvent the government's controversial internet surveillance bill, writes Mark Tran
fields.trailText: Wily web users will easily be able to circumvent the government's controversial internet surveillance bill, writes Mark Tran.
fields.body:
The government's contentious internet surveillance bill, already under threat from the House of Lords, could be rendered unenforceable by simple security mechanisms that already exist.

The regulation of investigatory powers (RIP) bill has angered industry and civil rights groups because of its implications for personal and corporate privacy.

But one problem which has so far been overlooked is the practicalities of its implementation. An investigation by NetworkNews, a weekly publication on internet issues, has highlighted two technical loopholes which could render the bill unenforceable: users' ability to hide their passwords; and the difficulty of tracing "keys" used to encrypt information.

The bill allows security services such as MI5 to monitor a user's internet patterns (although initially they won't be to look at the contents of websites and email). If security services suspect criminal activity, they can request a government warrant to intercept and decode internet content.

The first technical hurdle facing the faces is the problem of "steganographic file systems", which safeguard access to data on a computer's hard drive. Users can select an infinite number of passwords. One password is needed to get past the first layer, another to get past the second layer and so on. Although the RIP bill obliges users to reveal their passwords if requested, this system means there is no way of knowing if a user has in fact revealed every password.

The technology to implement steganographic file systems already exists for Unix operating systems. Although it is not yet up and running for the more popular Windows operating system, it would be easily adaptable.

The second difficulty concerns the transmission of data from one user to another. The Deffie-Hellman key exchange system, which has been around for 20 years, enables users to conceal these transmissions, thereby preventing the authorities from seeing which sites are being visited and which messages sent.

The system creates a secret "key" - a pin number not known even by the user - which scrambles the message while it is being sent over a secure connection. After transmission, the key is destroyed automatically. The system is inexpensive to install, virtually undetectable - and legal.

"One of the effects of the bill is to give an incentive to people to deploy such technology," said Nicholas Bohm, a member of the e-commerce working group of the Law Society. He said that the government was becoming worried at the furore over the Home Office proposals.

He predicts that the government will try to salvage the RIP bill by getting rid of the more contentious aspects. "But if the Home Office digs its feet in, it is possible there will be a revolt in the Lords, who will throw it out."

Caspar Bowden, research director for the Foundation for Information Policy, believes the outcry over RIP makes it more difficult for the government to "steamroll" this legislation through. He said that a situation which "allows you to be snooped on is not conducive for a business-to-business environment or individuals".

The Home Office says it is confident that the bill takes account of emerging technologies. A spokesman said the main task of RIP was to update legislation dating back to 1985, and said security services would rarely demand encryption keys from internet users. "Nine times out of 10 we would ask for the plain text printout," the official said.

But civil rights groups maintain that the bill represents an assault on personal freedom - and businesses are angry at the potential loss of commerce if dot.com companies shun the UK because of concerns about confidentiality. Unease over the bill has reached such a pitch that more than 48 pages of amendments have been proposed to block the home secretary's proposals in the Lords.

fields.headline: The last word on literacy?
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's deputy literary editor Giles Foden questions the relevance of syntactic exactitude in the computer age
fields.trailText: The Guardian's deputy literary editor Giles Foden questions the relevance of syntactic exactitude in the computer age
fields.body:
Last Saturday, in a newspaper that shall remain nameless, I saw an advertisement for a "literacy agent" and, later that same day, a publisher's blurb promising an "exiting" novel. Oh dear. If the so-called professionals can't get it right (it should, of course, have been "literary agent" and "exciting"), what hope for the rest of us?

The news that one in five Britons is "functionally illiterate" (a strange piece of language in itself) comes as no surprise. I'm a novelist and I find myself wandering every now and then. Or should that be wondering? Still, even Homer nods and I'm in the best of company: Kingsley Amis once wrote to Anita Brookner pointing out 40 grammatical mistakes in two pages of one of her novels.

Some writers, such as the poet Geoffrey Hill, make grammar the fulcrum on which their work rests, weighing heavy moral arguments in the placing of a semi-colon; others don't worry too much about it, relying on what's known as descriptive grammar - the notion that if people talk like that, then it's ok.

There was a time when using "ok" would have been infra dig. We certainly don't have to write in that stuffy 1950s style any more. The important point is this: if there is a failure to communicate clearly, then we have a problem as a society.

It doesn't look good - although it is also worth bearing in mind that illiteracy has been an issue since the dawn of writing. It is not as if (it never is) there has been some golden age of super-literate Britons. On the other hand, the rise of televisual/video-game culture and the decline in reading as a pastime have clearly taken their toll in the last few years.

But even there we can find some relief. People aren't less intelligent. It's just a different kind of intelligence, a different kind of grammar, one in which spatial and narrative awareness are more important than syntactic exactitude. You only need watch a couple of kids hunched over their consoles to see this in action.

I'm not saying this is a cause for celebration. Words are my life. But there's a shower of pixels coming, piped into every living room in the land; and when it comes, it's those who aren't ready who will be described as functionally illiterate.

webTitle: Zimbabwe's ruling party wins majority despite opposition gains

fields.headline: Zimbabwe's ruling party wins majority despite opposition gains
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe's ruling party won a narrow majority in Zimbabwe's parliamentary elections, despite historic gains by the opposition and strong signs of discontent with his 20-year rule.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe's ruling party won a narrow majority in Zimbabwe's parliamentary elections, despite historic gains by the opposition and strong signs of discontent with his 20-year rule.

With results announced in all 120 parliamentary districts this morning, President Mugabe's party captured 62 seats to the opposition Movement for Democratic Change's 57. A small independent party won one seat.

The closely contested race was unprecedented in a country where President Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party has been virtually unchallenged since independence from white-minority rule in 1980.

"We are on the path of change," said the opposition leader, Morgan Tvsangirai. "I believe there are enough members in parliament who believe there's a need to start on a new direction for the country."

"Anyone who believes the destiny of this country rests on Robert Mugabe must have his head examined," Mr Tvsangirai said.

The opposition can expect to have a strong voice, but little power, in the new parliament. President Mugabe and his allies can appoint 30 additional parliamentary seats, giving him at least 92 votes in the 150-seat legislature - enough to be able to pass legislation comfortably.

President Mugabe, 76, still has two years left in his term, and has said he will not include opposition figures in his cabinet.

But Mr Tvsangirai said he would challenge President Mugabe for the presidential post in elections scheduled for 2002.

The parliamentary election came after months of political violence and the takeover of white farms by black war veterans, in protests sanctioned by President Mugabe's government in a bid to strengthen its support among landless blacks. President Mugabe has vowed to seize at least 800 white farms after the elections.

MDC officials claimed the results showed that government intimidation worked in some rural areas. David Coltart, the MDC legal adviser and a successful candidate, said the opposition plans to challenge some results in court. "In many of these constituencies, they have only won through intimidation," he said.

The opposition performed well in urban areas, as expected, but also won seats in President Mugabe's rural strongholds in the weekend election. Several high-level ruling party officials and cabinet ministers lost their seats.

The home affairs minister, Dumiso Dabengwa, received fewer than 4,000 of more than 24,000 votes cast in his district in the south-western city of Bulawayo.

The large turnout in the country's elections, estimated in excess of 3m of the 5.1m registered voters, overwhelmed counting stations, leading to delays in confirming results.

fields.headline: 27 June: In brief
fields.standfirst: Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas plan for their divorce, Coen Brothers are rewriting The Ladykillers, and Destiny's Child record Charlie's Angels theme tune
fields.trailText: Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas plan for their divorce, Coen Brothers are rewriting The Ladykillers, and Destiny's Child record Charlie's Angels theme tune
fields.body:
Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas, whose first child and marriage are both imminent, insisted last night that they have agreed terms amicably for a pre-nuptial agreement should the couple divorce. Zeta-Jones was said to be 'furious' after Douglas's lawyers drew up a contract giving her just £1m a year of Douglas' £150m fortune in the event of the two love-birds being forced to separate. She was allegedly demanding £3m a year and a house. Details of their agreement have not been made public.

The Daily Telegraph reports that Joel and Ethan Coen, the duo behind Fargo, The Big Lebowski and O Brother Where Art Thou, have started writing a new, updated version of the classic Ealing comedy The Ladykillers. The 1955 film starred Alec Guinness and Peter Sellers, and told the story of a senile old lady who rents out a room in her townhouse to a bankrobber. Things don't quite go to plan when he and his gang try to bump off the old dear.

US R&B act Destiny's Child are to record the new theme tune to the much hyped Charlie's Angels film. The film stars Cameron Diaz, Drew Barrymore and Lucy Liu. The song, titled Independent Woman, will be released on the movie album soundtrack in November.

fields.headline: Complaints
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about making a fuss when things go wrong on the net
fields.trailText: All you need to know about making a fuss when things go wrong on the net
fields.body:
1. What Australians have known for years has been confirmed in a national complaints culture survey, so it's semi-official: we are a nation of whingers.

2. It's all the government's fault, of course. John Major started it with his national charters, and the present lot are just as bad with their "people's panel".

3. We've had ombudsmen for years, squirreling away great masses of complaints. There are established favourites, like the Broadcasting Standards Commission, the Advertising Standards Authority and the dear old Press Complaints Commission.

4. Now they are multiplying like rabbits: there is even an Estate Agents' Ombudsman. Someone should complain.

5. The best - ie most sinister - title of any public sector complaints service appropriately deals with the inland revenue and is called The Adjudicator.

6. The real growth in the whinge business, however, is in the private sector. There is a flourishing complaints software industry, and new agencies like Complaindomain are making a bob or two in third-party whingeing.

7. Another promising new site is being set up, specifically to pass on complaints from, and seek redress for, disappointed holiday-makers.

8. Some webbots, of course, prefer to do their own thing. When they're not too busy dealing with UFOs.

9. The British grizzling industry, however, has a long way to go to match the flair of US outfits like bitchaboutit.com.

10. And just compare the privately run Police Complaint Center with our own feeble Police Complaints Authority.

fields.headline: No 11: Costinha
fields.trailText: Ah, Portugal. Home of Luis Figo, Rui Costa and Sa Pinto. I suppose Costinha is another artist extraordinare, who paints pretty pictures with his play Steady on a second Mr Barry Davies! Because just like the Brazilians had Dunga, the Portuguese also need people to do the nitty-gritty things. And Costinha is one of them.
fields.body:
Ah, Portugal. Home of Luis Figo, Rui Costa and Sa Pinto. I suppose Costinha is another artist extraordinare, who paints pretty pictures with his play Steady on a second Mr Barry Davies! Because just like the Brazilians had Dunga, the Portuguese also need people to do the nitty-gritty things. And Costinha is one of them.

I catch your drift. You mean he's a Latin firebrand who likes to kick people up in the air, don't you! His lawyers maybe reading this, so let's just call him a skilful ball-winning midfielder with a quick temper.

But I can't remember him playing against EnglandThat's because he didn't. In fact his first performance in Euro 2000 came in the 87th minute against Romania

It's all coming back now! Wasn't he was the one who came on and scored with a dodgy header in about the sixth minute of injury time? Spot on!

Wasn't that a 0-0 draw waiting to happen? Not according to Costinha it wasn't. "I could smell a goal coming. I thought I'd score, only with my foot," was his post-match assessment.

So tell me a bit about this lad. Part of that great Portuguese Youth team that won everything I suppose Not quite, 25-year-old Costinha was a bit of a late developer. He previously played lower division football with Clube Oriental de Lisboa, AS Machico, CD Nacional Madeira and CF União Madeira, and it was only when he was transferred to Monaco in 1997 that his qualities began to be appreciated.

But national honours with Portugal followed soon afterwards, surely Not really. Costinha only made his debut for the national team in October 1998 during the 3-0 Euro 2000 qualifying victory over Slovakia. His brief appearance against Romania the week before last was only his third cap.

So how come he started against Turkey? Didn't you see him against Germany? Costinha ran tirelessly in midfield, popping up in both penalty areas to upset the rather rigid Germans..

But France will be an altogether different proposition Perhaps, but Costinha remains confident. "People always said we had a lot of skill. But we were not aggressive enough and did not have the mentality to win. But look how we were losing 2-0 to England and changed that to 3-2. And against Romania right to the last minute we believed we could win.

So why are Portugal so good at the moment? "I think the mentality has changed," Costinha says. "In the past we didn't have players in other countries. Now we have people at Barcelona, Lazio, in France and England and so on. That means we know how other countries play and it has brought a winning mentality."

Don't say: "He might have bags of flair but I bet he couldn't do it on a wintry night at Boundary Park"

Do say: "He just might be the Portuguese Pat Vieira."

Not to be confused with: Luis Figo, Cafu, Didier Deschamps

webTitle: Ex-MI5 man to sue Cook over Gadafy plot denial

fields.headline: Ex-MI5 man to sue Cook over Gadafy plot denial
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: David Shayler, the renegade MI5 officer, plans to sue Robin Cook over comments the foreign secretary made about a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy.
fields.body:
David Shayler, the renegade MI5 officer, plans to sue Robin Cook over comments the foreign secretary made about a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy.

"Mr Cook's claims that my allegations were 'pure fantasy' will be exposed as defamatory as they induced people to conclude that I was inventing information to serve my own ends," Mr Shayler said.

The foreign secretary dismissed the allegation in a BBC television interview last year. A classified MI6 report - distributed throughout Whitehall, including the Foreign Office - subsequently revealed that MI6 was approached by a plotter with details of a plan to kill Col Gadafy in 1996.

The MI6 report was posted on the internet. Mr Shayler said MI6 paid the plotter for the information.

He confirmed that he plans to return to Britain where he faces charges under the Official Secrets Act.

He indicated that he would do so sometime during the summer.

He recently received an undertaking from the crown prosecution service that "provided satisfactory conditions were agreed" it "would not object" to his application for bail.

fields.headline: Victorious Mugabe defies British critics
fields.standfirst:
We should not be surprised that voters in rural Zimbabwe have backed the ruling party, argues deputy foreign editor Victoria Brittain
Zimbabwe's ruling party wins majority despite opposition gains
fields.trailText: 27 June, 10.45am: We should not be surprised that voters in rural Zimbabwe have backed the ruling party, argues deputy foreign editor Victoria Brittain.
fields.body:
The victory of President Robert Mugabe's Zanu-PF party at the polls will have surprised many in Britain who have been led by the extraordinary campaign by the British press and the Foreign Office to believe that Zimbabweans were united in a passionate desire to see the back of the present regime.

Their unveiled personal attacks on the president as demented, and his supporters as thugs, overlooked the fact that - as the outcome has shown - Zimbabwe is a society deeply divided between urban and rural societies, and where ethnic divisions have great significance.

President Mugabe may not be a democrat on the Westminster model, but for about half the country, notably in the rural areas, he represents continuity with a liberation struggle of which they are extremely proud. Meanwhile the opposition, with its prominent white businessmen and its foreign backing, is something to be very suspicious of.

Now the humiliation of the president has not happened, what next? No one can forecast what power the new opposition in parliament will have on policy, but it is likely to be limited to pushing for a crackdown on corruption.

The critical questions facing Mugabe and his government are the creaking economy, land redistribution, and Zimbabwe's role in the Congo war.

It is unlikely that Mugabe has any intention of embracing elements of the opposition's neo-liberal economic programme. Nor will he see any reason to curb the de facto land redistribution which the war veterans and their followers have imposed.

In fact the two remaining years of Mugabe's presidency are likely to see a hotting up of the land wars, unless the international community steps in with substantial funds to assist an orderly paying-off of white farmers.

It is on the disastrous Congo war that Mugabe is most likely to change tack in the coming months. The huge costs have been a key element in the country's economic near-collapse, and the president's prestige has been seriously undermined by the charges of his armed forces' links to dubious mining ventures in the Congo.

And Mugabe is a shrewd enough diplomat to know that the tide in other parts of Africa is running strongly in favour of a peaceful solution to the Congo war. He recently made overtures to the key player on the opposing side, Rwanda, and an announcement of the withdrawal of his troops would do wonders for his image before the forthcoming Organisation of African Unity summit.

fields.headline: Zimbabwe goes to the polls
fields.standfirst:
The ruling Zanu-PF party has won a majority in the elections, but the opposition has attracted unprecedented support. Derek Brown explains the implications for Robert Mugabe's 20-year rule
Special report
fields.trailText:
The ruling Zanu-PF party has won a majority in the elections, but the opposition has attracted unprecedented support. We explain the implications for Robert Mugabe's 20-year rule.
Special report
fields.body:
Could President Mugabe be forced out of power?
He is very unlikely to lose the presidency, at least not constitutionally, because his Zanu-PF party has won the country's parliamentary elections. It held on to 62 seats, with the opposition, the Movement for Democratic Change, winning 57 and a small independent party gaining one seat. Zanu-PF's majority is supplemented by 30 members personally appointed to parliament by the president. Ninety-two allies in a 150-member parliament should be enough for President Mugabe's government to function effectively and pass legislation, although Zimbabwe's new opposition suggests that some Zanu-PF members will be prepared to vote against their president.

Was President Mugabe re-elected along with his party?
No. The presidential elections are not scheduled to be held until 2002. President Mugabe is now likely to claim that these elections give his government the mandate to continue with its campaign of land reform, forcing privileged white farmers off their land and reallocating it to landless black people. But the MDC's arrival, out of nowhere, has encouraged its leader, Morgan Tvsangirai. He says he will challenge Mr Mugabe for the presidential post in two years' time.

Who are the Movement for Democratic Change?
The MDC is the most effective opposition group Zimbabwe has known since Mr Mugabe led the country to independence in 1980. It is backed by organised labour, and has widespread support in urban areas which have been hit hard by relentless economic decline. There are fears that the Zimbabwean economy is close to meltdown, with an imminent risk of bank failures.

How has the president defended his rule?
By unleashing a reign of terror; by claiming that the opposition is in the pocket of the white minority; by blaming Britain for his country's ills; and by banning about 200 foreign observers from the elections. The head of the European Union's observer group, Pierre Schori, says he has never encountered so many problems with accreditation, or seen so much pre-election violence. At least 32 people died in the run up to the polls.

Is the violence all one-sided?
By no means, though the Zanu-PF thugs have the tacit support of the government and large sections of the police, who have turned a blind eye to much of the intimidation of MDF supporters. Opposition leaders claim that President Mugabe, after a lifetime's struggle for democracy, is now obsessed with keeping power at any cost.

Is the opposition cowed?
In the run-up to the election many ordinary voters appeared to be unafraid of Zanu-PF intimidation. The president drew 6,000 supporters to an election meeting in Harare, while Mr Tsvangirai attracted 30,000 boisterous supporters to his rally. The MDC claims that in many constituencies the Zanu-PF only won through intimidation. The party's legal adviser, David Coltart, has said the party plans to challenge some of the results in court.

What now for the white community?
They are mostly keeping their heads down, though it is no secret that many would love to see the back of President Mugabe. Many whites have fled the country since the wave of violent farm seizures by Zanu-PF militants began. Those who remain in the dwindling ranks of the Commercial Farmers' Union must fear that there will be more anti-white action as well as anti-white rhetoric from the president. He said last week that "Zimbabwe is a black man's land, and a black man will determine who gets it".

What do Zimbabwe's neighbours think of recent events?
There are fears that the anti-white violence could spill over into South Africa. South Africa has an even larger white minority which, as in Zimbabwe, controls a disproportionate amount of land and wealth.

fields.bodyText: Could President Mugabe be forced out of power? He is very unlikely to lose the presidency, at least not constitutionally, because his Zanu-PF party has won the country's parliamentary elections. It held on to 62 seats, with the opposition, the Movement for Democratic Change, winning 57 and a small independent party gaining one seat. Zanu-PF's majority is supplemented by 30 members personally appointed to parliament by the president. Ninety-two allies in a 150-member parliament should be enough for President Mugabe's government to function effectively and pass legislation, although Zimbabwe's new opposition suggests that some Zanu-PF members will be prepared to vote against their president. Was President Mugabe re-elected along with his party? No. The presidential elections are not scheduled to be held until 2002. President Mugabe is now likely to claim that these elections give his government the mandate to continue with its campaign of land reform, forcing privileged white farmers off their land and reallocating it to landless black people. But the MDC's arrival, out of nowhere, has encouraged its leader, Morgan Tvsangirai. He says he will challenge Mr Mugabe for the presidential post in two years' time. Who are the Movement for Democratic Change? The MDC is the most effective opposition group Zimbabwe has known since Mr Mugabe led the country to independence in 1980. It is backed by organised labour, and has widespread support in urban areas which have been hit hard by relentless economic decline. There are fears that the Zimbabwean economy is close to meltdown, with an imminent risk of bank failures. How has the president defended his rule? By unleashing a reign of terror; by claiming that the opposition is in the pocket of the white minority; by blaming Britain for his country's ills; and by banning about 200 foreign observers from the elections. The head of the European Union's observer group, Pierre Schori, says he has never encountered so many problems with accreditation, or seen so much pre-election violence. At least 32 people died in the run up to the polls. Is the violence all one-sided? By no means, though the Zanu-PF thugs have the tacit support of the government and large sections of the police, who have turned a blind eye to much of the intimidation of MDF supporters. Opposition leaders claim that President Mugabe, after a lifetime's struggle for democracy, is now obsessed with keeping power at any cost. Is the opposition cowed? In the run-up to the election many ordinary voters appeared to be unafraid of Zanu-PF intimidation. The president drew 6,000 supporters to an election meeting in Harare, while Mr Tsvangirai attracted 30,000 boisterous supporters to his rally. The MDC claims that in many constituencies the Zanu-PF only won through intimidation. The party's legal adviser, David Coltart, has said the party plans to challenge some of the results in court. What now for the white community? They are mostly keeping their heads down, though it is no secret that many would love to see the back of President Mugabe. Many whites have fled the country since the wave of violent farm seizures by Zanu-PF militants began. Those who remain in the dwindling ranks of the Commercial Farmers' Union must fear that there will be more anti-white action as well as anti-white rhetoric from the president. He said last week that "Zimbabwe is a black man's land, and a black man will determine who gets it". What do Zimbabwe's neighbours think of recent events? There are fears that the anti-white violence could spill over into South Africa. South Africa has an even larger white minority which, as in Zimbabwe, controls a disproportionate amount of land and wealth. Where can I find out more? webTitle: Two-thirds off tickets to Beau Travail screening and interview

fields.headline: Two-thirds off tickets to Beau Travail screening and interview
fields.trailText: Film Unlimited readers can buy tickets for a screening of Beau Travail followed by the Guardian interview with the director, Claire Denis, at £5 each (normal price £14)
fields.body:
As the culmination of the National Film Theatre's Claire Denis season, what is arguably her masterpiece, Beau Travail, will be screened on Wednesday night, followed by an interview with the extraordinary French director.

As Jonathan Romney wrote during last year's London Film Festival, "Denis has been making extraordinary films for the last decade, but remains an unknown and (apart from her first film, Chocolat) undistributed quantity here. Her films tend to return to questions of sexuality and race - Chocolat (1988), for instance, was about a young girl (pointedly named France) growing up in the Cameroons and learning the ways of colonialism. Beau Travail, however, is unlike anything Denis has made before: stark and stylised, it's a semi-vérité, semi-ballet fantasia, as well as an adaptation of two versions of Billy Budd - Herman Melville's original story and Benjamin Britten's opera, used on the soundtrack."

Beau Travail has already been chosen by some critics as one of the stand-out films of the 90s. In a foreign legion outpost in Djibouti, Sergeant Galoup (Denis Lavant) leads his men in manoeuvres and physical exercises that are more like homoerotic ballet routines.

Galoup is dedicated to his commanding officer, but life at the camp is disturbed by the arrival of handsome recruit Sentier, leading to Galoup's disgrace.

A thinly-disguised reworking of Herman Melville's Billy Budd, orchestrated with extracts from the Benjamin Britten opera, Beau Travail is a powerful study of male discontents.

After the screening, Claire Denis will be present to discuss the film and her career with Jonathan Romney. Beau Travail is at 6.30pm on Wednesday 28 June, and will be followed by the Guardian interview with the director.

We have 50 tickets at £5 each (full price £14) available exclusively for Film Unlimited users. To buy one of these discounted tickets, please call the NFT box office on 020 7928 3232 and quote Film Unlimited.

The offers applies only to this screening and ends on 28 June 2000; only two discounted tickets per caller.

fields.headline: Shipman inquiry 'must be in public'
fields.trailText: A public inquiry into how serial killer GP Harold Shipman came to murder so many of his patients was vital "to restore faith and confidence in GPs and the NHS", the High Court has been told.
fields.body:
A public inquiry into how serial killer GP Harold Shipman came to murder so many of his patients was vital "to restore faith and confidence in GPs and the NHS", the High Court has been told.

The call for an open inquiry came as 113 relatives of those who died began their legal battle for the right to an investigation which was fully open to the press and public.

Eight national newspaper and media groups joined them in the action triggered by the decision to hold the inquiry in private.

Earlier this year Shipman, 54, was convicted at Preston Crown Court of murdering 15 patients, but he is suspected of killing nearly 200.

Augustus Ullstein QC, appearing for the bereaved families, told two judges that throughout the Shipman affair the relatives had co-operated with the police and the coroner "to a very marked degree" despite the tragedy which had befallen them.

In many cases, their grief was increased by having to go through the exhumation and re-burial of their loved ones.

They had all been led to believe they were to have a public inquiry as a result of statements made in the House of Commons by Health Secretary Alan Milburn in February. He had said the inquiry would be conducted in public.

But Mr Milburn had now made it clear he believed the inquiry should be in private, although its report would be made public, along with any evidence the inquiry team "feel appropriate" for publication.

Mr Ullstein asked Lord Justice Kennedy, sitting with Mr Justice Jackson, to overturn Mr Milburn's decision. He argued the relatives, some 30 of whom were in court listening, had a "legitimate expectation" that the full inquiry would be in public - "fairness and justice" demanded an open inquiry.

He said: "These are the very men and women whose confidence in the NHS and in general practitioners needs to be restored. They represent, not only the families, but also perhaps the ordinary men and women of the general public whose faith and confidence in the NHS needs to be restored as a result of the activities of Dr Shipman."
