webTitle: Who wants to be a legionnaire?

fields.headline: Who wants to be a legionnaire?
fields.standfirst:
French director Claire Denis caused a sensation with Chocolat. Now she has made a homoerotic Billy Budd - with soldiers sweating in the desert instead of sailors toiling at sea. Jonathan Romney on a tale of jealousy and martyrdom

 Buy tickets to the Beau Travail screening and Claire Denis interview at two-thirds the normal price
fields.trailText: French director Claire Denis caused a sensation with Chocolat. Now she has made a homoerotic Billy Budd - with soldiers sweating in the desert instead of sailors toiling at sea. Jonathan Romney on a tale of jealousy and martyrdom
fields.body:
These days only over-night sensations seem to count for much in cinema, so it's gratifying when an already established name steps into the limelight 12 years after her first feature. French director Claire Denis became a name to watch in 1988, with her first film Chocolat, an oblique study of colonial tensions in Africa. Since then she has made a series of audacious, low-budget features - six in all, none shown here - but now British fans have the chance to see her work once again.

Her boldest film yet, Beau Travail has once more made critics in France and the US take notice. Beau Travail, many are saying, has thrown Denis into a new league of film-making. Some US critics have used jazz analogies: suddenly Denis's work has loosened up so dazzlingly that she's become a Charlie Parker, an Ornette Coleman. And when it comes to whipping up complex, unpredictable variations on a standard theme, Beau Travail is definitely up there with the bebop greats. Inspired by Billy Budd, Herman Melville's tale of jealousy and martyrdom on the high seas, Denis has set her story in a French Foreign Legion camp in Djibouti, framing the sweating shaven heads against stark salt flats, to extracts from Benjamin Britten's Melville-inspired opera.

It's not as if France was going through a fashion for films about the Foreign Legion, a topic pretty much invisible on screen these days. "It's not a taboo subject," Denis says. "It just doesn't interest people. You can spend your whole life in France without ever thinking about the Legion." But Denis discovered analogies between the Legion and the naval universe of Billy Budd: "a male world, with internal rules and codes of honour".

The rules in Beau Travail become a sort of abstract dance, the Legionnaires' manoeuvres suggesting something between samurai discipline and the limbering-up of a radical gay corps de ballet. It's not really a dance film, Denis says, although she worked with a choreographer, Bernardo Montet. That was the only way that she could create an "ideal army" on a minimal budget. "We started with the motions of military training, and worked to form a coherent military unit using only 15 men. I played them the Britten opera, which I listened to while I was writing the script. But we never set out with the word 'dance' in mind. We just thought of work."

Beau Travail is Denis's first return to Africa in a film since Chocolat, inspired by her own childhood as the daughter of a government functionary. The family frequently moved around west Africa, with the exception of a year in Djibouti, a French overseas territory in east Africa that gained independence in 1977. But Denis, 54 , stresses Beau Travail was not made in the spirit of autobiographical pilgrimage. "I remember being dazzled by the beauty of the Red Sea, the desert. You don't forget a landscape like that. I always thought of Djibouti as a place where human history hasn't really begun yet - or perhaps it's already over. There's something in the landscape that's stronger than human civilisation. There's no agriculture, for example, and there are live volcanoes. And there's the Legion."

Shooting in Djibouti contributed to the nervy, abstract quality of Beau Travail. "I thought war might start again with Eritrea, or the French army might stop us shooting. I felt so insecure I said, 'We'll take it day by day, because tomorrow it might all be over.' That liberated some kind of energy."

Any militaristic ideals of empire that still attach to the Legion in France are thoroughly skewed in Denis's film. Her "ideal" army looks futile and perverse, toiling away in a desert void. It's also a distinctly homoerotic world - inevitably, Denis says. "If you film 15 men under the sun, in great physical shape and in uniform, it's bound to look homoerotic. That is the image of the Legionnaire - go to certain gay clubs in Paris and you'll see a lot of that imagery."

What's unusual is that such a reverie of male physicality has been filmed by two women, Denis and her regular photographer Agnès Godard. Denis can't deny that there is an erotic resonance for her. "When you work with actors, they abandon themselves to the person filming in a way that's erotic in itself. But I'm not so much interested in images of male beauty, or female beauty. What I like is the idea of a group, even if it's just two people - the idea of solitude within a group."

Many of Denis's films are close-up studies of male groups locked together in claustrophobic isolation - like the two black men embroiled in the cockfighting underworld in her brutally realistic S'En Fout La Mort (No Fear No Die), or the Cameroonian musicians Les T tes Brlées, whose first French tour Denis filmed in her documentary Man No Run.

There's a group within the group in Beau Travail: Melville's infernal triangle of beautiful recruit, lofty commander and embittered, jealous sergeant. The last is played by Denis Lavant, the savage-looking star of Leos Carax's first three films. In Beau Travail, he comes into his own as a tough, tender monster, dancing out his agonies in the final disco solo, like a Travolta burning in a private hell. "That whole question of what it means to be a man and join the Legion: Denis Lavant had already thought about it himself, and it played a big part."

Another star of the film is Michel Subor, the lead in Jean-Luc Godard's Le Petit Soldat in 1960. Both Subor and Lavant are new to Denis's world, but she tends to work repeatedly with the same actors, such as Beau Travail's Grégoire Colin. "I have very strong relationships with my actors when I'm shooting. When you love an actor's work, you always feel you have to go further and you make several films together. One film just gives you time to get acquainted."

Denis's loose repertory cast also includes Béatrice Dalle, Alex Descas and US madcap Vincent Gallo, who all feature in the film she's currently completing, Trouble Every Day. It just might, Denis says, live up to its advance billing as a horror movie.

Denis served her apprenticeship as assistant to an improbable range of major-league directors, among them Jim Jarmusch, Wim Wenders, Dusan Makavejev and especially the enigmatic new wave veteran Jacques Rivette. What she learned most of all was a particular attitude to filming. "I never liked directors who simply shoot in order to translate a script into images. I was always interested in people who try to capture the moment on set, a piece of time. That's what I try to do. If the script wins, then nothing happens between me and the actors. I prefer to film the film: the relationship between myself, the location, the time passing and the characters."

Probably the most consistently exciting director in France at the moment, Denis is certainly the one who does most to undermine the image of French art film as vaporous and talky. Even when her films look on the surface like straight realism, they have a way of locking you into a closed world and making you watch while things happen - sometimes things you can't believe any director would risk tackling. Take her 1993 film J'ai Pas Sommeil (I Can't Sleep). Inspired by a real case, this Paris-set story has a central character who is a gay, black serial killer of OAPs. It seems a perversely challenging starting point for a film Denis intended as a critique of the rightwing paranoia that she felt prevailed in Paris at the time. Or perhaps it's just an unusually rigorous example of "capturing the moment".

"For me, it was a testament of that period, of that city in the 90s," Denis says. "I think it's important for cinema to be a witness to the times. You have to leave something behind you. Renoir said that you should film neighbourhoods that are about to be demolished, before they're forgotten. And that's what cinema is about - the need to leave traces."

 The Guardian Interview with Claire Denis is on Wednesday at the NFT, London SE1 (020-7928 3232). Beau Travail is released on July 14.

webTitle: The stars set to come out for Marshall (with two exceptions)

fields.headline: The stars set to come out for Marshall (with two exceptions)
fields.standfirst: In wisden.com's gossip column this week, we explain how you can see 18 Test captains in the same match (with two notable exceptions), how Brian Johnston's grandson is catching the eye and why Phil Tufnell has at last won a contract of his own
fields.trailText: Botham and Gower opt out of the firing line
fields.body:
Botham and Gower opt out of the firing line

If you want to see a matchless array of talent - and don't mind some elderly fielding - the place to be is not any of this summer's international matches, but next month's charity game in honour of the late Malcolm Marshall.

The one-day match in London on July 27 features almost all the big West Indies and England names of Marshall's era. Sir Viv Richards leads a Malcolm Marshall XI including Clive Lloyd, Joel Garner, Michael Holding, Gordon Greenidge, Desmond Haynes - and two veterans who are still scything through England: Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh.

The England teams who struggled manfully against that lot will be represented by Graham Gooch, Mike Gatting, Allan Lamb, Robin Smith (skippering the side), Alec Stewart and Angus Fraser. They turn out under the banner of an International PCA Bunbury XI reinforced by Shane Warne, Wasim Akram, Mohammad Azharuddin, Michael Slater and Justin Langer. No fewer than 18 former Test captains have now confirmed their participation.

It might have been 20, but there are two giants missing from the line-up. There's no Ian Botham, and no David Gower - and it's not because they don't fancy another encounter with the Caribbean fast men. The two Sky TV stars have both given up the game for good. Gower, who does other things for charity, recently told me why: "I don't want to play, that's the simplest way of putting it," he said. "I enjoy the game from a totally different perspective now."

The organisers thought of asking Botham and Gower to umpire the game, which takes place at the Honourable Artillery Company Ground in the City of London (tickets: 020 7344 4444). But then they decided that a cast list of this quality required proper umpires, and an invitation went out to Dickie Bird instead. He accepted, then remembered a previous commitment. So the Holders (Vanburn and John) will supervise a contest which should raise thousands of pounds for the Mali Marshall Trust, a fund set up to support Marshall's widow Connie and their seven-year-old son Mali.

No fewer than 44 players are taking part at one stage or another, Jimmy Adams, Brian Lara, Darren Gough and Graham Thorpe among them. "You'll never see so many great players on one field again," says Bunbury founder David English, the main organiser. "It's the kind of day Malcolm would have loved."

Johnners' grandson also rises

As the schools cricket season reaches its climax, one of those catching the eye is the grandson of the late great BBC commentator Brian Johnston. Nick Oldridge, Stowe School's wicketkeeper-batsman, recently emphasised his class by stroking five fours in the final over of a match against Oundle. Not that it was quite enough to give his side victory: they finished 10 runs short, with Oldridge 50 not out, and the game was drawn.

Oldridge's recent performances have just about persuaded Harold Rhodes, the former Derbyshire and England fast bowler who coaches Stowe's 1st XI, to recommend that Surrey take a look at him this summer. "Oldridge is very, very talented," says Rhodes. "He times the ball beautifully, and is an extremely good 'keeper. He wants a career in cricket. He could go all the way."

Oldridge, 17, established himself in the 1st XI unusually quickly, as a 15-year-old 'keeper, and will end his Stowe days as captain next season - unless it's felt the triple role would prove as burdensome for a schoolboy as it did for Alec Stewart with England.

Rhodes is still enthusing about the way Oldridge went after Oundle's strike bowler in that final over: "There were three straight drives to the sightscreen, then the bowler lost his rag and dug a couple in. Nick pulled them both to the boundary. Super shots, all five of them." He adds: "His biggest problem is that he tries to entertain too much. He should be getting 100s, not 50s." Brian Johnston, himself a wicketkeeper, would surely have taken a more indulgent view of his grandson's Gower-like half-centuries.

The Cat gets another life

Phil Tufnell has finally secured an international contract. Overlooked by England for both a Test and a one-day contract, he has been preferred to a number of contracted players for another deal. Tufnell has been signed by the London Evening Standard to write a fortnightly column on this summer's internationals. He succeeds Jeff Thomson, Zimbabwe's bowling coach, who filled the slot during the recent Test series.

Why did the paper prefer Tufnell to Messrs Hick, Vaughan, Flintoff or Caddick? "He's more interesting," says the Standard sports desk. "He's always good copy." It is the Middlesex slow left-armer's first attempt at a regular newspaper column, and he writes it himself, in longhand, before typing it up in the offices of his manager, round the corner from Lord's. The manager, Mike Martin, won't discuss figures but the contract is thought to be worth £3,000-£5,000.

The first column, published on the eve of the Edgbaston Test, was typically playful, but also prescient - the headline was "Windies still have the ability to inflict pain". But Tufnell is far from resigned to being an onlooker. As Martin stresses: "Phil's bowling well and is still very confident he can get back into the England set-up this summer."

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). E-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com

The one-day match in London on July 27 features almost all the big West Indies and England names of Marshall's era. Sir Viv Richards leads a Malcolm Marshall XI including Clive Lloyd, Joel Garner, Michael Holding, Gordon Greenidge, Desmond Haynes - and two veterans who are still scything through England: Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh. The England teams who struggled manfully against that lot will be represented by Graham Gooch, Mike Gatting, Allan Lamb, Robin Smith (skippering the side), Alec Stewart and Angus Fraser. They turn out under the banner of an International PCA Bunbury XI reinforced by Shane Warne, Wasim Akram, Mohammad Azharuddin, Michael Slater and Justin Langer. No fewer than 18 former Test captains have now confirmed their participation. It might have been 20, but there are two giants missing from the line-up. There's no Ian Botham, and no David Gower - and it's not because they don't fancy another encounter with the Caribbean fast men. The two Sky TV stars have both given up the game for good. Gower, who does other things for charity, recently told me why: "I don't want to play, that's the simplest way of putting it," he said. "I enjoy the game from a totally different perspective now." fields.headline: The end of Myers' Dieter
fields.trailText: Universal Studios have shut down pre-production on the latest Mike Myers project, Dieter. As we reported earlier this month, Universal and Myers have been involved in a legal battle over the film since Myers walked away from the project claiming the script wasn't ready.
fields.body:
Universal Studios have shut down pre-production on the latest Mike Myers project, Dieter. As we reported earlier this month, Universal and Myers have been involved in a legal battle over the film since Myers walked away from the project claiming the script wasn't ready.

Universal issued a breach of contract suit on June 5, saying it wanted the $5m already spent on the film plus loss of profits back; 25 employees stayed on the payroll, but the actor refused to come back. Even Steven Spielberg tried to mediate between the two parties, but neither would budge.

The film, based on one of Myer's Saturday Night Live characters, was due to start shooting this August. Universal chairman, Stacey Snider, has blamed Myers for the lay-offs: "While we are extremely disappointed that we won't be making this film, we are particularly anguished when considering all the talented individuals who came on board based on Mike Myers' commitment to this project and as a result gave up other projects to do this film."

Myers was set to make $20m on the project, but backed out because he said the script was unacceptable. "I cannot in good conscience accept $20m and cheat movie-goers," he said in a statement earlier this month. His lawyer has said that his contract calls for Myers' script approval before the film starts shooting.

fields.headline: Campus chic
fields.standfirst: High street names like Armani and Gucci were once far removed from students' ideals and pockets. Not any more. Baggy pants are out, designer clothes are in
fields.trailText: High street names like Armani and Gucci were once far removed from students' ideals and pockets. Not any more. Baggy pants are out, designer clothes are in
fields.body:
Scruffy. Baggy. Badly. Everyone knows how students dress, don't they? The popular image of A Student is still heavily influenced by The Young Ones and Withnail and I, both of which are at least 15 years old. And TV shows and magazine articles still rely lazily on this old student stereotype.

Well, you can forget all that: students have moved on and closer to the once unimaginable - absolutely fabulous.

"I was expecting the whole just-got-out-of-bed look," says Raemen Meghji, who has just completed his first year in econometrics at the London School of Economics.

"But I was really surprised by how much some people here spend on clothes. You see serious labels around the place, like Armani and stuff like that."

Jessica Loden, a first year at Edinburgh, agrees. "It is quite smart here, and there does tend to be a bit of a uniform of pink pashminas, long black coats and designer labels."

When living in a sea of 10,000 of your peers, the quickest - though maybe not cheapest - means of carving out your own identity (shorthand for proclaiming Who You Are) is through your clothes.

Think of the heavy metal fans proudly wearing their Metallica T-shirts, or the university athletes, seemingly inseparable from their tracksuits. Now more mainstream designer labels seem as acceptable as the more youthful ones. Over the past decade designers such as Gucci, Prada and Alberta Ferretti have been attracting a younger customer, so it is not surprising that this is slowly being reflected in university campuses.

Thanks to a highly fashion-conscious, young Hollywood (Gwyneth Paltrow, Brad Pitt, Uma Thurman, et al), designer clothes are no longer associated with staid middle-age or the equally off-putting image of Sloaniness.

Nor does this trend seem to be limited to big city universities. Students at East Anglia, Warwick and St Andrews universities all mentioned, respectively, the recent popularity of Prada bags, Armani shirts and Joseph trousers.

"OK, we all have no money," says Dave Telfer, a student at Nottingham Trent. "But clothes are so important at university, and some people are willing to sacrifice other things for the sake of clothes. People say it's especially so with girls, but I think it's with boys, too."

Some learn to compromise between their diminishing bank account and love of fashion. "You see people here wearing expensive trousers with an inexpensive T-shirt, or some other top they picked up in a thrift store," says Carl Wilkinson, a finalist at Oxford.

Raemen suggests this is partly due to the increasing numbers of wealthy foreign students at British universities who will have been raised wearing a cut above the average high street fare. More students work during their gap year, and some continue while studying, giving them extra spending power.

Also, thanks to influential lifestyle and fashion magazines such as i.D and Dazed and Confused, an interest in clothing no longer carries the stigma it once did, especially among male students. Magazines aimed at 18- to 35-year-olds celebrate designer clothing alongside more youthful, alternative labels. No longer is spending an inordinate amount of money on attention-grabbing and ostentatiously pricey clothing seen as laughable or vain.

And if you feel uncomfortable with this fascination with designer labels, be grateful you're not at university in the States. Holly Heatherington, a sophomore at Princeton, describes her college's collective style as "Ralph Lauren button-down shirts and pearls".

But how does this meld with the demands of university? Do students really go to the library wearing Donna Karan? "It's just a nice little luxury, and one that will now give you some cred with your peers," says James Bates, a student at Manchester University.

"Students, particularly finalists, are really anxious about finding jobs when they finish and are becoming independent; if you dress in jeans and hooded tops all the time, you feel like a kid. Dressing up makes you feel a little less scummy and more confident, even if you live in a hell-hole full of festering plates of food. Also, you then always have something to wear to job interviews."

Despite their growing presence at universities, however, designer labels are not, fortunately, de rigueur: you are unlikely to be mocked if your wardrobe is lacking in Valentino or Lacroix. For most students, such clothing is as out of reach as meeting every essay deadline.

"Despite the emphasis on appearance, students aren't fashion fascists, simply because there is such a range of styles," Carl explains. "It's just that the old image of students - tracksuit bottoms, three-day-old plates of baked beans, watching Teletubbies all day - never did apply, and is perhaps even less true today. People, and that includes students, are just more fashion-conscious these days."

"There is an in-between," says James. "But if you want to stand out from the crowd, as well as give yourself a bit more confidence - which you sometimes need at university - what better way than to wear amazing clothes? Students cannot live by combats alone, you know."

Unless they're from Calvin Klein, presumably.

The Boutique Geek look that's open to all

Of course, not every student can afford Gucci or Pucci. But this does not mean they are relegated to fashion ignominy. On the contrary, students are known for making a pound stretch as far as possible which, for some, can furnish them with a whole new, much trendier wardrobe.

Although the NHS specs look, popularised by the likes of Jarvis Cocker and Chris Evans, might be sooo 1997, their Geek Chic look lives on - but not as we knew it. Boutique Geek Chic is the sartorial expression of irony, just as lounge music is irony in a musical form. Small wonder, then, that this look is particularly beloved of teenage boys, who are probably also thrilled to have found an alternative to fairly mundane high street offerings.

Roughly speaking, the staples of a Boutique Geek Chic wardrobe are as follows: loud Hawaiian shirts, old Sainsbury uniform shirts, T-shirts from concerts in the Eighties (Metallica, Rick Astley, Duran Duran), 30-year-old Savile Row suits, oddly patterned trousers, silk shirts, and anything else found in the 50p and under basket in the local charity shop. The lad who lists Oxfam, Scope and Cancer Research among his recreational activities may be exceptionally community-minded, but he might equally be a shopaholic.

The benefits to Boutique Geek Chic are obvious: no one else will be sporting your outfit; your clothes express that you have an ironic, intelligent sense of humour; you get to wear fun clothes without looking effeminate, and it is dirt cheap. As to who wears the look, a safe rule of thumb is the lad who trawls through Sam's Crazy Records for hours on end in search of that elusive vinyl recording from 1972, or he who sifts through charity shop bins, looking for that perfectly hideous (or hideously perfect) Hawaiian shirt.

This is not a look for the guys, but for the individual. Sadly for the Boutique Geek Chic geek, the look is no longer quite so individual. Just as designers such as Matthew Williamson and Jean-Paul Gaultier are mining a rich ethnic seam from Rajasthani Chic - once the preferred budget style of travellers to Goa and 14-year-old Camden Market devotees - so some are cashing in on the charity shop look, aka The Vintage Look.

Prada's enormous seventies-style sunglasses, Gucci's huge floral prints and Paul Smith's Hawaiian shirts are all worryingly reminiscent of Boutique Geek Chic - tacky, yet somehow fascinatingly cool.

Even worse, the high street has picked up on Boutique Geek Chic, with those bastions of homogeneity, French Connection and Next, stocking baggy smart trousers and loud summer shirts for men. For Heaven's sake, even Ant and Dec have adopted the look, and few 20-year-old, heterosexual males want to resemble Saturday morning kids' TV presenters.

This all rather takes the fun out of Boutique Geek Chic, much in the way the mass CD market, the endless compilation tapes and car advertisements have firmly removed the irony from Burt Bacharach and Dean Martin.

Once everyone else gets the joke, where's the excitement? Where's the individuality? Hopefully for debt-stricken, fashion-starved students, it can still be found somewhere for less than a pound.

 Hadley Freeman

fields.headline: Self made man
fields.standfirst: Will Self's schooldays are not what you might expect. He tells all to  John Crace
fields.trailText: Will Self's schooldays are not what you might expect. He tells all to John Crace
fields.body:
Anyone thumbing through the comment book at the fig-1 art gallery in London, where a droid-like Will Self was recently installed for a one week novella-writing stint as a tableau scribblant, might have been stumped by one particular entry. In between the mindlessly dull and the smart-arsed, trying-too-hard-to-be-clever, lay the baldly enigmatic, "Colin Dudley would have been proud of you".

So who, or what, is Colin Dudley? A trope out of Self's fiction? The doyen of London's literati?

"He was one of my English teachers," Self explains later. "He was actually very good but it was his appearance that most caught the eye. He was flamboyantly bisexual, with a wig where the crêpe showed through underneath, and he wore extremely tight jeans that displayed his tackle to maximum effect. For lessons, he'd play Donovan tapes and tell us how he used to take speed."

For someone who has made a living out of the provocative bon mot, there is very little side to Self these days. He's a large man with an even larger presence, but his bad boy days are well and truly over. You still wouldn't ever mark him down as one of life's dabblers, but what you see is now pretty much what you get. The artifice is back where it belongs, in the fiction rather than his life. So when he says, "I was the conformist of the family," you have to take him seriously.

Conformity, it turns out, was a relative concept chez Self. His father was an academic, specialising in political science and town planning, and his mother was a liberal New York Jewish wiseacre. "It was my brother who dropped out of school to go into business who was considered the rebel," he smiles. "My dad thought he was déclassé for turning to trade, while my mum thought he should have progressed beyond traditional Jewish mercantile pursuits."

Self drew the family plaudits for his creativity, but they came with a high price. Most children get to fight with their parents at some stage, yet Self never had that luxury.

"There was nothing to react against," he continues, "as my mother was always just that bit more anarchic than me. I remember my last day at my first school, Golders Hill. All those who were leaving were supposed to shake hands with the mannish Mrs Davies, but I told my mum that I wanted to tell her to get lost and that I hated her. My mum just said, "Good idea. You kick her in the shins and tell her to piss off and I'll have the car waiting at the bottom of the steps with the door open and the engine running."

"So did you?"

"God, no," he replies, horrified. "But it was the same with my drug-taking. Until I started taking heroin, she positively encouraged it. She thought it was just a phase."

"A long phase."

"Yeah, 25 years," he guesstimates. "You can see why I have such a confused attitude towards authority figures."

Which might explain why the first teacher ever to make a positive impression on him was the complete antithesis of what you expect. University College Junior School was naice liberal Hampstead posh through and through. Mr Marston, the 5th form Latin teacher, wasn't. He was a former sergeant in the marines whose preferred mode of dress was the full Batman rig, complete with cane.

"He represented everything I hated," Self observes, "but I came to like him and he came to like me." However, the mutual admiration almost certainly grew out of a shared sense of the macabre than out of family values. "He was fond of telling us how one officer used to peer down the barrels of his platoon's rifles," he continues. "He came to the last soldier and ordered him to pull the trigger. Which he did, and blew the officer's head off. Mr Marston told this as if it was a parable, but I'm still not exactly sure what the meaning is."

Come secondary school, Self was moved to the local grammar, Christ's College. A few of the boys may have spoken like Derek and Clive, but it was by no means rough and for Self it was another non-experience, with little to kick against. He marked his territory in his second week when he wrote "Down with Thatcher" on the blackboard to celebrate the local MP and then minister for education's school visit, which earned him two weeks' toilet duties, but for the most part the school did nothing but show forbearance for Self's adolescent rebelliousness.

His penchant for oddballs re-emerged in his two English teachers, Colin Dudley and Mike Smith. "Smith was a wonderfully colourless man who gave nothing away about himself," Self says. "We tried to track him on motorbikes and mopeds to find out more about him, but we failed abjectly. He was a great teacher, though; he was very good on exegesis and he introduced me to structural critical theory when I was 16."

Smith recognised an intellectual precocity behind Self's frontiness and set out to nurture it. He advised Self against studying critical theory at Oxford, on the grounds that it would ruin any career he might have as a fiction writer, and steered him towards philosophy. All went according to plan, until Self arrived at Oxford, whereupon he disengaged academically and pursued applied pharmacology instead.

Indeed his one novel contribution to ratiocination stemmed from his recreational interests. "I advanced an Argument from Hallucination," he offers, "whereby you could prove reality is real by taking a strong psychotropic drug. When you were coming down, you took another psychotropic drug and if you noticed the difference it proved there must be a substratum of reality on which the two drugs must be acting."

He adds that his tutor, the philosopher Galen Strawson, was highly taken with this theory and you can sense that Self still reckons the argument has merit. In between the mindlessly dull and the smart-arsed, trying-too-hard-to-be-clever, lay the baldly enigmatic, "Colin Dudley would have been proud of you". So who, or what, is Colin Dudley? A trope out of Self's fiction? The doyen of London's literati? "He was one of my English teachers," Self explains later. "He was actually very good but it was his appearance that most caught the eye. He was flamboyantly bisexual, with a wig where the crêpe showed through underneath, and he wore extremely tight jeans that displayed his tackle to maximum effect. For lessons, he'd play Donovan tapes and tell us how he used to take speed." For someone who has made a living out of the provocative bon mot, there is very little side to Self these days. He's a large man with an even larger presence, but his bad boy days are well and truly over. You still wouldn't ever mark him down as one of life's dabblers, but what you see is now pretty much what you get. The artifice is back where it belongs, in the fiction rather than his life. So when he says, "I was the conformist of the family," you have to take him seriously. Conformity, it turns out, was a relative concept chez Self. His father was an academic, specialising in political science and town planning, and his mother was a liberal New York Jewish wiseacre. "It was my brother who dropped out of school to go into business who was considered the rebel," he smiles. "My dad thought he was déclassé for turning to trade, while my mum thought he should have progressed beyond traditional Jewish mercantile pursuits." "There was nothing to react against," he continues, "as my mother was always just that bit more anarchic than me. I remember my last day at my first school, Golders Hill. "But it was the same with my drug-taking. Until I started taking heroin, she positively encouraged it. She thought it was just a phase." "A long phase." "Yeah, 25 years," he guesstimates. webTitle: Affleck tipped to play a younger Jack Ryan

fields.headline: Affleck tipped to play a younger Jack Ryan
fields.trailText: Ben Affleck seems the hot favourite to step into Ford's shoes to play Jack Ryan in the next Tom Clancy adaptation
fields.body:
Ben Affleck, who was dubbed the next Harrison Ford by Miramax boss Bob Weinstein some years ago, seems the hot favourite to step into Ford's shoes to play Jack Ryan in the next Tom Clancy adaptation, The Sum of All Fears.

Ford announced earlier this month that he would not be reprising the role of the family-loving CIA agent after he met with director Phillip Noyce, who directed the star in his previous two outings as Ryan, and they couldn't agree on a script.

The only problem could be that Harrison was 52 when he last played Ryan in Clear and Present Danger in 1994, while Affleck is a mere 27 years old. Also, it is not clear how the film will deal with Ryan's family: Anne Archer has played Ryan's wife in both the Ford films and his daughter, 18-year-old American Beauty star Thora Birch is now all grown up and getting on with her own film projects. It has been suggested that the new film will take a "Jack Ryan - The Early Years" slant.

There are also rumours emanating from Mr Showbiz that although time and money have been invested into The Sum of All Fears, there is a chance that the project will be ditched in favour of bringing back an earlier Jack Ryan adventure such as The Cardinal and the Kremlin, which would be a way of getting around the age difference.

Ford was not the first actor to play Jack Ryan. Alec Baldwin first brought the role to the big screen in The Hunt for Red October in 1990, and the word is that Clancy always favoured Baldwin over Ford to play his rugged hero. The writer will be launching its latest Ryan book this August, entitled The Bear and the Dragon.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the transfer talk bounced up and down on some turf, tossed into the air, and then hit over a net at speeds of over 120mph.
fields.trailText: Arsenal are to sign Corinthians midfielder Edu for £6m, according to Planet Football. The 22-year-old will sign a five-year contract.
fields.body:
Arsenal are to sign Corinthians midfielder Edu for £6m, according to Planet Football. The 22-year-old will sign a five-year contract.

Wolves defender Lee Naylor is the latest left-back to be linked with Liverpool. Meanwhile, Anfield defender Rigobert Song will join Marseille in a £3.5m deal.

Everton, Derby, Leicester, Charlton and Manchester City are all interested in Coventry's transfer-listed striker Noel Whelan.

Bolton are making attempts to sign Chelsea's Mikael Forssell on a long-term loan.

Newcastle have rejected a £4m bid from Valencia for Didier Domi. Bobby Robson is holding out for £5m.

Manchester United failure Massimo Taibi will join Napoli in a one-year loan deal with a view to a permanent £3.5m transfer. The Italian club are also interested in Sheffield Wednesday's Pavel Srnicek.

Celtic's Mark Viduka will join Leeds in an £8m deal on Friday, while Davor Suker will complete a free transfer from Arsenal to West Ham on Thursday after ironing out work-permit problems. Meanwhile, Juventus have signed Monaco striker David Trezeguet for £14.6m.

webTitle: Amazon.bomb: How the internet's biggest success story turned sour

fields.headline: Amazon.bomb: How the internet's biggest success story turned sour
fields.standfirst:
The pioneering internet bookstore he founded in his garage made him a darling of Wall Street and Time's person of the year. Then on Friday Jeff Bezos saw the value of his company cut by a fifth. He tells Jane Martinson why he still believes Amazon.com will one day sell us everything

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The pioneering internet bookstore he founded in his garage made him a darling of Wall Street and Time's person of the year. Then on Friday Jeff Bezos saw the value of his company cut by a fifth. He tells Jane Martinson why he still believes Amazon.com will one day sell us everything
fields.body:
Every Friday night is party night at Amazon.com's headquarters in Seattle, Washington, and last Friday was no exception. As Jeff Bezos, the company's youthful founder, bounds into the staff canteen clad in the regulation blue shirt and khakis of the dot.com executive, the only sign that this might not be the start of an ordinary weekend at Amazon is the television news crews thronging outside. But Bezos ignores them, focusing instead on the technicians setting up the music system for that evening's function. A blast of feedback shakes the room. "I've got blood coming out of my ears, now, people!" Bezos says, and laughs the laugh that nobody who meets him fails to remember: a sound - part hyena, part Mike Myers's Dr Evil - that erupts at the oddest of times, preceding him down corridors, derailing your train of thought.

Most people were expecting blood on the carpet. For last Friday was one of the oddest days to hear Bezos's trademark guffaw, and the first time Amazon might justifiably have cancelled the staff shindig - probably the worst day in the history of the internet retailer that had become the shining success story of electronic commerce. The day had cost Bezos personally around a billion dollars. It began with a report from Lehman Brothers, the investment bank, warning that the company was haemorrhaging cash and might not survive. Analyst Ravi Suria highlighted Amazon's "weak balance sheet, poor working capital management, and massive negative operating cashflow - the financial characteristics that have driven innumerable retailers to disaster through history." It was a day during which Amazon's shares lost 20% of their value, and 51m of them changed hands. A company worth about $40bn (£25bn) just before Christmas had ended the day worth $12bn (£7.5bn), and things did not improve during trading yesterday.

Amid such dire warnings, few people expect the bunting to come out on July 15, the fifth anniversary of the company's launch. Except, perhaps, Bezos himself. The energetic 36-year-old takes an attitude to losing $1bn (£625m) in one day that is, to say the least, long term.

"Three years ago our stock was $1.50 a share, today it's $30-something. There have been many, many days when our stock has gone up 20% in a day" - that laugh again - "and if stocks can go up 20% in a day, they can go down 20% in a day. All internet stocks are volatile, including Amazon.com... we are nowhere near running out of cash, and we are not at all worried about it." ("He is always like this," says Bezos's assistant, Lizzie Allen. "Always optimistic.")

Amazon, taken to court two years ago for claiming to be the earth's biggest retailer, has unquestionably become one of its best-known brands. A company that started as an online bookseller has assiduously purchased the rising stars of e-commerce, and now offers music, videos, kitchenware, garden tools, DIY equipment and more. But even with his firm's vast product range and expanding customer base - 1.4m people in the UK alone - Bezos's optimism is beginning to look increasingly isolated. Despite the company's vigorous expansion and development, including proposed same-day delivery in some British city centres soon, the year that Amazon is expected finally to haul itself into the black grows ever more distant. Famed Wall Street analyst, Mary Meeker, predicts losses of $96m (£60m) this quarter and $83m (£51.8m) next, and the firm sacked 150 people in January, its first redundancies. This is a crunch time, and not just for Amazon: many dot.com stocks are already in freefall, and if the industry megalith hits trouble, many others will surely follow. The fate of a lot of paper fortunes will turn on what happens to Bezos next.

Until the beginning of this year, the Amazon story had almost seemed too good to be true. The deification of Bezos - America's second-richest man under 40, with an estimated net worth of $4bn (£2.5m) prior to last Friday - reached its high point at the end of 1999, when the Princeton graduate and self-confessed geek was selected as Time magazine's person of the year, an award previously given to Martin Luther King and the Queen. Bezos, to his credit, downplays the hero-worship. "Sometimes I think Time magazine chooses somebody and really chooses that person, and sometimes I think it is really choosing somebody as a symbol for something much bigger," he says, "and I would claim that's what it was in my case. They were not choosing me as much as they were choosing the internet and me as a symbol of e-commerce."

Amazon has certainly symbolised the radical - many would say foolhardy - techniques of business development that have come to rule cyberspace. Its strategy of putting market share ahead of profits and taking on established offline players has entered the business lexicon: today, people use "being Amazoned" to refer to the fate of a company that is about to lose out to a younger, nimbler rival. Bezos's obsession with his company is key to the success of this approach: "I know a lot about e-commerce," he says, "but it's because I think about it all the time. I'm constantly thinking about Amazon.com, e-commerce and the internet. It's in my every waking moment and most of my sleeping ones." Bezos dismisses criticism of the notion of investment in future business to the exclusion of present-day profits. "The internet truly is a big deal so it hasn't been over-hyped in that sense," he says. "It will probably be a bigger deal than anyone realises. Long term, there is an irrational under-exuberance."

It all began for Bezos when he was working as a technical expert for DE Shaw, a Manhattan hedge fund. His wake-up call, as he describes it, occurred when he read that use of the web was growing at a remarkable 2,000% a year. Within a few months, he had packed in his day job and left New York with his wife, MacKenzie, and their dog. His adoptive father, a Cuban native who married Jeff's mother when he was four, gave him a car and invested a total of $300,000 of his retirement money in the new venture. Jeff and MacKenzie, a writer, drove the car for five days across the country to Seattle, spending their first night at a motel and the second camping beside the Grand Canyon. He typed a business plan while his wife drove. "I knew it wasn't likely to work," he says, when asked if he ever doubted the wisdom of his venture. "The doubts are when you think it might work." And he laughs uproariously again.

When Bezos talks about the early days - when he worked out of the converted garage of his new home with the company's first two employees - he sounds supremely happy. He once described his decision to give up a well-paid day job to start something which could easily have failed as part of the "regret minimisation framework". He did not want to look back and regret taking the easy way out. "Most regrets are acts of omission, not commission," he says. "Right now, I am very happy. I know that I will have absolutely no regrets about being focused on Amazon.com."

Much of this early down- home atmosphere remains at Amazon's shabby Seattle offices. The Friday parties are just one aspect of this; to save on overpriced office furniture, the standard company desk still consists of a pine door, purchased from a DIY store and propped up on four pieces of timber. As in many other internet firms, employees are partly remunerated in company stock, giving them something of Bezos's sense of ownership - or, according to a more pessimistic reading, buying them off with paper money that, on a day like last Friday, can begin to look decidedly like Monopoly cash.

But Amazon's finances have also raised eyebrows in far more fundamental ways. The company insists that the money flowing into it is being invested in its infrastructure. But US newspaper investigations reveal that the company is carrying more than $2.1bn of junk-bonds debts, supported by only $25.6m (£16m) of equity - and that around 20% of the company's assets consist of balance-sheet "goodwill", sums that emerge when a company acquires another company for more than it is worth, writing off the difference against earnings. Far from being ploughed back into the business, critics point out, hundreds of millions of dollars of income is being used simply to service the company's enormous debts, frittering away an average of $10m (£6.25) each month. And margins don't look like improving: any company, given an adequate marketing budget, can set up as a putative rival to Amazon simply by undercutting its prices. Such rivals make huge losses in the process, but given that huge losses are something of a status symbol in the online economy, this isn't necessarily an insurmountable obstacle.

Time magazine describes Bezos as a visionary, a man who saw the future five years before the rest of us did. So great is his reputation that one analyst warned me not to waste our interview asking him about finances because "he has so much else to offer". Bezos is keen to exploit this reputation to keep his investors on side and focused on the future. "What you see today and what you think of as e-commerce is so primitive," he says. "Computers are not always on; people don't even have them in their kitchen or bedroom." He cheerfully imagines a day when the ubiquity of computers means that we will be ordering everything we need, not just books, or CDs, or pets, from Amazon.

In the interim, Bezos insists the company has no plans to fire any more people to cut costs this year. It may slow down its rate of acquisitions, he says, because it finds little of interest in the etailers that are in dire straits. "In most cases, unfortunately, we're not interested because it's a question of what would we be getting. We have great technology and a great brand name." But amid the confidence and laughter, Bezos sounds an almost unwitting note of warning. Talking of how he never expected to really make a go of Amazon.com in those early years as he drove across America, he says: "Most start-up companies do fail, but most fail slowly. It takes six or seven years for them to fail, usually." As Amazon's fifth anniversary rolls around, Bezos may be wishing he hadn't said that.

 Amazon.com

fields.headline: Granada knives out for ITV
fields.standfirst: Charles Allen prefers carve-up of independent network to hostile bid for rival
fields.trailText: Granada Media yesterday offered the clearest signal yet that it would prefer to negotiate a carve-up of the ITV network to making a hostile bid for one of its two main rivals.
fields.body:
Granada Media yesterday offered the clearest signal yet that it would prefer to negotiate a carve-up of the ITV network to making a hostile bid for one of its two main rivals.

Charles Allen, executive chairman of Granada Media which is due for a stock market flotation next month, said a more practical solution to the structural issues facing ITV would be an "agreed deal" between the three dominant players.

That appeared to be a softening of Granada's stance since it announced plans in January to bid for either United News & Media or Carlton Communications and break up their agreed £8bn merger.

Mr Allen predicted there would be a single ITV company within two to three years.

He said Granada remained serious about a bid for either company once the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, gives his judgment on the consolidation of ITV next month.

But he added: "If the rules don't allow us all to do what we want, then to purchase key assets [from Carlton/United] is maybe something that would tempt us. Not crumbs from the table but key assets. The next step for ITV is two strong players able to invest and drive the network forward."

Under existing legislation, no single company can have more than 15% of audience share, which is likely to impose conditions on any combination.

Mr Allen added a note of caution, however, saying he was not optimistic about the chances of a rapprochement between himself and his opposite numbers, Lord Hollick at United and Michael Green of Carlton. "The most likely outcome is that we will have to make a move because of the egos in this business, even though the best outcome would be to agree a well-balanced ITV."

Granada intends to raise £1.2bn-£1.5bn to add to its warchest, through flotation of up to 20% of the company. The media division will ultimately be fully demerged from Granada's hospitality business following the latter unit's merger with Compass.

The price range for the flotation has been set at between 465p and 525p a share, giving the company a value of £6.8bn-£7.8bn. Conditional trading in the shares is due to begin on July 11.

Mr Allen reiterated his ambition for Granada to be at the helm of a single ITV company which he said would generate revenues of £2bn and achieve savings of up to £120m by reducing areas of overlap including advertising sales and transmission.

Granada Media, which already has an audience share of around 11.2%, would find it difficult to swallow one of its rivals whole.

It owns the Yorkshire, Tyne-Tees, LWT and Granada franchises as well its stake in GMTV and cable channel Granada Plus. Carlton, which owns Central and West Country as well as its London franchise, has 8.8% of viewing and United - with Anglia, Meridian, HTV and a stake in Channel 5 - has 9.2%.

Mr Allen said that if the company emerged from the present struggle as the less dominant player it would turn its attention to acquisitions in Europe.

ONdigital, Granada and Carlton's pay-television business, remains on course for flotation in the next 12-18 months and is targeted to break even with 2m subscribers in 2002.

webTitle: Why women's cricket needs Annamania of its own

fields.headline: Why women's cricket needs Annamania of its own
fields.trailText: Guess who dominated the BBC's highlights of the first day at Wimbledon? And whose photograph was on the front of The Times yesterday - and The Daily Telegraph and the G2 section of the Guardian last Friday - before she had even stepped into SW19?
fields.body:
Guess who dominated the BBC's highlights of the first day at Wimbledon? And whose photograph was on the front of The Times yesterday - and The Daily Telegraph and the G2 section of the Guardian last Friday - before she had even stepped into SW19?

Yes, she's back in town. The Russian sensation, the blonde bombshell, the teen dream, the tabloid darling - Anna Cor-nikova. The world's 17th-best female tennis player, but the world's No.1 pheromone phenomenon.

This is a woman who last year earned £286,360 in prize-money but seven million dollars in sponsorship - more than any other tennis player bar Andre Agassi. In Britain's cities, 20ft-high posters of Anna in her Berlei bra have sprouted up and if you open your newspaper you catch Anna in Athena-poster-style bottom-scratching mode, advertising sportinglife.com.

Kournikova is a very beautiful woman and a pretty hot tennis player. But there's the rub: pretty hot isn't world beating. She is yet to win a Grand Slam singles title.

Deeply irritating as it must be for other better, but less-photogenic female players, there is little doubt that Kournikova has given women's tennis a massive boost since she first appeared five years ago. Sponsors, photographers, writers, commentators and crowds drool over her. Men come to see her and, almost by default, watch women play sport. Kournikova has kick-started interest in a game which 15 years ago was seen as dull and plodding, despite Martina Navratilova's status as one of the most gifted athletes of the twentieth century. (She wasn't a babe, you see.)

Kournikova, and to some extent women's tennis, have made an uneasy pact with the devil. If you flirt with the media you seem to have to accept horrible knicker shots, endless speculation about your love life and intrusive questioning. It also means that other players, whose talents lie purely on the court rather than the catwalk, have to suffer cruel comparisons and snide remarks.

But on the other hand David Beckham, Ryan Giggs and the Liverpool Spice Boys helped attract women to football, which is widely acknowledged to be a Good Thing. And Kournikova seems to positively revel in all the attention.

So perhaps this is what the England women's cricket team needs. There has never been a female cricketing pin-up. Not that England's women are or have been unattractive, just that the sport is in the doldrums and you would need someone of Kournikova's hand-jerk sensuality to make the grade, or the page.

Zoe Goss, the Australian allrounder tried it. She posed naked (but for her strategically placed hands) on a bed of cricket balls for Total Sport magazine. As a result, she was said to have been shunned by her peers and soon found herself out of the side.

You can understand her team-mates' frustration. Why should a female cricketer have to take her clothes off to make the headlines? The Australian team were great, but only when one of them posed naked did they gain international headlines.

Should sportswomen, and men, be judged on their looks? Of course not. But, as all that research showing that babies respond more positively to a conventionally beautiful face than an ugly one proves, the human race is aesthetically driven. From the cradle to the grave we are drawn to beautiful things.

Just imagine the crowds at Taunton on Wednesday, for the fourth one-day international against South Africa, if Anna turned out in perfectly fitting cricket whites, tossing that long blonde plait. More media coverage: yes. More spectators: yes. More sponsorship: yes, yes, yes. And English cricket might even make the front page.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. Click here for the previous Women's Page, on the England fast bowler with an MBE, Clare Taylor

webTitle: UN to sack its general in Sierra Leone

fields.headline: UN to sack its general in Sierra Leone
fields.standfirst:
Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: The head of the United Nations peacekeepers in Sierra Leone is to be replaced after the collapse of public confidence in his force. Senior officials are trying to put the blame on a UN press officer for the popular scorn directed at their operation.
fields.body:
The head of the United Nations peacekeepers in Sierra Leone is to be replaced after the collapse of public confidence in his force. Senior officials are trying to put the blame on a UN press officer for the popular scorn directed at their operation.

UN sources say the secretary general, Kofi Annan, is seeking to remove Major-General Vijay Jetley to try to restore credibility after hundreds of UN troops surrendered to rebels in recent weeks. They handed over quantities of weapons, including armoured cars, which were subsequently used to attack government forces.

New York is also concerned that Gen Jetley is allowing UN policy in Sierra Leone to be held hostage to the fate of 21 Indian peacekeepers in rebel captivity, similar to the earlier abductions that paralysed the UN in Freetown, the capital.

Sierra Leone's press ridicules the peacekeepers as cowards and questions what use they are. A popular column in one daily, For Di People, satirises Gen Jetley as General Tetley and his men as grazing water buffalo oblivious to what is going on around them.

The UN secretary general's special representative in Freetown, Oluyemi Adeniji, called a press conference last week to denounce the local press coverage. The move backfired when Mr Adeniji described the UN as the "victim" of the conflict in Sierra Leone and said it lacked the power to protect the people. This instantly raised the question of why the UN force was there.

Mr Adeniji is also at the forefront of a controversial attempt to defend his and Gen Jetley's leadership: a confidential report to UN headquarters in New York blames a press officer for the loss of faith in the UN among local people.

The accusation stems from a dramatic incident in early May when Phillip Winslow, then spokesman for the UN mission in Freetown, announced that two large columns of rebel fighters were bearing down on the capital.

This created considerable alarm in the city and helped to prod the British government into sending troops to Sierra Leone.

The report was incorrect. The rebels had attacked a small town about 25 miles from Freetown, but not in the numbers claimed nor with the intent of taking the capital. The next day the UN admitted to its "rather serious error".

Though said not to get along, Gen Jetley and Mr Adeniji joined forces to blame Mr Winslow for the debacle, saying that he overreacted to unverified reports and spoke without permission. Neither statement is correct.

The fiasco was set in motion by fleeing peacekeepers who grossly overestimated the size of the rebel attack, claiming "two or three groups of a couple of hundred fighters each" were on route to the capital.

After receiving the report, Gen Jetley phoned President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah and then the British high commissioner and the American ambassador to warn them. Then the general told Mr Winslow to make the announcement that a large rebel attack on Freetown was imminent.

The force's credibility was already damaged after nearly 500 UN troops surrendered without a struggle to rebels, including about 200 Zambians who capitulated to 21 rebels.

But replacing Gen Jetley is proving contentious. He is a two-star general. The Indian government is insisting that he be replaced with another of its nationals and, to save face, a three-star general. But Nigeria, which is expected to provide the largest contingent of troops for the bolstered UN force, is also pressing to lead.

None of this will do much to restore Sierra Leoneans' faith in UN peacekeeping.

webTitle: How to become Dion Dublin in five easy steps

fields.headline: How to become Dion Dublin in five easy steps
fields.trailText: Quiet journalists; the new Alan McInally; a tired and emotional Karel Poborsky.
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"For me, Figo is simply the best player in the world at the moment. Figo has more influence on his team than Zidane and is also more effective in front of goal" - A timely boost for the Portuguese before tomorrow's semi-final comes from, er, Frank Leboeuf.

THE EURO-TORIAL

There's a whole day to go until we see any more football at Euro 2000, so there's no real wonder that this morning's papers are at something of a loss as to what to talk about. Almost in unison they cast an eye over the four semi-finalists and draw conclusions as to the future progress of the England side. You might have thought that 30,000,000 words on the topic last week was enough, but there you go.

The main conclusions drawn by Fleet Street's finest revolve around the shared "fluidity" of the four remaining teams. The Telegraph's Henry Winter observes that "versatility is the key with the Dutch" while a headline in the Independent reads: "France's fluidity emphasises size of Keegan's task". Even Big Ron, writing in the Guardian, would like to form a free-roaming midfield of Paul Scholes, David Beckham, Kieron Dyer and Steve McManaman and tell them: "There's a football. Just go out and kick it between you."

But wasn't that what Kevin Keegan was telling his players only last week? Obviously, players with something approaching close control in the middle of the park would be a bonus, but simply picking your most creative players does not a tactical leap make.

For example: Paul Bosvelt, the Dutch right back, is not the most technically gifted of players (just ask Denis Irwin) but he dominated the entire right flank on Sunday by knowing when and where to attack, and when to stand off. Gary Neville has played for one of the best sides in Europe for over five years, but showed neither Bosvelt's initiative nor his common sense. How much of this is down to Keegan, and how much to the player we cannot say - but it's worrying all the same. The Euro says: "There's a book of tactical instruction. Go out and read it between you."

FIVE STEPS TO DION DUBLIN

While viewing figures suggest that couch potatoes have been sticking with the BBC during Euro 2000 - the England Germany game saw Gary beat Des by 2-1 - there is a real cause for concern. That cause is, of course, the metal horn-blowing Dion Dublin.

Drafted in at the start of the tournament, Dion has single-handedly lowered the level of punditry to McInally-ian depths. Here, the Euro brings you five ways in which you can emulate the Aston Villa striker:

1. Offer very little insight into matches

2. Talk instead about how confident the lads are

3. Repeat what Mark Lawrenson said just a couple of seconds ago

4. Laugh at viewers when they dare to suggest that Paul Ince isn't that good

5. Wear the same blue shirt every day

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM BREATHE.COM

Euro 2000. Big screen sport action. In a pub. With your mates. Win a £200 tab behind the bar at Yates's Pubs all around the country....go to www.breathe.com, click on the Euro 2000 link and enter the draw.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

The German FA (DFB) have denied they have appointed Bayer Leverkusen's Christoph Daum as the new national team coach. "A decision has not yet been made," DFB spokesman Wolfgang Niersbach said today. "There has not yet even been an official meeting with Daum," he went on. Wolfgang went on to claim that he didn't know who Daum was, how you spelt Daum, or that Daum was even a word in the German language. The press then left him alone.

Italy are still waiting on the fitness of captain Paolo Maldini ahead of tomorrow's semi-final encounter with Holland. Maldini has a strained thigh (ie: all the water has been removed from it) and his absence could force a tactical change on coach Dino Zoff. "I want to verify the situation of Maldini to see if he can recover for the semi-final. If he can't then I will change the situation," Zoff said, adding that this would involve the right people, right time, just the wrong location.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hey guysh, it'sh Karel Pob...pob...poborshky here! I've been having it large with the guysh for the lasht 24 hoursh and I'm feeling a little, a little... excushe me... blooaarrgggghhh!... that'sh better... I'm jusht going to have little sleep...

Zzzzz... Christian Ziege has announced he is to stay at Middlesbrough. "I haven't spoken with anybody about a move - nor do I want to," said the German wing-back before turning into a beautiful butterfly and taking wing into the bright bright sun... Zzzzz

Zzzzz... Slovenian star Zlatko Zahovic has been tipped to move from Olympiakos to Bundesliga side Munich 1860. The middling German side believe they will beat Fiorentina to Zahovic's signature and partner him with new signing Erik Mykland of Norway. I can smell cheesy jelly... Zzzzz

Zzzzz... Australian striker Mark Viduka has agreed terms with Leeds United. He will complete his move from Celtic on his return from Japan, the land of swirly dragons and flying noodles... Zzzzz

Uh! Whassatt? I musht have drifted off! And who'sh painted "plonker" on my forehead in Dairylea? Thoshe guysh...

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

British Eurosport: Euro 2000 Football (9.30am)
It's on now. You just might catch it.

The Spirit of Euro 2000 (10.15pm)
A whole hour about the making of Claymore Crag, the official Uefa whisky, aged for 8 months and specially blended to make you violent.

Euro 2000 Nightclub (11.15pm)
Recreate the feeling of a real club in your own home by filling your bathroom sink with vomit and inviting an aggressive hoodlum in from the street to kick your face through.

Euro 2000 By Night (12midnight)
Watch out - this is a con. All they've done is turn the cameras off.

fields.headline: Britain 'could have saved Italian Jews'
fields.trailText:
British intelligence knew in advance about the Nazis'
1943 plan to deport Italian Jews to Auschwitz and
Winston Churchill's government could have prevented
their deaths, according to US documents declassified
yesterday.
fields.body:
British intelligence knew in advance about the Nazis' 1943 plan to deport Italian Jews to Auschwitz and Winston Churchill's government could have prevented their deaths, according to US documents declassified yesterday.

The British knew the day-to-day plans of the SS and German intelligence from radio intercepts deciphered by experts at the decoding centre, Bletchley Park. US historians who have studied the newly available documents said it was clear that the fate of the Jews was not a high priority for MI6 or the British government, and nothing was said.

The documents largely refer to intelligence that MI6 shared with their American counterparts in the OSS, the precursor to the CIA, and are likely to fuel the emotive debate about how much Britain, the US and their allies could have done to stop the Holocaust.

The British government approved their publication yesterday, but has declined to release British archives that would throw more light on the wartime thinking and decision-making about Europe's Jews and the Holocaust.

Timothy Naftali, an expert on intelligence history, said British intelligence knew about the plan to deport the 8,000 Jews in Rome to Auschwitz about five days before they were rounded up.

"A statement by Churchill or Roosevelt, carefully camouflaging the form of the information received, might well have led the Jews in Rome to take seriously the rumours that actually existed," Mr Naftali said. "These people could have found a way to get out. At least they should have been given a chance."

The key document is an intercept of a message from German headquarters in Rome to Berlin on October 6 1943 saying: "Orders have been received from Berlin by Obersturmbannfuhrer Kappler to seize and to take to northern Italy the 8,000 Jews living in Rome. They are to be liquidated."

Kappler was the German police attache in Rome which was by then under Nazi occu pation. The message was intercepted and sent to Bletchley, but it is unclear what happened next. According to Mr Naftali, who has studied US-British intelligence cooperation in the war, intercepts normally took no more than five days to decipher and translate.

They were then sent to MI6 counter-intelligence headquarters in Mayfair, and handed to Richard Brooman White, head of the Italian desk.

Mr Naftali said the news of the Nazi plans for Rome's Jews would certainly have been circulated in Whitehall by October 11. It would also have been passed to the Americans through Andrew Berding, an OSS liaison officer in London. But neither London nor Washington acted on the information, and the Jews were never told of what was in store for them. They were rounded up on October 16 and about 1,000 later died in Auschwitz.

"In 1943 the Jewish question was not foremost in the minds of the people who saw this material," Mr Naftali said. "It seemed to have no link to winning the war. There was a tendency among some in the British government and to a lesser extent in the US government to view information about the treatment of the Jews as exaggerated."

A vivid illustration of this lack of concern was a note sent in 1942 to a subordinate by Sir Stewart Menzies, who was then "C" - the head of MI6 - about what to do with the information about the Holocaust.

"I should be grateful if you could arrange for a dossier to be made of all police messages received to date which contain evidence on this subject and send it to me for the Foreign Office. This work need not, of course, be given high priority," the note reads.

Washington had access to the same intelligence, and showed a similar lack of concern. Furthermore, British intelligence failed to make the most of its huge archive on the Holocaust available to the Nuremberg war crimes tribunal after the war.

Eli Rosenbaum, the director of the US justice department office of special investigations, which is studying Nazi war crimes, said a number of Nazi officials could have been prosecuted on the strength of the MI6 intercepts. In particular, the archive points to the role played by Karl Wolff, the SS chief in Italy, who remained at large for at least 20 years after the war.

"This does raise important and difficult questions about allied conduct after receiving this intercepted information," Mr Rosenbaum said.

The British also had a unique insight into attitudes and knowledge about the Holocaust within the German military, from bugging the cells of its prisoners of war.

The transcripts form a key part of the archive released yesterday. One prison-cell conversation between Major General Von Felbert and Lieutenant General Kittel concerned a massacre of hundreds of Jews in near Dvinsk in Latvia by German and Latvian SS troops.

"Men, women and children," Kittel said, "were counted off and stripped naked; the executioners first laid all the clothes in one pile. Then 20 women had to take up their position - naked - on the edge of the trench, they were shot and fell down into it ... They seized three-year-old children by the hair, held them up and shot them with a pistol and then threw them in. I saw that for myself."

Kittel then mused: "If one were to destroy all the Jews of the world simultaneously there wouldn't remain a single accuser."

Felbert, clearly shocked, replied: "It doesn't need to be a Jew to accuse us - we ourselves must bring the charge; we must accuse the people who have done it."

fields.headline: Mugabe party wins election
fields.trailText: President Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party won an outright majority in Zimbabwe's elections, fighting off a strong challenge by the main opposition party, according to results released early today.
fields.body:
President Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party won an outright majority in Zimbabwe's elections, fighting off a strong challenge by the main opposition party, according to results released early today.

With results in 100 of 120 parliamentary districts announced, the main opposition Movement for Democratic Change had won 48 seats and the ruling party 51, in the country's most hotly contested parliamentary election since independence 20 years ago, officials said. A small independent party won one seat.

Such a closely contested race is unprecedented in a country where President Mugabe's party has ruled virtually unchallenged since 1980. The opposition held only three seats in the previous parliament.

The MDC won up to 85% of the vote in some urban areas, but the ruling party scored strongly in rural areas, where pre-election intimidation on behalf of Mr Mugabe's party was strongest. The MDC would have 76 of the 120 elected seats to take control of the 150-member parliament. The remaining 30 seats are appointed directly by Mr Mugabe, who has two years of his presidency left to serve.

The parliamentary election came after months of campaign-related violence and unrest over the takeovers of hundreds of white-owned farms by armed black squatters. Opposition members said the takeovers were sanctioned by Mr Mugabe's government. Some accused the government of encouraging the takeovers to build its support among landless black people before the vote.

After early results were announced on national television, some MDC supporters drove through the streets of Harare honking their horns. They gave the open hand salute of the party and shouted the MDC slogan: "Change!" But MDC officials also said the results showed that government intimidation had worked in some rural areas. David Coltart, the MDC legal adviser who won a seat in the election, said the opposition planned to challenge some of the results in court.

"In many of these constituencies, they have only won through intimidation," Mr Coltart said. The opposition performed well in urban areas, as expected, but also won seats in Mr Mugabe's rural strongholds.

Several cabinet ministers and senior officials of the ruling party lost their seats. The MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, failed to win a seat.

Justice minister Emmerson Mnangagwa was crushed nearly two to one in his rural district by an opponent who had fled the district and gone into hiding after being attacked by ruling party militants. Mr Mnangagwa has been considered a possible successor to President Mugabe. Home affairs minister Dumiso Dabengwa received less than 4,000 of the more than 24,000 votes cast in his district in the southwestern city of Bulawayo.

With Zimbabwe's economy in shambles, the opposition party posed the strongest challenge to Mr Mugabe's party since it led the country to independence from white-minority rule 20 years ago.

The large turnout, estimated in excess of 3m of the 5.1m registered voters, overwhelmed counting stations, leading to delays in confirming results.

The turnout "was just too large ... more than twice as much as ever before," said Tobaiwa Mudede, the state registrar general.

International observers from the European Union said the campaign had been badly tainted by violence and could not be considered free and fair. At least 30 people were killed ahead of the vote, and thousands were beaten and threatened, mainly by ruling party militants.

Leaders in Mr Mugabe's party "seemed to sanction the use of violence and intimidation against political opponents and contributed significantly to the climate of fear so evident during the election campaign," the EU said. Opposition supporters also waged attacks, but they were far fewer and their leaders were clear in their condemnation of the violence, observers said. Meanwhile, police were being deployed throughout the country to prevent any violence between the rival parties. Riot police were sent to the southwestern Harare suburb of Budiriro, the scene of repeated clashes in previous weeks between ruling party militants and opposition supporters. There were no reports of any clashes, and police appealed for calm.

"Those who win must be graceful and not target losers. Those who lose must accept losing with honour," police commissioner Augustine Chihuri said in a nationwide broadcast.

In the months leading up to the election, armed ruling party militants occupied hundreds of white-owned farms, demanding they be divided up and given to landless blacks.

Opposition candidate Roy Bennett, a white farmer who temporarily had to flee his property after it was overrun by ruling party militants, won a strong victory in his Chimanimani district near the Mozambican border.

webTitle: Senators hostile to Brussels aid campaign for US trade link

fields.headline: Senators hostile to Brussels aid campaign for US trade link
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The unofficial Conservative campaign to draw Britain away from the European Union and into the economic orbit of the United States will this week see four Republican senators arrive in London to make the case for British membership of Nafta, the North American Free Trade Area.
fields.body:
The unofficial Conservative campaign to draw Britain away from the European Union and into the economic orbit of the United States will this week see four Republican senators arrive in London to make the case for British membership of Nafta, the North American Free Trade Area.

To the astonishment of Whitehall officials and the delight of election planners at Labour HQ in Millbank, senator Phil Gramm, the combative Texan chairman of the senate's powerful banking committee, will deliver a speech implicitly making the case for a UK-Nafta link in London on Tuesday. Symbolically that is Independence Day, the 4th of July.

Under current EU rules such a move would effectively force Britain to choose between the EU and the US, though Tories loyal to William Hague's "in Europe, but not run by Europe" policy insist they can do both. Some secretly hope otherwise as part of their drive to quit the EU.

Mr Gramm and his three senate colleagues, Jim Bunning and Mike Crapo, both members of the Republican-controlled banking committee, plus senator Jeff Sessions, are also seeking meetings with government ministers and officials after they arrive on Thursday.

Last night the Tory defence spokesman, Iain Duncan-Smith, a Thatcherite Euro-sceptic who seeks closer ties with Nafta, said that the unofficial US delegation "shows it is becoming quite a serious issue".

Senator Gramm, who defected from the Democrats in the Reagan era, has long voiced hostility to protectionist aspects of EU trade policy - a view reciprocated in Brussels. He complains that the EU's insistence since its inception on negotiating trade matters collectively restricts the freedom of member states to do their own bilateral trade deals. That is unlike Nafta which includes both Canada and Mexico, which has its own trade arrangements with Brussels. One important advocate of Britain leaving Europe and joining Nafta is Conrad Black, the Canadian owner of the Eurosceptic Telegraph newspaper group.

In Washington last night the banking committee's spokesman said that Mr Gramm will be addressing the Centre for Policy Studies, a Tory think tank, on the need for more free trade in goods and financial services. "He thinks it's a good idea," she said. The White House has supported British EU membership for 40 years, but the mood in Washington is changing. Mr Gramm's spokesman said that UK membership of Nafta would be "a first step to building a bridge between North America and Europe".
