fields.headline: The best translation scene
fields.body:
Lt Andrew Tyler (Matthew McCon-aughey), Chief Klough (Harvey Keitel) and their crew have taken over a German submarine. Its original crew have been taken prisoner. Unfortunately, however, they now have to sail it, and only one crew member, Wentz (Jack Noseworthy), can speak German.

Tyler anxiously scans the deck.

"Everything's in German."

Tyler, Klough and the crew move from one piece of equipment to another.

"Activate the torpedoes?" commands Tyler, more in hope than expectation.

"What about these?" asks Klough, pointing at a set of cogs.

"I don't know", Wentz replies. "There's no label."

He glances over at the cogs.

"OK, those are the off-valves, these are the mid-ship vents, and these are the main duction valves."

Tyler strides over to the tannoy system.

"Tank, Tank, I need speed! The lights are on, so there's got to be some power left in these batteries."

Cut to the torpedo room. Tank (Dave Power) receives Tyler's message.

"I can't read anything."

"OK, find out how many fish are left in these tanks and figure out how to launch them."

Meanwhile, Klough and Wentz are trying to get the sub moving. They peer at a series of switches.

"Klar, klar, klar!" exclaims Klough. "What the hell does klar mean?"

"Klar means clear. All compartments secure."

"White for green?"

"White for green."

Finally, the sub begins to dive below the surface.

See also: The Usual Suspects, The Godfather II, Midnight Express

Don't see also: Police Academy 4 - Citizens On Patrol

Pointless trivia: Jack Nose-worthy's screen debut came in the video for the Bon Jovi single Always.

webTitle: Elian case goes to final appeal

fields.headline: Elian case goes to final appeal
fields.standfirst: The Elian Gonzalez case: special report
fields.trailText: Elian Gonzalez's Miami relatives asked the US supreme court yesterday to block the six-year-old boy's return to Cuba. Unless it agrees, Juan Miguel Gonzalez will be free to take his son home tomorrow, when a federal appeal court order lapses.
fields.body:
Elian Gonzalez's Miami relatives asked the US supreme court yesterday to block the six-year-old boy's return to Cuba. Unless it agrees, Juan Miguel Gonzalez will be free to take his son home tomorrow, when a federal appeal court order lapses.

The relatives' lawyers lodged a formal supreme court appeal and asked Justice Anthony Kennedy, who handles emergency matters from Florida for the court, to keep Elian in the US until the case is heard.

A few weeks more delay would be a minimal cost in a case with such high stakes, they told the judge.

Elian was rescued off the Florida coast in November after his mother and 10 other people drowned when their boat sank on its way from Cuba to the US.

The appeal says the legal issues "boil down to a single straightforward question: can the [US immigration and naturalisation service] deprive an alien child of his statutory and constitutional right to apply for asylum without conducting any hearing of any kind - or even without interviewing the child himself?"

fields.headline: Mugabe suffers backlash at polls
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party was struggling neck and neck with the opposition Movement for Democratic Change last night after just over half the results were declared in last weekend's general election. By midnight, Zanu-PF had won 32 of the 62 seats spanning a broad range of constituencies, both rural and urban.
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party was struggling neck and neck with the opposition Movement for Democratic Change last night after just over half the results were declared in last weekend's general election. By midnight, Zanu-PF had won 32 of the 62 seats spanning a broad range of constituencies, both rural and urban.

The turnout, at 65%, was the highest for 20 years. During the evening police set up roadblocks in Harare to prevent clashes between supporters of the rival groups. Zanu-PF has dominated Zimbabwean politics since independence in 1980, and the loss of its overwhelming control of parliament to a new movement less than a year old was a severe setback.

Mr Mugabe had tried to make the unequal share of land between white and black farmers into the main campaign issue but a sizeable proportion of voters, angry over unemployment, high inflation and government corruption, a majority of voters responded to the MDC's slogan of change.

They were not convinced by Mr Mugabe's claim that the MDC was a stooge of Britain and a puppet of white commercial interests.

In one of the more notable results, Roy Bennett, a white farmer whose farmworkers chased away a group of pro-Zanu-PF war veterans occupying his land, won a seat for the MDC. In Bulawayo North East, Welshman Ncube, the MDC's secretary general, took a stunning 85% of the vote.

But in a sign that intimidation can work, the ruling party won easily in rural Murehwa North, where gangs had beaten up hundreds of voters.

Early results put the MDC in the lead and if it were to emerge with a a majority of the 120 seats being contested it would not require Mr Mugabe to stand down. As president his term lasts until 2002. He also has the right to appoint 30 additional seats.

The first three seats announced were all from around Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second city, and were all won by the MDC. But the next 10 seats declared included rural constituencies, which Zanu-PF had tried hard to win. The MDC won five of them.

"Those who have lost should not let their disappointment turn into anger and violence," he said. The winners should "share their victory with those who have lost". Earlier, there were fears that voters would become frustrated by the delay in the count and turn violent. "The turnout is just too large, overwhelming, twice as much as we have experienced," said Tobaiwa Mudede, the registrar general.

Officials were still verifying the ballots by checking the total against the number of counterfoils to ensure there had been no stuffing of the boxes or removal of papers. Zanu-PF ministers yesterday backed away from statements on Sunday by John Nkomo, the party chairman, that Mr Mugabe would not appoint the opposition to form a government even if it won a parliamentary majority.

"His remarks will be misinterpreted by many people," Nathan Shamuyarira, the minister for industry and commerce, said. "The result shapes the way the president is going to run the government. Whatever cabinet he comes up with, parliament can block legislation. You want the support of parliament."

But ministers rejected the accusations. "There was more violence in the run-up to voting in South Africa and East Timor last year, yet the polls were described as free and fair," Mr Shamuyarira said.

fields.headline: Whose film is it anyway?
fields.standfirst: Chicken Run was made in Bristol, so how come US audiences get to see it first?  Andrew Pulver  on a box-office anomaly
fields.trailText: Chicken Run was made in Bristol, so how come US audiences get to see it first? Andrew Pulver on a box-office anomaly
fields.body:
British films, it seems, are like British actresses of the Catherine Zeta Jones variety: they have to do well in the US before they're fully appreciated back home. The latest evidence? The most homespun of movies, Chicken Run, has already been released in the US to a massive $17.5m opening weekend take - a full week before British cinema-goers get to see it. Produced by the Aardman studio in Bristol - which, in Wallace and Gromit, has already invented national icons as comforting as tea cosies and woolly mufflers - Chicken Run taps into a similar vein of misty eyed nostalgia, being a sort of barnyard version of The Great Escape.

Chicken Run, you might have imagined, is the perfect movie for Britain's increasingly beleaguered film industry to crow about. Especially as it comes hard on the heels of U-571, the submarine movie that is a particularly outrageous example of Hollywood rewriting history. Hackles will no doubt be rising among the overly patriotic - first they nick our espionage exploits, now they're nicking our lovable cartoon animals.

But the decision to prioritise Chicken Run's US box-office run is determined by one simple factor: it is not really British at all. Like the large majority of the films by which mainstream British cinema defines itself, Chicken Run is bought and paid for by a foreign company. In Chicken Run's case, it is DreamWorks SKG, the US studio operated by Steven Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen, which put up the $42m funding. It joins a long list that includes The Full Monty, Four Weddings and a Funeral, Shakespeare in Love and The English Patient. And every one of these films was released in the US before Britain.

There's no doubt that, for all these movies, their success at the US box office had a significant impact on their reception in the UK. Four Weddings, especially, a landmark success in that pre-lottery era before British cinema's insane self-delusion set in, owed plenty to its US success in whipping up enthusiasm back in the UK. The Full Monty, conversely, dribbled around America like an old-fashioned sleeper hit, while clocking up astonishing business over here. In recent months, the pattern has changed somewhat, with Elizabeth and Notting Hill (both funded by the US studio Universal, through its deal with the British company Working Title) nudging their way into Britain's cinemas before America's. And two genuinely homegrown hits, Trainspotting and Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, did impressive business in the UK many months before opening in America - to largely indifferent figures.

But the issues surrounding our national cinema remain the subject of fierce and near-permanent debate. Lots of people have pointed out that since so many films are international co-productions, it hardly matters where most of them actually come from any more. That British films won't, or can't, be launched on to British audiences is part of a wider problem, and one that is actually much more important to legions of increasingly antsy UK film audiences. Britain is still so low down the list of international release territories that, in cinema terms, it is some sort of smalltime backwater. Every major release of the summer will be released in the US first - but what's extra galling is that a film like Mission: Impossible 2 will be released in some 30 countries - including Australia, Israel, Colombia, Turkey, New Zealand, Mexico and South Africa - before the UK.

The old explanation used to be that we in this country had to make do with film prints recycled from a film's original US release, but that clearly doesn't apply to other English-speaking territories. In these days of internet-fuelled globalisation, when anyone with a modem can have instant access to every rumour of a project's production from pitch session to colour grading, Britain's lowly status has become more evident than ever.

In the old days, movies used to be sold piecemeal across the globe, thereby contributing to a patchy, random release pattern. That system, to some extent, is still in use, largely at the small-money, independent end of the market. The big movies, the event releases, have long since been absorbed into mighty international corporations, with their own distribution offices in every principal territory, with the clear directive to co-ordinate release strategy on a global scale. The rough rule of thumb, incidentally, is that the US box-office takings will equal the rest of the world combined, so the primacy of the US audience is understandable and obvious.

The big movies, too, are vehicles for whole chunks of ancillary income - merchandising, soundtracks, novelisations, websites, etc - lending more point than ever to the convergence of marketing, and the associated businesses that take care of these individual aspects. Hence the importance of a successful opening weekend, and the increasing amount of prints made up for a film's first appearance. A large chunk of Mission: Impossible 2's budget went into the 3,653 prints that ensured its monstrous $70m opening-weekend receipts. (Compare Star Wars Episode 1 - The Phantom Menace which opened on 2,970 screens for $64m.)

Complaining about the activities of such behemoth organisations is about as pointless as it gets: Britain isn't even the biggest market in Europe (we're third, after France and Germany). The marketing planners for the big movies are looking for a steamroller effect, spreading outwards from the US west coast. This delay actually suits the UK distributors just fine, as the US box office acts as a litmus test for their own product. Film distribution everywhere is a high-risk activity, and getting higher risk all the time as budget cost soar. If Titanic had gone the way of, say, Mission to Mars, it's possible that both 20th Century Fox and Paramount might no longer exist. It's an unarguable fact that there's no automatic equation between a film's quality and its box office, and that marketing campaigns simply reflect conventional wisdom about a film's monetary worth. Who would have predicted that American Beauty would do $130m in the US? Or John Travolta's Battlefield Earth, make barely $20m - on 3,000 screens.

If the situation is difficult for the big-money films, then it's positively horrific for the small-but-good sector. Britain has just got hold of Woody Allen's Sweet and Lowdown - but he has already finished another one, Small Time Crooks, which has already been released in the US. They've lapped us. In distributor's language, Allen has a "temperate" audience, which means it is unaffected by any kind of marketing hysteria: it is small but guaranteed, so there is no incentive to change it.

The only time it has deviated from this laggard schedule was when the life-imitates-art Husbands and Wives was released to capitalise on Allen's relationship difficulties - even though an earlier film, Shadows and Fog, was still unreleased. In truth, Britain's market for non-mainstream cinema is so small that independent distributors can rarely afford the prices demanded by films that have done well at the Sundance festival or wherever, and have to play a waiting game to get the price down. The delays and manoeuvres surrounding Kevin Smith's unexpectedly profitable (in the US) Miramax hit, Chasing Amy, meant that for a while it looked like it might not make it Britain at all. One Sundance winner, a film called Sunday starring David "Poirot" Suchet, never did.

In the end, it's the consumer that suffers. But while Britain remains - relatively speaking - largely uninterested in the movies, it's unlikely that the situation will change. The recent enthusiasm for UK-made films has given distributors confidence in the product; unfortunately, that enthusiasm has often proved to be sadly misplaced. Meanwhile, if you're going to Jakarta tomorrow, don't forget to pick up that Mission: Impossible 2 ticket when you get there.

webTitle: Surprise poll shows French in favour of fast EU integration

fields.headline: Surprise poll shows French in favour of fast EU integration
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Less than a week before Paris takes over the EU presidency for a six-month term meant to get some important decisions made, French leaders will take heart from a new survey showing that their once-sceptical citizens have turned into committed Europeans - and that a large majority want even faster integration.
fields.byline: Jon Henley  in Paris and John Hooper  in Berlin
fields.body:
Less than a week before Paris takes over the EU presidency for a six-month term meant to get some important decisions made, French leaders will take heart from a new survey showing that their once-sceptical citizens have turned into committed Europeans - and that a large majority want even faster integration.

"What's new here is that the French are no longer afraid of Europe," said Pascal Boniface, director of the Paris-based Institute for International and Strategic Relations, interpreting the findings of the CSA polling agency survey.

"They've made a careful, reasoned choice and have understood that it can both protect what they already have and offer them new advantages."

According to the survey, carried out for the left-leaning daily newspaper Libération and France 3 television, 59% of the French now describe themselves as "enthusiastic" or "favourable" to the European project, with 41% saying that they are "sceptical" or "opposed".

Even more revealingly, in a country that likes to see itself as a pillar of Europe but has never been altogether happy about the necessary sacrifices, fully 70% of respondents said they would like to see European integration speeded up, while only 25% wanted it slowed down.

The figures represent a remarkable shift in French public opinion. Two other surveys of similar scope in the last decade showed much more divided feelings.

In 1997, 49% of the French pronounced themselves pro-European, and 48% anti. And in 1992, just after the country had voted narrowly to ratify the Maastricht treaty on a range of integration measures, only 45% wanted faster progress towards European union.

Several factors lie behind such a marked pro-European swing, observers say. Most important, the French economy has picked up sharply in the last couple of years. Overall growth is set to clip along at 4% this year and unemployment to fall below 10%.

French confidence in the future is sky-high, and with it comes a desire for a stronger, bigger and faster-moving Europe: fully 62% of respondents to the latest survey said they wanted the EU enlarged to include the candidate members of eastern Europe, while 61% were in favour of "certain countries advancing without waiting" for others.

"The fear there once was of a loss of national identity, of being crushed by the Brussels machine - we're just no longer in that debate," Mr Boniface said. "And for the French government it's a very good thing: if it presents the people with reasonable options for further EU integration, it will have their support."

Overwhelmingly, the French people are in favour of the sweeping institutional reforms needed to propel the EU forward: 67% back qualified majority voting within the council of ministers, one of the thorniest issues on which the French presidency must try to reach agreement by December.

Other controversial measures include extending majority voting on most EU issues, redistributing the votes of member states on a weighted basis, deciding the size of the future European Commission and approving "reinforced cooperation" to let some states integrate faster.

President Jacques Chirac - now in Germany on a state visit, and under heavy pressure to match his hosts' Euro-enthusiasm - is expected today to outline a proposal for an EU constitution when he becomes the first head of state to address the German parliament in Berlin. Though he said at the weekend he believed that the EU could have its own constitution within two years, it remained unclear to what extent his vision matched Germany's emerging, increasingly federalist outlook.

The German chancellor, Helmut Schröder, injected new urgency into European affairs last week when his officials proposed a new round of inter-governmental talks on the "big issues" around 2004. His foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, earlier called on EU states to commit themselves to an eventual federation. But he argued that it should comprise, rather than replace, the existing nation states.

Comments by Mr Chirac published yesterday by the German financial daily Handelsblatt left open the question of whether he rejects or backs the Fischer approach. He said he hoped for a "united Europe of states, rather than a United States of Europe".

Speaking later in Berlin's city hall, Mr Chirac said: "Our future has to be the union of our Europe." But he cautioned: "Everyone will keep their strengths and their identities. Nations will not disappear."

webTitle: Regulation too rich for their lordships to digest

fields.headline: Regulation too rich for their lordships to digest
fields.standfirst:
Lords reform: special report
Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The day after Lord Levy hit the front pages seemed a good time to go to the first session of the Neill committee, now examining standards of conduct in the House of Lords. They want to decide if the peers require the same tough rules as the Commons.
fields.body:
The day after Lord Levy hit the front pages seemed a good time to go to the first session of the Neill committee, now examining standards of conduct in the House of Lords. They want to decide if the peers require the same tough rules as the Commons.

In the past we may not have needed this. Lord Malfeasor would no more have taken a bung than worn a ready-tied bow at dinner. But nowadays, under the popular "send money to the Labour party plus six vouchers from special crisp packets and receive a peerage" scheme, almost anyone can get in. New rules may be needed.

Though not in the view of the first witness, the former leader of the Lords Ivor Richard, a man so grand and self-assured that he makes Roy Jenkins seem like Frank Spencer.

As does his spiritual leader, Lord Richard engages in his own distinctive gestures. Whereas Lord Jenkins cups the breast of a plump young peasant girl, Lord Richard's hands flop majestically from side to side, as if conducting a very slow band, or chastising a naughty fish.

He has also turned vagueness into an art form. He doesn't give evidence; he muses aloud. "In terms of enforcement," he pondered, "you run into difficult waters. How do you discipline a peer? After all, what can you do to a peer?"

He was against too much paperwork, which might upset the peers. "I hope we don't go over to the House of Commons system," he offered. "I think it would be too much for their lordships to digest."

And this could be a serious problem, as you would know if you'd tried the Lords steak and kidney pudding.

In his view, the House of Commons had gone too far. "That's my gut feeling. The idea you have to declare a free air ticket if you go to a conference in Istanbul!"

Lord Richard wobbled delicately at the very thought of having to declare a free air ticket.

"I slightly reject that. I feel uncomfortable with it." (As someone of his mighty girth undoubtedly would in anything but a first-class seat, or preferably two first-class seats.)

Next up was Lord Owen. His interrogators included three peers, three knights, two privy counsellors, and a QC. It is not a riff raff- intensive committee. It would take a bold man to condescend to or patronise them, but David Owen managed it.

He even declared his own interests. "I have very large shareholdings, with a substantial amount of interest," he announced, rather in the manner of Violet Elizabeth Bott's father telling us about his wife's pearls. He too felt that regulations were a bad idea. 'They would be tiresome, irritating, and would send the wrong message." (Such as: "Don't take too many freebies from the makers of toxic chemicals.")

Then he told them with ineffable, thunderous, Owenite grandeur that he was not arguing with them. "I think you've achieved quite a lot, in a short time."

I decided that my continued presence was sending the wrong message, and repaired to the Commons, where the industry minister Patricia Hewitt was making a statement about the human genome project. Ms Hewitt always sounds as if she is telling a backward child how to put Lego together, so the effect was as if, to save money, the BBC had merged Blue Peter with the Open University, telling how you can make a nuclear reactor with empty yoghurt pots.

If I understood her, the genome project is a fantastic scientific achievement, or will be when we know what to do with it.

It is as if people had slaved for years to compile the telephone book. Now all we need is for somebody to invent the telephone.

Next: Nobel prize-winners map the molecular structure of Michael Fabricant's hair.

As does his spiritual leader, Lord Richard engages in his own distinctive gestures. Whereas Lord Jenkins cups the breast of a plump young peasant girl, Lord Richard's hands flop majestically from side to side, as if conducting a very slow band, or chastising a naughty fish. He has also turned vagueness into an art form. He doesn't give evidence; he muses aloud. "In terms of enforcement," he pondered, "you run into difficult waters. How do you discipline a peer? After all, what can you do to a peer?" He was against too much paperwork, which might upset the peers. "I hope we don't go over to the House of Commons system," he offered. "I think it would be too much for their lordships to digest." And this could be a serious problem, as you would know if you'd tried the Lords steak and kidney pudding. In his view, the House of Commons had gone too far. "That's my gut feeling. The idea you have to declare a free air ticket if you go to a conference in Istanbul!" Lord Richard wobbled delicately at the very thought of having to declare a free air ticket. "I slightly reject that. I feel uncomfortable with it." (As someone of his mighty girth undoubtedly would in anything but a first-class seat, or preferably two first-class seats.) Next up was Lord Owen. His interrogators included three peers, three knights, two privy counsellors, and a QC. It is not a riff raff- intensive committee. It would take a bold man to condescend to or patronise them, but David Owen managed it. He even declared his own interests. "I have very large shareholdings, with a substantial amount of interest," he announced, rather in the manner of Violet Elizabeth Bott's father telling us about his wife's pearls. He too felt that regulations were a bad idea. 'They would be tiresome, irritating, and would send the wrong message." (Such as: "Don't take too many freebies from the makers of toxic chemicals.") Then he told them with ineffable, thunderous, Owenite grandeur that he was not arguing with them. "I think you've achieved quite a lot, in a short time." I decided that my continued presence was sending the wrong message, and repaired to the Commons, where the industry minister Patricia Hewitt was making a statement about the human genome project. Ms Hewitt always sounds as if she is telling a backward child how to put Lego together, so the effect was as if, to save money, the BBC had merged Blue Peter with the Open University, telling how you can make a nuclear reactor with empty yoghurt pots. If I understood her, the genome project is a fantastic scientific achievement, or will be when we know what to do with it. It is as if people had slaved for years to compile the telephone book. Now all we need is for somebody to invent the telephone. Next: Nobel prize-winners map the molecular structure of Michael Fabricant's hair.

fields.headline: Ultrasoundings
fields.standfirst: NCT or not NCT
fields.trailText: NCT or not NCT
fields.body:
Week 30

Start antenatal classes. It says so in the NHS pregnancy book. If only it were that easy. Yoga is fully booked. "Too many births this month. It's because of the eclipse," says the voice at the other end. The eclipse? "We're suffering the knock-on effects," she says, solemnly. I decide not to enquire further. After all, I'm already booked into National Childbirth Trust classes. My midwife beat the rush for these by signing me up in week 10. "You won't be wanting the hospital ones," she said, glancing round at my stack of pregnancy books, my copy of the Guardian, my organic veg box.

Actually, I wasn't completely enthusiastic about the NCT. Every mother I know went to classes, mostly to make babysitting contacts, and I've heard a few horror stories about terrifying videos, or being reprimanded for falling off your bucket during squatting exercises, or threatened with expulsion for not taking cheek-stretching for men (to simulate birth pangs, you understand) with the proper gravity.

And more serious stuff, too. The NCT still has its political side. I've heard of classes that began with the teacher saying: "A quarter of you will have a caesarean and I want you to know you are giving your child a very, very bad start in life." I know women who took the whole drug-free message very seriously, then felt terrible failures when they gave in to medical help, or who put off an epidural until the last minute and then tore themselves up pushing the baby out because they couldn't feel anything, or who insisted on natural deliveries for heavy breech babies and ended up exhausted, with a caesarean and a bashed-up pelvic floor.

In my local Oxfam, I even found an original copy of the book that started the whole movement off : Sheila Kitzinger's The Experience of Childbirth (1971), which famously pictures the author laughing as she gives birth to twins. We may think she has been blessed with a wide pelvis and particularly stretchy insides: the book instead has much to say about your inner psychosexual drama and definitely implies that the inability to give birth without drugs results from Freudian causes.

On the other hand, it is from a different age. The Experience of Childbirth assumes that many "girls" giving birth were virgin brides, that they were not working, that, gloriously, their local council would send a cleaner round for a fortnight after a home birth. And, in that different age, the book and the NCT fought the good fight: against over-medicalised, paternalistic childbirth, against enemas, shaving, pethidine, paralysing painkillers, forceps, routine episiotomies and against all births happening uphill, in bed, with your feet in stirrups. I'm grateful for all this, but it does seem that, in my hospital at least, the battle has been won. There's a birthing pool, aromatherapy, beanbags and birth so active, you practically jog till you drop.

I arrive at my first NCT class, in short, suspicious and ready to strop. But our teacher turns out to be calm, knowledgeable and entirely disarming. She begins by telling us that she will show no videos and recommend no birth plans. She quotes from the Lancet rather than Sheila Kitzinger and offers enticing information about both acupuncture and the particularly skilled, light epidurals now available. There are no buckets anywhere in sight.

The class, many of whom came in with the same suspicious expressions as mine, relax. We even smile and start offering up our own experiences. The men, who arrived obviously terrified of being made to bond, address the odd remark to one another about technical matter such as TENS machines.

Our teacher gets down to the nitty-gritty: how to cope with NHS maternity wards - these have, because of cuts, deteriorated beyond recognition since 1971 - and how to get out of them quickly. Also, which were the 50 most popular children's names last year. We all spring on these over tea, murmuring: "No, we can't go for Samuel, it's as common as Joshua" and we carefully do not betray our chosen names to the other couples in case we start a trend. It's all so sensible, I begin to wonder if it can be the NCT at all.

But we have an interruption. One of the class wants to give birth live on the internet. She is wondering how she can best get the phone link and camera into the delivery room. I'm thrilled. Perhaps we are still on the cutting edge of childbirth practice after all. We chip in our own suggestions. Our teacher warns us that the hospital may be crowded. "Oh yes," we all agree. "Very. Because of the eclipse."

webTitle: Ministers back down on email 'spy charter'

fields.headline: Ministers back down on email 'spy charter'
fields.standfirst: Privacy on the net: special report
fields.trailText: The government is to back down following public uproar over a new security services legal framework, which critics claim will give British spies untrammelled access to email.
fields.body:
The government is to back down following public uproar over a new security services legal framework, which critics claim will give British spies untrammelled access to email.

Ministers will today table amendments to the regulation of investigatory powers bill making it clear that the security services will require individual warrants to gain access to email messages or transactions.

There had been widespread fears that the bill as drafted would have meant the security services merely needed to seek a general warrant for a website or internet service provider, and thereafter any detailed information gleaned from that electronic system would require no further warrant.

The amendment will be tabled in the Lords today in time for the next committee stage scrutiny of the bill.

The Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, also promised yesterday that ministers will table amendments to allay business fears about the costs to companies of complying with the bill.

He is expected to sharpen up the distinction between the revenue and capital costs of complying with the proposed new regulatory regime.

Some businesses have claimed the new regime will cost private business as much as £640m over the next five years.

Mr Clarke has also agreed to reduce requirements on business to hand over their encryption key to the security services, saying they will only be required to hand over text rather than the key itself.

fields.headline: Men, again
fields.standfirst: The north-east is failing to bolster the numbers of women active on the political scene - and evidence points to similar problems elsewhere
fields.trailText: The north-east is failing to bolster the numbers of women active on the political scene - and evidence points to similar problems elsewhere
fields.body:
In the face of "New" Labour's interest in renewing regional government, a study has dug into the structure and manning of government in the north-east and found it remains as middle-aged, middle-class and male as ever.

Men form 87% of the (non-statutory) regional assembly, 87% of the region's MPs, 77% of its elected councillors, 74% of members of housing association boards and even 66% of the regional arts council. Andy Capp may have loosened his working-class roots a little - he would probably be called Andrew today - but he still is not giving Florrie a look-in.

Grey men have always stared out of civic photographs in the region. They have now taken over supposedly new institutions such as the regional assembly. The question posed by the study is what this means for the next stage of regionalisation. It needs bubble and zip; do these men have them?

The report looks at one region, but its findings are certain to be repeated elsewhere; Yorkshire is about to commission a study of its own and the north-west is expected to follow suit. The nub is that to make a difference, an elected regional assembly would have to engage public interest and enthusiasm. And yet "government in the north-east largely denies or prevents real participation by 'ordinary people'".

Government in the English regions should be classic ground for reformers, even popular movements (the government is going to require a referendum, before it allows any region to go gallivanting after full regionalisation as in Catalonia or Baden Württemberg). Except that, on this evidence, there aren't two sides in the democratic debate. The very people who currently "deny and prevent" are the ones who in the new dawn would be required to be "engaging and enthusing". They exclude - and not just women. Members of ethnic communities and people with disabilities are next to invisible on councils and quangos alike. And where on earth is youth? Who is there to power and glamorise political change; whose bliss at being alive in a period of constitutional revolution becomes very heaven?

The study of the north-east found only 38 councillors aged under 35 - that is 3.3% of the total. On police authorities it was scraping to locate anyone under 45 (two in Durham and only one in Cleveland ). As the report says "the sections of the community most likely to have had direct experience of being policed, especially younger working-class people, are hardly represented at all".

Cleveland police authority makes the point particularly effectively, embroiled as it is in the Ray Mallon/Operation Lancet affair which has caused a regional furore. "Our annual meeting was open to the public but nobody came", the authority plaintively told the researchers. Meanwhile Durham police are having trouble at the cutting edge. "Their website has been 'under construction' for many months and simply has an image of the police force badge."

The net and other ways of recruiting to quangos - "active citizens", classes in schools - form predictable parts of the report's solutions. But the study does point to one, perhaps unexpected island of better practice. As far as middle-class, middle-aged male domination goes, the great institutional exception is the National Health Service: 20 of the 33 non-executives on local health authorities are women and the chair of the regional authority is Zahida Manzoor, a businesswoman and former nurse.

How does the NHS do it? Simple, really, and in accordance with the sort of best practice which ensures gender-balanced regional committees with guaranteed ethnic and disabled membership in an organisation not featured in the report, the National Lottery Charities Board. As well as being increasingly keen on transparency and openness, the NHS has copied the NLCB with "representation targets" aimed at reflecting the region's population more closely.

There is one big, and very north-eastern flaw. Of 98 members of NHS trusts in the region, 38 are affiliated to Labour and only six to other parties. In that department, the report says with understatement, "there is still much scope for reform". The disabled are also glaringly absent from positions of power within the NHS: none sit on the region's six authorities, none on the 25 primary care groups and only two on the 17 trusts.

Is it merely "politically correct" to insist on change, as critics said of the government's move this week against the office of high sheriff, to which so few women and ethnic minority people have been appointed? To do nothing is as "political", because of the way that an established network inevitably renews itself largely from the ranks of the similar and like-minded.

"It is common ground that public service should be better understood and respected," says the report. It is not a question of bashing the older people who do participate. The report underlines the "substantial amount of time and effort" men like Councillor John Williams of Darlington and Councillor Don Robson of Durham devote to their multifarious offices.

"But to gain that better understanding and respect, the powerholders and their institutions need to show openness, accountability and above all, a commitment to enabling all citizens to contribute to the running of their region."

 Who Runs the North East Now? Department of social policy, Durham University DH1 3JT

fields.headline: Levy told to explain 'missing million'
fields.standfirst:
No 10 stands by Labour peer as Tories step up onslaught over tax

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservatives last night stepped up the pressure on the Labour fundraiser Lord Levy by demanding that he explain the "missing million" in his annual accounts.
fields.body:
The Conservatives last night stepped up the pressure on the Labour fundraiser Lord Levy by demanding that he explain the "missing million" in his annual accounts.

As MPs on both sides of the Commons privately debated Lord Levy's £5,000 tax bill on a strikingly low 1999 income - for a millionaire - of £20,000, Downing Street sought to deflect public concern towards the privacy implications behind the Sunday Times' possession of the peer's tax return.

But the Tory opposition smelled blood and pressed home with its double-headed campaign to discover more about both Lord Levy's financial and diplomatic status as Tony Blair's personal envoy to the Middle East.

After the ruling at the weekend by Mr Justice Toulson that Lord Levy's status as a public figure associated with a party actively hostile to tax avoidance made him a legitimate object of press inquiry, MPs are braced for more tit-for-tat disclosures.

Downing Street - which was happy to see the tax exile status of the Tory party treasurer, Lord Ashcroft, exposed to public criticism - took the view that "people's tax affairs are a matter for them and the question here is how information which has appeared in a newspaper got there".

Labour MPs were also keen to point out that News Corp, the Murdoch-owned parent company of the Sunday Times, is famous for its tax-efficient practices which minimise tax liabilities around the world.

However the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, and aides to the Tory leader, William Hague, hammered home unanswered questions about Lord Levy.

The music impressario who made a fortune after modest beginnings has insisted that his 1999 tax bill was low because he had been living off capital on which no tax was liable - and had done so for a single year after 30 years of paying up to £250,000 in tax each year.

The Tories took that figure as a baseline from which to infer that Lord Levy needed £1m of income a year to sustain his lifestyle. They aimed to goad the Labour peer into explaining in more detail his allegedly sophisticated tax planning arrangements.

Lord Levy, who raised up to £7m for Labour before the 1997 general election, insists that he has never engaged in the lawful tax-avoidance schemes favoured by the rich, let alone illegal tax evasion which is also widespread.

Yesterday Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, also weighed in to defend Lord Levy and the role he had played in "increasing British representation and influence" in the Middle East.

Mr Maude was quick to leap on that claim too. In a series of questions he asked for more details about Lord Levy's Middle East role, including whether he had ever served as a personal envoy for Ehud Barak, prime minister of Israel, or any other head of government - in addition to Mr Blair.

Mr Cook's remarks about his "key crucial role in getting the [peace process] talks going" was in marked contradiction to Mr Blair's claims in the past that he was "nothing more than a glorified messenger".

Mr Maude said: "Labour's secrecy is bordering on paranoia. What is the prime minister trying to hide?"

The Conservatives are also keen to know why the Foreign Office refused to answer questions about any intelligence briefings Lord Levy might have had for two months, in contrast to the Ministry of Defence which, the Tories said last night, had promptly admitted in March that Lord Levy had met Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of defence staff, four times and "discussed" the Middle East.

"At his request Lord Levy was briefed on the situation in Syria," by the defence intelligence chief before a visit in March 1999.

Mr Cook told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "I've seen the telegrams and met the ambassadors who have worked with him. They all are full of praise for the way he has increased British representation in these areas.

"I can also tell you that in a big key role to the peace process, he played a key crucial role in getting the talks going. He has done a good job and I think he will certainly continue to do that."

Downing Street also continued yesterday to insist that Lord Levy enjoyed Tony Blair's full backing.

A spokesman for the prime minister said: "Lord Levy has paid tax. He has paid significant amounts of tax. What he has done in the year in question is live off the capital on which he has paid tax.

"The prime minister continues to have a high regard for Lord Levy."

webTitle: Owen backs lobbying curbs on peers

fields.headline: Owen backs lobbying curbs on peers
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: Peers should be banned from holding multiple contracts with lobbying companies to prevent the abuses of parliament seen in the Commons during the 1980s, Lord Owen told a new inquiry into standards of conduct in the Lords.
fields.body:
Peers should be banned from holding multiple contracts with lobbying companies to prevent the abuses of parliament seen in the Commons during the 1980s, Lord Owen told a new inquiry into standards of conduct in the Lords.

He was giving evidence on the opening day of an inquiry launched by Lord Neill, chairman of the committee on standards in public life.

The inquiry is examining whether to tighten up the present Lords register of interests; limit the scope of lobbying and consultancies, including whether to outlaw paid advocacy by peers; and introduce a new code of conduct for peers.

Lord Owen said: "Quite simply, if someone who holds the directorship of a major lobbying company is approached to sit in the Lords, they should be told that perhaps they should no longer hold that post."

He favoured a mandatory declaration of peers' business interests and the registering of single consultancies.

But he was against setting up a Lords equivalent of Elizabeth Filkin, parliamentary commissioner for standards, to enforce the new register or investigate suspect cases, and did not see why peers should have to register all their paid trips, as MPs have to.

Lord Owen, who sits as a crossbench peer, also backed the judge's decision that the Sunday Times was right to be able to publish details of the tax affairs of Lord Levy, Labour fundraiser.

Earlier Lord Richard, the former Labour leader of the Lords, also backed the mandatory declaration of peers' business interests but opposed widespread reform of the procedures, including new detailed rules for peers' conduct.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Book of the day
fields.body:
Book of the day

Delving into the dark literary past reveals a 1972 tome entitled Alternative Edinburgh - A City Guide with a Difference. And it's not too kind to the fair city, accusing it of raping its culture and conning its tourists. But the advice to stingy partygoers wanting to avoid spending cash on their hosts gives away the author's identity. "Get a carrier bag filled with a couple of empty cans and two half bricks in the bottom." Step forward prudent chancellor Gordon Brown.

Snoop of the day

Michael Brown, former Tory whip and now newspaper columnist, revealed how during his time in office days were spent toiling in the washrooms of the Houses of Westminster. The MP turned sketchwriter told the BBC how the Conservatives had a "bogwatch". "Not I hasten to add for the reasons some of you may be thinking of, but because very revealing conversations between MPs tend to take place there."

Today

Commons: Learning and skills bill, remaining stages. Lords: Child support, pensions and social security bill, report.

webTitle: Poverty pleas win Britain £3bn in EU aid

fields.headline: Poverty pleas win Britain £3bn in EU aid
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: The European Commission yesterday unveiled a record aid package worth almost £3bn for Britain's poorest regions after a protracted negotiation which forced Tony Blair's government to parade its relative poverty.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Michael White  in London
fields.body:
The European Commission yesterday unveiled a record aid package worth almost £3bn for Britain's poorest regions after a protracted negotiation which forced Tony Blair's government to parade its relative poverty.

Announcing final approval of the package, officials in Brussels said that the money - to be shared between Merseyside, South Yorkshire, West Wales and the Valleys and Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly - should generate tens of thousands of new jobs and pay to train new skills.

But hard negotiation is far from over as the regions scramble to force Whitehall to provide the necessary matching funds, partly private, partly public, which EU rules require.

The Treasury has already been accused of diverting away existing funds - one reason for the coup that ended Alun Michael's rule at the Welsh assembly - and ministries are hard pressed to find the kind of industry orientated project Brussels wants.

According to commission projections, by 2010 the cash (provided under the "objective one" category) should generate 154,000 jobs and provide training for 420,000 people out of a total beneficiary population of 5m.

But it is also an admission of failure. Despite repeatedly insisting that the UK economic model is right for Europe Mr Blair has had to admit that Britain is now 12th wealthiest member state in terms of GDP per head.

With 8.9% of yesterday's EU-wide package it has the largest share and, together with Finland, is the only state to have aid to its poorest regions increased in the current round, rather than cut or maintained at previous levels.

Coincidentally yesterday, a Labour leader from one of the poorer regions, Alan Donnelly, the north-east based leader of Britain's Labour MEPs until he quit in December, accused Gordon Brown of wanting to stifle debate on an issue of vital importance to the regions - UK membership of the single currency zone.

Launching the US academic study which predicts 20% faster growth over 20 years inside the zone the Blairite Mr Donnelly joined fellow north east MPs, Peter Mandelson, Nick Brown and Stephen Byers, in saying that the promised referendum might be lost if the pro-euro case is not made now.

The EU aid package was agreed at last summer's Berlin summit, which set spending plans until 2006. But yesterday's statement gives the green light for strategic targets and priorities. Actual projects are to be agreed locally later.

The four objective one areas have been designated highest priority where development is lagging behind and per capita wealth is less than 75% of the EU average.

South Yorkshire gets £700m to "arrest the decline of the region". The money will be used to steer the regional economy away from dependence on traditional sectors and focus on small and medium enterprises and information technology - a general EU preoccupation.

Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly have the lowest average income of Britain's objective one areas and won its new status only after being separated from richer Devon.

It will receive £300m "to address the continuing weaknesses of a predominantly rural and tourist economy such as low wages, seasonal employment and a peripheral location".

West Wales and the Valleys get over £1.1bn to tackle "a great diversity of industrial, rural and social problems".

Merseyside gets more than £800m to continue the fight against high unemployment, a skills shortage and major industrial decline, especially of port-related activities.

fields.headline: Doctors attack 'consumerist' NHS initiatives
fields.standfirst:
Blair's 'foolish' telephone advice scheme diverting funds from core services, BMA conference hears
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The British Medical Association yesterday attacked ministers for diverting scarce health resources into headline-grabbing "consumerist" initiatives, such as NHS Direct, without offering any evidence that they benefited patients or reduced either the workload of GPs or of hospitals.
fields.body:
The British Medical Association yesterday attacked ministers for diverting scarce health resources into headline-grabbing "consumerist" initiatives, such as NHS Direct, without offering any evidence that they benefited patients or reduced either the workload of GPs or of hospitals.

Its annual representative meeting called on the government to halt expansion of NHS Direct, the nurse-led telephone advice service introduced two years ago as a flagship initiative to improve patients' access to information and reduce demand on family doctors.

The service covers two-thirds of the country and is due to go nationwide by the end of October. But doctors' representatives yesterday voted overwhelmingly for a freeze.

They said that there was no evidence to show NHS Direct had reduced workloads for GPs or hospitals. It had not cut patients' demand for doctors' time, but diverted money from the core services of primary care.

"It's time for Tony Blair to admit he was wrong and abandon this foolish scheme so funds can be switched back into general practice," said Jane Milson, a Grimsby doctor.

David Brownridge, a Worcester GP, said: "Surely it is time for a proper evaluation of this brainchild of Tony Blair." Like the prime minister's new son, it would be "protected and guarded and cloaked in secrecy and only given an airing for the purposes of political spin".

The BMA also passed motions criticising experimental walk-in centres set up by the government in a dozen towns in competition with conventional GP surgeries.

Julian Neal, a Portsmouth GP, said: "Our health service must seek to provide high quality patient care rather than modernist, short term consumerist initiatives."

Terry John, a GP from Walthamstow, north London, said the walk-in centres showed the government was "tinkering at the edges with consumer initiatives while the core of the NHS is starved of funds and support".

The BMA's leaders did their best to keep the lid on simmering discontent from the grassroots for fear that it might weaken the association's new-found influence in the government's NHS review.

Ian Bogle, the BMA chairman, said: "I don't want to be too cynical. I have waited for 13 years on the national scene to see a government that consulted [with doctors]." Although the conference was sceptical about government promises of increased resources, it was "not half as critical as it has been some years".

Dr Bogle had appeared to attack the government at the start of the conference when he described proposed national centres for retraining failing doctors as "boot camps". But later he said the Department of Health was no longer pursuing the idea and the BMA could accept an alternative proposal for doctors to be offered advice and support in their own hospitals or surgeries.

His tone will reassure Alan Milburn, the health secretary, that the BMA is not a threat to his plans for reforming the NHS, as it was to Labour ministers when the service was created in 1948.

But Dr Bogle's attitude was not reflected in the string of motions passed by the conference reflecting cynicism about the government's promise of extra resources for the NHS.

Chaand Nagpaul, a north London GP, said: "We implore the government not to squander this money on some flighty ideals of modernisation, but to use it to get the basics right, repair the cracks and make a real difference to the health of the population."

Ronald Timms, of Southend, said: "We still need to know how much and how this money is to be spent. Insistence on the short term populist solutions proposed by the spin doctors has meant there is a loss of faith in the government."

Jonathan Fielden, from Berkshire, said: "Our politicians seem unable to look beyond the next soundbite. We want the government to look at long term options, but all we get is political kneejerks."

S Datta, a Manchester doctor, criticised "utterly unacceptable spin doctoring of almost everything related to the NHS". He said: "There comes a point where distortion becomes fabrication. It's time to send a message to the spin doctors from the real doctors that we will not stand idly by and watch them deliberately mislead patients to satisfy their political ends."

A spokeswoman for the department defended the performance of NHS Direct. "It has been introduced to provide the public with faster and easier access to information, advice and reassurance about health problems. The service has been well used by the public, with over 2.5m calls having been made so far.

"Early evidence suggests that these schemes not only help patients, but also appear to lead to reductions in work for the GPs involved."

webTitle: Chinese top asylum seeker list as applications backlog eases

fields.headline: Chinese top asylum seeker list as applications backlog eases
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: More asylum seekers come to Britain from China than any other country, with 575 arriving last month according to Home Office figures published yesterday.
fields.body:
More asylum seekers come to Britain from China than any other country, with 575 arriving last month according to Home Office figures published yesterday.

The monthly figures also provide further evidence that Britain's asylum system is slowly recovering from a backlog of processing requests to stay. Last month 10,756 decisions were made, more than double the number a year ago, and the number of cases waiting for a decision continues to fall, from 104,000 in January to 89,900.

Some 41% of the applications decided last month were given either full refugee status or exceptional leave to remain on compassionate grounds. The number of appeal decisions has also begun to rise, and reached an all-time high of 5,105 in May.

The immigration authorities hope the number of decisions each month will rise to 15,000 in the autumn, so they can meet their target of eradicating the backlog by next April.

The monthly figures show that there were 6,185 applications in May, an increase of 295 over the previous month. Chinese applications jumped from 455 in April to 575 in May. The next largest group came from Sri Lanka, 495, followed by Iran, 460, and Afghanistan, 405.

Police from Britain, the Netherlands, France, Germany, and Belgium were meeting yesterday to discuss how to step up efforts to combat international trafficking in people.

A spokeswoman for the national crime squad said the only way to tackle the trade (which claimed the lives of 58 Chinese in a container lorry in Dover earlier this month), was to pool resources and intelligence across Europe. Combating the gangs behind the trade was now the squad's priority, taking over from drugs.

webTitle: Zanu-PF rebuffs claim of unfair poll

fields.headline: Zanu-PF rebuffs claim of unfair poll
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's ruling party yesterday rejected the EU observers' condemnation of the election campaign and the charge that the government had "failed to uphold the rule of law" by apparently sanctioning violence and intimidation against opponents.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's ruling party yesterday rejected the EU observers' condemnation of the election campaign and the charge that the government had "failed to uphold the rule of law" by apparently sanctioning violence and intimidation against opponents.

"Considering the countries they represent, we didn't expect anything positive from them. They have been hostile to us all along," said Chen Chimutengwende, the information minister.

Jonathan Moyo, Zanu-PF's campaign manager, called the EU's assessment "an insult to the people of Zimbabwe. The people of Zimbabwe are capable of coming to their own verdict," he snapped.

The EU decision to issue an interim statement on the campaign only five hours after the polls closed was criticised by some European diplomats, but it was drafted with the heads of the EU missions in Zimbabwe.

Pierre Schori from Sweden, who led the team of about 190 EU observers, made it clear they wanted to produce their interim verdict before all the results were known, so as not to appear partisan. He said: "The term 'free and fair' is not applicable in these elections."

Observers criticised the registrar-general for problems with the voters' roll which meant that thousands of people were turned away because their names were not on it. They also accused the registrar-general of deliberately blocking monitoring by not giving access to civic groups.

The most stinging criticism covered violence and intimidation during the campaign, especially in rural areas. Up to 40 people, most of them opposition supporters and candidates, were killed. In about half of the 80 rural constituencies, it was either impossible or very difficult for the opposition to campaign, said Francisco Cobos, the EU's main election adviser.

The EU statement said that Zanu-PF was responsible for the bulk of the violence, although the opposition Movement for Democratic Change was not blameless. It said MDC leaders were "clearer in their condemnation of violence", while Zanu-PF leaders appeared to sanction it.

fields.headline: Mugabe's opponents scent historic victory
fields.standfirst:
Monitors sleep with ballot boxes to stop rigging as suspense mounts before election result
Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: "Rest in pieces Zanu-PF, we won't miss you," read the placard on a makeshift coffin driven through Bulawayo yesterday even before Zimbabwe's opposition claimed early victories in the watershed elections.
fields.byline: Buchizya Mseteka in Bulawayo  and  Andrew Meldrum  in Harare
fields.body:
"Rest in pieces Zanu-PF, we won't miss you," read the placard on a makeshift coffin driven through Bulawayo yesterday even before Zimbabwe's opposition claimed early victories in the watershed elections.

Supporters of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) were in a carnival mood in the country's second city and predicted a landslide victory over President Robert Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party.

"Only a miracle can save Zanu-PF and miracles are hard to come by these days," said a weary Bernard Mtombeni, an MDC election agent who had not slept since voting began on Saturday.

The turnout to elect 120 members of parliament looked like being one of the highest since independence in 1980, when Zanu-PF won a sweeping majority that it has not relinquished since.

MDC leader Morgan Tsvangirai was confident the heavy turnout would favour his party.

At vote-counting stations in and around Bulawayo, supporters gathered outside as the process of sorting ballots got under way. Others were glued to the radio to listen for results. The final outcome is not expected before late today.

Mr Mtombeni was among hundreds of MDC election agents deployed across the country, many of them sleeping overnight at polling stations to ensure ballot boxes did not go missing.

"It's a lot of hard work but there was no other option. We were highly suspicious that boxes could be tampered with, so we had to put a system in place to ensure this did not happen," said an MDC electoral official, Malcolm Davidson.

The opposition in Matabeleland - which occupies a swath of Zimbabwe's south-west, and is traditionally opposed to the Zanu-PF government - has used a combination of ingenuity and courage in the face of violence from pro-government militants. In the 1980s, Mr Mugabe brutally crushed its Bantu-speaking Ndebele people, who make up 15% of the country's population.

In Bulawayo South constituency, in the heart of the region, opposition members have been threatened, beaten, raped and abducted by shadowy pro-government gangs and liberation war veterans.

Crowds also gathered yesterday in the capital Harare, in front of the central government building where the first votes were announced. Armed riot police put up roadblocks on main streets in the city, fearing riots and demonstrations, no matter who wins.

"This atmosphere of intense suspicion is very tiring," said a polling agent, Graeme Black, who was watching the counting of ballots at Allen Wilson School in the Harare Central constituency.

"The government authorities have been changing the rules every few hours which creates confusion. First they said no one could leave the counting station, but then, after Zanu-PF officials came in and out, they changed the rules to say that candidates could go in and out.

"They said polling agents could not travel with the ballot boxes as they were transported to the counting stations, but at the last minute they said they could. This confusion makes things tense." The counting process was cumbersome and very lo-tech. The numerous checks and verifications appeared to ensure accurate counts, but many government critics still feared rigging.

"I slept with that ballot box and I travelled with it to this counting station," said Taurai Mahasha, a poll monitor.

"We are not going to chicken out on this monitoring. It is our job to make sure that the vote is fair and transparent. We want to see that the people's will is reflected in this vote."

A sociology student from the University of Zimbabwe, Brilliant Mhlanga, 23 was also watching the counting process intently. "I'm doing this because I stand under the banner of students' rights," he said.

"We must be fully involved in building our nation. We must witness every step of the elections so that we can point out any discrepancies. I can say right now that the authorities are changing the regulations and the procedures and people are getting confused. But we will be vigilant."

Crowds also gathered yesterday in the capital Harare, in front of the central government building where the first votes were announced. Armed riot police put up roadblocks on main streets in the city, fearing riots and demonstrations, no matter who wins. "This atmosphere of intense suspicion is very tiring," said a polling agent, Graeme Black, who was watching the counting of ballots at Allen Wilson School in the Harare Central constituency. "The government authorities have been changing the rules every few hours which creates confusion. First they said no one could leave the counting station, but then, after Zanu-PF officials came in and out, they changed the rules to say that candidates could go in and out. "They said polling agents could not travel with the ballot boxes as they were transported to the counting stations, but at the last minute they said they could. This confusion makes things tense." The counting process was cumbersome and very lo-tech. The numerous checks and verifications appeared to ensure accurate counts, but many government critics still feared rigging. "I slept with that ballot box and I travelled with it to this counting station," said Taurai Mahasha, a poll monitor. "We are not going to chicken out on this monitoring. It is our job to make sure that the vote is fair and transparent. We want to see that the people's will is reflected in this vote." A sociology student from the University of Zimbabwe, Brilliant Mhlanga, 23 was also watching the counting process intently. "I'm doing this because I stand under the banner of students' rights," he said. "We must be fully involved in building our nation. We must witness every step of the elections so that we can point out any discrepancies. I can say right now that the authorities are changing the regulations and the procedures and people are getting confused. But we will be vigilant."
fields.bylineHtml: Buchizya Mseteka in Bulawayo and Andrew Meldrum in Harare

webTitle: Punishing Austria only aids and abets ugly Haiderism

fields.headline: Punishing Austria only aids and abets ugly Haiderism
fields.standfirst:
Act now, before the French gain the European Union's presidency

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Struggling to define some political principles, the European Union made one of its members, Austria, a pariah. That was in January. Europe issued a moral statement, and Austria was duly punished. But the policy has become self-defeating.
fields.body:
Struggling to define some political principles, the European Union made one of its members, Austria, a pariah. That was in January. Europe issued a moral statement, and Austria was duly punished. But the policy has become self-defeating. It wasn't wrong, but it is no longer right. Now the EU probably has only until the end of this week to change it. A policy that once expressed broad European ideals urgently needs rescuing from the grip of narrow national politics. British liberals need to face the implications.

The man who first set ostracism rolling was Austria's own head of state, President Thomas Klestil. Fearing he might be pressed to accept a new coalition including the neo-fascist Freedom party led by Jörg Haider, he privately encouraged other EU countries to send out warning signals. They agreed to do so. Austria, they said, would face sanctions if this happened. But it did happen. The threat did not work. At the political level, Austria has been ostracised for five months. When the foreign minister came to London the other day, the only public figure who would receive her was, fatally, Margaret Thatcher.

The EU action wasn't deeply considered. National leaders were more engaged that foreign ministries, and the commission had no say. The gesture was abrupt and rather grand. Haider's party has a shocking record of Holocaust denial, immigrant-bashing and related Hitlerite taints. Its involvement as junior partner in the coalition cast the first shadow over the mutual trust and common values that have governed the EU for 40 years. Led by France and Belgium, which have kept their own burgeoning fascist parties out of government, the union agreed to assert the limits of tolerable political extremism.

The message was to Austria, but also to aspirant members of the EU, especially those in the second tier such as Romania and Bulgaria with little democratic tradition. It was meant to lay down the standards of decency the EU would defend. Austria, to some extent, heard the message. Haider, of course, despised it. But before being sworn in, the new government averred more strongly than any predecessor Austrian complicity in Nazi crimes.

It has since done nothing, as a government, to advance the worst of the Freedom party's baleful programme. It has not acted against minority rights, nor undermined democracy. Haider, albeit with subversive intent, has left the party leadership. The EU case against Austria remains, uncomfortably, in the realm of theory rather than practice.

Like many acts deriving from political lunge more than diplomatic calculation, modes of exit from this one were not thought out. Now that exit seems necessary, it faces big obstacles. Though more an irritant than a scourge, the sanctions are building punitive consequences, all in the wrong places.

In several EU countries, they're beginning to be seen as a threat to national political integrity. Tolerable, even admirable, as a temporary measure, they're growing into what looks like an indefinite assault on a country where 27% of voters, after all, did vote for Jörg Haider. Denmark, in particular, registers alarm at such an override of democracy. Even though "Brussels" had nothing to do with this, the Danish referendum on the euro could be determined by nightmare images of EU impositions on the democratic will, if the Austrians aren't restored to normality before September.

From Austria itself, the effects could spread deep and wide. A plebiscite on sanctions is promised there, also in September. Though Haider's support hasn't grown much, indignation at the sanctions has. This is certain to excite more anti-EU feeling, producing a vote that asserts Austria's determination not to be bossed around. Haider's anti-immigrant rhetoric will become more not less resonant. Opposition to enlargement, by far the most important item on the EU agenda, will intensify and, since this requires a unanimous vote, could drive Austria, backed by a popular mandate, to block it altogether.

Most players in the EU game now seem to understand this. Even those once most outraged by the Haider party's presence in government privately admit that sanctions ought to end. Austria, they say, mustn't be let off the hook, and must still be watched. But this can't go on indefinitely. She must be given the prospect of remission for good behaviour. Tony Blair takes this line. The question is: can the collective talents of 14 countries' diplomacy be mobilised in time to stop a spiralling diplomatic calamity? Or will a piece of genuine supra-national idealism be destroyed, ironically, by national politics?

The key culprit here is the key originator: France. Which is where Portugal comes in. Next week France takes over from Portugal as president of the EU. For France the original desire not to encourage its own National Front vote - the objective was fair enough - has shifted into rivalry between President Chirac and prime minister Jospin as to which can outdo the other in proven dedication to the anti-fascist cause. The presidential election approaches. More immediately there are municipal elections, in which Chirac fears the National Front. It's commonly reckoned that, once France takes over the EU, the portcullis will come down against any Austrian deal, and may stay down during the next two presidencies, first Sweden then Belgium, both in the van of the anti-Austria campaign.

Much rests, therefore, on the dying days of the Portuguese presidency. Portugal, it must be said, has not done well so far. Nor have the Austrians, with their propensity to blab about any private diplomacy that might be going on. But now the end game looms, and everybody knows it. A deal just might be done, whereby Austria achieves a suspension of sanctions, conditional on accepting a few months' invigilation of her conduct. She may have to promise to take part in EU anti-racist campaigns, which she hasn't yet done. Another idea is for more explicit anti-Nazi history teaching in schools. Exactly who would make the analysis of Austria's behaviour, and how long the transition would last, are sensitive questions. But it seems exceedingly important that Antonio Guterres, the Portuguese prime minister, gives what remains of his energy to pushing hard on both Paris and Vienna before Friday.

Austria is a hard case. Hella Pick, in her penetrating new study Guilty Victim: Austria from the Holocaust to Haider (IB Tauris, £24.50), says that Haider's very presence in politics casts doubt on the country's efforts over the last decade to portray itself as a mature democracy. But the EU has done as much as it practically can to lay its demands on the line. Indefinite sanctions, unremissible by any corrective action except the improbable de-election of the Freedom party, only make the problem worse. The best way to stop Haiderism is to end a punishment that has had its day.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Al Capone | Hope Floats | The Negotiator | Come And See
fields.body:
Al Capone

(Richard Wilson, 1959)

9am, Carlton Cinema

Harsh monochrome account of Chicago's number one gangster, from his early assassination of Big Jim Colosimo (Joe De Santis) through to his conviction for tax evasion. Rod Steiger, as a master method actor, apparently wore Capone's underwear. Fay Spain plays his girl, Martin Balsam is a crooked reporter.

Hope Floats

(Forest Whitaker, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

Having learned that her husband is having an affair with her best friend, Sandra Bul lock's Birdy flees with her young daughter to her mother's house in the deep south. The townsfolk are only too ready to revel in the misfortune of this former beauty queen. Added to this, her plain-speaking mother is trying to set her up with the local carpenter (Harry Connick Jr). Forest Whitaker conjures up some moving moments as three generations of women edge around each other and Birdy faces up to her future, but ultimately these are outweighed by a schmaltzy feel-good cosiness.

The Negotiator

(F Gary Gray, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

Samuel L Jackson's ace hostage negotiator (pictured) is framed for murder and embezzlement; he reacts by taking his main accuser (JT Walsh) and a bunch of police bigwigs and admin staff hostage and demands that a negotiator from another district (Kevin Spacey), handles the crisis. The pair are soon working together to root out top-level corruption. The face-off between two of the US cinema's most charismatic leads provides a powerful charge to Gray's clever drama; it's a pity, though, that the pair share so little time on screen.

Come And See

(Elem Klimov, 1985)

1.55am, FilmFour

Horrific account of the second world war as it was fought in German occupied Byelorussia, now Belarus. Aleksey Kravchenko plays a young peasant returning on leave from his partisan unit in 1943 to find his village slaughtered; at the next hamlet he witnesses SS troops going about their work. Saving Private Ryan comes nowhere near.
