webTitle: A blacked-out vehicle, a piece of Irish history

fields.headline: A blacked-out vehicle, a piece of Irish history
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: When Cyril Ramaphosa arrives at his office in Johannesburg at 11.30am today, he will have completed a seven-day journey that has taken him across the world and into Ireland's history books. He is a witness to what may finally be the end of 30 years of violence, human loss and private agonies in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
When Cyril Ramaphosa arrives at his office in Johannesburg at 11.30am today, he will have completed a seven-day journey that has taken him across the world and into Ireland's history books. He is a witness to what may finally be the end of 30 years of violence, human loss and private agonies in Northern Ireland.

It is a place reserved for him and the former Finnish president, Martti Ahtisaari, as the only two outsiders present on a warm summer's day in Ireland when the IRA opened three arms dumps to them.

The journey of the two international inspectors began on Monday last week when Mr Ramaphosa flew north out of Johannesburg airport and met his colleague, the former Finnish president, in London.

Their movements over the next three days in the Republic of Ireland may have taken them to the south, to the slopes of the Magillycuddy Reeks and the Slieve Bloom Mountains where the IRA has historically stored arms, or perhaps they tramped the Co Cavan border.

What they saw was the first ever voluntary display of IRA weapons to outsiders. Yesterday morning they confirmed that they believed that the IRA weapons had finally been stored and could not be used without their knowledge.

It is a huge step - the closest the IRA will ever come to decommissioning its arms.

The details of exactly what the inspectors saw when those dumps were opened are reserved for the next chapter of the history books.

Did they see what remained of the three tons of semtex brought in from Libya to the Wicklow Coast between 1984 and 1987? Perhaps it was just a couple of the kalashnikovs the IRA have been buying in eastern Europe since the Bosnia war ended. Perhaps the dump, like the one discovered by the Irish police under a farmhouse in Co Laois, had its own electricity supply, air vent and heating system to keep the weapons at optimum temperature.

The IRA drove the inspectors to the dump. The vehicle's windows were blacked out. There were no blindfolds. Mr Ahtisaari, who ran the negotiations between Nato and Russia during the Kosovo war, and Mr Ramaphosa, one of the most influential black leaders in South Africa, are not men who travel blindfolded.

"These are international statesmen and there is trust there," a source who spoke directly with the IRA after the operation told the Guardian. "The whole basis of this operation is trust and secrecy."

Even the inner cogs of the Irish government were unaware of what had taken place late on Friday afternoon. "This is unprecedented, uncharted water. In 24 years in the job. I haven't seen anything like it," said one of the men at the heart of the Dublin government.

After the inspections the dumps were sealed using one of three techniques - a wax steal, stamped by the inspectors (most unlikely), an electric current run across the entrance to register an interference (also unlikely), or concrete.

They will back in three months to check that the arms have indeed been "put beyond use"

"You can be sure of one thing. This is as good as it is going to get. You will never see IRA arms being put through the metal grinder. They will rust in the ground but never be handed over," the source told the Guardian yesterday.

What the IRA still has to rust under the ground is somewhere in the region of 600 detonators, six flame throwers, a Sam surface to air missile, 50 rocket launchers, 20 heavy machine guns, 12 machine guns and three sniper rifles. Most of these came courtesy of Colonel Gadafy some time between 1984 and 1987; the Armalites and 600 AK47s also hidden are a spin-off from the Balkans.

In a small cottage along a coast road in County Donegal is a shabby single storey cottage with its kitchen and dining room windows blocked out with white paint. It is the summer home of a 58-year-old man who, last Monday, finally issued the invitation for his foreign visitors to come and visit the dumps: Brian Keenan, once described as "most intelligent, energetic and resourceful military operator the modern IRA has yet produced".

He's not been seen much around the cottage, where the garden is full of wild Donegal cotton. He has been busy, spending two years persuading the IRA to put their "arms beyond use".

There are two important things to note about Brian Keenan. He has always said the IRA will never decommission. But they also say that if you get Brian Keenan's pulse, you get the pulse of the IRA. Yesterday in the early morning Donegal sunshine, his home looked like that of a man who had finally reached a quiet place.

fields.headline: We are not amused
fields.trailText: Crawfie: The Royal Nannie Who Wouldn't Keep Mum | In Defence | Syndicate
fields.body:
Two royal Daimlers swished along the rainy road to Balmoral past the house where Crawfie lived. Their speed did not slacken. Marion Crawford had been Princess Elizabeth and Princess Margaret's governess for 17 years, the best part of her life and her childbearing years. In retirement she wrote her memoirs, The Little Princesses, and the first button flew off that buttoned-up court like a bullet. In time the air would be full of flying buttons.

According to Crawfie: The Royal Nannie Who Wouldn't Keep Mum (Channel 4) it was done at the instigation of the Foreign Office, but the royal family never forgave her.

Perhaps she bought this house on the road to Balmoral in the hope that one day they might wave. They never did. It is a scene reminiscent of the young Henry V seeing his old friend and father figure, Falstaff, at the roadside.

"My king! My Jove! I speak to thee, my heart!"

"I know thee not, old man."

Every heavy word a blow. When Crawfie tried to kill herself, the emergency services found a note: "The world has passed me by and I cannot bear those I love to pass me by on the road." When she died in 1988, there was no wreath from the royal family.

Though The Little Princesses is sugary to a diabetic degree, it is clearly authentic (unlike Crawfie's Column in Woman's Own, which was written by some guy in the office). There is one disturbing anecdote showing the strain on young Princess Elizabeth.

"I became quite anxious about Lillibet and her fads. She became almost too methodical and tidy. She would hop out of bed several times a night to get her shoes quite straight, her clothes arranged just so. One day, rebelling all of a sudden, she picked up the big, ornamental silver inkpot and placed it without any warning upside down on her head. She sat there with ink trickling down her face and slowly dying her golden curls blue."

You could say that Crawfie poured a bottle of ink over the princesses. A senior courtier said "She snaked", but Faith Quartermaine said "She was stitched up." Quartermaine was then home editor of Women's Own, which ran The Little Princesses. Now 79, she is formidable to an entertaining degree, saying "Oh, yes, it was quite dreadful!" on the crest of a laugh as if surfing disaster. Buoyancy is useful in an editor.

I was struck by how female the whole fuss was. It was always the queen's approval that was sought. The queen who wrote dashingly slapdash letters to Crawfie saying it would be all right if the information were not seen to come from her as "People in positions of confidence with us must be utterly oyster." The queen who later said Crawfie must have gone off her head. Had we no king? The education of the princesses and all its rippling implications were clearly considered women's business.

Crawfie's doctor in Aberdeen described her as very, very presbyterian, sitting with a blank face as her husband cracked barrack- room jokes. Crawfie had married George Buthlay, a banker. His niece thought him great fun. Her niece found him disturbingly attentive and wrote to her aunt about it. Crawfie, who had learned a thing or two from the royals, never spoke to her again.

She was paid $85,000 for The Little Princesses. As her American publisher said, "A hunk of money." It bought the nice house in Aberdeen where the Daimlers never stopped.

In Defence (Granada) is another attempt on the part of ITV to get their money's worth out of Ross Kemp. They bought a strong personality with a muscled swagger and a face like a swinging fist. All this shouts villain. He is cast here as a barrister with a conscience like a salted snail, almost disabled professionally by sensitive misgivings. It is a well made and acted series, which may repay patience.

Syndicate (BBC1) is a new quiz with the added ingredient, sadism. Contestants are cruelly traded for points by their captains. "This is a struggle for mental supremacy, a fight for survival. At stake - humiliation and defeat", says Nick Ross, who is cast rather against type as a tough egg. "Understand?" he grates. "Yes, Nick", they say meekly. Of course, they do. They are very bright indeed. They don't know the maximum untaxed income, but they do know George Washington had hippopotamus teeth.

This seems hard on the hippopotamus.

Marion Crawford had been Princess Elizabeth and Princess Margaret's governess for 17 years, the best part of her life and her childbearing years. In retirement she wrote her memoirs, The Little Princesses, and the first button flew off that buttoned-up court like a bullet. In time the air would be full of flying buttons. According to Crawfie: The Royal Nannie Who Wouldn't Keep Mum (Channel 4) it was done at the instigation of the Foreign Office, but the royal family never forgave her. Perhaps she bought this house on the road to Balmoral in the hope that one day they might wave. They never did. It is a scene reminiscent of the young Henry V seeing his old friend and father figure, Falstaff, at the roadside. "My king! My Jove! I speak to thee, my heart!" "I know thee not, old man." Every heavy word a blow. When Crawfie tried to kill herself, the emergency services found a note: "The world has passed me by and I cannot bear those I love to pass me by on the road." When she died in 1988, there was no wreath from the royal family. Though The Little Princesses is sugary to a diabetic degree, it is clearly authentic (unlike Crawfie's Column in Woman's Own, which was written by some guy in the office). There is one disturbing anecdote showing the strain on young Princess Elizabeth. "I became quite anxious about Lillibet and her fads. She became almost too methodical and tidy. She would hop out of bed several times a night to get her shoes quite straight, her clothes arranged just so. One day, rebelling all of a sudden, she picked up the big, ornamental silver inkpot and placed it without any warning upside down on her head. She sat there with ink trickling down her face and slowly dying her golden curls blue." You could say that Crawfie poured a bottle of ink over the princesses. A senior courtier said "She snaked", but Faith Quartermaine said "She was stitched up." Quartermaine was then home editor of Women's Own, which ran The Little Princesses. Now 79, she is formidable to an entertaining degree, saying "Oh, yes, it was quite dreadful!" on the crest of a laugh as if surfing disaster. Buoyancy is useful in an editor. I was struck by how female the whole fuss was. It was always the queen's approval that was sought. The queen who wrote dashingly slapdash letters to Crawfie saying it would be all right if the information were not seen to come from her as "People in positions of confidence with us must be utterly oyster." The queen who later said Crawfie must have gone off her head. Had we no king? The education of the princesses and all its rippling implications were clearly considered women's business. Crawfie's doctor in Aberdeen described her as very, very presbyterian, sitting with a blank face as her husband cracked barrack- room jokes. Crawfie had married George Buthlay, a banker. His niece thought him great fun. Her niece found him disturbingly attentive and wrote to her aunt about it. Crawfie, who had learned a thing or two from the royals, never spoke to her again. She was paid $85,000 for The Little Princesses. As her American publisher said, "A hunk of money." It bought the nice house in Aberdeen where the Daimlers never stopped. In Defence (Granada) is another attempt on the part of ITV to get their money's worth out of Ross Kemp. They bought a strong personality with a muscled swagger and a face like a swinging fist. All this shouts villain. He is cast here as a barrister with a conscience like a salted snail, almost disabled professionally by sensitive misgivings. It is a well made and acted series, which may repay patience. Syndicate (BBC1) is a new quiz with the added ingredient, sadism. Contestants are cruelly traded for points by their captains. "This is a struggle for mental supremacy, a fight for survival. At stake - humiliation and defeat", says Nick Ross, who is cast rather against type as a tough egg. "Understand?" he grates. "Yes, Nick", they say meekly. Of course, they do. They are very bright indeed. They don't know the maximum untaxed income, but they do know George Washington had hippopotamus teeth. This seems hard on the hippopotamus.

fields.headline: Uncovering the guns
fields.standfirst:
This is decommissioning in all but name
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: They said it would never happen and now it has. The IRA has opened up its arsenal to outside view, allowing two respected international statesmen to see what the organisation describes as its "weapons, explosives and other equipment". The two inspectors, the former Finnish president, Martti Ahtisaari, and the one-time secretary general of the African National Congress, Cyril Ramaphosa, could not have been more effusive.
fields.body:
They said it would never happen and now it has. The IRA has opened up its arsenal to outside view, allowing two respected international statesmen to see what the organisation describes as its "weapons, explosives and other equipment". The two inspectors, the former Finnish president, Martti Ahtisaari, and the one-time secretary general of the African National Congress, Cyril Ramaphosa, could not have been more effusive. Eschewing the usually sober language of those charged with supervision of decommissioning, the two men declared themselves wholly satisfied: "The process that led to the first inspection visit and the way in which it was carried out makes us believe that this is a genuine effort by the IRA to advance the peace process". Tony Blair heard that message directly from the two inspectors yesterday, prompting him to do some immediate effusing of his own: peace in Northern Ireland, he said, "has never had a better prospect than it has today".

Those warm words are entirely justified. An organisation once committed to a bloody armed struggle has entered a new era: that much is clear by the statement from Messrs Ramaphosa and Ahtisaari that the IRA can no longer use the weapons in the inspected dumps without the verifiers knowing they have been used. Of course there may be other dumps which the inspectors have not seen. But the symbolic point is clear: by narrowing its military options in this obvious way, the IRA is moving beyond war and violence, towards peace and politics.

Still, this is not the end of the process - just the beginning of the end. There is still much that has to be handled with care. One line in yesterday's IRA statement deserves particular attention: it reminded the two governments that the paramilitaries were making their move "in the context of a series of commitments" by London and Dublin, especially London. That was a not-very-coded reference to the Patten proposals on police reform. Republicans insist that the IRA's move was only possible because of a British commitment to make wholesale changes to the Royal Ulster Constabulary. If those changes are diluted out of all recognition, there will be loud grumblings within republicanism that the movement has been conned - and that concessions like yesterday's are not yielding the fruits they should.

The second risk is on disarmament itself. Mr Blair stressed yesterday that the inspections did not amount to decommissioning, but merely a step on the way. Assorted Unionist politicians echoed that same point. This may prove to be a mistake. For the genius of the inspections idea was to find a way for the IRA to put arms beyond use without hitting the symbolic obstacles that made decommissioning a barrier to peace for so long. This was a way for the IRA to decommission on its terms.

Lest anyone doubt it, just listen to the words used by the republican rejectionists at the weekend meeting of the hardline 32 County Sovereignty Movement in Dundalk. They accused the pro-peace IRA and Sinn Fein leadership of betrayal, for effectively decommissioning. There is no need for British and Unionist politicians to force these pro-peace republicans to spell it out: everyone knows what they are doing. Instead, we should follow the sage advice of the Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern. He called yesterday for decommissioning to be dropped as an issue in the peace process - never to return. He's right. It has only ever brought trouble. Now that an artful way has been found to get round it, the parties should grab it with both hands - and move on.

webTitle: Premiers clash as IRA arms move welcomed

fields.headline: Premiers clash as IRA arms move welcomed
fields.standfirst:
 Blair sounds cautious note as Ahern sees end to decommissioning saga
 Unionists and Sinn Fein hail announcement as historic first
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart Bertie Ahern clashed over the IRA's arms gesture yesterday, raising fears that the peace process could once again be stalled by the issue of paramilitary disarmament.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart Bertie Ahern clashed over the IRA's arms gesture yesterday, raising fears that the peace process could once again be stalled by the issue of paramilitary disarmament.

Within minutes of the IRA's announcement that it had opened up its dumps for inspection, the prime minister appeared on the steps of Downing Street to hail the development as a "very substantial step" forward. But Mr Blair, sensitive to unionist demands for actual disarmament, said the inspection of dumps was "not decommissioning itself".

His remarks appeared to be contradicted by Mr Ahern who said he hoped decommissioning would no longer be an issue. Speaking in Oslo, the taoiseach said: "I think that brings the decommissioning saga to, hopefully, a successful end."

London and Dublin insisted last night that there were no differences between the two prime ministers. One British source said Mr Ahern had been trying to say that decommissioning would now no longer be a divisive issue while accepting that the process was far from over.

The conflicting signals, which reflected the opposing views of nationalists and unionists, were a reminder that decommissioning could still threaten the peace process.

Mr Blair sounded a cautious note because he wants to reassure unionists that yesterday's announcement will lead to full IRA disarmament. The Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, who accepts the IRA's gesture is a significant step forward, re-entered government with Sinn Fein on the basis that there would be "credible and verifiable" decommissioning.

Significant gesture

Mr Ahern, on the other hand, knows that republicans believe they have now come close to fulfilling their side of the bargain under the Good Friday agreement. Republicans believe that sealing their dumps, which will allow the inspectors to rule on whether arms have been used, meets the call for weapons to be "placed beyond use".

Despite the contradictory responses yesterday to the IRA announcement, the British and Irish governments are confi dent they will be able to maintain the momentum of the peace process.

Ministers took heart when all pro-agreement parties, including normally sceptical Ulster Unionists, hailed the IRA announcement as an historic first. "In 200 years there has not been an initiative like this," the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, said.

Even unionists recognise that yesterday's development was a far more significant gesture than the two other occasions when the IRA disarmed in the last century. After the 1916 Easter Rising republicans surrendered their arms at gunpoint to the British. After the 1922 civil war Eamon de Valera ordered his forces to dump their arms, but this was not monitored.

Mr Trimble said the announcement had vindicated his decision to re-enter government. "I think today is good news and I hope those who doubted whether it would happen will acknowledge that we have made progress," he told CNN.

A British source said the IRA underlined its commitment to the process by following its arms announcement with a promise to re-establish contact with the international disarmament commission. Under legislation governing the process, General John de Chastelain, the commission chairman, has to rule on whether weapons have been put beyond use.

British sources said they hoped decommissioning could be wrapped up by next June, the date set in the deal which saved the peace process this spring. However, they stressed they would not be imposing any new deadlines.

"If we talk about deadlines we will put ourselves back in the box we have just escaped from," one source said. We are not getting back into deadlines."

Ministers will now hope to bed down the peace process through a twin track process under which progress on one front will lead to progress in other areas.

Amenable

The IRA's gesture, ministers hope, will serve to underpin unionist confidence in the power-sharing executive and make them more amenable to issues such as police reform. If unionists warm to the process, the theory goes, the IRA will then be more amenable to further gestures on decommissioning.

The next step on decommissioning will be for the IRA to agree to allow the two arms inspectors to return to the three dumps they saw last week. It is by no means inevitable that they will return because the inspectors can only function with the cooperation of the IRA.

If the inspectors do return, they will be able to assess whether the dumps have been tampered with. Seals were placed on the dumps last week.

The progress yesterday's announcement showed prompted Peter Mandelson to declare: "I think we are seeing the shadow of the gunman fading away."

fields.headline: Low water at Amazon
fields.standfirst:
It brings a much needed dose of reality

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The fall from grace of Amazon.com is good for the economy and, maybe, good for the company itself.
fields.body:
The fall from grace of Amazon.com is good for the economy and, maybe, good for the company itself. No one can take away from Amazon its stunning achievement in virtually inventing the dot.com company and being its most spectacular success story (physically if not financially). In less than five years it has become the world's biggest bookshop and has been diversifying feverishly in order to become the world's one-stop shop for a wide range of consumer goods. But in doing so its shares flew too close to the sun and have now melted. They fell 19% on Friday making a 70% fall during the past six months. This is part of a much wider melt-down that has hit US and UK internet stocks generally.

This is good news for two reasons. First, it has brought a dose of realism into a crazy world in which investors seemed to think that net stocks were beyond the laws of gravity. They are not. They have to make profits, like others. Amazon's price soared ludicrously beyond reality considering it is losing money heavily in an environment in which price cutting is endemic. The company claims it has over $1bn in its coffers (the result of selling stock on the back of its overhyped share price). That may be so but it won't last long at the pace it has been leaking cash of late. And if Amazon is in this state, what about the rest?

The second reason is that the fall of the dot.coms hasn't brought down the rest of the economy with it. So far, that is (don't bet on it). Some economists had predicted a scare scenario in which the surge in hi-tech stocks (which provided the wealth to fuel America's consumer spending boom) would go into reverse thrust. People, suddenly feeling poorer because of falling stock markets, would stop spending, thereby propelling the economy into recession. Maybe the crash hasn't happened yet because of the spatchcock way in which the fall in technology shares occurred - up one day down the next, affecting different stocks in different ways and often offset by a rise in old economy stocks. People are at last realising that, for all their glamour, most dot.coms targeting consumers are just selling old economy goods in a different way - and with thousands of global competitors prepared to undercut them. There will eventually be an almighty shake-out from which only the super-fit will survive. Meanwhile, consumers should take advantage. Seldom has there been such a good time to shop.

webTitle: Inspectors satisfied with cooperation on checking dumps

fields.headline: Inspectors satisfied with cooperation on checking dumps
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The report on the inspection of IRA weapons dumps by Martti Ahtisaari and Cyril Ramaphosa:
fields.body:
The report on the inspection of IRA weapons dumps by Martti Ahtisaari and Cyril Ramaphosa:

This report is being issued following our appointment as arms inspectors on May 6, 2000, and our first inspection of IRA weapons dumps.

We accepted our appointment on the basis of terms of reference set out in a joint statement issued by the Prime Minister and the Taoiseach and the statement by the leadership of the IRA on May 6, 2000.

In its statement of May 6, the IRA leadership pledged to initiate a process that will completely and verifiably put IRA arms beyond use in the context of the statement made by the two governments on May 5, 2000.

Besides undertaking to resume contact with the Independent International Commission on Decommissioning (IICD), the IRA leadership agreed to put in place within weeks a confidence-building measure to confirm that their weapons remain secure.

We see our mandate as being the inspection of the contents of a number of IRA arms dumps, reporting to the IICD that we have done so, and re-inspecting these dumps regularly to ensure that the weapons have remained secure.

In preparing for the first inspection visit, we were briefed by the British prime minister, the Irish foreign minister, the British secretary of state and the commissioners of the IICD.

We also consulted most of the parties that have endorsed the Good Friday agreement. In addition, we consulted independent specialists in the field of arms control, who had previously participated in arms inspections elsewhere and had expertise in the area of verification.

The purpose of these consultations was to help us develop credible methods for inspection and verification.

We have now carried out our first inspection. We inspected a number of arms dumps. The arms dumps held a substantial amount of military material, including explosives and related equipment, as well as weapons and other material.

We observed that the weapons and explosives were safely and adequately stored. We have ensured that the weapons and explosives can not be used without our detection.

We are satisfied with the cooperation extended to us by the IRA to ensure a credible and verifiable inspection. All our requests were satisfactorily met.

We plan to re-inspect the arms dumps on a regular basis to ensure that the weapons have remained secure.

The process that led to the first inspection visit and the way in which it was carried out makes us believe that this is a genuine effort by the IRA to advance the peace process.

The IRA statement:

On May 6 the leadership of the IRA announced an unprecedented initiative which had the effect of breaking the impasse at that time in the peace process.

In our statements we made it clear that our initiative was in the context of a series of commitments made by the two governments, especially the British government.

We announced that we would:

 Resume contact with the IICD (Independent International Commission on Decommissioning), and

 Put in place a confidence building measure.

We now wish to confirm that we have re-established contact with the IICD, and that a number of arms dumps have been examined by the two agreed parties.

These dumps contained a substantial amount of material including weapons, explosives and other equipment.

The leadership of the IRA have consistently sought to enhance the peace process. This initiative demonstrates once more our commitment to securing a just and lasting peace.

fields.headline: Hounded out
fields.standfirst:
Scottish row over hunting job losses

The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: A row has erupted over a new report which claims only around 300 full-time jobs would be lost if Scotland adopts a fox hunting ban.
fields.body:
A row has erupted over a new report which claims only around 300 full-time jobs would be lost if Scotland adopts a fox hunting ban.

The study, commissioned by the Scottish executive, said 20 jobs would be lost directly, with the remainder going in associated activities.

Scotland has 10 mounted hunts, which kill an average of 543 foxes a year. A private member's bill to ban hunting is at its first stage in the Scottish parliament.

Anti-hunt activists, who have claimed the report was biased against them, said that in this respect the results were encouraging. Les Ward, of Advocates for Animals, said: "The hunters' deceit has been exposed. They claimed that between 3,000 and 14,000 jobs would be lost as the result of a ban."

The report, by the Macaulay Land Use Research Institute, said income to Scottish businesses from the 10 mounted hunts would fall by £260,000 and the impact beyond the hunting fraternity would be small. However, Doug Ross, of the Scottish Countryside Alliance, said a hunting ban would be disastrous for rural Scotland.

"We hope the Scottish executive will devote the same energy to defending a rural minority as it did with a lifestyle minority and section 28," he said. "Scottish hunting is very much perceived as a pest control service. It is very, very classless."

Labour SMP Mike Watson, a sponsor of the bill, said it boiled down to a non-economic issue - that hunting animals for pleasure did not belong in the 21st century and should be banned.

Les Ward, of Advocates for Animals, said: "The hunters' deceit has been exposed. They claimed that between 3,000 and 14,000 jobs would be lost as the result of a ban." The report, by the Macaulay Land Use Research Institute, said income to Scottish businesses from the 10 mounted hunts would fall by £260,000 and the impact beyond the hunting fraternity would be small. However, Doug Ross, of the Scottish Countryside Alliance, said a hunting ban would be disastrous for rural Scotland. "We hope the Scottish executive will devote the same energy to defending a rural minority as it did with a lifestyle minority and section 28," he said. "Scottish hunting is very much perceived as a pest control service. It is very, very classless." Labour SMP Mike Watson, a sponsor of the bill, said it boiled down to a non-economic issue - that hunting animals for pleasure did not belong in the 21st century and should be banned.

webTitle: Firms say 2m not up to the job

fields.headline: Firms say 2m not up to the job
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: One in four employers are unable to fill vacancies because applicants lack basic skills, according to research for the government published today.
fields.body:
One in four employers are unable to fill vacancies because applicants lack basic skills, according to research for the government published today.

Low-skilled adults in particular must be given a second chance to retrain and acquire necessary qualifications to equip them for jobs in the burgeoning computer and hi-tech industry, it says. At the same time more youngsters should be encouraged to develop the mathematical skills demanded by businesses.

The research forms the basis of the final report from the national skills task force, set up two years ago to advise the government on the mismatches in supply and demand of skills to the economy. David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, will respond to the report today.

Among its findings, obtained through a telephone survey of 23,000 employers and face-to-face interviews with 4,000 bosses, respondents claimed almost 2m of their staff were not fully proficient to do their jobs. Seven million adults - one in five - are considered functionally illiterate.

The jobs most affected by skill shortages are those in craft and technical areas.

"Higher levels of skill benefit the individual, the firm and the economy," the report says. Around half the employers anticipated "commercial problems would arise in the next two or three years as a result of shortfalls in the skills of existing employees".The research focuses on how much employers value numeracy skills, yet only 45% of youngsters gain a GCSE grade C in maths, 10% of this group passes A-level maths and 1% of graduates gain a maths degree.

The report says young adults with GCSE maths can earn 10% more than their counterparts without it. In addition, there is only a limited pool of young people with a good level of ability in a "hard" science such as physics.

The qualifications level of the workforce has risen significantly over the past 20 years, fuelled mainly by higher qualifications gained by new entrants to the labour market. The proportion of young people gaining five or more GCSEs, at least two A levels, and acquiring degrees have all risen substantially since the late 1980s. But the growth has been largely in academic qualifications rather than in vocational certificates.

There has been little growth in the qualification levels of the established adult workforce, who have failed to take advantage of adult education courses or other forms of training to boost their skills.

The findings highlight the low level of attainment in vocational qualifications in Britain compared with European neighbours. Germany, for example, has three times the proportion of its workforce holding a vocational qualification at level three.

The report identified continuing strong demand for specialist information and communications technology skills, with the IT sector said to need to recruit more than half a million people in the next 10 years.

Chris Humphries, chairman of the national skills task force and director general of the British Chambers of Commerce, said: "Skill shortages are impacting heavily on firms' abilities to compete, and act as a drain on business productivity. We need a series of new measures to ensure we develop a high skill, high value added economy."

webTitle: 38 seconds - that really is a quick buck

fields.headline: 38 seconds - that really is a quick buck
fields.trailText: After the disgrace of Mike Tyson's boxing "match" on Saturday night (Glasgow counts the cost of controversy after Tyson ends fight in 38 seconds, June 26), I wonder how much longer the man will be given a licence to continue changing boxing from a sport into a freak show. I almost feel indignant that he has the nerve to compare himself to the likes of Sonny Liston after the match.
fields.body:
After the disgrace of Mike Tyson's boxing "match" on Saturday night (Glasgow counts the cost of controversy after Tyson ends fight in 38 seconds, June 26), I wonder how much longer the man will be given a licence to continue changing boxing from a sport into a freak show. I almost feel indignant that he has the nerve to compare himself to the likes of Sonny Liston after the match.

But the question remains: who sanctioned or arranged this fight? In footballing terms, it was Manchester United versus the Women's Institute second eleven.

Perhaps the time has come to stop focusing our anger on Tyson and recognise that the whole structure of boxing is inept and quite happy to use Tyson's position to make a quick buck. The sport has become a farce, and the empty seats at Hampden are testimony to boxing's rapidly declining credibility. The only way forward is for the top boxers (and that excludes Tyson) to form their own federation, owned collectively, with a realistic grading system.


Steve Iafrati
Smethwick, West Midlands
s.a.iafrati@wlv.ac.uk

Mike Tyson's post-fight outburst wasn't all that different from the stream Ali used to gush after bouts, declaring his beauty and "I am the greatest and I can whup any man alive". It's naive to think Tyson's crude attempt was anything more than an effort to build interest in his future fights. It's also silly of people who attended the fight to whinge about the brevity of the bout. Fights lasting less than a minute aren't all that rare in the heavyweight division and have included some famous encounters. You take your chances going to the fights, especially to see the heavies.


Ronald R Odgers
Hove, East Sussex
ronald.odgers@talk21.com

One can only hope that Jack Straw at long last feels as profoundly humiliated and ashamed at letting an unbridled and deeply offensive thug called Mike Tyson into this country as he did over letting a few chair-throwing football ninnies out. If not this is political contrariness gone bad.


Geraldine Monk
Sheffield

fields.headline: Billy's lesson for the yobs
fields.trailText: Billy Bragg's proposition that education will transform the eurosceptic psyche of British hooligans hits the nail on the head (Time to move on, boys, June 24).
fields.body:
Billy Bragg's proposition that education will transform the eurosceptic psyche of British hooligans hits the nail on the head (Time to move on, boys, June 24). We must, however, pick educational solutions that work. Sentence football louts to two to five years European community service, working in German hospitals, French old people's homes or Dutch asylums. This will provide the sort of learning experience that can never be achieved in a classroom.

While we're about it, how about sentencing Jörg Haider and William Hague to similar educational experiences in each other's country?

Chris Coverdale
London

 Billy Bragg highlights the important role of education in countering the hooligan mindset that continues to draw on the myth of Britain "standing alone" during the second world war. The new subject area of education for citizenship, introduced in English schools from September, will be an essential vehicle for addressing this issue in schools.

For example, it requires the study of UK relations with the EU, the Commonwealth and UN; the origins and implications of the diverse national, regional, religious and ethnic identities in the UK; and the need for mutual respect and understanding. What is now needed is the support and resources necessary for schools to successfully plan and deliver this work.

While in Belgium or Holland the hooligans might have chanted "if it wasn't for the English, you'd be Krauts", its instructive to note that without the contribution of the 4m Commonwealth servicemen to the British war effort in 1939-45, this letter might well have been be written in German.

Steve Brace
Commonwealth Institute, London

 I agree with Billy Bragg that education plays an important role in enabling "young people to understand... history and culture". However his comments about contemporary history teaching are ill-informed. Teachers do not "fail to enlighten" students about the consequences of the past.

This term my Year 8 classes have been studying Gandhi's non-violent protests again British control of India. This has included discussing the British army's role in the massacre at Amritsar, British control of the salt industry and the army's violent response to protests at the Dharasana salt works.

Part of the coursework for my GCSE humanities group is a comparative study of the Nazis' actions in the 30s and 40s and neo-Nazi groups in Britain, Europe and the US now. Year 9 will shortly be studying the second world war with a focus on the impact on women's lives, not using "history books which concentrate on Spitfires and Hurricanes".

My school is hardly unusual in this respect. "Blame the teachers" is a Murdoch line, Billy, and you should know better.

Louise Clarke
Brighton louclarke@cwcom.net

 Billy Bragg is right to assert that education is central to any move away from the traditional English xenophobic mindset. Let's not forget, however, the efforts of the Thatcher governments which introduced legislation expressly to de-politicise the young.

Outlawing politics and social studies graduates from teaching degrees and politics from the curriculums of secondary schools has resulted in a generation lacking political knowledge or interest. Any "political education" is likely, therefore, to be the result of a diet of jingoistic tabloid headlines and footballers' pronouncements. It's certainly one aspect of Thatcherism which was 100% successful.

D Mitchell
Sheffield Dougie1@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Undercover
fields.standfirst: A case of police ingratitude
fields.trailText: Kent police, no slouches when it comes to briefing the press, have fallen out with the BBC over Undercover. That jack-of-all-charges "wasting police time" has even been mentioned. The police say they found no evidence that serious offences were committed by staff at the care home where reporter Donal MacIntyre worked, using a hidden camera. The police did caution two people on the basis of evidence supplied by the BBC but now regret the home was closed - a decision taken by their colleagues in Kent county council's social services department after the programme was shown.
fields.body:
Kent police, no slouches when it comes to briefing the press, have fallen out with the BBC over Undercover. That jack-of-all-charges "wasting police time" has even been mentioned. The police say they found no evidence that serious offences were committed by staff at the care home where reporter Donal MacIntyre worked, using a hidden camera. The police did caution two people on the basis of evidence supplied by the BBC but now regret the home was closed - a decision taken by their colleagues in Kent county council's social services department after the programme was shown.

This looks like a case of ingratitude. Police efforts to track trouble-makers and racists masquerading as football supporters benefited from Mr MacIntyre's efforts. If anyone can be held responsible for triggering a police inquiry it must be the county council. The police threat to secure damages from the BBC is not only intimidatory, it ignores the chain of statutory responsibility. The BBC, rightly, points out it made no criminal allegations. Its report illustrated a "culture of neglect", which could be said to be proven; the home's matron admitted there were incidents of abuse of residents.

Television documentary producers walk a fine line. Subjects can be rebarbative. To make them entertaining, within the conventions of the medium, film and video are clipped and condensed. Programmes get made in moral monochrome; reality is often greyer. Yet too little of Mr MacIntyre's type of investigation is done. The media, newspapers included, do not do enough getting under the skin of recalcitrant institutions, painfully acquiring the knowledge that only comes with time. Undercover came of a slim but brilliant pedigree. Some of the mud slung at it in the past few days will stick. If executives now reconsider the large investment this reporting demands, Kent police's would-be exposé of the exposers will have malign effect.

fields.headline: Member's disclosure
fields.trailText: We suffered a burglary a few nights ago and among the items stolen was my MCC membership pass.
fields.body:
We suffered a burglary a few nights ago and among the items stolen was my MCC membership pass. When I told my mother that the thief would be able to watch England play the West Indies at Lord's this week she replied, "Serves him bloody right".

Christopher Douglas
Longtown, Herefordshire

 If M Davis (Letters, June 24), has a taste for exotic out of season vegetables that have to be kept at great cost in cold storage for several months he must expect to pay the price. If he could supress his desire for parsnips he could enjoy Cornish new potatos, English tomatoes or best Cheddar strawberries and still stay warm next winter.

Michael Follett
Bristol village_greens@hotmail.com

 "Sanctimonious" (Letters, June 26) is a good example of fine words butter no parsnips. Restore the link between pensions and average earnings and we will burn what we bloody like.

Myrna Shaw
Hackney Pensioners' Convention

 A headline on page 7 informs us: Joining euro "would double growth and bring US-style affluence" (June 26). On page 8 we are told that "only Russia and the US in the industrialised world have higher rates of child poverty". That's a use of the word affluence I haven't come across before.

Alan Gray
Brighton AlanStPaul@aol.com

 If the Zimbabwean people disappoint President Mugabe by voting for the opposition (Mugabe to defy election verdict, June 26), then, with the extensive powers he has, could he not do as Berthold Brecht suggested and simply dissolve the people and elect a new one?

Nigel Baldwin
Portsmouth N.Baldwin@btinternet.com

fields.headline: We're taxed at source
fields.trailText: On page 3 of yesterday's issue (Charmer who woos Labour donors, June 26), for some reason headed "news", there appear the following statements in an article by your journalists on Lord Levy (whom I have never met):
fields.body:
On page 3 of yesterday's issue (Charmer who woos Labour donors, June 26), for some reason headed "news", there appear the following statements in an article by your journalists on Lord Levy (whom I have never met):

1. "one wealthy business man ... suspected ..."

2. "... admitted a Labour business adviser"

3. "... said a senior Labour figure"

4. "Legend also has it ..."

5. "Questions are being asked about ..."

6. "Sources in Whitehall and Damascus maintain ..."

7. "A friend of the peer maintains ..."

8. "Some ambassadors were rash enough to ..."

9. "There are repeated reports that ..."

10. "A diplomat asked ..."

11. "Those who know [him] best, however, insist ..."

I have rarely read such an informative, probative and persuasive article.

Lord Wigoder QC
House of Lords

 The real reason for the Sunday Times attacking Lord Levy (Blair backs millionaire in tax row, June 26) must surely be that they were miffed at someone seeming to have found a more efficient way of minimising their tax liability than Rupert Murdoch.

If Murdoch's companies coughed up taxes on their UK operations as readily as Lord Levy seems to have done in the past then the Sunday Times's stance might not be so hypocritical.

Graham Townsend
Reading

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: An article headed Kit off for the girls by Tom Dewe Matthews in the Friday Review, April 24, 1998, relied heavily in one section on material from an article by Jack Barth published earlier in the American edition of Premiere magazine. Although the Guardian article used quotations obtained exclusively by Mr Barth and appropriated phrases of his, no acknowledgment was made to him or to Premiere magazine. Mr Dewe Matthews is paying the fee he received from the Guardian to Mr Barth.
fields.body:
An article headed Kit off for the girls by Tom Dewe Matthews in the Friday Review, April 24, 1998, relied heavily in one section on material from an article by Jack Barth published earlier in the American edition of Premiere magazine. Although the Guardian article used quotations obtained exclusively by Mr Barth and appropriated phrases of his, no acknowledgment was made to him or to Premiere magazine. Mr Dewe Matthews is paying the fee he received from the Guardian to Mr Barth.

In a report headed Woman who killed disabled sons is freed, page 6, June 24, we described James Lowe as the director of social services on the Isle of Wight. The director is, in fact, Charles Waddacor. Mr Lowe is a senior manager with the Isle of Wight social services directorate. Apologies to both. White appeared for Wight in an early edition but was corrected for later editions.

At the end of our piece about the Ystwyth valley, pages 10 and 11, Travel, June 24, we recommended a book, A Welsh House and its Family: The Vaughans of Trawsgoed, by Gerald Morgan. Mr Morgan has pointed out that the accompanying article included a number of mistakes from which a reading of his book should have saved us. Among these were our statement that the Vaughans were the largest landowners in Cardiganshire from the 14th to the 20th centuries (that should have been the 17th to 20th centuries); that the Vaughans never learned Welsh (they were a Welsh-speaking family until the 18th century); that their former home was taken over by the University of Wales (it never was); that it became a Grassland Research Station (it did not: it was bought by the government in 1947 and became the Welsh headquarters of the Agricultural Development and Advisory Service). Part of the farmland originally belonging to Trawsgoed (but not the mansion itself) is now run by IGER (Institute for Grassland and Environmental Research). Apologies for all that.

A letter from Richard Heller, page 19, yesterday, appeared with "Through referendums and devolved elections..." changed to "developed elections". Apologies.

In our television review, page 22, G2, yesterday, we referred to Dominic Matham. The correct name of the actor is Dominic Mafham. He did not play the part of the handyman in Up Rising, ITV. That was Richard Coyle.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Surface mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9897. Email: reader@theguardian.com

webTitle: Making a packet on the patent for life

fields.headline: Making a packet on the patent for life
fields.trailText: It is odd that Craig Venter should "be vilified by the scientific fraternity for allegedly filing more than 20,000 provisional patents on human genes" (Who owns the genome, G2, June 26), and even odder that Bill Clinton and Tony Blair made their joint appeal for the human genome to be freely available.
fields.body:
It is odd that Craig Venter should "be vilified by the scientific fraternity for allegedly filing more than 20,000 provisional patents on human genes" (Who owns the genome, G2, June 26), and even odder that Bill Clinton and Tony Blair made their joint appeal for the human genome to be freely available.

We can expect commercial companies to squeeze every last ounce of profit out of a situation, however immoral their behaviour seems to ordinary people, as long as their activity is within the law.

It is governments who lay down the legal framework within which those commercial companies operate. If the law allows the human genome to be patented then it clearly has fundamental flaws, and it is only the likes of Clinton and Blair who have it in their power to change it. Yet they do nothing but wring their hands and make empty appeals.

Tom Beaton
Richmond, Surrey

 I am puzzled by the assumption that the genome can be patented. The third paragraph on page 9 of the Patent Office's booklet Patent Protection is headed: Excluded inventions. It states. "No matter how ingenious, unusual or beneficial an idea may be, an invention is not patentable if it is merely a discovery, scientific theory or mathematical method".

Stephen Taylor
Walsall DSAWTaylor@cs.com

fields.headline: Pay round
fields.trailText: A £2m bonus for dome staff (Report, June 26)? It certainly is not needed for the stress of coping with increased numbers of visitors or the financial success of the project.
fields.body:
A £2m bonus for dome staff (Report, June 26)? It certainly is not needed for the stress of coping with increased numbers of visitors or the financial success of the project. Is it to keep staff quiet on the ineptness of the whole operation? As the dome is losing money, presumably these bonuses are paid for by the taxpayer. This sets a tidy precedent for government when it comes to the health and education sectors.

Richard Lorch
London

 Spokesman: "The figures quoted are ridiculously over-hyped. Everyone who has worked on this project has worked between two and three times the hours they were paid for". Just like teachers then...

Irene Yates
Redditch

 Which performance does the bonus relate to? A Comedy of Errors?

Keith Conlon
London

fields.headline: Agonies of fertility treatment
fields.standfirst: Emotional price paid by women outweighs physical discomfort
fields.trailText: The scale of emotional suffering for couples undergoing fertility treatment is vastly underestimated, and can damage marriages and ruin friendships, a conference on fertility at Bologna in Italy heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The scale of emotional suffering for couples undergoing fertility treatment is vastly underestimated, and can damage marriages and ruin friendships, a conference on fertility at Bologna in Italy heard yesterday.

Elizabeth Kopitzke, from the University of Kentucky college of medicine, said that the physical discomfort caused by treatments faded into insignificance compared with the emotional agonies involved. "Becoming a parent is part of one's core identity. For those who can't have children, life is diminished; they lose their link with the future," she said.

"It becomes difficult to mobilise action in the present and life seems to be on hold. Their whole identity is disrupted and they can't seem to visualise themselves in the future. We scientists and doctors may not be able to measure these experiences in our studies and questionnaires, but it doesn't mean they don't exist."

Everyday life was distorted. The children of friends and family served as a painful reminder of a couple's infertility, while the announcement of a colleague's pregnancy could fill them with despair - making some women loathe going to work for fear of an unexpected announcement.

"Social relationships are dramatically affected by infertility. Things people used to enjoy now fill them with dread." Family get-togethers and even trips to shopping centres full of mothers with pushchairs could be a source of pain. Many women became what Dr Kopitzke called "super copers" - making a super human effort to hide their distress. "Constant efforts to regulate these emotions may take a significant toll," she said.

"We don't know what the long-term effects may be, but we do know from studies that these acts of self control and volition deplete 'psychic energy', which is an important self-resource, particularly when patients feel they have no personal control over their lives. There is bound to be a cost for these frequently stoic 'super copers'."

While 20% of women said they suffered physical discomfort during fertility treatment, 80% admitted it caused them emotional distress. Dr Kopitzke conducted a survey of 45 women who came to her clinic, and found half of them were clinically depressed. She believed the emotional toll of infertility was higher than most research had shown.

"We know that people who are more distressed are less likely to participate in studies. This can skew results and show that people are less distressed than they really are."

There came a point when clinicians should stop putting infertile couples through more and more hoops. They needed to consider the wider view.

"As the momentum on patients' emotional and financial investment increases, it gets more and more difficult to make the decision to stop," she said. "In our quest to help people, we can forget to help them to stop."

fields.headline: Womb surgery breakthrough
fields.trailText: A new keyhole surgery technique for operations on the womb could drastically reduce the numbers of women having to undergo hysterectomies, according to doctors in the Netherlands.
fields.body:
A new keyhole surgery technique for operations on the womb could drastically reduce the numbers of women having to undergo hysterectomies, according to doctors in the Netherlands.

The keyhole method is hard to learn and carry out. Many doctors prefer to recommend a hysterectomy rather than attempt to remove the fibroids and polyps that afflict many of the 10% of women who have menstrual disorders.

At the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology conference in Bologna yesterday, Mark Emanuel from Spaarne Hospital, Haarlem, described a new device which would speed up and simplify such operations.

It consists of a rotating surgical blade inside a specially-designed endoscope - a thin tube set with a tiny camera which allows the surgeon to see inside the womb.

The unwanted tissue is sucked into the tube and cut away.

The current method of keyhole surgery used for the womb is called resectoscopy. The endoscope goes in through the cervix, but uses a wire loop electrode and electrical current to remove tissue.

There are potentially dangerous side-effects, such as burns or damage from the special liquids that have to be used which can enter blood vessels and upset the balance of electrolytes in the blood.

There have been cases of women who have sued for compensation after being left paralysed or blind.

So far, 15 patients have been treated in the Netherlands using the new technique with no side effects.

"The most important aspect of the new method is its simplicity," said Dr Emanuel yesterday. "Resectoscopy is effective but involves a large number of steps, is tiring, difficult to learn and to become expert at. Many doctors are reluctant to use it, preferring hysterectomies. So there is a need for an alternative technique.

"The shaver's safety and easiness of use will, hopefully, increase the number of gynaecologists who will use hysteroscopic methods.

"This means that the number of patients who will benefit from the advantages of minimal access surgery instead of undergoing unnecessary hysterectomies should also increase."

The technique halves the operating time and allows safe saline solutions to be used to wash out the uterus instead of the riskier solutions needed when electrodes are used, he said.

Dr Emanuel said he is now working on the development of blades to enable the surgeon to remove the entire lining of the womb where necessary.

He wants to make the device smaller so that women can ultimately have their operations performed under local anaesthetic as day surgery.

webTitle: Big industry detects big dollars on the net

fields.headline: Big industry detects big dollars on the net
fields.standfirst:
Business to business exchanges could become online order books for manufacturers

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Around 40% of American car buyers use the internet to help make their choice, but only around 3% order online. America's carmakers and many of their suppliers would like the number who buy via the net to increase dramatically, knocking their costs for six.
fields.body:
Around 40% of American car buyers use the internet to help make their choice, but only around 3% order online. America's carmakers and many of their suppliers would like the number who buy via the net to increase dramatically, knocking their costs for six.

Central to the strategy is Covisint - an online partnership between America's big three carmakers - General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler plus Renault-Nissan. The idea came out of the manufacturers' desire to use the net to order from suppliers. Initially the carmakers were each going their own way - until some suppliers complained about having to deal with each separately.

Covisint will operate not just by running the transactions between the manufacturers and their suppliers, but also between the suppliers and their suppliers - ideally, all the way back down the supply chain to the raw materials.

'Impact on costs'

Effectively a business to business - or B2B - exchange, Covisint would make a turn on every deal. That, according to Frank McKulka, president of BASF Corporation, part of the world's biggest chemicals company, which is mulling over whether to sign up, "is where the big dollars are".

The automotive industry is not the only one looking at the B2B concept. Industries from aerospace to the utilities are getting in on the act. Last week, Anglo-Dutch group Corus announced that it was linking up with three rival European steelmakers - Thyssen Krupp, Usinor and Arbed - to set up an e-commerce marketplace. Yesterday Bayer, the German chemicals and pharmaceuticals group, said it plans an online marketplace for chemicals.

The impetus may come from buyers, as in the US motorindustry, from suppliers or from "market makers" - third party firms offering a service linking buyers and sellers in a single industry.

Analysts at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter argue that B2B e-commerce is "the latest step in the evolution of the internet as a trading platform". In a detailed study of the potential impact on a broad range of European industries they argue that, while the short term impact may be limited, B2B is likely to have "a potentially very significant impact on procurement costs and work flows in the medium term".

Work flows are a crucial element for the motor industry. If buyers were to order over the net and manufacturers could deliver within a time scale, the customer would accept. If that happened, Covisint would not only be a B2B system, it would also become a huge forward order book for the industry.

According to Mr McKulka, the US makes 17m to 18m cars a year. At any time about 3m can be in lots waiting to be sold - inventory against expected demand. At $20,000 a vehicle that comes to $60bn (£40bn). Cut out that "idle" inventory and not only is the customer satisfied but the industry becomes more profitable. According to some calculations the system could save up to $3,560 on a $20,000 car, although Mr McKulka reckons just under half that might be closer to the mark.

So why aren't the suppliers queueing to sign up? For some, like BASF Corp, which has a raft of businesses unconnected with the car industry, it is a question of which bits of which operations are to be brought under which umbrella. Its German parent company, for example, is part of a B2B exchange in the chemicals and thermo-plastics industries. Others are suspicious that this is just another wheeze by car manufacturers to squeeze suppliers.

Regulatory hurdles

There are regulatory hurdles, too. The US federal trade commission is showing interest in Covisint. As one Detroit insider put it: "When any of the big players in the motor industry mentions co-operation the trust-busters sit up and take notice."

It is not only the motor industry that is coming under the regulatory spotlight in the American B2B market. The Senate's commerce committee plans to assess the implications of the exchange planned by the airline industry. The department of justice, fresh from its success against Microsoft, is showing interest in the B2B exchanges too.

The European commission has yet to have found a B2B project referred to it but the indications are that, while it accepts there are big savings to be made, it will look hard at any competition issues it believes are being raised.

But if the B2B companies can convince regulators that they are promoting, not stifling competition, the early players are likely to steal a march on their rivals.

According to Morgan Stanley, "once some of these exchanges actually start operating... early participants have the opportunity to improve their competitive edge significantly over slower moving competitors in terms of procurement cost savings through improved visibility on price and product availability".

fields.headline: No: 1664
fields.standfirst: Hans Kung
fields.trailText: Hans Kung
fields.body:
Appearance:
Freeze-dried Al Gore.

Is that a rug he's wearing?
Of course not, he's a 72-year-old rogue Catholic theologian, and as such has no time for earthly vanity.

Ooh. Just how rogue is he?
Swiss-born Kung thinks that hell doesn't exist, priests should get married, birth control is good, and the Pope ain't infallible. An enraged Vatican banned him from giving Mass in 1979, amid heated controversy.

Everybody was Kung view fighting?
Indeed. It was a little bit frightening.

Cool. He sounds very modernising, very Third Way.
Funny you should say that. Postmodern pietist Kung is also something of a spiritual guru to Tony Blair. Our glorious leader is going to speak at Kung's global ethics foundation conference in Tubingen on Friday.

Global Ethics Foundation, huh? Sounds impressive.
Well, Kung is good mates with Henry Kissinger, so take that with a pinch of salt.

Wait a minute. Isn't our Tony an Anglican?
Yes, but he enjoyed Kung's book, On Being a Christian, and Cherie's a Catholic. We're nothing if not inclusive in New Labour.

Does Kung have any other famous political friends?
Helmut Schmidt, Jimmy Carter and Lord Callaghan all have the turbulent priest's ear.

He's on the side of the angels, then?
Well, Kung despises "Church conservatism", and thinks Catholics, Muslims, Protestants and other faiths should all work together globally.

So we should welcome asylum-seekers of all creeds?
Steady on. Kung thundered recently that "lazy" people shouldn't be able to rely on state handouts for a living.

Eh? What about "Give us this day our daily bread"?
Catholicism's equivalent of Clause 4. Our revolutionary leaders must defeat the forces of old-fashioned idealism.

Do say:
"Kung is the new Luther. (And we don't mean Vandross.)"

Don't say:
"What's the Third Way between salvation and damnation?"

webTitle: London dearest capital city in EU

fields.headline: London dearest capital city in EU
fields.trailText: Keeping a London roof over your head costs a fortune, the price of a trip on public transport empties your wallet and, in the first week of Wimbledon, the cost of a tennis ball in the capital is revealed to be three times higher than in New York.
fields.body:
Keeping a London roof over your head costs a fortune, the price of a trip on public transport empties your wallet and, in the first week of Wimbledon, the cost of a tennis ball in the capital is revealed to be three times higher than in New York.

According to a survey published yesterday, Londoners are in the unenviable position of living in the most expensive city in the European Union and the 10th most costly in the world.

Even the price of a phone call to a bank to plead for an overdraft is three times more expensive in London than in Rome.

And it's not just London: Birmingham and Glasgow are pricier than Berlin and Toronto, according to the annual cost-of-living rankings compiled by the management consultants William M Mercer.

For one month's rent of a furnished three-bedroom house in Chelsea, you can rent two of the same in a good area of New York and four of the same in Lisbon.

London has steamed 30 places ahead of Paris on the world scale, with rents, jeans and toothpaste double the price of their equivalents in the French capital.

The survey compared the cost of more than 200 items and services across 146 countries, including petrol, full-time maid service, a box of 40 tampons, and a litre tub of vanilla ice cream.

Rehan Mustafa, who compiled the research, said London topped the EU because of the strength of the pound, the weakness of the euro, and very high costs for everyday goods.

The survey aims to help international firms decide allowances for expatriate workers. And, with the cost of a taxi from Heathrow to the centre of London costing three times the Berlin equivalent, it may raise concerns that London is pricing itself out of the market as a European business base.

A spokesman for the London Chamber of Commerce said that the capital's ranking was cause for concern. "The cost of living in London is something that international businesses are complaining about.

"This month, we surveyed 100 foreign banks in the capital and found that expense was a worry for them.

"About 92% said commercial property prices in London were higher than in other European financial centres. We have to keep our eye on this if we want to compete."

Tess Sullivan, a senior researcher at Which? magazine, was not surprised at London's ranking.

"This is the second time in six months that London has been voted the most expensive city in the EU.

"It came seventh in the world in a similar survey by the Economist intelligence unit in January."

She added: "I don't like to use the term rip-off Britain, but the British are paying more than most other European countries for branded clothing and other goods. There does not seem to be a logical reason. Some people blame transport costs, VAT and high shop rents. But I am not convinced.

"Manufacturers are benefiting and consumers are losing out."

But Londoners might spare a thought for the residents of Tokyo which topped the list for the second year running.

Rent costs in the Japanese capital are twice those of London, business suits for men and women cost three times their London equivalents, and a 500g pack of butter will set you back £5.31.

At the opposite end of the scale, the capital of Ecuador, Quito, has usurped Harare in Zimbabwe to become the least expensive city in the world.

There, for the price of one taxi ride in London, you can buy 225 litres of petrol.

Counting the cost around the world

Berlin

Berlin certainly seems cheap - until you come to live in the city.

Food and drink are generally less expensive than in London, and you can get a decent meal for much less. A two-course lunch for two with wine and coffee at one of the city's more fashionable haunts costs £56.

The snag is accommodation. Quality flats are a rarity - all the more so with thousands of officials and others pouring into the new capital from Bonn. In the trendy, but still only partly gentrified, east Berlin district of Mitte a new two-bedroom flat could easily cost £1,300 a month.
John Hooper

New York

Low prices in the stores are balanced by astronomical rents. You might have to find upwards of £1,875 a month for a modest apartment in the fashionable West Village, though perhaps someone in the rent-stabilised space directly below is paying £330.

A trip to see Cabaret on Broadway will set you back £47, while a cinema seat is an average £6.

You may well be wearing a shirt you had dry-cleaned for 95p and a pair of Levis you picked up for £25, though you may want something smarter to go to one of the city's leading restaurants, such as Le Cirque 2000 where the prix fixe dinner is £31.

But Alain Ducasse's restaurant at the Essex House on Central Park South comes with a tab of £94 a head before wine or coffee, and a tip of 15% to 20% is expected. A subway ride costs 95p to anywhere on the system.
Mike Ellison

Paris

Most things seem cheaper in Paris than in London, starting with accommodation: many Parisians pay per month what Londoners expect to pay per week.

Transport is good value at £5.50 for a carnet of 10 metro or bus tickets. Supermarket shopping is no more expensive than Tesco or Sainsbury's.

But the biggest difference, the one that comes as a serious shock to the wallet on every trip back to London, is in eating out. It is still perfectly possible in Paris to enjoy a superbly cooked three-course meal, including wine, for £20-£25 a head. Most restaurants have a set menu for £18-£20.
Jon Henley

Tokyo

Sky-high prices hit their peak in the Ginza area of Tokyo, where a coffee can set you back £5.60. When it comes to the cinema, a ticket is £11.25 - no matter how old and cramped the facilities.

If you feel like extending your visit, a modest two-bedroom apartment 30 minutes from central Tokyo starts at £187,000.

The stay in hospital while having a baby averages at £1,875, while on the other hand a "love hotel" charges £25 for two hours.

A packet of 20 cigarettes costs £1.50 to £1.75, and £3.75 will get you a filling and warming lunch of noodles or "curry-rice".

Electrical products are 10% to 20% less expensive than in London, as well as being a year ahead in technology. For some reason, paper products are also very reasonable. A packet of five boxes of tissues costs just £1.87 and many companies give out free packets as advertising.
Jonathan Watts

Delhi

Delhi is cheap - though not as cheap as you might expect. A reasonable two-bedroom flat in central Delhi costs £640 a month, but a prestigious colonial bungalow costs £2,200 plus. Hotels can be expensive, as much as £200 a night for a single room.

Wine (usually horrible) is £8 a bottle at least. Everything else is a bargain: £2 to go to the cinema (very hard to get a ticket, though); lunch for four at an air-conditioned Chinese restaurant costs £10. A cafe au lait, only available in top hotels, costs 45p.

Finally, clothes are good value: £11 for a man's silk shirt, £3 for a set of white kurta pyjamas. Even in India the pure pashmina of your dreams is going to dig a hole in your bank balance: expect to pay £159.
Luke Harding
fields.bodyText: Keeping a London roof over your head costs a fortune, the price of a trip on public transport empties your wallet and, in the first week of Wimbledon, the cost of a tennis ball in the capital is revealed to be three times higher than in New York. According to a survey published yesterday, Londoners are in the unenviable position of living in the most expensive city in the European Union and the 10th most costly in the world. Even the price of a phone call to a bank to plead for an overdraft is three times more expensive in London than in Rome. And it's not just London: Birmingham and Glasgow are pricier than Berlin and Toronto, according to the annual cost-of-living rankings compiled by the management consultants William M Mercer. For one month's rent of a furnished three-bedroom house in Chelsea, you can rent two of the same in a good area of New York and four of the same in Lisbon. London has steamed 30 places ahead of Paris on the world scale, with rents, jeans and toothpaste double the price of their equivalents in the French capital. The survey compared the cost of more than 200 items and services across 146 countries, including petrol, full-time maid service, a box of 40 tampons, and a litre tub of vanilla ice cream. Rehan Mustafa, who compiled the research, said London topped the EU because of the strength of the pound, the weakness of the euro, and very high costs for everyday goods. The survey aims to help international firms decide allowances for expatriate workers. And, with the cost of a taxi from Heathrow to the centre of London costing three times the Berlin equivalent, it may raise concerns that London is pricing itself out of the market as a European business base. A spokesman for the London Chamber of Commerce said that the capital's ranking was cause for concern. "The cost of living in London is something that international businesses are complaining about. "This month, we surveyed 100 foreign banks in the capital and found that expense was a worry for them. "About 92% said commercial property prices in London were higher than in other European financial centres. We have to keep our eye on this if we want to compete." Tess Sullivan, a senior researcher at Which? magazine, was not surprised at London's ranking. "This is the second time in six months that London has been voted the most expensive city in the EU. "It came seventh in the world in a similar survey by the Economist intelligence unit in January." She added: "I don't like to use the term rip-off Britain, but the British are paying more than most other European countries for branded clothing and other goods. There does not seem to be a logical reason. Some people blame transport costs, VAT and high shop rents. But I am not convinced. "Manufacturers are benefiting and consumers are losing out." But Londoners might spare a thought for the residents of Tokyo which topped the list for the second year running. Rent costs in the Japanese capital are twice those of London, business suits for men and women cost three times their London equivalents, and a 500g pack of butter will set you back £5.31. At the opposite end of the scale, the capital of Ecuador, Quito, has usurped Harare in Zimbabwe to become the least expensive city in the world. There, for the price of one taxi ride in London, you can buy 225 litres of petrol.
