webTitle: Kennedy call to scrap school tests and targets burden

fields.headline: Kennedy call to scrap school tests and targets burden
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Government targets obliging schools to monitor millions of separate performances measures should be scrapped, together with compulsory annual testing of pupils, the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, will say today.
fields.body:
Government targets obliging schools to monitor millions of separate performances measures should be scrapped, together with compulsory annual testing of pupils, the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, will say today.

Mr Kennedy will condemn Whitehall-set monitoring as a "shocking" bureaucratic burden on schools, and will propose the axeing of national monitoring measures, including Sats tests which measure pupils in maths, English and science and are used in the compilation of school league tables.

"Government targets assume a percentage of failure," Mr Kennedy will say. "I want to see an education policy where every child matters."

Since Labour took power in May 1997, a total of 4,585 targets has been set for schools, colleges and local education authorities, according to Lib Dem research. Targets are in turn broken down into 306,480,472 separate measures to be monitored, the party's study indicates.

Mr Kennedy, addressing local councillors at the Local Government Association annual conference, will propose that this huge number of performance measures should be replaced with a single statutory requirement for schools to develop an individual education plan accountable to parents, the local education authority and the schools inspectorate Ofsted.

Schools would no longer have to put pupils through national tests at seven, 11 and 14.

There have been reports of growing concern among parents over stress suffered by youngsters sitting the tests.

By attacking Whitehall interference in schools' running, Mr Kennedy will add to the mounting debate over how much freedom individual schools should be permitted. The government will be attacked on a second front at today's conference when Labour council leaders warn Tony Blair that he faces a widespread revolt if ministers remove education and social services functions from town hall control.

In a bitter attack on the government today, Sir Jeremy Beecham, leader of the Local Government Association - which represents England's big councils - will signal a big campaign against Downing Street's so-called "front line first" policy.

Sir Jeremy, a member of Labour's national executive who has traditionally been associated with the centre right of the party will tell the LGA's annual conference that transferring education and social care directly to schools and new trusts would be both "unworkable and in terms of local democracy completely unacceptable".

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with kd lang
fields.trailText: Getting personal with kd lang
fields.body:
Full Name:
Kathryn Dawn Lang

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why?
Yes, for security reasons, which means I can't tell you what it was.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why?
Never. Well, maybe to get into a bar when I was younger.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?
"Water in a thirsty world." Everyone's overly confident in personal ads, right?

What was the last illegal thing you did?
I broke the law riding my motorcycle in L.A.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?
The thing I'm most proud of that I did recently was to buy my Mom a brand new Volvo for her birthday. It's a kid's dream come true to be able to do that.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?
It's a toss up between Roy Orbison and Lyle Lovett.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?
kdl.

Has a critic ever made you cry?
Yes. On more than one occasion.

What would you advertise without a fee?
Vegetarianism.

What would you never advertise?
Meat.

What wakes you up screaming at 4 in the morning?
Garbage trucks in New York City.

What takes you to a "happy place"?
My dog.

 kd lang's album Invincible Summer is out on Monday (Warner Bros). She tours the UK from 3-12 October.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 As if Jack Cohen didn't do enough damage by siring Shirley Porter, the firm he founded has brought shame (look away, Jane Asher, look away) on the noble cake. Wicked, sexist Tesco now sells a £7.99 cake called "Miss Busty Boobs" (not even Ms, if you please)... a Victoria sponge with raspberry and, on its top, a pair of large breasts barely contained by a corset. A customer in Hammersmith (and what a shocking store that is: call those tomatoes?) receives only partial satisfaction from head office (of which more below), so we ring Melodie Isaacs in the press office. "They've been selling incredibly well," you mean like hot, er...?, "incredibly well. They're slightly cheeky, but not offensive." So you say, Melodie, but how would you like to be confronted by a walnut and date gateau entitled "Mr Waggling Winkle"? Head office is more conciliatory, the top man writing back to say, in view of her protests that it is offensive to women, they will in future stock it "on the top shelf". It's one way to keep Andrea Dworkin out I suppose, but really... top shelf cakes? Where will it end?

 At the Church House bookshop in Westminster, passersby are tempted by the "summer reading" window display. Prominently displayed among tomes on Lambeth Palace and the New Youth Bible is - yes, you guessed it - Pride and Perjury by Jonathan Aitken, positioned next to a plastic beach spade. How good to see Jonathan's spiritual rebirth going so well... and how much better still when the lying, cheating swine digs out that Arab hush money from wherever he moved it to after the Swiss bank, and pays us what he owes.

 Two long-term projects make no progress. The campaign to have Professor Stanley Unwin installed in Countdown's dictionary stalls when Richard Whitely again fails to call back, and a radical review of tactics seems imminent - as it does with alopecian Sun editor David Yelland. He too will not respond, in this case to faxes requesting a chat (his own suggested mode of contact) about journalistic etiquette when someone is clearly drunk at a party (you will recall recent snaps of Lord Frederick Windsor). David, you will know Joe Louis's dictum on the matter of running and hiding. Call today, there's a lamb, and spare us the inconvenience of having to attend the Yelland doorstep.

 I am sad to learn how low the relationship between Nos 10 and 11 Downing Street has sunk. Members of Mr Tony's entourage now refer to the chancellor not as "Gordon" or "the weirdo" or any other traditional appellation, but simply as "Cyclops". What a horrid reference (and they'd want a lecture about taste from me) to an eye lost through a genetic disorder. I've spent, ooh it must be minutes trying to think up some witty allegorical reference to the story of Odysseus escaping the Cyclops strapped to the undercarriage of a sheep. But I can't. So I say merely this: poor show.

 Stephen Glover is oddly amicable in the Spectator. In an item about parliamentary sketch writing, he praises the Independent's Simon Carr and confesses to an old friendship between them. However in an unironic rebuke to Mr Tony for giving Tina Brown only a CBE, Steve is not quite so honest. "Whatever you may think of her, she achieved a great deal at Vanity Fair and the New Yorker," he declares... but while it's enchanting to read Steve being so generous about a successful editor, it would be nice to know if this is down purely to his generous nature or whether the little thing the two had going at Oxford many years ago had anything to do with it.

 News of such blatant electoral malpractice in Zimbabwe is very disturbing. It's kind of Mr Tony to spare top people from Millbank to help out Robert Mugabe, of course, but with Labour in such deep trouble at the moment is now really the right time?

fields.headline: Pill 'helps 30% quit smoking'
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: A revolutionary anti-smoking treatment claimed to be twice as effective as nicotine patches is available on NHS prescription from today.
fields.body:
A revolutionary anti-smoking treatment claimed to be twice as effective as nicotine patches is available on NHS prescription from today.

Zyban has a 30% success rate in trials, double that for patches or chewing gum. Its manufacturer, Glaxo Wellcome, claims to have the first therapy to tackle the biochemical basis of addiction, by de-sensitising the brain's nicotine receptors, rather than simply breaking the habit or providing a nicotine replacement.

The drug has been endorsed by the Department of Health and the British Lung Foundation and is already on sale in the United States and Canada. Zyban will cost the NHS £85.70 for each smoker's two month course; potentially the total cost could run into hundreds of millions of pounds if only a small percentage of Britain's 13m smokers ask for a prescription.

However, Mark Britton, chairman of the British Lung Foundation, yesterday pointed to the £1.7bn annual cost to the NHS of treating smoking-related diseases, and to the 120,000 smoking deaths every year. Chris Steele, a Manchester GP who runs the largest cessation clinic in Europe, described Zyban as a milestone in smoking treatment. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, also welcomed the drug.

Zyban, licensed under the generic name of bupropion hydrochloride, modifies two neurotransmitters in the brain believed to play a role in nicotine addiction: dopamine, implicated in cravings, and nora drenaline, associated with withdrawal symptoms.

Surveys find that 70% of smokers want to give up, and 30% try to quit in any given year; 3% succeed using will power alone, while the success rate for nicotine replacement therapies stands at 16%.

Two clinical studies published in the New England Journal of Medicine found that of 1,500 chronic smokers treated with Zyban, 30% were not smoking one year later.

Patients begin the two month course at least a week before quitting smoking, starting with one 150mg tablet a day and increasing to two; a very few patients report minor side effects such as headaches in the early weeks.

Patients are also given support including health benefit charts and motivational letters at critical stages, as well as access to a helpline.

Clive Bates, director of Action on Smoking and Health (ASH), warned that Zyban might not be as successful as the manufacturer claimed, adding: "We have to watch out for wonder-drug hype about Zyban. It's good but it's not a silver bullet - smokers are still going to need lots of willpower and determination to keep trying."

Yesterday a survey by a firm of analysts, Euromonitor, showed that government campaigns had failed to reduce smoking. Some 1,338 cigarettes were smoked per person in 1999 compared with 1,358 in 1995, a drop of one packet a year, despite a 25% rise in the price of cigarettes. Anti-smoking groups blamed a "fashion blip" that had created teenage smokers. However, Britain still has one of the lowest rates in Europe: only the Scandinavians and the Dutch smoke fewer cigarettes.

The national helpline, Quit, is on 0800 002 200.

webTitle: News at Ten to resurface on 24-hour current affairs channel

fields.headline: News at Ten to resurface on 24-hour current affairs channel
fields.trailText: News at Ten is to return: but not quite as we knew it. ITN, which made the programme for ITV before it was axed last year, is to resurrect it for its new 24-hour news channel.
fields.body:
News at Ten is to return: but not quite as we knew it. ITN, which made the programme for ITV before it was axed last year, is to resurrect it for its new 24-hour news channel.

Julia Somerville, who presented the show the night before it left the screens last year, will front the new version. "I think it's a great thing, there's an obvious demand for it," she said yesterday.

The ITN News Channel will launch on August 1, and will be available to cable and digital satellite viewers. ITN owns the News at Ten brand, and has discussed its plan with ITV, which is now involved in a protracted wrangle with the independent television commission over the programme's demise.

Since there is virtually no prospect of News at Ten returning on terrestrial television, whatever the outcome of the row between ITV and the regulator, ITN is free to use the brand on its new channel, although it would not say whether the introductory "bongs" would return.

Announcing details of the new channel, a joint venture between ITN and the cable company NTL, ITN chief executive Stewart Purvis said: "We know this concept fits in with the busy lifestyle of many Britons. The latest American research shows that although network news audiences are declining, the audiences for all-news channels are not, and those for online news are growing rapidly."

In addition to Somerville, the channel will boast established ITN names such as Carol Barnes and John Suchet, and the former Six O'Clock News host Andrew Harvey, who is moving to the channel after more than 30 years with the BBC.

Barnes said she would continue with her part-time role as a magistrate in Brighton, for which she is undergoing training, while Somerville will continue her daily radio show on the London station LBC.

fields.headline: Broadcasters 'take liberties' on TV sex
fields.standfirst: Concern among viewers increasing, says watchdog
fields.trailText: Broadcasters are putting ratings and profits before the feelings of sensitive viewers with increasingly frequent assaults on the rules governing sex and bad language on television, watchdogs said yesterday.
fields.body:
Broadcasters are putting ratings and profits before the feelings of sensitive viewers with increasingly frequent assaults on the rules governing sex and bad language on television, watchdogs said yesterday.

The Broadcasting Standards Commission said that chiefs should account for their actions themselves instead of constantly attempting to "get away with what they can".

Launching the commission's annual report, the chairman, Lord Holme, announced that broadcasters should "grow up and take responsibility for themselves".

Figures showed the commission was dealing with a 44% increase in complaints by viewers and listeners over the past two years. The top concerns are sex, swearing and violence on TV, and there are increased worries about the ethics of using children in television programmes.

There has been a rise in complaints about negative racial and regional stereotyping, and there is evidence of an emerging "north-south divide" in reactions to the use of bad language on TV and radio: northerners appear to be more concerned.

Complaints about sex formed 20% of the total received by the commission in the past year, 3% down on the previous year. Matters of taste and decency prompted the most concern, forming 50% of the total.

BBC2's Goodness Gracious Me topped the complaints table with 118 for a scene in the comedy show which mocked the Eucharist - the commission upheld the concerns; 41 complaints were received for anti-Welsh comments on Talk Radio, and were upheld; but 36 complaints about a Channel 4 documentary about bestiality were dismissed.

The commission revealed that only 3% of last year's total number of complaints were made about Channel 5, which is increasingly reliant on a diet of titillating programming: its game show Naked Jungle, presented by Keith Chegwin in the nude, prompted only seven complaints.

Broadcasters should take a more proactive role in addressing viewers and listeners' concerns instead of "maximising audiences and return for shareholders", Lord Holme said. "One of the most striking things about broadcasters is the assumption that their responsibilities are those laid on them by government or regulators and that their job is, to put it crudely, to get away with what they can."

Lord Holme urged restraint upon programme-makers. "It is almost built into the system that if you are an ambitious young producer you want to push the envelope, and what stops you from doing whatever the hell you want is regulation or government."

If broadcasters favour lighter-touch regulation, they should first demonstrate - like large companies who publish mission statements against which they are judged - that they are committed to taking their responsibilities seriously. "The more they call for light-touch regulation, the more they are going to have to grow up and take responsibility themselves," Lord Holme said.

While the BBC, Sky and Channel 4 had made some inroads into self-regulation, ITV and Channel 5 had some way to go.

Lord Holme said he felt the boundary on the use of swearwords was being pushed faster and further than the "broad mass of the British public" accepted. He conceded that attitudes are changing over the portrayal of on-screen sex. "After the watershed, in context, with due warning, people seem to be more tolerant of a wider range of sexual behaviour than they were."

But Lord Holme warned broadcasters not to step ahead of changes in the wider world. "Society is not changing at the same speed. What's acceptable in the metropolis may not be acceptable to more traditional audiences."

Research suggested that swear words were tolerated less in the north than in the south, he said.

webTitle: Fresh leads in hunt for blaze suspect

fields.headline: Fresh leads in hunt for blaze suspect
fields.trailText: Australian police hunting the itinerant fruit picker Robert Long, who is wanted in connection with the hostel fire that killed 15 backpackers, were following up five possible sightings in South Australia yesterday.
fields.body:
Australian police hunting the itinerant fruit picker Robert Long, who is wanted in connection with the hostel fire that killed 15 backpackers, were following up five possible sightings in South Australia yesterday.

A spokesman for the state police said that a man who fitted Long's description had been seen in various parts of the south of the state near Adelaide, several hundred miles from the Queensland town of Childers, where the fire took place early last Friday.

"We know Long has no links in South Australia, whereas he does have links in Victoria, Western Australia and New South Wales," the spokesman said.

The News South Wales link is that Long's parents live south of Sydney. Fighting back tears, his father, Syd Long, made an emotional televised plea yesterday, begging Robert to get in touch with his parents.

"Please pick up the telephone and call, we need to know that you are safe and well," he said.

"Remember, Robert, your mum and I love you. We are ready to help you work through the events of last week, and let us help you, son."

Acting Detective Superintendent Bill Prior, the officer in charge of major crime investigations in South Australia, said that Long had a history of violence and should not be approached by members of the public.

A spokesman for Queensland police, acting Superintendent Ken Benjamin, said his officers and fire investigators were examining a home video taken of the blaze from across the street by a member of the public and suggested that its contents would be useful.

Another 11 bodies were removed from the remains of the Palace hostel yesterday.

The last bodies are due to be removed today before their transfer to Brisbane for formal identification and postmortem examination.

webTitle: Annan urges new push to end poverty

fields.headline: Annan urges new push to end poverty
fields.standfirst:
Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: The world's richest states must open their markets and show greater generosity in debt relief to help revitalise the global drive to beat poverty, the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The world's richest states must open their markets and show greater generosity in debt relief to help revitalise the global drive to beat poverty, the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, said yesterday.

At a poorly attended conference in Geneva convened to assess the halting progress in raising the living standards of the one billion-plus people living on $1 a day, he warned that developed countries must recommit themselves to battle against human misery.

"Fifteen years from now, will there still be tens of millions of primary-age school children who are not in school?" he asked. "Will small children and pregnant women still be dying every minute from malaria and other preventable diseases?

"Will treatment for Aids still be priced far beyond the means of those suffering from it in developing countries?"

He added: "Rich countries have an indispensable role to play by further opening up their markets, providing deeper and faster debt relief and giving better focused development aid."

The conference, a special session of the UN general assembly, is monitoring whether the world is on track to meet targets set in Copenhagen in 1995 which commit countries to halve the number of people living on $1 a day, give every child a primary education and cut the number of child deaths by two-thirds.

"Our commitments have not been fulfilled." the Danish prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, said in the keynote speech. "We could have done better, much better."

While 120 world leaders were in Copenhagen to launch the anti-poverty campaign, only 15 heads of state - most of them from Africa - are at the week-long Geneva conference.

Mr Annan released the first report jointly compiled by the world's four principal development and monetary organisations: the UN, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.

It shows that the number living on less than $1 a day has actually grown, to 1.2bn from about 1bn in 1995. The World Bank admits that the number will not fall in the next eight years unless something is done.

The report highlights two of Mr Annan's favourite themes: education, especially of girls; and women's reproductive health. These are now accepted as the most effective keys to promoting development and ending poverty.

Stressing the need for industrialised and developing countries alike to work for sustainable growth that favours the poor, the report focuses on the seven interrelated development goals set at UN world conferences in the 1990s, which, if achieved in the next 15 years, will improve the lives of millions of people.

"All countries, developed and developing alike, signed on to this agenda, often at the highest political level," Mr Annan said. "Since then people have been asking whether the world has made good on these commitments.

"What has worked? What did not, and why? And what can we do better? This report provides some answers.

Among the report's findings are:

 As growth increased in the mid-90s, the number and proportion of people living on less than $1 a day fell rapidly in Asia, but little or not at all in Africa. Income inequality remains a barrier to progress in Latin America;

 More than 100m children will not be in school in 2015, if current trends prevail;

 The gender gap in primary and secondary enrolment is narrowing, but not fast enough to reach the goal of eliminating disparities by 2005;

 For every country that cut infant and under-five mortality rates fast enough to reach the goals, 10 lagged behind and one moved backwards, often because of HIV/Aids;

 Skilled care during pregnancy and delivery can do much to reduce the 500,000 maternal deaths each year;

 By 1997, fewer than half the countries in the world had environmental sustainability strategies.

The report will serve as a joint contribution by the four bodies to the G8 meeting in Okinawa on July 22.

UN chief's aims

 To halve the proportion of people living on less than $1 a day

 Enroll all children in primary school

 End gender disparities in schools

 Reduce infant mortality

 Reduce maternal mortality

 Give access to reproductive health services

 Promote environmentally sustainable development

webTitle: Lecturer 'killed woman to be friend in afterlife'

fields.headline: Lecturer 'killed woman to be friend in afterlife'
fields.trailText: A university lecturer consumed with thoughts of loneliness and suicide told a murder trial yesterday that he killed a "caring" colleague so he could have a "friend in the afterlife".
fields.body:
A university lecturer consumed with thoughts of loneliness and suicide told a murder trial yesterday that he killed a "caring" colleague so he could have a "friend in the afterlife".

Steven Reid, 34, who later planned to end it all by slashing his wrists, said that after deciding to take Elizabeth Stacey "with me" he bludgeoned her to death with a rolling pin bought for the purpose. "I didn't want to be alone in the afterlife, I didn't want to be alone."

He told Middlesex Guildhall crown court in London of his largely "aimless" existence with hardly a friend in the world. "I thought I could have a positive relationship with Liz in the afterlife. I still wanted to remain friends with her. I know it sounds ridiculous now, but it seemed to make a lot of sense at the time."

Reid, of Marylebone, central London, denies murdering Miss Stacey, 24, on November 5 last year after luring her into a seldom-used Westminster University psychology research lab.

The court has been told that the issue of diminished responsibility could be raised by his defence.

He told of his unhappy childhood in Edinburgh. A string of jobs followed as a housing association clerical assistant, working for the DSS, and selling double glazing and insurance.

He told Jeffrey Pegden, QC, defending, that he attempted suicide with antibiotics and a bottle of whisky. He decided to study psychology in the hope that it would "help me to relate to people".

When Miss Stacey began working as a psychology department research worker last September, he was feeling extremely depressed. Her arrival made him feel much happier.

He denied being sexually attracted to Miss Stacey. While there was a "mutual bond" between them, it was one based on genuine friendship.

The idea of killing her came some days before her death. But he only decided to batter her to death "when we were in the room together, she was sitting at the computer and I was standing behind her".

Reid was arrested 12 days after the alleged murder living under a false name in Brighton.

The trial continues today.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Police cleared of racial abuse
fields.body:
Police cleared of racial abuse

Two detectives were yesterday acquitted of racially abusing an Asian colleague after a tour of a brewery.

A Manchester crown court jury found detective constables Stewart Kelly, 37, and Martin Hazlehurst, 44, not guilty of racially aggravated harassment of Vijay Singh, 29. The officers were suspended by Greater Manchester police in February last year.

Dando accused remanded

Barry Bulsara, 40, who is charged under his original name, Barry Michael George, with the murder of the TV presenter Jill Dando, was remanded in custody until July 25 when he appeared before Bow Street magistrates in central London yesterday.

Crime unit head suspended

The head of a unit set up to combat crime in Salford, Greater Manchester, has been suspended following a call to the council's whistleblower hotline.

John Willis, council chief executive, said Ann Weir, head of Safer Salford, would remain suspended on full pay until an investigation had been completed.

Sex academic swapped porn

John Howe, a sexual health lecturer at the University College of Medicine in Cardiff, was yesterday fined £3,000 with £1,000 costs at Newport crown court and ordered to register as a sex offender for five years after a jury found him guilty of swapping images of naked children on the internet.

Good Samaritan deed is fatal

An 83-year-old woman died yesterday after being hit by a motorist who stopped to help her 78-year-old friend who had collapsed in the road in Camberley, Surrey.

webTitle: Rise in criminals sent back to Britain

fields.headline: Rise in criminals sent back to Britain
fields.trailText: The number of convicted criminals deported to Britain - mainly from the United States - has doubled in the past two or three years, according to a London-based charity which resettles expelled former inmates.
fields.body:
The number of convicted criminals deported to Britain - mainly from the United States - has doubled in the past two or three years, according to a London-based charity which resettles expelled former inmates.

At least four or five people a week, mostly men and often with long criminal records, are now arriving at Gatwick or Heathrow with nowhere to go and no friends or close family.

Many of the deportees left Britain so long ago they assumed they had become American citizens. The increase has been so rapid that the charity Prisoners Abroad, whose primary aim is to provide support for British subjects jailed overseas, is running short of hardship funds to care for the influx.

"We have people sent back for murder, rape and manslaughter," said Steve Szumski, the organisation's chief case worker. "A few years ago we were seeing three or less a week, now it's four, five, six, sometimes even seven a week. It's rising all the time. The majority come from the US, a few from Canada or France."

A surge in the American prison population to more than 2m has coincided with the effects of the 1996 US Anti-Terrorism Act and reform of US immigration laws, which vastly expanded the category of offences - such as "aggravated felony" - liable to deportation.

Anyone sentenced to more than a year in prison for drink driving, for example, can be sent back to Britain, an official in the Immigration and Naturalisation Service (INS) in Washington confirmed.

The Home Office does not keep precise figures of deportees who have served time in prison. Nor is it one-way traffic; Britain also repatriates foreign nationals, such as drug couriers, once they have completed their jail sentences.

"These people are deported without any preparation. They arrive with no knowledge of England, often only with the clothing they stand up in and they tend to fall through the benefit system," said Mr Szumski.

"We are the only agency doing this kind of work, filling in the gaps in the welfare provisions until the former inmates have signed on and found accommodation. We can't go on much longer, our budget is already overspent, and that will mean these people will be homeless and penniless on the streets."

An INS spokeswoman agreed that there was "a growth in removals". In 1995, the department's records show 142 former inmates were deported to Britain; by last year that figure had risen to 220.

Kevin Hugh-Jones, 42, a former prisoner who arrived back in Britain six weeks ago, admits many of the deportees have only one skill: violence. "I know if it wasn't for this help I might be out there sticking knives in people to get money," he said in an American accent that bore no trace of his native Wales. "In prison I saw a guy stabbed to death over a dollar.

"These ex-criminals have been thrown on the streets with no means for surviving. They may be tempted to go back to doing what they know they are good at. It can take five or six weeks to get a benefit claim."

Born in 1957 in Bangor, north Wales, Mr Hugh-Jones moved with his family to Canada when he was four, and a few years later to Ohio. During the Vietnam war, he served in the army although not overseas.

He insists that he is innocent of the offences of burglary, theft and battery for which he was convicted in Florida.

"What really irks me is that the oath my family took to become US citizens is almost exactly the same one I swore in the army - except I said I would protect the country with my life."

After spending nearly four years in prison - including 13 months in solitary confinement - he has been deported, he says, despite the fact that his case is still in the appeal courts.

Among the ranks of ex-convicts dumped in Britain, however, he enjoys one small privilege: as a US military veteran he is entitled to burial in the US. The only way Kevin Hugh-Jones is therefore permitted to return to the land where he was brought up and saw military service, and where his family still live, is in a coffin.

A surge in the American prison population to more than 2m has coincided with the effects of the 1996 US Anti-Terrorism Act and reform of US immigration laws, which vastly expanded the category of offences - such as "aggravated felony" - liable to deportation. Anyone sentenced to more than a year in prison for drink driving, for example, can be sent back to Britain, an official in the Immigration and Naturalisation Service (INS) in Washington confirmed. The Home Office does not keep precise figures of deportees who have served time in prison. Nor is it one-way traffic; Britain also repatriates foreign nationals, such as drug couriers, once they have completed their jail sentences. "These people are deported without any preparation. They arrive with no knowledge of England, often only with the clothing they stand up in and they tend to fall through the benefit system," said Mr Szumski. "We are the only agency doing this kind of work, filling in the gaps in the welfare provisions until the former inmates have signed on and found accommodation. We can't go on much longer, our budget is already overspent, and that will mean these people will be homeless and penniless on the streets." An INS spokeswoman agreed that there was "a growth in removals". In 1995, the department's records show 142 former inmates were deported to Britain; by last year that figure had risen to 220. Kevin Hugh-Jones, 42, a former prisoner who arrived back in Britain six weeks ago, admits many of the deportees have only one skill: violence. "I know if it wasn't for this help I might be out there sticking knives in people to get money," he said in an American accent that bore no trace of his native Wales. "In prison I saw a guy stabbed to death over a dollar. "These ex-criminals have been thrown on the streets with no means for surviving. They may be tempted to go back to doing what they know they are good at. It can take five or six weeks to get a benefit claim." Born in 1957 in Bangor, north Wales, Mr Hugh-Jones moved with his family to Canada when he was four, and a few years later to Ohio. During the Vietnam war, he served in the army although not overseas. He insists that he is innocent of the offences of burglary, theft and battery for which he was convicted in Florida. "What really irks me is that the oath my family took to become US citizens is almost exactly the same one I swore in the army - except I said I would protect the country with my life." After spending nearly four years in prison - including 13 months in solitary confinement - he has been deported, he says, despite the fact that his case is still in the appeal courts. Among the ranks of ex-convicts dumped in Britain, however, he enjoys one small privilege: as a US military veteran he is entitled to burial in the US. The only way Kevin Hugh-Jones is therefore permitted to return to the land where he was brought up and saw military service, and where his family still live, is in a coffin.

webTitle: Bidders vie for Daewoo market muscle

fields.headline: Bidders vie for Daewoo market muscle
fields.trailText: America's big three carmakers yesterday went head to head in the battle to acquire South Korea's Daewoo Motor and with it a leading position in one of Asia's most important vehicle markets.
fields.body:
America's big three carmakers yesterday went head to head in the battle to acquire South Korea's Daewoo Motor and with it a leading position in one of Asia's most important vehicle markets.

Ford entered the bidding on its own, General Motors teamed up with its new strategic partner, Fiat, while DaimlerChrysler joined forces with Hyundai as part of a broader alliance between the two companies.

The automotive business is up for sale after the financial problems which hit the Daewoo group, one of South Korea's biggest industrial conglomerates.

The team auctioning the motor business has said it will cut the list of bidders to one or two at the end of this week and a final decision is expected to be announced in September.

Although Daewoo Motor is heavily in debt it has attracted the interest of the big three mainly because of its strength in Asia. It also has production capacity in eastern Europe.

With the markets in the US and Europe seen as close to saturation, the big car companies are keen to build up their operations in regions which appear to offer higher growth opportunities.

"There are four centres of top quality auto production in the world and South Korea happens to be one of the four, along with North America, Europe and Japan," according to Meera Kumar, spokeswoman for the Ford bid team.

Daewoo has the capacity to produce some 2m cars a year, although last year its sales fell short of the 1m mark. Some 340,000 vehicles were sold in South Korea.

Analysts said DaimlerChrysler's decision to ally with a local group could give it an edge but others said Hyundai's inclusion in a grouping that acquired its biggest domestic competitor could prove problematical because of overlapping facilities, models and services.

"DaimlerChrysler may not be as interested in Daewoo as Hyundai clearly is," one analyst said. "Daimler already has a controlling stake at Mitsubishi Motors while Hyundai hopes to defend its market share."

DaimlerChrysler certainly displayed caution. "We are going to investigate the merits of a potential alliance between us and Daewoo. If we come to the conclusion it makes sense, we will go ahead. In the case that it does not, we will stop," said a director, Eckhard Cordes.

The joint bid for Daewoo is the first move in an alliance which has seen the US-German company take a 10% stake in Hyundai for $430m (£287m) with an option to increase that to 15% within the next three years.

Under the GM/Fiat bid, the US carmaker would emerge as the largest shareholder in Daewoo, with Fiat taking up to 20% and creditors retaining a stake in the company. "Our business plan will give Daewoo the best opportunity for rapid normalisation while preserving the identity of Daewoo Motor," said GM's chief executive officer, Richard Wagoner.

Ford said Daewoo offered it a presence in markets where it wanted to bolster its position. "Where Daewoo is strong we are weak," said Ms Kumar.

webTitle: Americans move in on Yorkshire Post

fields.headline: Americans move in on Yorkshire Post
fields.standfirst: Regional Independent Media is target for acquisitive Gannett
fields.trailText: Regional Independent Media, which owns the Yorkshire Post newspaper, yesterday said it had received a takeover approach from acquisitive American media group Gannett.
fields.body:
Regional Independent Media, which owns the Yorkshire Post newspaper, yesterday said it had received a takeover approach from acquisitive American media group Gannett.

RIM, which was a buy-out from Lord Hollick's United News & Media in 1998, is one of the largest remaining independent regional newspaper groups in the UK.

Its acquisition would be part of the rapid consolidation of the market. Analysts suggest the business would be worth around £650m.

A statement from RIM yesterday said it was undertaking a review of the options available with its adviser, Credit Suisse First Boston, including continuing along the path to a flotation later this year.

It added that the company was in receipt of a number of other approaches which could lead to a trade sale.

Chris Oakley, chief executive of RIM, said the approach had been "an expression of interest" rather than a firm offer. He added that the group would be in a position to make a further announcement some time in the autumn.

Gannett entered the UK market in the middle of last year when it paid £1.3bn for Newsquest, the third largest publisher of regional papers. Last month it added Newscom for £444m.

In the US, Gannett publishes 74 daily newspapers, including USA Today, and owns 22 television stations.

Any acquisition of RIM would have to be approved by the trade secretary, Stephen Byers. Gannett said it intended to seek a rubber stamp ahead of a formal offer being made.

Venture capital group Candover is the majority investor in RIM with 50% of the company. The other shareholders are Goldman Sachs and the Dutch venture capital group, Alpinvest.

The business, which publishes daily and weekly titles throughout the north of England, was bought for £360m.

The group publishes 101 titles, with the Yorkshire Post being one of the oldest in Britain - the newspaper was founded as the Leeds Intelligencer in 1754.

RIM's other daily titles include the Yorkshire Evening Post in Leeds, the Star in Sheffield, the Lancashire Evening Post in Preston and the Wigan Evening Post.

The company reported a 15% increase in pre-tax profits to £32.8m during 1999 on a 6.1% rise in revenues to £156.3m.

RIM also controls some 16 websites tied to its regional titles and is one of six regional publishing companies with a shareholding in Fish 4 - the regional press classified database which allows users to gain access to advertising for cars, jobs and property on the internet.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Ofwat appoints new chief
fields.body:
Ofwat appoints new chief

A career civil servant, whose most recent job was as a procurement official with the Metropolitan Police in London, has been named as the regulator of Britain's water industry.

Philip Fletcher takes over from Ian Byatt, head of Ofwat for 11 years, at a time of major upheaval for the industry, as companies seek ways to address the punitive regulatory price review Mr Byatt imposed at the end of last year.

Budget surplus widens in US

The US federal budget surplus will widen to a record $211bn (£141bn) in the fiscal year to September 2000, compared with the previous estimate of $167bn released in February, Bill Clinton said yesterday.

This compares with a surplus of $124bn in fiscal year 1999. The White House now projects that it will pay down $2.9 trillion of publicly held debt between now and 2010 and eliminate the debt by 2012.

This fiscal year would mark the third government surplus in a row for the first time in over 50 years. If the surplus comes in as expected, it would total 2.2% of GDP, the largest unified surplus as a share of the economy since 1948.

JSB Software in £66m deal

British firm JSB Software Technologies yesterday bought Cyber Patrol, a division of US toy maker Mattel for £66m.

"This acquisition will help us expand in terms of geography, technology and market segments," said JSB Chief Executive Steve Purdham, adding that Cyber Patrol's expertise would allow JSB to garner a "significant portion" of the internet monitoring that goes on at 17,000 school districts in the US.

JSB provides and markets software that helps firms, schools and other organisations monitor their online activity.

AngloGold buys into Ashanti

The world's largest gold miner, AngloGold, yesterday bought 50% of Ashanti Goldfield's Geita gold project. AngloGold will pay Ashanti $205m (£137m) in cash for the stake in the Geita project in Tanzania and will procure or provide project financing to the project of $130m.

The two groups said they had also settled the terms of a joint venture agreement which would govern how the two partners will operate the project.

In a joint statement they said that the mine was expected to be officially opened on August 3 this year. Geita's annual production is estimated at 500,000 ounces at an operating cost of under $180 an ounce.

Microsoft to be pursued by EC

European competition commissioner Mario Monti said yesterday that his agency will continue to investigate Microsoft's alleged anti-competitive behaviour in Europe - no matter what happens in a similar case in the US or in the presidential race. Microsoft is appealing a court ruling to the effect that it abused its monopoly.

fields.headline: Cadbury forced to shop around
fields.trailText: Cadbury Schweppes is to seek other acquisitions after losing out in the bidding for snack foods group Nabisco.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and  Jill Treanor
fields.body:
Cadbury Schweppes is to seek other acquisitions after losing out in the bidding for snack foods group Nabisco.

Philip Morris, the tobacco and food conglomerate, clinched control of Nabisco Holdings over the weekend in a complicated $15bn (£10bn) transaction which involves the part flotation of its Kraft food division.

Kraft, combined with the Nabsico food brands, will be catapulted into the position of the world's most profitable food company and second only in size to Nestlé of Switzerland.

The battle for control of Nabisco followed a three-month tussle in which Cadbury Schweppes and Danone of France made a joint bid to compete against Phillip Morris. The transaction is understood to include a break-up fee of $450m.

The bidding process also involved finding a new owner for Nabisco's parent company, Nabisco Group Holdings, which faced the prospect of falling into the hands of the veteran Wall Street financier Carl Icahn.

Instead, what is essentially a shell company, formed when RJR Nabisco was broken up, was bought by RJ Reynolds Tobacco, once part of the Nabisco group, for $9.75bn. Mr Icahn is thought to be on track to make a $600m profit on his stake in the holding company.

Geoffrey Bible, chairman and chief executive of Philip Morris, said yesterday that he expected the initial public offering of shares in the Kraft food division to generate $5bn to $10bn, which will be used to pay the debt from the Nabisco deal.

He denied reports that the IPO was a prelude to a full-scale separation of the group's food and tobacco assets. Wall Street analysts had suggested the company was considering such a break-up in the face of continuing legal difficulties related to its tobacco business.

Philip Morris was driven to outbid the other suitors largely by a desire for Nabisco's position in the fast-growing market for snacks. Mr Bible said Kraft's share of that market in the US was expected to grow from 6% to nearly 20% following the acquisition.

The combination of Royal and Jell-O was the only part of the deal, which is expected to undergo close examination from competition regulators on both sides of the Atlantic.

Cadbury Schweppes said yesterday that it would "keep an eye out" for other deals.

Some analysts expressed relief that the group had not been lured into paying too much for Nabisco.

Cadbury's shares fell 1.5p to 418.5p.

webTitle: Kosovans accuse four British peacekeepers of theft

fields.headline: Kosovans accuse four British peacekeepers of theft
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Four British soldiers of the peacekeeping force in Kosovo have been accused of stealing money and valuables from ethnic Albanian civilians at a checkpoint, the Ministry of Defence confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Four British soldiers of the peacekeeping force in Kosovo have been accused of stealing money and valuables from ethnic Albanian civilians at a checkpoint, the Ministry of Defence confirmed yesterday.

The four members of the 2nd Battalion, the Royal Regiment of Fusiliers have been separated and given other duties.

The civilians say that the soldiers took mobile phones, cameras and up to £10,000-worth of German marks at a checkpoint in the provincial capital, Pristina.

"Because it was a four-man patrol and an allegation was made that money and effects were stolen, they are all under investigation," an MoD spokesman said.

"But we don't know yet whether it's one or more that actually are being accused."

The military police special investigation branch was investigating, and the soldiers "would be dealt with quite severely" if the allegations proved true, he added

Meanwhile international aid agencies which pulled out of Serb-held areas of the flashpoint town of Mitrovica last Friday said yesterday that they would not return until there were better guarantees for the safety of their staff.

"If we were to go back without some kind of explicit agreement [with Kosovo Serb leaders], then next time we will have somebody killed. It will not just be a matter of somebody being beaten," said Paula Ghedini of the UN refugee agency UNHCR, which coordinates the international aid effort.

Ms Ghedini had a letter from Oliver Ivanovic, the self-proclaimed leader of the Serbs in Mitrovica, saying the aid organisations' decision to suspend work was "hasty and politicised". The Serb National Council in north Mitrovica did not support violence and had condemned individuals responsible for recent attacks on aid staff and their vehicles.

Ms Ghedini said this fell short of what was needed. In less than a year, 90 aid agency vehicles had been damaged and 36 destroyed in Mitrovica in clearly coordinated attacks.

Dennis McNamara, UNHCR chief in Kosovo, was meeting the Serbs and UN security staff in Mitrovica and the situation would be reviewed daily. Meanwhile, the UN police were working to improve their response.

webTitle: Corus warns of more job losses and blames pound

fields.headline: Corus warns of more job losses and blames pound
fields.trailText: Anglo-Dutch steelmaker Corus warned yesterday that more job losses are on the way - with Britain set to bear the brunt of the cuts
fields.body:
Anglo-Dutch steelmaker Corus warned yesterday that more job losses are on the way - with Britain set to bear the brunt of the cuts

Since the merger of British Steel and Hoogovens to form Corus last October, the group has announced plans to cut about 2,200 jobs - including 1,200 in South Yorkshire detailed last week. But yesterday the group warned that the strength of the pound would mean further job losses.

"The serious erosion of the competitive position of the group and its customer base in the UK, as a result of the strength of the pound against the euro, inevitably means that further difficult decisions will have to be taken in order to improve our competitive position," the group said in a statement accompanying its first ever figures, which showed that in the six months to the beginning of April Corus made a pre-tax loss of £113m.

The group made it clear that the losses stemmed entirely from the main business, carbon steel, "largely due to the situation which obtained in the UK". Both the stainless steel and aluminium operations turned in operating profits.

Analysts believe that Corus's ability to cut costs and boost efficiency will be crucial to improving profitability.

"The company is being encouraged to be more efficient, for example to re-engineer its product delivery and optimise between sites. Corus really has more customers in continental Europe so it has to be able to deliver to them at the best revenue," according to Alan Coats, a steel analyst at Merrill Lynch.

But Denis MacShane, Labour MP for Rotherham, pointed to the recent recovery in the euro against the pound and said he was concerned that Corus was in danger of creating a self-fulfiling prophecy basing its future strategy on a currency imbalance "which is now moving in the steel industry's favour".

However, there was some more positive news from the group. It said: "The market outlook for for carbon steel for the rest of 2000 appears to be generally strong, especially in the US and European markets, although concern remains about demand in the UK due to the relative strength of the pound."

Corus shares yesterday closed down 4.5p at 97p.

webTitle: Be penny wise when it comes to Wray

fields.headline: Be penny wise when it comes to Wray
fields.standfirst: Lawyer's letter underlines risks
fields.trailText: A bullying letter has arrived in this office from Kingsley Napley, the lawyers, who say they have been "consulted" by the Colombus Group,a small publishing firm, over an article in these pages referring to the dealings of Nigel Wray who, until last week, was deputy chairman of Colombus.
fields.body:
A bullying letter has arrived in this office from Kingsley Napley, the lawyers, who say they have been "consulted" by the Colombus Group,a small publishing firm, over an article in these pages referring to the dealings of Nigel Wray who, until last week, was deputy chairman of Colombus.

The letter accuses us of "materially" misquoting from a report by accountants KPMG and alleges a number of factual inaccuracies in our reporting. "It is abundantly clear that you have been cavalier, to say the least, in the way in which you have reported the matter," the letter states, before going on to demand all manner of undertakings from this newspaper.

Well, providing anything of the sort is going to be a little difficult since Kingsley Napley's charges are entirely misdirected. The article complained of - a piece on the reverse takeover of shell company Knutsford, where Mr Wray is also on the board - made no mention of Colombus or, indeed, Mr Wray's dealings. What is more, KPMG's "confidential document" has not been written about or quoted from in any form. Until now, that is.

For the bemused it should be explained that KPMG is reported to have carried out a forensic audit at Colombus (which is being taken over by another publisher Highbury House) following three separate raids on the company by officials from the Department of Trade last year. No action followed the raids, but a series of articles recently appeared in the Times focusing on a big sale of shares by Mr Wray a few weeks before a profits warning by Colombus and also while the DTI probe was still under way.

Mr Wray has protested that he did not know about the DTI's concerns and certainly knew nothing about the impending profits warning when he sold his stock. There is no reason to doubt the man's word. But, given Kingsley Napley's nudge, this is probably as good a chance as any to warn that, on past experience, any regular medium-to-long term investor who sinks money into a company where Mr Wray is involved stands a good chance of losing a sizeable portion of their investment.

The financier is a leading proponent of the City's penny-stock game. Typically, Mr Wray and his associates bring a small, high-risk company to the market in a flotation pitched at a few pence per share. A group of professional investors support the issue, raising a few million pounds for the company, before selling all or most of their shares to other investors.

These new shareholders may be regular punters, attracted to penny shares because they have read a tip-sheet advertisement promising untold riches for those who dream big and buy small. Alternatively, the new shareholders may be one of a number of so-called City bucket shops - fringe stockbrokers that buy big parcels of penny stocks and then use teams of high-pressure tele-salesmen to sell the stock on at an inflated price to amateur investors.

Mr Wray's record of directorships, past and present, runs to many dozens of companies - firms such as Trocadero (now renamed Chorion), Burford, Nottingham Forest, Grantchester, Talisman, and so on. In many cases, Mr Wray's shares enjoy an initial surge, fuelled by excited publicity, only to slump once the low quality of the underlying business becomes apparent. The last mug punter in loses all the money.

There is nothing illegal about any of this. It is just how a portion of the small company community operates through the London stock market. But it is a shabby business all the same.

Formula One

The simple fact that a retailing business created by one little (albeit energetic) guy in the space of 11 years is carrying a price tag of £1.6bn draws knee-jerk scepticism.

But then Charles Dunstone, chief executive of Carphone Warehouse is not selling fashion-fickle slacks or sofas on dubious credit terms. He is in the mobile phone business and will be a prime distributor of the next generation of portable gizmos and, whatever predictions are taken, sales growth will be exponential. More importantly, perhaps, Mr Dunstone has created a clean, customer-driven business, with a highly-motivated work force. The formula is already rolling through Europe and further afield, with visible success.

In terms of the numbers, analysts reckon Carphone will make around £43m this year on an Ebitda basis (that's earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation). That puts the business on a discount to, say, Matalan, the highly-rated discount shopping chain.

With the issue price having been reined back slightly in volatile market conditions, the shares look a worthwhile, if slightly racy, investment. And those applying should sign up for the three-month retail investment lock-in, designed to warn off market stags. It is probably the only way investors will get a meaningful allocation of shares.

webTitle: Mexico threatens to scupper labour pact

fields.headline: Mexico threatens to scupper labour pact
fields.trailText: The Mexican government is threatening to scupper an international agreement on labour and environmental standards for multinational firms, unless it is allowed to bend the rules for foreign firms that line its US border, writes Charlotte Denny.
fields.body:
The Mexican government is threatening to scupper an international agreement on labour and environmental standards for multinational firms, unless it is allowed to bend the rules for foreign firms that line its US border, writes Charlotte Denny.

Members of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development were set to sign up to the guidelines at a meeting in Paris today, but after days of intense diplomatic negotiations, the Mexican government is still refusing to accept the new code without amendments.

One of the few developing country members of the OECD, Mexico argues the draft guidelines threaten inward investment. The mostly American-owned "maquiladoras" that line the Rio Grande border operate under much lower safety and environmental standards than firms in the US, and could be forced to tighten up their operations under the OECD's code.

Diplomats had hoped that a voluntary agreement at the OECD would take some of the sting out of the row on labour and environmental standards that derailed the attempt to launch a new round of global trade talks in Seattle last December.

However, the Mexican government's position suggests that the divide between rich country governments and the developing world remains as wide as ever. The Mexican government is thought to be worried about provisions in the guidelines requiring it to consult with non-governmental organisations and international bodies like the ILO when problems arise with firms.

"We think the guidelines are an excellent document, but we have some concern about their implementation," Mexican trade minister Herminio Blanco told Reuters. "We think there are several loopholes that could lead to harassment of foreign direct investors."

But the country's hard line stance has angered other OECD members. Trade unions and some non-governmental organisations in particular had hoped the guidelines would prompt multinationals to use the same best practices abroad as at home.

"It's about the high route to economic development versus the low route," said one source, close to the OECD. "The Mexicans are trying to suppress labour standards in the hope of attracting foreign investment." Trade ministers from the OECD face a deadlock at their meeting this morning as by tradition, the OECD operates by consensus. If Mexico refuses to back down, the OECD may be forced to turn the code into a non-binding declaration.

fields.headline: Terror in the park
fields.standfirst: Gunmen open fire on basketball players
fields.trailText: Police suggested that the attack in Jackson Park in Chicago on Sunday might have been linked to gang rivalry, but said they were continuing to investigate the motive.
fields.body:
Police suggested that the attack in Jackson Park in Chicago on Sunday might have been linked to gang rivalry, but said they were continuing to investigate the motive.

"Everybody started running," said an eyewitness, Ken Dunbar. "A lot of people were falling from getting hit by bullets."

The wounded fell in an area covering two blocks in Chicago's South Side, a far cry from the soaring skyline of the city's prosperous downtown area.

"A group of two or three offenders opened fire on a group of people playing basketball," said Pat Camden, spokesman for the city's police department. "I don't think it was random. There may be some history here but it's too early to tell."

Three people were arrested and at least two guns were recovered. One person, a 24-year-old man was critically ill yesterday and another, aged 25, was said to be in a serious condition. Two more were in fair condition, including the pregnant woman, 18, whose baby was unhurt.

fields.headline: Highbury in £58m Columbus takeover
fields.trailText: Magazines group Highbury House Communications finally completed its long-awaited acquisition of Columbus Group's publishing assets yesterday in an all-share deal worth £58.7m.
fields.body:
Magazines group Highbury House Communications finally completed its long-awaited acquisition of Columbus Group's publishing assets yesterday in an all-share deal worth £58.7m.

The takeover is Highbury's largest to date - and its ninth in 18 months - and more will follow shortly, according to chief executive Ian Fletcher. "Once this deal is completed we will have an annualised turnover of £130m and will start to register on the radar screen as a significant player."

In March, Highbury, which publishes Sports Illustrated in Britain, paid £39m for rival publisher Nexus.

Columbus's publications including Harper's wine guides and the World Travel Guides. Mr Fletcher said its consumer focus would compliment Highbury's business publication driven core business, providing new database management and marketing opportunities.

Highbury has offered 21 new shares for every 40 Columbus shares. Upon completion of the deal Mr Fletcher will become executive chairman of the enlarged group, with Columbus chief executive Jeremy Isaac continuing in the same role at Highbury.

Highbury is the second publishing group Mr Fletcher has built up after developing and then selling the Yellow Advertiser free newspapers group.

Columbus plans to demerge its Dateline dating agency, marry it to two other dating businesses and float the new concern on AIM.

The new dating agency holding company will be called OneSaturday and include internet entrepreneur Chris Matthew's singles website firm Sirius. He plans to develop OneSaturday across Europe and offer events, travel and financial services for single people.

Mr Matthews, who will become chairman of the new group, said the website would allow people to meet people online in a secure environment, knowing they are communicating with bona fide clients.

Mr Matthews, 50, who is not single himself, said: "If you are serious about meeting people OneSaturday will offer security - you have to prove who you are."

The site would also offer information for singles about holidays and social events. Mr Matthews said he thought expansion of the business would be driven by making using a dating agency more socially acceptable.

Highbury shares closed off 1.25p at 61p, while Columbus slipped 1.5p to 28.75p.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: No Triumph, No Tragedy | The Summer Of 1940
fields.body:
Like his father, sociologist Dr Tom Shakespeare has achondroplasia, a hereditary condition in which the long bones fail to develop fully. As a consequence he is only 4ft 5ins tall and, as he tells Peter White in No Triumph, No Tragedy (9.0am, 9.30pm, Radio 4), suffers the double handicap of an unusual surname and of people staring at him. But he leads a full life and has had two children of his own. He is, in fact, much more embarrassed about inheriting a baronetcy.

The final part of Michael Aspel's history of The Summer Of 1940 (9.00pm, Radio 2) deals with an episode which has reached subsequent generations only as comedy. Anticipating a German inva sion after Dunkirk, Local Defence Volunteers (pictured) were recruited - and immediately dubbed "Look, Duck, and Vanish" by sceptical countrymen. Winston Churchill reacted by changing their name to the Home Guard and, within a year, saw them deployed as a formidable army more than a million strong.

fields.headline: Comedy of errors
fields.standfirst: Why do people become stand-up comedians? Because they can make people laugh? Well, no. These days, comedy is just a fast track route to a 'proper' television career - as the ubiquitous Alan Davies has proved.
fields.trailText: Why do people become stand-up comedians? Because they can make people laugh? Well, no. These days, comedy is just a fast track route to a 'proper' television career - as the ubiquitous Alan Davies has proved. By Danny Leigh
fields.body:
It's a funny thing, conventional wisdom. Take that nugget of venerable hokum about stand-up comedy attracting the kids who were bullied at school, the ones with the ache to make big laughs to ease the trauma of their sorry collective adolescence.

Guess what? It's all lies. Because the dark, prosaic truth is that the only personality types stand-up pulls in as routine are the maniacally ambitious and the (coincidentally) aggressively unfunny. If you don't believe me, have a gander at BBC1 tonight where, for one hour and twenty minutes, we'll be graced with not one but two sometime comics-turned-full time thespians and ad-men.

First comes the long-awaited (by its producers) return of Hope And Glory (9.30pm), the bloodless, unpopular melodrama wherein Lenny Henry single-handedly saves state education without once saying "Oh-kayyyyy." Now, personally, I always thought the most astute verdict on this would-be variety act (still doing the soul, Lenny?) came from a gaggle of Peckham yout' on an obscure, mid-90s farrago called Raw Soup: asked for their opinion of Mr Versatility, they promptly collapsed in a fit of derisive sniggers. Loveable Len, they giggled, was simply "too white". And to that sentiment, there's really nothing left worth adding.

Indeed, the only interesting thing about Hope And Glory is that it opens the BBC's twin-header of erstwhile jokers - the second part of which rears up at 10.20pm in the form of A Many Splintered Thing, an impossibly unctuous vehicle for Alan Davies that could easily double as a purposeful incitement to firebomb the Groucho. Davies is, of course, the man who took comedic multi-tasking to a whole new level of grim ubiquity, diversifying first into drama (well, Jonathan Creek), then Abbey National sales representation. On one level, it's a phenomenon that's been around for years: the career trajectory whereby a serviceable gimmick (Lenny Henry: cuddly, Mark Lamarr: spiky, David Baddiel: likes wanking) can make renaissance men out of people who were no good at their job to begin with. Can't write, can't act, aren't funny? I'll fax the contracts over.

Yet Davies (gimmick: woman's haircut) has become the apotheosis of the form, a bold evolutionary leap forward from the Henrys and Baddiels. We trust his judgement on endowment mortgages, we watch his underlings hawk signed pictures on his other BBC series, Stand Up With Alan Davies. Somehow, the man has reached critical mass.

Which is probably why A Many Splintered Thing, in which he ostensibly stars as a jingle-writing adulterer from Muswell Hill (great reference, love it), finds him playing nothing more than Alan Davies, modishly accessorised with gay best friend. Alan calls his mistress's breasts Derek and Colin, Alan gurns during fellatio (a sight sufficiently bilious to put you off both sit-coms and oral sex), and Alan idles by as the kind of dialogue no one on earth has ever actually said piles up like so many repeat fees, even managing a smile when he's told that "women have g-spots and men have snooze buttons" (and BBC scriptwriters evidently have no friends).

Davies's trick is, of course, maintaining his vapid, everyman persona in the face of the show's media-incestuous gags about TV rights and frequent nasty-minded misogyny. Perfect symbiosis: a comedy for people with no sense of humour, starring a personality without any. Except that's not strictly true: behind the shark eyes, beneath the hair, there is a glimmer of (hugely) studied cheek, a plastic blokeishness also employed by Naked Chef Jamie Oliver, who - with his various ad campaigns and imminent self-promoting magazine - acts as Davies's only real competition for sheer icky omnipresence.

But that's all. Otherwise, Davies is nothing but a big, blank space where an identity should be. Which isn't only a result of the egocentric bashfulness hinted at on Stand Up With, where laughing boy could be found announcing that comedy shouldn't concern "telling people about your personal misery" (oh go on mate, tell us about your personal misery). It's also a surefire way to avoid treading on toes, to never risk offending where you can ingratiate instead. Off-camera remains anyone's guess. Davies is, if nothing else (and he is nothing else), a pro, his intimate, observational shtick merely the Colgate grin of a door-to-door salesman. That's why the elaborate fantasy sequences which season A Many Splintered Thing stink the place out: because it's impossible to imagine Davies fantasising about anything besides tripling his voiceover rate.

It's also what explains his success, and his role as an emblem of our current culture - the same smug celebrity hamster wheel his nominally alternative predecessors (Elton, Mayall et al) so gleefully fed into. Richard Blackwood, Davina McCall, Charlie Dimmock, Carol Vorderman and there, atop the whole scrupulously deodorised heap, Alan Davies.

So, for one reason and one reason only, A Many Splintered Thing makes essential viewing: as a weather vane for the times, taking on the same role 'Til Death Us Do Part performed during the late 60s and Reggie Perrin embodied in the mid-70s.

Sadly, in Mezzobrow Uber Alles modern Britain, we're all Alan Davies fans now.

 A Many Splintered Thing, tonight, 10.20pm, BBC1

fields.headline: Inside Tate Modern
fields.standfirst: This week: Untitled (1989-92), by Robert Gober
fields.trailText: This week: Untitled (1989-92), by Robert Gober
fields.body:
You only really notice this work as you leave the room called Subversive Objects (Gallery 6, Still Life/Real Life/Object) at Tate Modern. The crowded room, with its pinky-red walls, is a sort of cabinet of sur-realist and surrealist-influenced curiosities. Beside the door, almost at floor level, is a realistic, clothed human leg. A turned-up trouser, a hairy white calf, a sock and a shoe stick out of the wall. I think of Magritte's steam train emerging from the fireplace in his famous painting.

"Memories remade" is one of the descriptions the American sculptor Robert Gober has given of his work. Who has not sat opposite a stranger and seen their trouser-leg ride up, revealing a disconcerting, unselfconscious view of flesh? I find something casual yet hopelessly tragic about this quotidian fragment - the worn, plain shoe, the pallid waxen skin. It is life-sized, but more like death than life.

I think of artists' studies in notebooks - a hand or an eye, a bit of drapery. But in the artist's aide- memoire we don't think of what is missing - the absent body. Nor do we think of sculpted busts or head-and-shoulders portraits in terms of severed heads, but accept instead the convention of a complete human being represented by the head or the face.

But the body's absence here is all too apparent. I begin to reconstruct the whole from the part, and think of how my eye lingers on strangers' bodies in public places. But there's something about the angle of the foot here that makes me think of a man unconscious or a corpse on the ground. I don't imagine that there is a man buried in the wall, but rather that the wall divides real space from the imaginary.
