fields.headline: The end of days
fields.standfirst: One painted seas and clouds; the other manipulates movies. But Turner and Douglas Gordon have one thing in common - their obsession with the Apocalypse.  Adrian Searle  gets a chance to see them side by side
fields.trailText: One painted seas and clouds; the other manipulates movies. But Turner and Douglas Gordon have one thing in common - their obsession with the Apocalypse. Adrian Searle gets a chance to see them side by side
fields.body:
The estuary light is a shifting, uncertain tide, flooding in through the windows and skylights, filling the room then ebbing away. The weather at the Mersey's mouth and the weather in the rooms where the paintings hang. The paintings appraise blanched afternoon skies, flaring sunsets, luminous coastal vapours, Venetian and Swiss lake light. Here are stormy seas and blazing wrecks, floundering ships, drownings, an angel standing in the sun.

The paintings belong to the first half of the 19th century, and also to a mythological time and space. The apocalyptic and the visionary are never far away in JMW Turner's work. He was not, as he is sometimes made out to be, an Impressionist. His paintings also belong emphatically to the here and now - this time, this place, a moment that seems to last forever.

We are accustomed to seeing Turner's paintings surrounded by fancy gilded frames, and further removed from us by a pane of non-reflective glass. Or to seeing them in reproduction - cropped into hard rectangles with rulered edges, as flattened printer's ink pictures on a white page. In the exhibition The Sun Is God at Tate Liverpool, curator Mark Francis has both addressed and undressed the Tate's collection of Turners, and turned off the gallery lighting. Naked and unframed on the bare walls, the canvases hang in ordinary daylight - if a light so subtle and shifting as this can ever truly be described as ordinary. The light sometimes reveals too much, and just as often frustrates the eye. As it rakes across the surface of one work, all you can see is stark, shining reflection, the tracery of cracks, the cupped paint, the mat patches and the skating-rink shine. As the light changes - as though someone were playing with a dimmer switch - the surface disappears and the image reveals itself.

Here they are, with all their wounds and scars. Out of the frames, you notice how many of the friable old canvases have been relined, glued with resins and wax to new, secondary layers of canvas. One can't always distinguish dirt and old, discoloured restoration from Turner's mucky, impastoed, knifed-on and dragged-over original paintwork. Or how much the aggressively sulphurous atmosphere of 19th-century London discoloured the lead pigments, or how unstable some of his new-fangled pigments - themselves the product of dirty industry - really were. But his touch and his intention remain clear. His painting is revealed as gloriously slovenly, a magnificent mess. He turned slops into atmosphere. The leavings and traces, like a real tide-margin, gave his work its meatiness and its veracity. His was a robust art, however diaphanous and insubstantial the effects he sought to capture.

I think of the artist, looking at his own work at the day's end, as the light shifted to the red end of the spectrum. We look at Turner here as he would have seen his own paintings, while he worked on them and deliberated over them, watching as the light fell, seeing how one colour struck out and then receded, how the light in the painting persisted longest as the daylight went. The painter invents light, and the painting responds to light. This exhibition needs time - just as much an element of painting as space or light. Turner unframed, unlit, is still Turner. Perhaps he is even more palpably himself.

Mark Francis has also curated the exhibition of Douglas Gordon's work at the same gallery. To reach both shows on the top floor, visitors are invited to use the service lift. There's no indication whether you are riding up or down, and the intention is to give the visitor the curious sense of arriving somewhere strange as the attendant drags the lift door open into the darkened space of Gordon's show. The skylights and windows here are blacked out, and the space has been turned into a pleasing labyrinth.

But making any connection between Turner and Douglas Gordon requires a leap of the imagination. What do they share, apart from the fact that Gordon won a prize named after the dead painter in 1996? Is it a question of light - cinematic light v painted light - or something more furtive, to do with both artists' interest in the biblical, and especially in the Book of Revelation?

Gordon is most famous for his works that pay homage to Hitchcock - 24 Hour Psycho and, more recently, Feature Film (based on the score of Vertigo), which was given another airing at the Royal Festival Hall last Saturday. Gordon's only film work here is a new piece, Deja Vu. This is a triple screening of DOA, a grim 1949 American film noir directed by Rudolph Maté. It is a very dark film about a man who is poisoned and recounts the events leading up to his murder while the drug slowly takes effect. Maté began his career in Germany and France, where he worked as cameraman on Dreyer's La Passion de Jeanne d'Arc, in which Antonin Artaud played the young monk. DOA (dead on arrival) is projected on three abutted screens. Gordon runs the film a little fast (as it would be seen on television, snipping minutes from the film), at normal speed and slightly slowed down. The three projections slowly go out of synch, creating inadvertent yet fortuitous synchronicities. The story is told in a series of flashbacks, and the sense of premonition and deja vu is heightened by Gordon's manipulation of it. Gordon turns watching into a curious psychic experience.

Gordon's show and the accompanying book - more a work in itself than a straightforward catalogue - are surprising for an audience who know him best from his film work. He even includes a text in homage to Turner, Afterturner, which plays on reversals and homophones. "The sun is good... The son is bad... The sun is god... God is the son." There is something relentless about Gordon's work, which is nowhere clearer than in a 1996 work, From God to Nothing. Three lightbulbs hang at different heights in a room. Running around the walls is a continuous text, at eye-height, like a horizon. It is a horizon of fear: "fear of god... fear of friends... fear of anal penetration... fear of teeth... fear of falling asleep and never waking up... fear of fear... fear of nothing." Almost any fear you've got is here. You walk around with an increasing sense of alarm, the lights casting eerie shadows before and behind you. Your own shadow looms, and you can't escape yourself. Coming to the fear of teeth, I knew my number was up. Reeling out, the next thing I saw was a photo of a black spot inked on to Gordon's hand, like Blind Pugh's dreaded Black Spot in Treasure Island. We're all marked, I thought. This is a major theme in Gordon's work.

He takes us into a yellow room where we can listen to the jazz that was around when Gordon's mum was pregnant with the young Douglas, in 1966. Coltrane and Archie Shepp lilt from the speakers. An earlier version, sited in a blue room, played the pop of the era.

Gordon's work is packed with references, and not only to film. His is a far more literary and literate art than his film appropriations alone might suggest. Its darkness is morbid, the reverse side of the Turner coin. Where Turner saw angels in the sun, Gordon writes of meeting the devil in a dingy bar. Scottish Calvinism and the influence of his mother's conversion to the Jehovah's Witnesses when Gordon was a child have marked him. His mum found Jehovah, and Gordon discovered Warhol and Duchamp. All the references in his work get inextricably mixed together.

If Turner's paintings are a stew, so too is Gordon's mind, as the catalogue, even more than the show itself, demonstrates. What his work reminds us is that the books we read, the films we see, the music we listen to and the art we look at are not secondary experiences, but become as much a part of our lives as falling in love, broken hearts, or being dragged around housing estates as a kid to doorstep strangers with the Watchtower. And they all end up getting used in Gordon's work. Gordon has the word "forever" tattooed on his forearm (he wanted the black spot tattooed on to his palm, but the tattooist wouldn't do it). Forever? Nothing lasts forever. I take the thought with me back to where the Turners hang, in the disappearing daylight.

 Douglas Gordon and JMW Turner: The Sun Is God are at Tate Liverpool (0151-702 7400) till October 1.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Cotton Appeal
fields.body:
Anna Kournikova: hate her, wouldn't want to date her. So said bitter lemon rivals at the start of Wimbledon yesterday. Dealing with the fact that the 19-year-old Russian is not only worth wads more but gets buckets more attention is clearly character-building for her fellow players. But Sidelines spots a bigger reason for concern: her smalls. The aforementioned wads were recently augmented by a £3m deal struck with Berlei to advertise their sports bras. "Only the ball should bounce" says the billboard, featuring a resolutely boing-free Anna. Given that equality is within our grasp, we can obviously look forward to a companion range starring That Lovely Tim Henman: how about "Only one ball should bounce and I'd rather it wasn't mine"?

But maybe he lacks Cotton Appeal. Coral bookmakers are offering 3:1 on Kournikova showing a knicker colour other than white, while sportinglife.com ads offer full-page flashes of arse. And why not? There's nothing we like better than a glimpse of crisp white cotton. It reminds us of schoolgirls. Mmm. And it's not as if it puts her off playing, er, what is it you do again, dear?

If those tennis dames are in any doubt about the rectitude of covering up, note that psychologists believe the ability to perform intellectual tasks plummets the more flesh a woman reveals. "A woman wearing a bikini literally can't think straight," says clinical psycho Dr Ron Bracey. "She may feel the effect for hours or even days." This week's Sidelines was written in a sealed binbag. (But what was I wearing underneath?)

fields.headline: Temper, temper
fields.standfirst: A new study shows women lose it if they lose things. What does that say about us? And why isn't female anger taken seriously?  Terri Apter reports
fields.trailText: A new study shows women lose it if they lose things. What does that say about us? And why isn't female anger taken seriously?  Terri Apter reports
fields.body:
You recognise it immediately: there is the sudden heightening of colour, the tightening mouth line, the hardening and increase in voice pitch. Here is a woman losing her temper. And, however brief her loss of control, she also loses face and loses dignity. If she's over 40, she is seen as a harridan. If she's over 30, she's called a "bitch" or a "cow". Only if she is 20, and very pretty, is she simply "highly strung".

It takes special skill for a woman to lose her temper well. To do so, she has to draw up her chest, hold her head high and speak loud and low. She also needs to be in a position of power. Only then can her anger become a source of respect rather than of ridicule. But even Margaret Thatcher, as prime minister, could feel sidelined by stereotypes. "When a woman shouts, she is said to be shrill; when a man shouts, he is said to be strong," she was reported as saying soon after she left No 10.

Our temper is what we lose when we think we have already lost control. An NOP poll of 1,000 people conducted for internet site yell.com found that people in Britain today are likely to "lose it" when they lose one of those little items that is essential to the smooth running of their lives. While men are likely to swear in anger when those car keys that were in their hand a minute before have now disappeared, women, the poll finds, are more likely to burst into tears and want to punch something.

The so-called over-reaction of women in this study can also be linked to an insecure sense of power. A perfectly secure person would not be fazed by these little glitches. They can't find the meeting agenda they put on their desk 10 minutes ago? No problem. They can borrow someone else's or ask a secretary to print out another copy for them.

In another frame of mind, however, walking into a meeting without the agenda makes one look bad, while losing one's car keys is a sign of ineptitude or persistent bad luck. While women today do not have a special claim on being stressed or hassled, they tend to take it personally. "I'm not coping" and therefore "I'm not up to scratch" is a familiar response.

We are more likely to lose our temper when we feel we don't have a right to be angry - and women are more likely than men to question the validity of their anger. In the 19th century, some child-rearing handbooks assumed that little girls did not even feel anger and therefore did not have to be taught how to control it in the same way boys did.

While anger is something we all claim now as part of our humanity, women still seem (and often see themselves as) ridiculous when they lose their temper. This can increase their anger ("Don't you dare laugh at me!") or lead to exaggerated apologies ("I really don't know what came over me").

Women's purported shame at their loss of temper is often used against them, just as their purported regret at giving in to sexual desire has been. Like all claims about any loss of control by women, it is plausible enough to distort a probable truth, particularly when a woman has been drinking. One effect of alcohol is to make people less inhibited and this inhibition lubricates the social scene. We are happy to take a risk with a joke or a gesture, we don't worry too much about the consequences of a verbal or sexual indiscretion, and we worry less about displaying hostility.

Many women fear their husbands more when they are drunk, knowing that they are then more likely to be abusive. A quirk of destiny means that when a man expresses hostility, he is more likely than a woman to injure his spouse. Relative to men's, most women's uninhibited hostility does little physical damage to a spouse. When a woman seriously injures a man, she has to plan ahead.

It may be women's physical strength, relative to that of men, that makes their anger often seem silly rather than frightening. But it is also this position of relative subordination that is likely to arouse anger in the first place. We shout, after all, when no one listens to our normal voice. We shout to make ourselves heard.

If this is so, then women may have to do a health check on their willingness to make themselves heard. While girls today are taught the dangers of being too nice and are encouraged to stand up for themselves, they still freeze over when disagreements arise between friends. While most women are advised that self-assertion is fair play at work, they remain far more likely to be indirect in their criticisms of employees or colleagues.

Even in the most neutral zone of human exchange, women's speech can be painfully indirect. "Would you like a coffee?" is a question that seems to have a simple yes or no answer, but it may be a ruse for attending to one's own desire for coffee while appearing to be looking after the desires of someone else. If a companion does not want a coffee, and the question was made because we actually wanted a coffee ourselves, then the no becomes a foil to fulfilment of our own wishes.

In the bedroom, too, British women are slow to tell their partners what's what. According to Shere Hite's new report, 60% of her British sample thought their men were no good in bed, yet they pretended to enjoy things rather than speak out. Perhaps they thought encouragement would, indirectly, lead to improvement.

Indirectness is an inefficient means of communicating. When we feel that we are not communicating, we feel ignored and frustrated. "They should know what I mean, I shouldn't have to ask," are the murmurings of someone who may be about to lose her temper because she lacks other means to be effective. When we are shouting, we could do well to suppose it is because we are not speaking clearly enough.

Even in the most neutral zone of human exchange, women's speech can be painfully indirect. "Would you like a coffee?" is a question that seems to have a simple yes or no answer, but it may be a ruse for attending to one's own desire for coffee while appearing to be looking after the desires of someone else. If a companion does not want a coffee, and the question was made because we actually wanted a coffee ourselves, then the no becomes a foil to fulfilment of our own wishes. In the bedroom, too, British women are slow to tell their partners what's what. According to Shere Hite's new report, 60% of her British sample thought their men were no good in bed, yet they pretended to enjoy things rather than speak out. Perhaps they thought encouragement would, indirectly, lead to improvement. Indirectness is an inefficient means of communicating. When we feel that we are not communicating, we feel ignored and frustrated. "They should know what I mean, I shouldn't have to ask," are the murmurings of someone who may be about to lose her temper because she lacks other means to be effective. When we are shouting, we could do well to suppose it is because we are not speaking clearly enough.

fields.headline: The bigger picture
fields.standfirst: Nick Ut's searing image helped end the Vietnam war. Now a new collection of his photographs gives a fuller account of the moments before and after the infamous plane attack.  Martin Woollacott  reports
fields.trailText: Nick Ut's searing image helped end the Vietnam war. Now a new collection of his photographs gives a fuller account of the moments before and after the infamous plane attack. Martin Woollacott reports
fields.body:
Every picture tells a story, but the stories which some pictures tell continue to develop long after the film was first put into its chemical bath. Nick Ut's photograph of nine-year-old Phan Thi Kim Phuc running in agony and fear out of her village after a napalm attack in June, 1972, had an extraordinary impact around the world.

While it certainly influenced attitudes to the Vietnam war, the image also rose above the detail of place and time, of witness and perpetrator, because it showed with terrible economy how war kills, damages and ruins children. There can hardly have been an adult in the world who has looked it then or since who did not instantly see their own daughter or sister running down that road in Kim Phuc's place.

The psychological history of the war seems inconceivable without this image. Along with half a dozen other photographs, it helped at some deep level to shape the popular feelings which in turn influenced policy. Kim Phuc's moment of terror deepened the scepticism with which, by mid-1972, the war was being viewed. The fact that the napalm strike was a case of friendly fire, the result of a mistake by the South Vietnamese air force, reinforced that message.

But the photograph only reached the world after passing through a gauntlet of human decisions and by means of a technology that now appears antique. The picture hung in the balance as Nick Ut, the 20-year-old Vietnamese photographer who took it, broke with standing instructions that film should be brought back without delay and drove Kim Phuc and other injured villagers to hospital, and again when an editor at the Associated Press bureau in Saigon rejected it on the grounds that it showed full frontal nudity. Horst Faas, the Austrian head of the bureau and himself a famous photographer, argued with headquarters in New York that an exception should be made. It was laboriously sent by photo transmitter to Tokyo, line by line. The image was so powerful that it was immediately appropriated by the Vietnamese communists for propaganda use.

Now, in an exhibition at the Science Museum, that extraordinary picture will appear in its context, in a set of Nick Ut's photographs showing the plane attack and how the terrified girl was subsequently rescued by a TV film crew.

Three years after those events, Nick Ut was flown out of Vietnam and has spent his life since mainly in North America, where he continues to work for AP. Kim Phuc has also settled in North America. She and her husband,Bui Huy Toan, defected in Canada while on a flight from Cuba to Moscow. Both of them will be at the Science Museum today, to meet the Queen when she launches the exhibition.

 Making the Modern World, part of the Wellcome Wing project at the Science Museum, London SW7 (020 7938 8000), opens tomorrow.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: • Merger decision
fields.body:
 Merger decision

European competition commissioner Mario Monti said yesterday that he will recommend rejecting Worldcom's $120bn (£80bn) purchase of Sprint if the companies make no changes to their merger plan.

Mr Monti said if there were no new proposals from Worldcom - and he noted pointedly none had been received yet - "well then, my proposal to the commission will be to prohibit the merger" by a July 12 deadline.

 Talks fail

Internet company Freecom.net yesterday reported that talks aimed at securing the sale of a large part of the group had collapsed. In a statement to the stock exchange the group, which in May revealed it had received an approach for part of its business, said negotiations have been terminated.

But it said that talks aimed at finding a telecoms partner for the roll out of its hosting strategy were continuing with further news on developments planned when "negotiations reach an appropriate stage".

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Not so long ago Freeserve was a stock market darling, a company which had made no profits and yet was valued at billions more than its parent, Dixons , a company with hundreds of outlets and a proven track record. Dixons chairman Sir Stanley Kalms thought that this was a case of the markets not quite getting their priorities right.
fields.body:
Not so long ago Freeserve was a stock market darling, a company which had made no profits and yet was valued at billions more than its parent, Dixons , a company with hundreds of outlets and a proven track record. Dixons chairman Sir Stanley Kalms thought that this was a case of the markets not quite getting their priorities right.

Now the chickens are coming home to roost.

Yesterday Freeserve topped the FTSE 100 fallers after pouring cold water on bid hopes. The internet firm confirmed it has held talks with T-Online of Germany, but admitted they were not expected to lead to an offer for the whole group. The lack-of-a-deal news was accompanied by full-year results which saw pre-tax losses extended to almost £20m, up from £1.5m loss last year. Freeserve shares shed 73.75p to 365p. Shares in Dixons suffered too, shedding 20.5p to 263.5p.

Other internet stocks fell in tandem and in reaction to Lehman Brothers' report on Friday raising fears over Amazon.com's creditworthiness and its revenue growth potential.

While Amazon recovered yesterday, its British relatives did not do so well: Infobank was off 52.5p to 887.5p, Scoot.com fell 7.25p to 156p, internet investor Durlacher was 3.75p lower at 105.25p and QXL was down 3.25p to 105.25p, although it could have been much worse, falling at one stage to 95p.

But Freecom.net bucked the sector, adding 3p to 63p after it said talks aimed at securing the sale of a large part of the group had collapsed.

Telecoms were troubled too. Colt Telecom fell 120p to £24.30, C&W was off 29p to £11.51 and BT was down 14p at 915p.

However, Telewest topped the FTSE 100 leaders list after news that Dutch-listed UPC has bought a 25% stake in the firm for an undisclosed sum. UPC has acquired the stake as part of an asset swap with its US parent firm, Unitedglobal.com. Telewest gained 25p at 299p.

At the close, the Techmark 100 index was down 26.4 points at 3,495.74.

Banks had a good day with Lloyds TSB rose 26.5p to 629p after HSBC Securities set a 720p price target. Barclays was 41p firmer at £16.06, Woolwich climbed 11.25p to 279p and Abbey National rose 11p to 762p.

Unilever rallied after recent falls, gaining 5p to 418p while another multiple combine doing well was Diageo, up 6.5p at 586.5p, reflecting speculation about a spin-off of its Pilsbury food unit, hot on the heels of the announcement of plans to float its Burger King unit on the New York stock exchange.

fields.headline: Pace Micro Technology
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
www.pace.co.uk
fields.trailText: Shares in Pace Micro Technology, Europe's leading digital TV set-top-boxmaker, closed up 24.5p at 959p yesterday. The price change values the company at £2bn, and came in the wake of a three-year deal with Comcast Cable Communications, the third largest cable company in the US.
fields.body:
Shares in Pace Micro Technology, Europe's leading digital TV set-top-boxmaker, closed up 24.5p at 959p yesterday. The price change values the company at £2bn, and came in the wake of a three-year deal with Comcast Cable Communications, the third largest cable company in the US.

The deal means Pace will be the only manufacturer supplying cable set-top boxes to both Motorola and Scientific-Atlantic, which combined control 95% of the cable infrastructure in the US. First delivery of the high specification 400,000-unit order is expected at the end of 2001.

Pace chief executive Malcolm Miller said: "This deal means we can reach the broad US market. It builds on the deal we did with Time Warner last year, and I would hope to sign at least one more US deal by the end of the year."

The deal follows strong interim results in December which valued Pace at £1.8bn, with half-year turnover up by 60% to £157m and pre-tax profits up by 53% to £12.7m. In May, broker Credit Suisse First Boston raised forecasts for year-end, pre-tax profits by 7% to £25.7m. Final results are expected in July.

Pace had a series of set-backs after its 1996 float, including falling sales and share price as the market waited for digital technology to take off. In 1998 the share price stayed below 100p despite new contracts with ONdigital, BSkyB, Cable & Wireless and NTL. Turnover and profits have had a bumper year, however, following the boom in digital broadcast technology.

One analyst said yesterday that, as the speed of digital roll-out accelerates, "Pace Micro has proven again it can develop and integrate its technology and open new markets. It is pretty encouraging."

fields.headline: Terry Forrestal
fields.standfirst: Gentle stunt man dedicated to a macho art
fields.trailText: For a man doing the most macho job on the film set, there was an unusual innocence about Terry Forrestal, who has died in a base-jumping accident in Norway, aged 52. He was utterly professional, meticulous and physically tough; he was also gentle, generous and wounded.
fields.body:
For a man doing the most macho job on the film set, there was an unusual innocence about Terry Forrestal, who has died in a base-jumping accident in Norway, aged 52. He was utterly professional, meticulous and physically tough; he was also gentle, generous and wounded.

For 15 years, Terry had been one of Europe's leading film stunt coordinators, designing, planning, budgeting and choreographing action sequences to fit the director's requirements. His credits include some of British cinema's greatest recent successes - The Full Monty, Trainspotting and Elizabeth among them - but his involvement in film went back to the days of Nicolas Roeg, Roland Joffé, Terry Gilliam and Hugh Hudson.

In television, he worked with Alan Clarke on Contact and Made In Britain, with Peter Kosminsky on Shoot To Kill, and with Charles MacDougall on Hillsborough. His last job was on John Strickland's Rebel Heart, for BBC television; they had the formidable task of mounting everything from lancer charges through 1916 Dublin streets to guerrilla ambushes in the Wicklow mountains.

Terry was born in Chesterfield and educated at Finchley Catholic grammar school in north London. He was shy and quiet as a boy, and contemplative as a teenager. But there was a restlessness about him that took hold soon after the death of his mother, just as he was finishing secondary education. He took her death hard and, abandoning plans to go to university, set off to travel the world.

Deeply affected by what he saw in Bombay and Calcutta, he returned home and, with an idealism that he never lost, determined to take up medicine and dedicate himself to the poor of the developing world. Though Terry stuck at his studies for almost a year, it was never a realistic ambition; he was never suited to the library or the lecture hall, and the pull of adventure proved impossible to resist.

In 1975, he joined the territorial army, and went on to the SAS at Hereford. He saw service in Ireland during the height of the "dirty war". He rarely talked about these years, routinely deflecting questions, even from very close friends like the producer Christopher Figg. After leaving the army, he made a smooth transition to the film world, notching up early credits on such productions as Brazil, Greystoke, Memphis Belle and Mona Lisa.

Terry was proud of his association with the SAS, but his views on Ireland were not what one might have expected from someone of this background. I first met him last November, when Rebel Heart's producer, Malcolm Craddock, introduced us at a lunch for director and cast.

I was surprised at his enthusiasm for a drama about the Easter rising and war of independence, but I had not counted on the depth of Terry's affinity with all things Irish. From the set in Dublin, he sent me an outline for a script based on his experiences as a soldier in Ireland, and we arranged to meet after he got back to London from his base-jumping holiday in Norway.

On the set of Rebel Heart, Terry, dressed as always in tracksuit and trainers, appeared cheerful. He had lost weight after a low spell following the break-up of his relationship with a young equestrian stuntwoman, and his sisters and friends thought he was getting over it. He was full of plans for the future, including setting up an equestrian centre to train stunt horses. However, those closest to him say he was still struggling with depression.

It seems almost too pat to suggest that Terry's pursuit of extreme sports stemmed from a profound and long-term unhappiness, but it is hard to avoid the conclusion. There was, as Malcolm Craddock said, a gap in his life. Base-jumping is one of the world's most dangerous sports, with the participant parachuting from a fixed object - usually a bridge or mountain.

In this case, it was a 3,000ft cliff - Kjerag, in Lysefjord, Norway. Terry made eight jumps with Allan Hewitt, a skydiving friend, but something went wrong on the final jump and he landed badly on a ledge 2000ft down. He signalled to a circling helicopter that his legs were injured, possibly broken.

Allan and the team alerted mountain rescue, but some 10 hours later Terry was still stranded on the ledge and out of communication. It was cold and darkness was falling. Possibly believing he had been abandoned, Terry decided - characteristically - to sort the problem out for himself, and jumped from the ledge. There was, however, insufficient height for his parachute to open properly. Unknown to Terry, rescue was only an hour or two away.

Terry Forrestal, film stunt coordinator, born May 13 1948; died June 10 2000

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Bill Papas (Obituary, June 26) had unconventional working practices.
fields.body:
Christine Eade writes: Bill Papas (Obituary, June 26) had unconventional working practices. My desk in the Guardian newsroom in 1968 was closest to his partitioned office. A few days after I joined the paper, the swarthy, exotic Papas popped his head out to ask: "How do you spell tomorrow?" I thought he had made a philosophical joke, but played safe by spelling it for him. A few days later, when he asked how to spell de Gaulle, I realised that his communication was visual, rather than word-based.

I was not his only close-at-hand resource. If his cartoon needed a pattern, he would hold his drawing paper against the grey partition which formed his office, and scribble on the paper to transfer the textured finish on to his cartoon. When he left the Guardian and England, I missed these unusual diversions.

Peter Rankin writes: Craig Stevens (Obituary, May 16) may have had his career revived by the television series, Peter Gunn, but we in Britain only knew Henry Mancini's theme tune. The TV series we did know Craig Stevens from was Man Of The World, made here in the early 1960s. This time he played a sophisticated, well-dressed photographer - and Henry Mancini wrote the theme for that too.

MA Blackwell writes: I consider that the one-man show, the Seven Ages Of Man by Sir John Gielgud (Obituary, May 23) was quite simply the finest piece of acting I have ever seen. Wearing a lounge suit and with just a chair, a side-table and a lectern, Sir John brought to life, in all their emotional complexity, a kaleidoscope of Shakespeare's characters. It was a tour-de-force and his audience was entranced. None of us fortunate enough to have been there will ever forget it.

webTitle: Russia says hacker was CIA spy

fields.headline: Russia says hacker was CIA spy
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia's domestic security service, the FSB, said yesterday that a Lithuanian had been caught hacking into the agency's computer systems and had confessed that he was spying for the US.
fields.body:
Russia's domestic security service, the FSB, said yesterday that a Lithuanian had been caught hacking into the agency's computer systems and had confessed that he was spying for the US.

"A Lithuanian citizen, exposed by members of the FSB, gave a detailed testimony that while being an agent of the Lithuanian state security department he was active on a CIA special operation from the beginning of 1999," said a statement by the successor body to the Soviet-era KGB.

The hacking operation, it alleged, aimed at getting information on the FSB's structure and on whatever counter-measures Russia was taking against western intelligence operations.

It said the unnamed agent also confessed that between April and May this year - before a visit by President Bill Clinton to Moscow - he had the task of recruiting an FSB agent through a meeting in Poland.

Mr Clinton visited Moscow at the beginning of this month and met his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, himself a former member of the KGB.

The two leaders hailed their meetings as the start of a new era of easier relations between the former cold war enemies after a year of tensions over arms control, Nato's bombing of Serbia and Russia's offensive in the breakaway republic of Chechnya.

The FSB has accused foreign intelligence services of stepping up their activities in Russia despite the end of the cold war.

The FSB has accused foreign intelligence services of stepping up their activities in Russia despite the end of the cold war.

fields.headline: Philippe Chatrier
fields.standfirst: French champion with a vision to transform the world of professional tennis
fields.trailText: Philippe Chatrier, who has died at the age of 72, was a man of passion and complexity, whose visionary influence helped transform the world of professional tennis. First, as president of the French Tennis Federation, and later as leader of the international body, he brought a rare blend of pragmatic commercialism and idealistic values to a sport he played at a high standard himself.
fields.body:
Philippe Chatrier, who has died at the age of 72, was a man of passion and complexity, whose visionary influence helped transform the world of professional tennis. First, as president of the French Tennis Federation, and later as leader of the international body, he brought a rare blend of pragmatic commercialism and idealistic values to a sport he played at a high standard himself.

By the time Chatrier made his bid for power, he had been French junior champion, played at Wimbledon and been a member of the French Davis Cup squad. Such was his energy that he founded Tennis de France magazine while working as a sports editor for a Paris newspaper. In his spare time, he ran an old boys rugby team that played a Press XV on the eve of Five Nation internationals. He was also involved in the archaic world of tennis politics, soon realising that the old guard would have to go if any progress was to be made.

In 1968, Chatrier engineered a situation whereby a political ally, the former French champion Marcel Bernard, was elected president of the federation for a four-year period. In that time he marshalled his forces, and completed the coup by getting himself elected as Bernard's successor. Unlike virtually all other amateur leaders of national federations, Chatrier was able to turn the post into a full-time job because he received money in the form of a trust from his magazine.

One of his first tasks was the renovation of the decaying complex at Roland Garros, which had been used briefly as a holding depot for Jewish prisoners during the second world war. Going directly to President Pompidou, he asked for £10m - and got it. Within a few years, he had also won permission to take over a couple of adjacent rugby fields, so that the complex could be doubled in size. When he assumed control of French tennis, there were 100,000 registered players and 500 clubs. Two decades later, the figures had leapt to 1.5m players and 10,000 clubs.

By then, Chatrier had become a major player on the international stage, as tennis struggled to come to terms with its new open status. He had also become very close to the professionals, who had been banned from the mainstream game before Wimbledon's Herman David forced the issue of open tennis in 1968. Jack Kramer, leader of the professional troupe, was to become a lifelong friend, as was Tony Trabert, another Wimbledon champion, who set up an office in Paris in the 60s.

It was during long meetings with Kramer, and one of the game's first agents, Donald Dell, that Chatrier poured over futuristic plans at his apartment on the Avenue des Ternes. There, one evening in 1969, Kramer laid out his blueprint for a grand prix circuit, while Chatrier's wife, the former British Wightman Cup player, Susan Partridge, served us all with drinks. The grand prix became the basis of the points-linked, world-wide circuit that is now incorporated into the ATP Tour.

Chatrier found the international federation less malleable. Far-flung presidents of small associations, who all had a vote, made for slow progress; Chatrier used to joke about how long it took "to get my elephants into line". Nevertheless, he worked tirelessly throughout the political battles of the 70s and 80s, chairing innumerable pro-council meetings, as he tried to balance the needs of an expanding professional sport with the ideals of the amateur game that were always close to his heart.

Along with his general secretary David Gray, the former tennis correspondent of the Guardian, he championed the cause of tennis returning to the Olympics, and was elected a member of the IOC in 1991.

Chatrier was an introspective man, who frequently seemed remote. He was also, however, a gregarious and charming host, whose brisk manner was softened by a ready humour. He was an excellent public speaker in French or English, and it was, sadly, at a dinner in Toulouse in 1991 that the first signs of his illness became apparent.

When he rose to speak, it suddenly became evident that he was losing the thread. His words were punctuated by 15 or 20 seconds of silence. It was so unlike Philippe that there were murmurs of incomprehension at our table afterwards. Alzheimer's disease would soon force him to step down from the the ITF presidency after an unprecedented tenure of 14 years.

After the dissolution of his marriage to Susan, with whom he had two sons, he married Claudine Cros, a leading French golfer, who nursed him when he retired to Brittany. Chatrier was one of the outstanding sports administrators of his age. Imbued with the Aquarian trait of wanting to change the world, he undoubtedly changed the world of tennis.

fields.headline: £26m haul found in suitcase
fields.trailText: Police in Egypt believe they have uncovered an important antiquities smuggling operation, after seizing items worth £26.6m.
fields.body:
Police in Egypt believe they have uncovered an important antiquities smuggling operation, after seizing items worth £26.6m.

A former police major-general who used to be head of security at Alexandria's Nozha airport, Reda Ahmed Aqrab, is alleged to have tried to play on his previous status at the airport to help dealers smuggle 150 Roman and Greek items to Germany last week.

Mr Aqrab and his travelling companion, Hamdi Abdel-Raouf, a businessman, are in detention pending charges after Mr Aqrab was stopped at Alexandria airport with a suitcase weighing 50 kilos.

He is reported to have joked with his former colleagues and staff, expecting the VIP lounge to be opened for him. Instead he was taken to his old office. In the case, customs officers allegedly found "a museum". Mr Aqrab then said he was carrying the case for Mr Abdel-Raouf.

The suspects are said to be part of a ring allegedly led by an Alexandria dealer.

Their homes and that of the dealer were later raided and more antiquities were recovered, police said.

webTitle: New law to end Iran's press purge

fields.headline: New law to end Iran's press purge
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: Iran is witnessing the death and rebirth of its reformist press, with the closure of one of the country's last progressive newspapers but the prospect of a new law to help resurrect some 17 publications which were banned in April.
fields.body:
Iran is witnessing the death and rebirth of its reformist press, with the closure of one of the country's last progressive newspapers but the prospect of a new law to help resurrect some 17 publications which were banned in April.

Conservatives in a special hardline clerical court on Sunday closed the Bayan daily - one of the few major progressive newspapers to survive the recent purge - leaving the reform movement stripped of the powerful voice that had roused massive public support in recent years.

But reformist MPs in the new national parliament began last week to reverse the damage by drafting a new law which will make it far more difficult for the courts to close newspapers arbitrarily.

One provision in the draft law requires that legal action against a newspaper must be heard by general courts in open session in the presence of a jury. Another protection allows publishers of banned newspapers to open another title immediately.

Reformers won a majority in February's parliamentary election, but conservatives in governmental bodies still have the power to overturn laws passed by parliament.

Iran's progressive press, has increasingly pushed the limits of free debate. By the time most of the newspapers was shut down in April, photographs of women were appearing on front pages while comments by Iran's highest officials were pushed to the back, and editorials were riddled with stinging criticism of the establishment.

fields.headline: Right to survive
fields.standfirst:
Ships push whale species to brink of extinction

WWF
International Whaling Commission national archives
fields.trailText: Ships are colliding with and killing slow-moving right whales in such numbers along the Canadian and US coasts that the species faces extinction.
fields.body:
Ships are colliding with and killing slow-moving right whales in such numbers along the Canadian and US coasts that the species faces extinction.

Only one calf was born this breeding season, and campaigners believe that unless the shipping lanes are moved during the whales' breeding season the carnage will lead to the disappearance of the northern right whale.

In a report published yesterday, the World Wide Fund for Nature said the precise areas where right males courted, mated and gave birth were known. Ships had to notify US and Canadian coastguards when they entered the area but this did not prevent the whales being run down.

Right whales were so-called because they contained so much oil they were easy to recover, because they floated after they were harpooned, making them the "right whale" to kill. But even after the species was protected in 1935, its population has failed to thrive.

Breeding success has been limited, and there are fears that pollution may be partly to blame. Only 38% of the females are thought to be reproductively active.

Exact numbers are not known but fewer than 300 adults are thought to survive in the north Atlantic. Six new calves were spotted in 1998, three last year and only one this year - the poorest season on record.

Despite the falling birth rate, the main cause of the decline has been from ships running down the whales. About 90% of dead right whales show injuries from being hit by ships.

The report was timed to coincide with the International Whaling Commission meeting next week in Australia, when Canada and the US will be asked to bring in further protection measures.

Stuart Chapman, international conservation officer for the WWF, said right whales returned to the same areas each year to feed and breed. So moving shipping lanes to spare them would be comparatively easy.

webTitle: Tough times loom for Japan's PM

fields.headline: Tough times loom for Japan's PM
fields.trailText: Japan's prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, has shrugged off his administration's poor showing in Sunday's general election after his ruling coalition lost more than 60 seats in the 480-seat lower house of parliament.
fields.body:
Japan's prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, has shrugged off his administration's poor showing in Sunday's general election after his ruling coalition lost more than 60 seats in the 480-seat lower house of parliament.

But Mr Mori, whose frequent gaffes are seen as the main reason for the slide in the administration's popularity, insisted that the conservative governing bloc still had the confidence of the public.

Whether he remains in power for very long beyond next month's G8 summit in Okinawa remains in doubt. Many in his Liberal Democratic party are seething at the election losses that they blame on Mr Mori's tendency to put his foot in his mouth.

With an upper house election due next summer, his popularity - now below 20% - will have to pick up quickly or he will be seen as a liability.

Cracks are also starting to emerge in the governing coalition, because the LDP's partners - the New Komei party and the New Conservative party - were the heaviest losers in the poll.

Despite a public show of support, officials of Komei - which has the backing of more than 7m voters - muttered to the press that they felt cheated by a lopsided electoral pact that worked mostly in the LDP's favour.

webTitle: Women in Kuwait call for suffrage

fields.headline: Women in Kuwait call for suffrage
fields.trailText: A group of Kuwaiti women yesterday launched a legal claim for full political rights. They are asking a court to decide whether the electoral law which prevents women from voting or standing for public office violates the constitution.
fields.body:
A group of Kuwaiti women yesterday launched a legal claim for full political rights. They are asking a court to decide whether the electoral law which prevents women from voting or standing for public office violates the constitution.

Last February the women attempted to register as voters, citing a clause in the constitution which says "all people are equal in human dignity and in public rights" - but their applications were rejected.

"Women achieved a lot of rights after the discovery of oil - in health, education, and so on," Dr Fatima al-Abdali, head of a Kuwaiti women's committee told a recent conference in London. "But there is a problem of women reaching decision-making positions and achieving political rights."

The Emir of Kuwait, Sheikh Jaber al-Sabah, has been attempting to improve women's rights and has appointed several women to key posts, including the rector of Kuwait university and the ambassador in Vienna. In May last year the emir issued a decree granting women full political rights, but parliament later rejected it as unconstitutional.

Supporters of women's rights then introduced a bill in parliament which was defeated by only two votes.

fields.headline: Testigo
fields.standfirst: Ferran Alegre, a vet, talks about healing a striped dolphin and returning it to the sea
fields.trailText: Ferran Alegre, a vet, talks about healing a striped dolphin and returning it to the sea
fields.body:
Sería una casualidad increíble volver a ver a Ulises. Lo reconocería en seguida. Lo rescatamos de la playa de Mataró el viernes 12 de mayo. Estaba semi comatoso. Teníamos dos retos: curarlo y devolverlo al mar.

Los delfines listados no soportan la interacción del hombre y mueren al ser capturados. Pero Ulises era joven y con muchas ganas de vivir.

Estuvo con nosotros 14 días. Ha sido una experiencia muy intensa y positiva. Al principio se desmayó dos veces y se hundió al fondo de la piscina. No nos separábamos de él ni un segundo. Finalmente vomitó unos plásticos y empezó a recuperarse, hora a hora, día a día. Respondía a nuestros tratamientos.

Una vez curado teníamos que devolverlo al mar lo antes posible. El 25 de mayo nos avisaron que había un grupo de delfines en la zona. Temíamos capturar de nuevo a Ulises para liberarlo - podía sufrir un colapso.

Nos embarcamos rápidamente. Tardamos cuarenta minutos en llegar al grupo. Lo introdujimos en el mar y nos quedamos observando. Se alejó nadando y saltando a gran velocidad, como hacen los delfines listados. Y ésta es la historia de Ulises.

El CRAM es un centro veterinario pionero en el Mediterráneo. Un objetivo es socorrer y devolver al mar las ballenas, delfines y tortugas con problemas. Cada verano reintroducimos en el mar unas setenta tortugas.

Qué pasa con los delfines? Con los delfines se establece una relación especial. Es una sensación que tienes con su mirada. Sus ojos expresan inteligencia. Espero que Ulises esté recuperado y no encontrarlo nunca herido o muerto.

 Ferran Alegre works for CRAM, the Centre for the Recuperation of Marine Animals.

avisar to tell, inform

una casualidad a coincidence

desmayarse to faint

una gana a wish

hundirse to sink

listado striped

la mirada a look

rescatar to rescue

un reto a challenge

socorrer to help

fields.headline: Physical education
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor rounds up sites that will get you moving
fields.body:
PE Central
****
Aimed at: teachers

Only the fact that it is aimed at US PE teachers stops this site from receiving a five-star rating. The quantity and quality of information available is high; PE teachers send in tips and ideas and the range of lesson ideas is vast.

Game Central Station
***
Aimed at: teachers and parents

Over 350 searchable games for all ages. Some would suit out-of-school activities (such as Scout and Guide meetings) as well as PE lessons.

Netball Resources
****
Aimed at: everyone

The most comprehensive resource of its kind on the net and against the myth that netball is a woman's sport. Visitors will find drills, opportunities to join regional teams and leagues, and excellent links (including the All England Netball Association).

Sport England
**
Aimed at: everyone

An efficient and well-organised site but, sadly, apparently one that is more concerned with outlining lottery expenditure than providing practical help and resources. But you can download various policy documents and a publications list, along with details of the Sportsmark awards for successful PE teaching.

Sport Scotland
***
Aimed at: everyone

Much better than the English effort, Sport Scotland does the same thing but is more accessible.

Non-traditional gym
****
Aim: teachers

A US site which, through a less rigid lesson structure, encourages children to become more aware of their own movements and more confident in gym lessons. A few key stage 1 and 2 plans are included but, if you have the equipment, any of the suggestions could be used in PE lessons.

LTA Schools
***
Aimed at: everyone

Three useful sites for teachers, parents and children from the Lawn Tennis Association. The LTA can help with in-service training for teachers. Parents can contact its well-organised network of coaches for post-Wimbledon and summer holiday classes.

Schools Athletics Assoc
**
Aimed at: everyone

A basic site which, as the webmaster points out, needs more contributions from visitors. Basic safety information and recent results are available, but much more could be done.

English Hockey Assoc
**
Aimed at: everyone

Competitions and hockey news are the staple diet here. Visitors with a suitable homepage can link it to the Hockeyville network, but there is little chance for newcomers to learn more about the sport. For enthusiasts only.

Get Your Kit On
****
Aimed at: everyone

To encourage youngsters to abandon their Playstations and make up for six weeks without PE lessons, the BBC and five sporting bodies are offering free taster sessions of tennis, golf, football and athletics for 11- to 16-year-olds. The site has details of venues and enthusiastic backing from Sara Cox and Tim Henman. You can also win one of five pairs of inline skates.

fields.headline: Martin Milner
fields.standfirst: Barbirolli's right-hand man who led the Hallé through arduous times
fields.trailText: Martin Milner, who has died aged 72, was an outstanding musician and a brilliant leader of the Hallé Orchestra, whose contribution to the musical life of Manchester, and the many other towns and cities in which he performed, is unlikely to be equalled.
fields.body:
Martin Milner, who has died aged 72, was an outstanding musician and a brilliant leader of the Hallé Orchestra, whose contribution to the musical life of Manchester, and the many other towns and cities in which he performed, is unlikely to be equalled.

Born in Bolton, he attended Bolton school, before going on to the Royal Manchester college of music to study the violin, where his professors included Henry Holst. He joined the Hallé as leader in October 1958, having been chosen by Sir John Barbirolli to succeed Laurance Turner.

He continued to hold that position with great distinction under Sir John's successors, James Loughran and Stanislav Skrowaczewski, until he retired in the summer of 1987 after 29 years, a significantly longer period than any other leader in the orchestra's 140-year history.

Martin joined the Hallé at a critical time. Barbirolli had decided to reduce his commitment to the orchestra, which was being greatly overworked because of its serious underfunding problems. He soon established a perfect rapport with Sir John, a relationship vital to the orchestra's success. Barbirolli trusted Martin absolutely; he had great respect for his opinions and musicianship, an attitude shared by the many guest conductors with whom Martin worked, including Bernard Haitink, Daniel Barenboim and Arvid Yansons.

Barbirolli once wrote to Martin: "You are the finest leader I have ever had in my fairly long career." And when the Hallé Concerts Society presented its gold medal to him in 1963, Sir John insisted that the presentation be made by "my dear friend and colleague Martin."

Martin had, by now, effectively become Barbirolli's right arm. While Sir John was away conducting in Houston, Berlin and elsewhere, he would send detailed instructions to Martin requiring him to rehearse his next Mahler symphony, or other work new to the orchestra, and ask that he carry out auditions for him.

Martin also gave many highly successful concerto performances with the Hallé, including the Elgar, Bartok, Nielsen, Sibelius and Walton concertos, the last of which he also performed with the orchestra abroad. His performances of the Elgar, in particular, and the many outstanding orchestral solos, as in Strauss's Ein Heldenleben and Mahler's 9th Symphony, attracted considerable critical acclaim. Less stressful, but also impressive, were his summer collaborations as leader of the King's Lynn Festival Ensemble, a quartet which featured Sir John (cello), Lady Barbirolli (oboe) and Ruth, Lady Fermoy (piano).

Martin had a keen sense of humour, and treated everyone - regardless of their importance - with the same consideration and respect. His understanding of the problems faced by aspiring young players was a great encouragement to many. His willingness to stand up for the whole orchestra, or for individual members, when he felt they were being unfairly treated by conductors - including Barbirolli - or by the administration, won him great respect. He was always available to colleagues for help and advice on musical or personal problems. He enjoyed all the attributes of a great leader - not least his refusal to ask others to do anything he would not do himself.

Martin's early career, as well as his down-to-earth northern upbringing, undoubtedly helped prepare him for his Hallé role. When he auditioned for the leader's position - at the very young age of 30 - he was, on paper, the least likely candidate to succeed. He was playing in a spa orchestra at Weston-Super-Mare; before that he had been a member of Thomas Beecham's Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, and had previously led the Buxton Spa Orchestra, in addition to undertaking many freelance engagements.

In those early yers, he survived the impossibly arduous Hallé schedule of more than 250 concerts a year, an experience that may have contributed to his being less tolerant of those, in later years, who complained of overwork while playing significantly fewer concerts.

One of Martin's non-musical attributes was his prowess at snooker and, in his free time, he would go to Sheffield or Preston to watch the game.

Married three times, he had nine children - three sons and three daughters by his first wife, Elizabeth Walton, and three sons by his widow, Diana Wanklyn, who is principal double-bass player in the Hallé Orchestra.

Martin Milner, violinist and orchestra leader, born February 17 1928; died June 21 2000

fields.headline: Videoconferencing
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor on the latest in virtual meetings
fields.body:
Until quite recently, video conferencing had a reputation as something of an executive toy. One successful executive compained he could no longer get away with eating sandwiches as he talked to Belgian staff over lunch. Teachers, for the most part, were too busy bringing ICT into the curriculum to worry about an expensive method of broadcasting.

If you banish the thought of regional sales executives discussing results, video conferencing becomes more interesting. Suppose that your KS3 class is a few weeks away from its annual German exchange. Your pupils may know the names of their German counterparts - and have written to them - but have little idea what to expect. Inge of Munich is doubtless just as nervous. Linking the schools with a video conference means the children can introduce themselves and talk in English or German before the exchange.

Sustaining the friendships made in Germany becomes far easier if pupils can continue to "meet" and talk on a regular basis. The speaking and listening skills which were beginning to soar by the end of the exchange need not vanish a couple of weeks later.

Modern languages is not the only subject that can benefit. Park View Community School in Durham was recently awarded £25,000 by BT for a design and technology project. Pupils from one school will send their designs to students at another, who will engrave them on acrylic or wood. "It mimics what happens in industry when the design is done in one country and manufactured in another," says the head of D&T, Christopher Wilding. (See our special report for details of how to enter the BT Schools Awards.)

Sussex Virtual College uses video conferencing as part of its distance-learning programme. Engineering students can watch their designs being built by robots; part-timers can watch their lecturer. They can also see them via a series of small screens. Questions are "flagged up" electronically and can be answered on the spot or later on. The scheme cost the department of education £1.4m to install across Sussex.

For a technical explanation of video conferencing, visit the University of Plymouth's guide.

fields.headline: Hospitals
fields.trailText: A visit to the hospital can be a daunting prospect for young children. Luckily, there are several books currently available to help put their minds at rest.
fields.body:
A visit to the hospital, whether to have a check up, stay overnight or even visit a friend or family member, can be a daunting prospect for young children. Luckily, there are several books, both fiction and non-fiction, currently available to help put their minds at rest.

Aimed at children aged two to six, Dick Bruna's Miffy in Hospital (Egmont, £2.99) is a reassuring, simple picture book. Featuring the familiar and much loved character Miffy the white rabbit, this title in the series follows her visit to the hospital to have her tonsils removed. The bold, colourful illustrations and simple text makes this a joy to share with young children.

Topsy and Tim Go to the Hospital by Jean and Gareth Adamson (Ladybird Books, £2.99) explains what happens when Tim has to go into hospital after falling out of a tree and bumping his head. He has an X-ray and stays in the hospital for a couple of nights, but manages to make plenty of friends, and looks forward to visits from his mum and twin sister Topsy.

Part of the First Experience series aimed at three- to seven- year-olds, this is a gentle introduction to what children might expect when staying in, or visiting, a hospital for the first time.

The ever-difficult Little Princess returns in this highly entertaining title from Tony Ross, I Don't Want To Go To Hospital (Andersen Press, £8.99). Adamant that she will not go to hospital to have a lump removed from her nose, she tries her utmost to avoid the visit. However, when she eventually gets there, she is reluctant to leave, as they treat her like a princess! This light-hearted story for three- to seven-year-olds is narrated and illustrated with humour, and will help children to approach a visit to the hospital without fear or apprehension.

Hospital by Carol Watson (Franklin Watts, £9.99) is one of several titles in the Busy Places series, which charts 24 hours in a familiar busy environment. This title focuses on a handful of staff, patients and visitors during a typical day at a hospital. Suitable for four- to eight-year-olds, this book combines many colourphotographs with bold, clear text, as well as listing some useful safety tips at the end.

Rather than being read from cover to cover, Hospital (Series: Separations) by Janine Amos (Cherrytree Books, £8.99) is an excellent reference book to be delved into at random. It explores hospital experiences through letters, short stories and bullet points which together succeed in raising some commonly asked questions and dispelling anxieties. Interspersed with watercolour illustrations and photographs, there is quite a lot of text. It may be difficult for younger children to read alone, but would be ideal to share with children aged five years and over.

Finally, Hospital in the series Building Works by John Malam (Belitha Press, £10.99) is an excellent title for readers from eight to 11, who demand a high level of information. Beginning with a fold-out plan of a typical modern hospital, the book explores, room by room, the function and running of each department. Moving from the operating theatre, to intensive care, to the children's ward, it also looks at behind the scenes departments such as the kitchens and laundry room.

Many of the extensive colour illustrations are labelled, and there is a detailed glossary at the back of the book. Ideal for use in the classroom.

 For a full list of titles about going to the hospital, contact Book Trust on 0906 516 1193 (calls charged at £1.50 per minute).

fields.headline: Violenza dietro alle sbarre
fields.standfirst: As jail guards and a director are charged with beating up inmates,  Mariacarla Pavoni asks what can be done about Italy's prisons
fields.trailText: As jail guards and a director are charged with beating up inmates, Mariacarla Pavoni asks what can be done about Italy's prisons
fields.body:
Il problema delle carceri italiane è esploso sui media all'inizio di maggio, con l'arresto di 82 persone, agenti di custodia e dirigenti del carcere di Sassari, in Sardegna. Pesanti le accuse: pestaggi e torture ai detenuti. La loro successiva scarcerazione non ha messo le cose a tacere. Da un lato protestano le guardie carcerarie, che si proclamano vittime di carenza di personale e strutture, dall'altro i "detenuti in lotta".

Questa la realtà con cui fare i conti: le carceri italiane, con una capienza regolamentare di 37.402 posti, ospitano 51.862 detenuti. Di questi, ben 41,21% sono stranieri, 36,10% si trovano in carcere per violazione della legge sulla droga e 29,26% sono tossicodipendenti.

Molte le proposte: costruire nuove carceri, impiegare più agenti, depenalizzare i reati minori, ripensare alla funzione del carcere, prevedere misure alternative alla detenzione. Dalle autorità religiose arriva la richiesta di indulto per l'anno del Giubileo.

Intanto una parte dell'opinione pubblica, spaventata dal crimine di strada, chiede pene severe per tutti.

Quale pensi debba essere la funzione del carcere?

Daniela, 17, studentessa - Penso dovrebbe aiutare il detenuto a meditare sul suo errore in solitudine e scontare la pena proporzionata al suo reato.

Simone,17, studente - Il carcere dovrebbe educare o rieducare la persona, per poterla reinserire nella società.

Bisognerebbe "ripensare" al carcere. Molti detenuti sono solo i pesci piccoli della delinquenza perché deboli o emarginati. Se non si riesce a renderli autonomi e forti, il carcere non ha senso.

Alfredo, 17, studente - Il carcere deve portare il detenuto a com-prendere la gravità del reato e le pene devono essere più dure o meno dure, secondo il crimine.

Vienna, 53, assistente volontaria - Come volontaria devo pensare che il carcere sia rieducativo. Alle Vallette, dove lavoro, si sta facendo un tentativo importante con le tossicodipendenze: un primo livello, per l'inserimento successivo in comunità.

Enrico, 31, obiettore di coscienza - Secondo la mia esperienza di servizio civile in un carcere minorile, il carcere rappresenta solo un'interruzione dei problemi. Quando si torna in libertà gli stessi problemi si ripresentano. Trascorrere l'adolescenza in un sistema repressivo e poi ritrovarsi nell'ambiente che ha generato il crimine non può portare dei cambiamenti, malgrado il lavoro e la buona volontà dei servizi sociali e degli educatori.

Quali consideri i problemi più gravi all'interno del carcere?

Daniela - Senz'altro il sovraffollamento. Ci sono più detenuti di quanti il carcere ne possa contenere. Molti reati minori potrebbero essere scontati in un altro luogo.

Alfredo - Giornali e televisione ne parlano molto, ma per capire i problemi del carcere bisognerebbe viverli in prima persona. Solo i detenuti possono sapere quale realtà si nasconde dietro quelle mura. Penso che esista violenza fra i detenuti e anche abuso di potere da parte degli agenti di custodia.

Vienna - Mi sono avvicinata al carcere recentemente. Lavoravo già in una comunità. Le prime volte che ci andavo, mi sentivo male. Anche da "liberi" il carcere è sofferenza. Vivere dal di dentro il carcere non è come pensarlo dall'esterno. Tutto è duro: la privazione della libertà, ma anche lo spazio, i rapporti, la mancanza di comunicazione.

Uno dei problemi di questo momento sono i rapporti fra guardie e detenuti.

Cosa pensi della proposta di indulto legata al Giubileo?

Daniela - Non sono d'accordo. Secondo me le pene devono essere scontate. Ma capisco che ci sia la necessità di diminuire la popolazione carceraria.

Alfredo - Questa richiesta non è coerente. I cittadini devono sapere che esistono pene che non vengono modificate. E poi la giustizia non c'entra con la religione.

Simone - Più che un collegamento col Giubileo, penso ci siano motivi di opportunità politica o di necessità di ridurre il numero dei detenuti, per frenare una situazione allo sbando.

Vienna - Non so se sia giusto. Per esserlo, dovrà far parte di un valido piano complessivo.

Quale tipo di delinquenza ti fa più paura?

Alfredo - Non riesco quasi a distinguere un tipo di delinquenza dall'altro. Vedo qualunque tipo di delinquenza pericolosa per la società e mi sembra che ormai ce la troviamo davanti a tutti i livelli.

Daniela - Mi fa paura la delinquenza legata agli extra- comunitari, gli immigrati che vengono sfruttati dalla malavita straniera e italiana.

Simone - Mi fa paura l'aggressione, a livello personale. Poi penso anche ai crimini che non si vedono per strada, il traffico di capitali e di persone, ad esempio.

Vienna - Temo lo spaccio della droga. Ma non i piccoli spacciatori, i poveracci, quelli che incontro in carcere, che sono vittime dello spaccio a loro volta. Temo i grossi personaggi, quelli che rimangono fuori.

Enrico - Temo soprattutto la violenza esercitata da posizioni di potere, da chi sfrutta la sua autorità sul più indifeso.

Glossario/Glossary

l'agente di custodia/la guardia carceraria guard

allo sbando (coll) running wild

dal di dentro from within

l'extra-comunitario person from outside the EU

fare i conti con qualcosa to face up to something

l'indulto (law) pardon (reduction of penalty)

in prima persona for oneself

mettere a tacere to hush up

non avere senso to be meaningless

non c'entra con (coll) has nothing to do with

il pestaggio (fam) beating

il poveraccio (coll) poor devil

il pesce piccolo (coll) small fry

le Vallette the name of Turin prison

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: My daughter is extremely able. I'm concerned that local state schools won't give her the academic education she needs.
fields.body:
My daughter is extremely able, with ambitions to become a vet. I'm concerned that local state schools won't give her the academic education she needs to get into top universities. We'd like her to go to the excellent, local public school, but I cannot afford it, even with a scholarship. What can I do?

Margaret Tulloch is spokesperson for the Campaign for State Education (Case).

I would challenge the assumption that a fee-paying education is automatically better than a state one. All schools must be judged upon their merits, by visiting them and talking to staff and parents whose children currently attend the school.

You feel that your child would benefit from an academic education and has ambitions to be a vet. But children's interests and abilities can change as they develop. A school should cater for this, rather than offer one type of education only - don't block off other avenues at too young an age.

Ensure that the school can provide chances to learn a range of skills. State schools usually cater for a wide variety of backgrounds, which helps children to cope better with most social encounters faced in adult life.

Find out how children similar to your own fare at various schools. Clarify whether special needs recognised after entry will be accepted, or if the child will have to leave or parents asked to pay extra. This is particularly pertinent to private education.

Find out whether candidates for public exams are selected, or whether all students can enter at the level appropriate to them.

Small class sizes should be used as an opportunity to enrich the curriculum, develop new ideas and allow the teacher to pay attention to individuals. Check that there are enough up-to-date books, computers, etc - and that they're used imaginatively.

This requires professionalism and on-going training. State schools have to employ trained teachers and have regular in-service training days. These are not requirements in private schools, although most do employ trained teachers and support some retraining.

Look for clear policies to deal with bullying and evidence of support for pupils in temporary difficulties, rather than exclusion as the knee-jerk response to any problem.

Investigate whether parents are encouraged to express their views through a home-school association. It's also useful to know how often you'll get reports and the chance to meet teachers.

You express concerns about the financial implications of a private education; could you spend some money on other educational advantages for the whole family, such as visits to concerts, plays, museums or travel?

There's a positive benefit to society in shared educational experiences in institutions that are open to all children and value their varying achievements. Through these experiences children can be helped to an acceptance of difference as something that enriches society rather than dividing it.

Helen Bate from Tarporley, Cheshire writes:

My son is studying to be a vet at Glasgow University after achieving the necessary qualifications at our local comprehensive.

If you or your daughter are concerned about your local school, you should ensure that you (or she) take control of her studies by obtaining copies of the relevant syllabuses and checking that her learning is complete. If necessary, extra tuition would help.

For veterinary medicine, extra-curricular activities are a must. Experience in veterinary practice can be arranged from an early age, and work experience with a range of animals would be beneficial. She should not neglect any other extra-curricular activities, especially those that may help her application to stand out. After all this, however, real determination is the best prerequisite for success.

Next week's query

My son will be starting year 9 in September. He's just found out that he's in bottom groups in every subject that "sets". He does try hard. What can we do to support him, and what should we be expecting the school to do to help him to try and move up?

fields.headline: Some you win...
fields.standfirst: Climate change is bringing unfamiliar wildlife to our shores and driving old friends out
fields.trailText: Climate change is bringing unfamiliar wildlife to our shores and driving old friends out
fields.body:
The climate of Britain is changing. The 1990s were the hottest decade on record. Did you notice? Probably not, with a home to shelter in and a fridge in which to store your food. But around us, the natural world is feeling the heat. Scientists say a whole range of plant, insect and animal species are adapting their behaviour to fit in with the hotter conditions.

Why is the climate changing?

Among other causes, pollution from cars and the use of fossil fuels - gas, coal and wood - are being blamed for putting excessive amounts of gases such as carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. These greenhouse gases allow the sun's rays into our atmosphere but stop them bouncing back into space, and so the world is heating up. In Britain some scientists think that temperatures will rise by between 1 and 2C by 2050.

Isn't that a tiny change?

No. Each one degree shift upwards in temperature is the same as Britain moving about 250km south.

How is this affecting Britain's plants, insects and animals?

Many species are very sensitive to temperature change. They respond in a number of ways. Some are starting to do things earlier in the year. Others are shifting further north and creatures that are not native to this country are starting to breed here. But not all are so flexible. Scientists are worried that some living things that can only survive in very specific environments may leave Britain entirely or face extinction as the climate alters.

Who is out there looking for signs of change?

Every year, the British Trust for Ornithology gathers information from its members about bird nests. Their observations over the past 25 years indicate that nearly a third of 65 species of birds are now laying their eggs earlier. Meanwhile, changes in butterfly behaviour and numbers have been spotted by the charity Butterfly Conservation. It relies on sightings by volunteers.

The Institute of Arable Crop Research at Rothamsted focuses on aphids and has been collecting them in 40 foot-high traps for the

last 30 years. And the evidence is that these insects are flying earlier. This matters greatly to farmers, who need to protect their crops earlier in the year against the aphids and the plant diseases they carry. At sea, since 1931 merchant ships have been dragging special silk nets for the Sir Alister Hardy Foundation, gathering information about plankton. The 200,000 samples taken in that time seem to indicate that warmer waters are causing dramatic changes in the microscopic life of the oceans around our shores. This may have a big knock-on effect for larger species of animals that rely on the plankton for food.

Who wins and who loses?

In the North Sea codfish will be big losers if temperatures rise. Even a 0.5C rise is enough to disturb them and send them north. Meanwhile a host of exotic sea species are heading into our coastal waters. These include leatherback turtles, trigger fish and giant sun fish which can grow as large as a small car.

It is feared that mountain birds such as the dotterel will soon find life in the Scottish Cairngorms intolerable. Species such as the little egret have started laying their eggs on the south coast, far from their normal nesting sites in southern Europe. Some non-native species have escaped from captivity into the wild and they, too, are thriving. In the orchards of Kent, ring-necked parakeets are becoming a pest - taking just a bite from each fruit.

Among the plant winners in a warmer Britain could be the rare lizard orchid, which has spread out from its narrow base around Sandwich Bay in Kent. Losers could be some very traditional plants, including woodland bulbs such as wild daffodils and bluebells. They may swamped by earlier-growing woodland weeds.

The hotter times have helped the nettle-loving comma butterfly to spread its range. But pity the poor adonis blue, a butterfly that depends on the equally rare horseshoe vetch in south England's chalky heathland. If dryer conditions kill the vetch then it is all over for the adonis - there are no suitable sites further north.

Is temperature change the only problem?

Many other factors affect plants and animals - among them pollution and the destruction of particular habitats. For some things, temperature change could be the last straw.
