fields.headline: Who's Mr Popular?
fields.standfirst: The head of Ofsted will soon be in great demand
fields.trailText: The head of Ofsted will soon be in great demand
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead, the head of the Ofsted inspection agency, will never have had as many invitations to look at particular schools as he is going to get tomorrow. The summonses, needless to say, won't be coming from headteachers. They'll be issued by college principals, armed with new information about the locations of schools with small sixth forms.

Details of local authorities with four or more schools with sixth forms of 50 or fewer pupils have been issued by the DfEE (see below). These will, no doubt, be raised when the chief inspector addresses college principals and chairs of governors today at a summer conference in Cambridge, jointly organised by the Association of Colleges and the Sixth Form Colleges' Employers' Forum.

Inevitably Woodhead will be urged by his audience to put these local authorities at the front of the queue for Ofsted area inspections. And it is probable that he will reply, as Ofsted's new head of post-16 inspections, Stephen Grix, already has, that it is up to ministers to select the targets for these. Grix has supplied quite a lot of detail of the new shape of inspection. "But there is nothing like hearing it from the main man," said one college head.

Principals will be wanting Woodhead's assurance that there will be a level playing field when Ofsted leads teams scrutinising sixth forms, sixth-form colleges and general further education colleges. Up until now, Ofsted school inspections have frequently given scant attention to sixth forms, sometimes devoting barely more than a paragraph to them in their reports.

In the light of figures recently issued by the DfEE, showing that sixth forms with 50 or fewer pupils achieve barely half the average A-level points scored in those with more than 201 pupils, principals will want to hear Woodhead confirm that smaller sixth forms will get particularly rigorous attention. They will also seek some guarantee that inspectors from Ofsted and the new Adult Learning Inspectorate, who will be jointly appraising 16-19 education, will point up the different levels of resources allocated to schools and colleges.

The further education sector has long resented what it sees as the significantly more generous funding school sixth forms get. Ofsted is required to consider value-for-money in its school inspections and the Learning and Skills bill introduces a similar requirement for post-16 inspections.

College managements are also concerned to hear that self-assessment, a cornerstone of the Further Education Funding Council inspection process, is retained by Ofsted. Woodhead was noncommittal on this point when he dined with Association of Colleges members recently. If self-assessment, which is not part of Ofsted school inspections, survives, it is unlikely to have a central role. Similarly colleges are keen for the "nominee" system to continue. Under the funding council regime, colleges could appoint a member of staff to liaise with inspection teams and generally be on hand to clarify any confusions, and answer queries.

Woodhead will also confirm tomorrow that governors are to get protection against litigation, provided they have behaved in good faith. Ministers' apparent change of heart on governor protection is hailed as a victory by the Association of Colleges, which has lobbied vigorously for college governors to get the same protection that school governors, charitable trustees and company directors enjoy. The association's lawyers reckon the amendment to the bill, today entering its Commons report stage, actually goes further than was being asked for. It appears to give college governors a wider shield than the other categories have, and to protect them from third party litigation, for example, from students and the wider public, provided they act honestly and reasonably.

  Local education authorities with four or more maintained secondary schools which have sixth forms of 50 pupils or fewer: Birmingham, Bristol, Gloucestershire, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Kent, Leeds, Lincolnshire, Liverpool, Nottinghamshire (supplied in a Parliamentary answer by education minister Estelle Morris).

fields.headline: Coming clean
fields.standfirst: Admit it - all this learning is about getting people into jobs, says  Clive Caseley
fields.trailText: Admit it - all this learning is about getting people into jobs, says Clive Caseley
fields.body:
Before all this "learning and skills" business started, the Secretary of State unveiled a target of 700,000 new learners, and a "something for something" deal for what we used to call the "further education sector".

A target of 700,000 may not be a lot if you are the Chief Executive of Vodaphone, but it is a seriously big figure if you are talking about increasing the number of Britons taking up educational opportunities. Depending how this is added up, it could mean a 30% increase over three years.

We are now beginning to see elements of the strategy through which this seismic change is to be achieved. Major campaigns to promote lifelong learning, such as the Ufi's learndirect; investment in new media and on-line delivery (notably Ufi, again, and BBC); and better guidance around the system (Ufi, and again, careers service, Connexions and the like).

Big numbers, big project... big question: isn't it about time we admitted that the reason for all this money and attention is so that people can get jobs (or better jobs)?

After all, most of these 700,000 new learners will either be training for specific industries, or learning generic skills to equip them for the workplace. (And that will include those with poor basic skills or special needs.)

Why are we so defensive about acknowledging this? It must be common sense that inclusion (as per the social scientists), and competitiveness (as per UK plc) are different sides of the same coin.

The best way to an inclusive society is, surely, to provide those excluded with the skills and support to find, get and keep a job.

And, as we know, the best way to a competitive economy is lots of tooled-up "knowledge" workers.

On one level, this is a pedantic point. Why be churlish about celebrating the great, flourishing diversity of learning? Why insist on a vocational view at the expense of other perspectives?

One reason is the sheer size of the thing. Stimulating demand and take-up on this sort of scale is a huge marketing proposition. As any advertiser will tell you, success in this will require clear, simple messages delivered to well-understood groups of customers in a language they understand. Segments, as they are known.

My fear is that in making a nod to each and every person, learning for each and every purpose, using each and every route, the whole project could lose focus.

To admit that this is mostly about vocational education is not to devalue other learning for other purposes.

But to try to be all things to all people - to maintain the integrity of a "sector" for its own sake - risks excluding many of the people to whom this campaign will most need to reach out, because they will not understand our jargon. Why can't we just say: "Come to college, get trained, get a better job." (Or something similar.)

More fundamentally, I think we should be wary of lumping all "learning" together, because it seems to me to be an artificial construct.

Sure, we need to understand better the many routes through which people navigate around the system.

Sure, it's a good thing for people to learn throughout their lives for all sorts of purposes. My dad enjoys the opportunity, now that he is retired, to take part in a range of courses, classes and hobbies. My brother can take advantage of technical and specialist courses as he retrains and requalifies for work in the new economy.

Sure these are valuable services. But they are not the same service. They are not even part of the same continuum - and to see them as though they are is to see them differently from the people who use them. And if you do that, in marketing, you're dead.

 Clive Caseley is Director of Communications at the Further Education Development Agency.

fields.headline: For alternative tastes
fields.standfirst: The year 10 taster day leaves a bitter flavour for  Donald Hiscock
fields.trailText: The year 10 taster day leaves a bitter flavour for Donald Hiscock
fields.body:
I have put off doing any preparation for next week's Year 10 Taster Day. This time last year I was bursting with anticipation at the thought of hundreds of young intellects eager to absorb knowledge in the silicon towers of their local further education college.

Patty, our head of corporate communications, had delivered a Powerpoint presentation on the potential marketing benefits of inviting coachloads of school children in for the day to get a taste of life at the cutting edge of post-16 education.

You couldn't argue with Patty's figures. I have never been very good at understanding graphs, but hers had impressive upward pointy bits. Patty's rousing rhetoric had me in a state of mild elation. More bums on more seats equals more funding units. Now that I could understand.

But reality dawned not long after the first wave of streetwise 15-year-olds came through the revolving doors. Or rather they didn't. What is it about young people and revolving doors? Why are they so difficult to negotiate? The doors, I mean.

I had landed a dangerously high profile front-of-house job. I was a bit like those greeters you get inside American supermarkets. "Welcome. Have a nice visit." But instead of handing out baskets with a smile I dished out leaflets with a frown. "Put that cigarette out and find your name on that whiteboard. Yes, I'm talking to you. Welcome."

I spent several depressing moments during the day picking up the contents of my welcome packs from the floor, bins and down the back of library shelves.

I had a team of student guides who took groups off to their classes. At intervals throughout the day there were tours of the campus. It was a case of Further Education College Uncovered, especially when Roxanne - one of my more outgoing students - became the most sought-after guide.

"Where are you taking them?"

"All the important places," she sneered. "The smoking area, the chip shop and the common room."

I felt a little more useful patrolling the corridors. Seeing me as a management lackey who had helped to organise the day, my colleagues avoided eye contact as we passed. They also turned a blind eye to knots of school children lurking in corners. It was my job to round up the skivers. But I was up against a well drilled outfit. They disappeared completely whenever I got within 10 yards of them.

"Bloody nightmare," said my mate Colin from maths, emerging from a classroom holding a trundle wheel. "I made an excuse to go and fetch something at one point, but they were all still there when I got back. I need a drink."

By the end of the day I had graduated to staffing the information point. I had fanned out copies of the prospectus and explored the London Underground map at the back of my diary before anyone sidled up.

"Where do the alternative tours start from?" asked a polite young man in a blazer.

"We've got an alternative prospectus produced by the student union," I replied, mystified by the request.

"They told me to ask for someone called Roxanne," he said.

Thinking about it again has made me realise that I don't need to do any preparation for next week. I can feel a bout of summer flu coming on.

fields.headline: Role model
fields.standfirst: So what lifelong learning are you doing, minister?
fields.trailText: So what lifelong learning are you doing, minister?
fields.body:
There are many skills you need to succeed in politics. Like the ability to look sincere when you're lying, to repeatedly evade direct questions and to stab someone in the back with a warm smile. As yet, though, no college has run evening classes in these arcane skills, with the result that it has been comparatively rare to find any politicians actively involved in adult learning.

So it was with quite some fanfare that Park Lane College recently announced that Leeds MP Hilary Benn, together with two of his constituency staff, had signed up for computing courses on its newly launched online arm. Benn, who has chosen to get savvy with word processing, spreadsheets, making presentations and the internet, said, "I have my own PC at the House of Commons and use it extensively every day, but I have been keen for some time to learn more sophisticated word processing skills."

Benn is widely acknowledged as one of New Labour's brightest and most ambitious backbenchers and is strongly tipped for a ministerial position in the DfEE at the next reshuffle. So, boldly going where few MPs have gone, with the noble exception of Tony Blair who 'fessed up to his computer illiteracy with gusto last year and signed up for a couple of classes in his Sedgefield constituency, could be construed as a canny career move.

And what of the DfEE team who dedicate their lives to extolling the virtues of lifelong learning? Some will no doubt be hightailing it down to the "exciting and comprehensive" new programme of professional development for ministers and senior civil servants unveiled by the Cabinet Office in March. But the DfEE remains silent on the other learning activities of ministers and senior civil servants.

Michael Wills, the minister responsible for Ufi, is well known as something of a computer whizz, but of David Blunkett, Malcolm Wicks, Baroness Blackstone, Nicholas Stewart and Peter Lauener, the official response is that "they are all very busy people". So we can probably safely assume there isn't a carpet weaver, chef or gardener among them.

Much the same goes for those involved in adult education outside the DfEE. The Association of Colleges has a policy that actively encourages further study amongst its staff, but almost everyone opts for some form of management training, including MBAs. Similarly, Paul Mackney, general secretary of Natfhe, has recently completed two staff training courses in race discrimination casework and fair selection in recruitment.

For a real breath of fresh air you have to turn to the National Institute for Adults in Continuous Education (NIACE). Every member of staff gets £200 a year as a contribution to their lifelong learning and earlier this year two people went off to learn equestrian skills in Devon. Even the director, Alan Tuckett, puts his money where his mouth is by taking piano lessons with his son. "I'm a very unreliable adult learner," he smiles. "My son is a lot better than me, but the lessons are the most enjoyable part of the week."

fields.headline: Electricians
fields.trailText: Electricians
fields.body:
Sugar? Yeah, eight please.

You must use a lot of energy. No, but you do, mate. This wiring is buggered.

Oh dear. I sense a large bill coming. Werll, that's what you get with an old house.

It's hardly old. Believe me, mate, this stuff's prehistoric.

So how much will it cost? Rewiring this lot? Rough guess... you're talking at least £!!!!!

What? That's with gold-plating, right? Ha ha. No. It's a major job.

And I'm clearly in the wrong job. Don't follow.

Well, obviously I should be an electrician. Why's that then?

I'd be able to afford a house with working parts. Ha ha.

Seriously. What do electricians do? We install and maintain all the cables, wiring, meters, switchgear, conduit, fitments and equipment needed for the safe and efficient use of electricity.

What about appliances? Give us a chance! Installation and contracting electricians are concerned with services such as lighting, power, heating and control systems within all types of buildings.

You get around a bit. Oh, yeah. Anywhere there's electricity: houses, offices, factories, hospitals, shopping malls, power stations, oil rigs...

And not just old buildings? Oh no. In new buildings, we work from technical drawings and plans that show where electricity is required. We must interpret the instructions deciding how to run cabling and where to place switches, sockets, lights and other devices. On smaller projects, we get to plan our own work.

And what does that consist of? It involves measuring, cutting, joining and fitting cables and trunking using a variety of hand and power tools, such as pliers, screwdrivers and drills.

Which you're carrying in that belt. I've always fancied one of those. Really?

I suppose the work can be pretty hazardous. Electricity is dangerous. We rarely work where the system is live. Installation electricians often do the work before the electricity supply is connected. On completion, we have to test an installation carefully to ensure that it is completely safe. Diagnosing, locating and isolating problems is an important part of the job.

What would I need to be an electrician? Patience, attention to detail and safety consciousness. The work suits those with practical craft skills, who enjoy seeing a job through from start to finish.

Electricians have to read and interpret technical drawings. They should be well organised and methodical and be able to focus on detail and safety. Solution-finding skills are needed. Fitness and personal mobility are needed. The work is Indoor and outside and quite often involves heights and confined spaces. Electricians must be able to work without supervision and be meticulous and careful when working on installations and equipment that carry high voltages.

Are you all self-employed? Some are. Others can be employed by campanies ranging from small family businesses to large national contracting firms.

What about training? People usually enter at 16 or 17 by applying for an apprenticeship with an electricity supply company, which combines work experience and off-the-job training. JTL organise training for the industry and it takes around four years. Apprentices work towards City and Guilds qualifications and NVQ level 3.

 JTL Head Office Stafford House, 120-122 High Street, Orpington, Kent, BR6 0JS Telephone: 01689 884100
 National Electrotechnical Training (NET), 34 Palace Court, London, W2 4HY Telephone: 0207 3134846
 learndirect 0800 100900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses.

fields.headline: Storm warning
fields.standfirst: Nick Tester  forecasts choppy seas ahead as the government's new further education flagship prepares to take to the water
fields.trailText: Nick Tester forecasts choppy seas ahead as the government's new further education flagship prepares to take to the water
fields.body:
It looks like just another routine diary filler. But tomorrow's meeting between Michael Wills and champions of colleges and of the nascent Ufi (University for Industry, as was) promises to be livelier than the usual Sanctuary Buildings sideshow.

At the very least, the technology minister will get his ear tweaked by representatives from Association of Colleges about their concerns for Ufi, whose own spokespeople will doubtless dish as good as they get.

Alarm bells have been jangling at the Association of Colleges as the government's lifelong learning flagship prepares to clear decks for its maiden voyage this September.

At tomorrow's gathering, colleges will be seeking clarification on a range of crucial issues that, they believe, have the potential to knock off course, if not wreck, the urgent task of expanding the quantity and quality of post-16 learning. Their claims will be countered by Ufi leaders tagging along to make sure their side of the story is taken on board.

A lot is at stake. The Ufi is, according to David Blunkett, "right at the heart of our policies on lifelong learning". It is getting over £84m of government funding this year alone, to help create learndirect - the brand name for a national network aiming, by 2003, to have 2.5m people annually using its information and advice services, plus another one million tapping into dedicated learning materials.

So far 56 "hubs" - local partnerships comprising colleges, local authorities, and businesses - have been set up. These are operating 251 development centres, many led by colleges, testing the delivery of over 200 on-line courses in subjects ranging from basic skills to business management. The centres have been chosen to, in the jargon, "fit learning into life". Hence they can be found in pubs, railway stations, football and rugby grounds, in addition to more orthodox places such as libraries and community centres.

Part of the problem is that, as they embark on these local partnerships, colleges and the Ufi don't entirely see eye to eye over the best way to forge the new learning opportunities. Worse, the former, with their vast experience, don't feel they are being listened to or that they're party to full information about what is going on.

Judith Norrington, Association of Colleges director of curriculum and quality, said colleges had a huge commitment to increase ways for people to learn. "Which is why the association wants to help the Ufi 'walk and talk'," she said. "It needs to learn from things that have already happened in colleges. It would be naive to believe colleges don't have some of the answers."

The questions being raised tomorrow will be technical and complicated, though the technology minister is not expected to be fazed by them. They range around funding and organisation, with some doubts thrown in over the quality of learning materials being offered by the Ufi and the hinterland of hubs, centres and "access points". Although not shared by all colleges, there's also a feeling that some of the new learning venues verge on gimmickry and possibly trivialise the serious business of education and training.

Some colleges want contractual arrangements between the various groups more clearly spelt out, especially if they are to avoid being forced to venture, once more, down the now discredited franchising route. This is particularly important, they claim, if student number targets are not met and hideous costs are passed on to them to deal with.

Of course, colleges are no strangers to being asked to repay money to the funding council halfway through a year, if they fail to enrol as many students as predicted. But it is a fairly straightforward, readily understood system. In the new Ufi regime, however, they don't reckon such certain ties will exist. They also want an appropriate pricing policy that doesn't harm community groups steadfastly refusing to charge any learning fees.

Criticism is also being made about the quality and suitability of some of the learning packages. Some are only available on-line and can't be downloaded, forcing learners to run up bigger phone bills. And some centres have discovered the technical specifications too sophisticated to make sense of.

There's worry, too, about Ufi products, designed to be competitive with those prepared by the formal further education sector, leading to a loss of college business. There might also be a falling out if some Ufi courses prove to have lower completion rates, because they had originally accepted all-comers in a drive to boost numbers. Colleges, on the other hand, might be more circumspect about who gets on an identical course - but blamed for not getting more learners in the first place.

Maggie Chadwick, principal of Furness College, Cumbria, who'll be attending tomorrow's showdown, reflected: "There are lots of practical difficulties and there were bound to be teething problems. But I don't think Ufi policy recognises the sort of infrastructure that's needed. Nor do they appear to know who their friends are. The lifelong learning agenda is much too important to get wrong and allow to sink without trace."

Ufi chief executive Dr Anne Wright was in a positive mood when these points were put to her. "We are looking forward to this meeting with the association and the minister," she said.

The Ufi, with its partners, was making "huge strides" in setting up an entirely new learning network, she pointed out. "Our approach is radical and innovative, and we are developing very fast."

The organisation, which is covering England, Wales and Northern Ireland, with a sister body being established in Scotland, claimed it would have up to 1,000 on-line learning centres and hundreds more on-line courses installed by spring next year, once theUfi and learndirect went fully operational in the autumn. It was confident it would stimulate, and meet, demands for lifelong learning, improve people's employment prospects and enhance business competitiveness.

Dr Wright added: "We are working closely with all our partners, including colleges, to develop the network, to make sure it builds on our partners' own expertise in open and distance learning, and to address, in discussion, exactly the kinds of issues which are now being raised."

fields.headline: West coast rebel
fields.standfirst: He could hold his tongue no longer - and all hell's broken loose.  Oliver Burkeman finds out why
fields.trailText: He could hold his tongue no longer - and all hell's broken loose. Oliver Burkeman finds out why
fields.body:
Whatever his faults - and some former university colleagues think he has many - it would be hard to accuse Christopher Brown of unoriginality. As any academic author knows, the acknowledgments section of a dissertation or a book is a place for abject sycophancy: for declarations of love to spouses, the brown-nosing of superiors in the hope of future promotion, the buttering-up of funders - and the requisite self-flagellating assurance that all errors are one's own responsibility.

So when Brown, a 28-year-old postgraduate researcher at the University of California at Santa Barbara (UCSB), appended a special "disacknowledgments" section to his Master's thesis in June 1999, he knew he was going against the grain. But three and a half years of pent-up fury at the petty bureaucracy and daily frustrations of grad-student life could be contained no longer - and on the last two pages of his 73-page study on the growth of mollusc shells, things boiled over.

"You fascists are the largest argument against higher education there has ever been," Brown fumed at the dean and staff of the graduate school, in a vigorous, if occasionally illiterate, tirade against the university "degenerates" who had been "an ever-present hindrance during my graduate career... All dealings with you have ended in sheer frustration. I'd rather take a hot stick in the eye than deal with your bureaucratic nonsense."

Against the staff of UCSB's Davidson Library, he railed: "Your strict adherence to self-serving, draconian policy has made it a supreme displeasure to work in your vicinity." One professor was branded a "prick"; the university's Board of Regents "a paragon of corrupt management". Taking bitterness to levels unknown even within academia - no easy feat - Brown concluded with a swipe at science itself, "for being a hollow spectre of what you should be. Your vapid conceits have rendered those in your pursuit lifeless, unfeeling zombies." With that, he left the world of scientific research forever, slamming the door behind him - or so he thought.

The body of Brown's work had already been approved by his thesis committee when he sneaked in the vitriolic addendum, but he reckoned without one of the library bureaucrats, who drew it to the attention of the Santa Barbara authorities.

Enraged members of the committee told Brown they would withhold his degree until he retracted the additions. Brown agreed to tone down some of the language, but refused to go further, and brought his case to the Foundation for Individual Rights in Education (FIRE), a pressure group co-founded by the high-profile civil liberties lawyer, Harvey Silverglate, to oppose what it sees as the scourge of "political correctness" on US campuses.

In response, the university called in its lawyers - and so what began as a prank borne of frustration has escalated, over the past year, into a full-scale battle over the alleged trampling of Brown's rights to free speech.

Last month, UCSB finally offered to award Brown his degree - but only after removing the offending pages itself. Brown has accepted the degree but he is, unsurprisingly, far from satisfied.

"They've spent the last 11 months withholding my degree while they ask me to remove this section, and now they've taken the choice out of it," says Brown, who now works for a Californian internet firm.

His lawyer, Paul Hoffman, filed a lawsuit 11 days ago and says victory is almost certain. "The legal case is as close to a sure winner as one finds in the law," argues the Boston-based Silverglate. "Most students praise their teachers and administrators in an acknowledgment section; Chris chose to criticise. That's his absolute right, and the faculty and administration should not be so thin-skinned... This is patently clear unconstitutional censorship: they effectively ripped the pages out of his thesis! Can you imagine a more graphic and clear form of censorship?"

Back at Santa Barbara, Charles Li - dean of the graduate school, and one of the targets of Brown's wrath - sees things a little differently. "This is not a freedom of speech issue at all." He argues that the thesis committee was being asked to endorse Brown's incendiary views - and to publish something that might elicit libel actions.

"We never wanted to deny him his freedom, and we don't question his freedom. But the faculty has the right to refuse to endorse anything a student writes. I can't overrule my colleagues' right to say they will not endorse such a thing."

Brown never intended his exercise in post-degree catharsis to become a constitutional battleground, but there's an undeniable sense that - far from being embarrassed by the national exposure his insults have received - he rather relishes his new role as a cause celebre.

"It's not my best piece of writing, but that's not really the issue," he says. "They're judging my scientific work on the basis of my opinions, and that sets a very dangerous precedent. Graduates are second-class citizens, and the faculty are the ruling class, trying to coerce the judgments of students. Some people have said what I did was childish, but others have said they wish they'd had the guts to do it."

Nor, he adds, were his "disacknowledgments" unique, and to prove it, he has the university library to unearth some exceedingly unorthodox - but permitted - dissertation acknowledgments, from the hyperbolically spiritual ("it would be ignorant of me not to acknowledge the Divine assistance I have received in all of my pursuits during the past five years I have been pursuing my PhD") to the plain insulting ("to the dumb ass who left his cooling water on for a laser that was off for two years, and subsequently flooded my lab, desk, and my most important files: may your lifeless, bloated, limbless bodies wash to shore and be picked clean by seabirds").

For Brown and his supporters, including the University of California Student Association, this is the key: that academic freedom of speech must include the freedom to be childish, insulting and vulgar, or it isn't freedom at all.

"You don't defend freedom of speech in cases where people are saying nice things that everyone agrees with," says Thor Halvorssen, Fire's executive director. "You need to defend academic freedom precisely where people are saying unpopular things. The Chris Brown case is a perfect example."

fields.headline: Grant aided
fields.standfirst: PhD students could get £5,500 more a year
fields.trailText: PhD students could get £5,500 more a year
fields.body:
Could the slave workers of the university research world finally be allowed to earn a decent living? Senior government sources say that ministers are considering a substantial hike in grants for PhD students in this year's Whitehall spending review. It comes as the two government bodies with responsibility for research students are considering proposals to improve the training of students.

The creation of a special over-arching panel for science and research as part of the government's current appraisal of future departmental budgets was seen as a positive sign by the academic community. Chancellor Gordon Brown continues to believe that university research will inspire and underpin tomorrow's successful high-tech businesses. But hopes for extra money were dashed earlier in the year after the prime minster, Tony Blair, made a public commitment to invest more in the NHS. One proposal which still stands some chance of survival when the allocations are unveiled next month, however, is a boost to the research council stipends for thousands of PhD students.

The proposed increase in funding would see research students funded by government research councils catch-up with the fewer, but better paid students supported by the Wellcome Trust. Research councils last year announced a £1,000 boost to PhD grants for students. Minimum grants are now set at approximately £6,500 a year.

But they still fall well short of the £12,000 salaries enjoyed by research students supported by the Wellcome Trust, which has campaigned for more support for PhDs. Government-supported students stand to win an extra £5,500 a year for living costs.

The debate over PhD funding has intensified in recent years. It has dawned on government officials just how important research students are for the future livelihood of academic communities, and for many industries. At the same time there has been increasing realisation of how badly research students have been treated up to now. They are among the worst-paid professional trainees in the country. And the boom in numbers in universities in the last decade means that standards in training vary dramatically across the academic sector.

Concerned that the introduction of tuition fees for university students was precipitating a fall in the number of filled studentship places supported by the government, the director general of research councils, John Taylor, last year asked the research councils to compile detailed reports on the numbers and characteristics of students now starting PhDs. Alarm bells were sounded two years ago when rising numbers of unfilled studentships were reported in the engineering and physical sciences.

Surveys of undergraduates have suggested that increasing debts and small PhD grants are causing many final-year university undergraduates to now think twice about research careers. Over half the final-year degree students undecided about postgraduate study cited financial factors as a major discouraging force, the first big survey of student attitudes to postgraduate training revealed.

The life sciences committee, which represents researchers in the biological sciences, recently called for an increase in PhD stipends, and more systematic training for students. It argued that this should be done even if total training budgets remained frozen and there were fewer PhDs.

Research training is now attracting more attention as part of a wider recognition among universities that equal opportunities and career management of academic staff needs urgent improvement throughout the higher education system.

As part of its review of research funding policy, the Higher Education Funding Council for England is expected to announce new measures to ensure students are trained in a suitable research environment. The review is likely to propose that university departments meet postgraduate training requirements before receiving research grants.

The government's science and innovation white paper, meanwhile, is next month expected to recommend that PhD students coming out of universities are taught the best mix of technical and managerial skills for jobs in industry.

Later in the summer, the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council and Medical Research Council are due to publish a consultation on future reforms for the funding of postgraduate research students in the life sciences.

The Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council has already published its own proposals, which would allow universities the freedom to decide the level and duration of grants for research students.

fields.headline: Fight for tradition
fields.standfirst: Tories try to make small sixth forms an election issue
fields.trailText: Tories try to make small sixth forms an election issue
fields.body:
The defence of school sixth forms teaching traditional A-level subjects including Latin, maths and separate sciences, and the creation of more of them, look likely to be a key plank of Conservative education policy for the next election.

The Tories will seek to paint Labour as a party promoting allegedly dumbed-down A-level subjects such as sociology and media studies in monolithic tertiary colleges.

The Conservative education spokesperson, Theresa May, has vowed to fight any closure of small sixth forms following the Learning and Skills bill, which will eventually put sixth-form and further education college funding on the same footing.

The strategy has already emerged in Richmond upon Thames, where Conservatives launched a crusade last week to create new sixth forms where Latin and other traditional A-level subjects would be taught as an alternative to the borough's tertiary college.

Schools should be allowed to specialise in a limited number of academic A-level subjects, said their spokesperson Geoffrey Samuel, a retired secondary head and former classics teacher.

He said he had approached DfEE officials and been promised that proposals for one or two sixth-form consortia would be "looked at sympathetically" by David Blunkett, the education secretary.

"We cannot, unfortunately, create a new sixth form in every school, but we can franchise out A-level courses to the private sector or to other schools, if necessary," Samuel said.

He said A-level subjects such as business or media studies could be dropped or taught in larger groups in order to concentrate on traditional subjects. "It is quality rather than quantity that should count," he said.

Theresa May, who has written to Samuel backing his proposals, said: "The Labour Party has a levelling-down agenda. Heads and governors of schools should be free to retain, set up or expand their own type of sixth-form education."

Conservative leader William Hague is also pursuing the issue in a bid to depict Labour as hostile to excellence and choice in education and keen to dilute the standards of university entry. At a recent meeting with headteachers, he promised to back them in fighting to preserve a traditional sixth-form education.

One of the heads at the meeting said later: "The meeting was called at Mr Hague's own request and he made it clear he personally was going to take charge of the sixth-form campaign."

Brigid Beattie, head of Burntwood School in Conservative-controlled Wandsworth, London, said: "Sixth forms are expensive but you can divide up the subjects between schools. I don't think young people need as wide a range of A-level subjects as people think.

"I do not think further education colleges are right for many academic young people in London who need more security - they are better for students aged 19 or over."

The move to set up new sixth forms was attacked by Pat Petch, chair of the Richmond governors' forum, who pointed out that the tertiary college at Richmond, the first in London, had been set up by the Conservatives 23 years ago to cater for all abilities, and had been a model for other colleges elsewhere in the country. "You are now proposing to undermine your own college," she said.

fields.headline: A helping hand?
fields.standfirst: Should those running universities declare if they are masons?
fields.trailText: Should those running universities declare if they are masons?
fields.body:
A row over whether freemasons should identify themselves on Newcastle University's Council is set to provide further ammunition for the government's attack on the cliquey and often secretive world of the academic ruling elite.

Concerns that university councils can be influenced by hidden interests have resurfaced after a decision by Newcastle's governing body to turn down calls from some academics for governors to declare whether they were freemasons.

As part of his attack on elitism, Chancellor Gordon Brown accused universities of still being governed by old school-tie networks. The education secretary David Blunkett last month, meanwhile, called for reforms to the "quaint" selection procedures for vice-chancellors, after highlighting the small numbers of women and staff from ethnic backgrounds who had been appointed as senior academic managers.

In 1996 the then Nolan committee on standards in public life said that while the principle of academic freedom let individuals pursue research and express opinions without political pressure, "it does not justify a lower level of accountability for higher education institutions".

The government is considering whether other professions such as police officers and crown prosecutors should be forced by law to disclose their membership of the freemasons after unsuccessful attempts to get them to register voluntarily. During a meeting of Newcastle academic staff last month, the council confirmed that it had rejected the request by 17 votes to two, with four members abstaining because they are members of the secret society.

The decision has prompted an angry response from some academics, who believe that university governing bodies should be more open about their activities. "I think if universities are to ever actually have equality of opportunity rather than just paying lip service to equal opportunities they need to be much more open and honest at all levels, and membership of bodies such as the freemasons should be declared by members of governing committees," said one Newcastle academic, who wished to remain anonymous.

But the leading members of the council, which draws half of its membership from outside the university, were quick to defend their decision. "If you could provide a shred of evidence that universities had ever been influenced by freemasonry, whether malign or not, I would start to take note," said Newcastle's vice-chancellor, James Wright, who stressed that the issue had been raised by a small minority of academic staff.

The vice-chair of the council and chief executive of the new international centre for life, Alistair Balls, said: "I am in favour of maximum disclosure - any record of conflicts of interest should be open to the public. But the majority felt that there is no evidence that it is significant. If there was a strongly held view by the majority of the academic community that the council should disclose such membership, I am sure that would be accepted by the council."

The masonic movement has strong historical links with the academic world. Many of the founding members of the Royal Society were masons. University masonic lodges are now commonplace. In the London area, an Oxford and Cambridge University lodge was established in 1866, followed by lodges for the universities of London, Edinburgh, Durham, and in 1964 a lodge for City University. In Cambridge there has been a scientific lodge since 1744 and an Isaac Newton university lodge since 1861.

Masons also have their own research lodges which study freemasonry traditions - the primary English lodge of research is called Quator Corinarti. One centre claims to be the first masonic university. The Committee of Vice-chancellors and Principals says it does not know how many university heads are currently members of the society.

Two years ago the Association of University Teachers campaigned for the compulsory disclosure of freemason membership. The CVCP declined to join the association's campaign, arguing that it was not appropriate to refer explicitly to freemasonry. Now it is understood that the committee is itself deciding whether to disclose the full details of voting results when university heads elect other heads as their representatives.

fields.headline: Lunch with a groove
fields.standfirst: Win a school dinner cooked by a celebrity chef
fields.trailText: This week is Focus on Food Week, part of the RSA/Waitrose Focus on Food Campaign, which encourages young people to learn, think about and appreciate food and its preparation. The theme for this year's activities is to learn about the wide range of cuisines from across the world that we enjoy in this country today.
fields.body:
This week is Focus on Food Week, part of the RSA/Waitrose Focus on Food Campaign, which encourages young people to learn, think about and appreciate food and its preparation. The theme for this year's activities is to learn about the wide range of cuisines from across the world that we enjoy in this country today.

Test your knowledge of international food by answering the following questions. If you get them right, you could have a chance of winning your school dinner cooked next term by a top celebrity chef!

If you don't have cooking facilities at your school, then we will bring them to you in the RSA Cooking Bus - a fully-equipped "culinary pantechnicon" housing a state-of-the-art kitchen and classroom.

There is also a superb range of prizes for runners-up, including a portable TV set for your class, recipe books and Focus on Food aprons.

How to enter

Answer the following questions:

What is coriander?

a) A herb

b) A draining spoon

c) A type of curry

What is basil?

a) An edible lizard from South America

b) A herb used in Italian cookery particularly with tomatoes

c) A glove-puppet fox with a bushy tail

What is a noodle?

a) A ribbon-like strip of pasta

b) A pig's head roasted for medieval banquets

c) A person who doesn't like cheese

What is okra?

a) A chat-show hostess on television

b) A type of Chinese goat's milk used for making yoghurt

c) A green, furry pod used in Indian and Caribbean cooking

What is pilau?

a) A fish of the herring family

b) An Eastern dish of rice flavoured with spices

c) A French herbal pillow that helps you to sleep

What is tournedos?

a) A mighty wind from Spain

b) A feast held after a knightly jousting tournament

c) A thick round steak of beef

Now complete the following tie-breaker in not more than 20 words:

It's fun to learn about food at school because...

Name of teacher:

Entry submitted on behalf of class:

Number of pupils in class:

Name of school:

Address:

Telephone number:

E-mail:

Out-of-hours contact number:

Do you have classroom cooking facilities?

Please send your completed entries, by Friday July 21, to: Amanda Roper, Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

If your school would like to sign up to the Focus on Food campaign, contact Lucy Burns on 01422 383191.

Terms and conditions:

 The competition is open to pupils in all primary schools up to and including year 6, and within the same age range in middle schools.

 Only one entry per school will be accepted, on behalf of only one class, which can be any age range.

 Teachers are invited to coordinate the class entry by using the questions as the basis for a discussion or a lesson on food.

 The winner and runners-up will be announced in Guardian Education and notified at the beginning of the autumn term. Arrangements will then be made for the meal to be cooked for the winning school.

 The final decision about the winner and runners-up will rest with the judges.

 Full terms and conditions available on request. Promoter: RSA/Waitrose Ltd, 7 Industrial Area Bracknell, Berks RG12 8YA.

fields.headline: By example
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod talks to two award winners from the National Teaching Fellowship Scheme
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod talks to two award winners from the National Teaching Fellowship Scheme
fields.body:
Contemporary dance workshops and tutorials in a Cambridge college seem worlds apart, but next month they are brought together in the £1m National Teaching Fellowship Scheme.

Among 20 star lecturers each receiving awards of £50,000 are Roger Carpenter, described as a lynchpin of medical teaching at Cambridge and Jayne Stevens, of De Montfort University, praised for her unorthodox approach to the study of dance. With the other winners, all nominated by universities in England and Northern Ireland to represent excellence in teaching, they will receive their awards at a ceremony in London on July 12.

On closer inspection both Stevens and Carpenter are linked by their willingness to experiment with new technology in their teaching. She uses video and digital images; he uses computer software. Both are passionately committed to teaching students - a passion the Institute of Learning and Teaching, which launched the awards this year, is keen to recognise and celebrate. The fellowships stem from concerns first advanced in Guardian Education by Sir Brian Fender, chief executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for England, about the need to redress the balance of recognition between research and teaching.

If the prime purpose of universities was to teach then this should be rewarded and count towards career advancement for academics as well as research, he argued.

Fellowships are held for three years and the money spent at the holder's discretion.

Jayne Stevens will be using her award to travel to dance departments in the UK and the US and buy time for reflection and investigation. Contemporary dance is a constantly evolving field, where teaching needs to keep in close touch with the professionals, she believes. "You can't just pull a lecture out of the filing cabinet from five years ago because things have changed," she says.

For her students at De Montfort, where she is already one of the university's teaching fellows, dance involves hard physical work with artistic and academic challenges. A day might involve a lecture on historical aspects of dance and film, looking at how space and time have been used by choreographers on film, she says. This could be followed by a workshop, learning how to edit video and look at movement through a camera lens as opposed to the naked eye. In the afternoon students might create their own work, followed by appraising their own and other students' work.

Roger Carpenter, of Gonville and Caius College, put forward by Cambridge as an outstanding teacher of immense intelligence and energy, found existing computer-assisted learning materials inadequate - "Students get to the bottom of them in ten minutes" - and set out to produce richer software for his students learning about the brain. His Neurolab software now accompanies his successful textbook Neurophysiology.

A growing dilemma for Cambridge and other universities is how to get students to the same starting point if they arrive with different A levels and perhaps different levels of teaching. The problem will increase as students do a wider variety of AS levels. Here short modules that student scan work through on their own on a computer can be very helpful, argues Carpenter, who in 30 years has taught some 10,000 students at Cambridge.

He will be employing some of his own students to help create these programs during his fellowship. Once they are placed on a website, sixth formers at schools and colleges will be able to access them free.

Winning lecturers

The top 20.

These lecturers will each get £50,000 awards in the first National Teaching Fellowship Scheme in recogition of their work in promoting student learning. All were recommended by their university or college as excellent.

fields.headline: The new democracy
fields.trailText: All local authorities should by now have appointed parent governor representatives to committees dealing with education.
fields.body:
All local authorities should by now have appointed parent governor representatives to committees dealing with education. Under regulations that took effect from September 1999, resulting from the School Standards and Framework Act 1998, elections should have been conducted among parent governors for between two and five representatives to each committee.

Within the context of local government modernisation, the authority has discretion over how many representatives and on which committees.

The key issue is representation. Parent governor representatives are elected to represent parents, not governors. Education department literature boldly proclaims them as a "new voice for parents" who will represent the views of all parents in the area, but not represent the interests of any particular group, school, locality or political party. Representatives will be able to vote and contribute to discussion and debate.

But how do they gauge the views of all parents? Are there not different interests at play here - perhaps to do with differential funding or the allocation of places? Representatives may have been elected on the basis of a geographical area or school type. If so, they need to be in touch with that "constituency" - perhaps holding local meetings.

This is likely to be unfamiliar for parents, who are not known for their interest in public meetings. Local media may prove to be a better vehicle - especially for disseminating information. And the local authority should be able to make its methods of communication available - the governor newsletter or local education authority website, for example.

All local authorities have resources allocated under the standards fund to support representatives - my guess is we will need every penny to kick-start the latest interesting development in local democracy.

DfEE

 Jane Martin is education officer (school governance and development) for Dudley local education authority. She writes here in a personal capacity.

fields.headline: Building strong links with Kenya
fields.standfirst: A group of Dorset students are heading off to Africa to help construct a new primary school
fields.trailText: A group of Dorset students are heading off to Africa to help construct a new primary school
fields.body:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, drawn up in 1989, makes the following statement: "Mankind owes to the child the best it has to give". And yet, according to Oxfam's figures, 130m children across the world do not go to school, which helps to explain why, at the beginning of the 21st century, nearly one in three people in the world cannot read or write.

Oxfam is one of many organisations that work to help poor people everywhere, by helping them to help themselves - a philosophy shared by staff and students at the Canford School in Wimborne, Dorset. On Friday, a group of four girls and four boys in the Lower VI and three members of staff will be travelling to Gilgil, in Kenya. Their mission is to assist the local villagers in building a new primary school.

Michael Symonds, a Latin, English and RE teacher at Canford and one of the staff going to Gilgil, explained how the project grew out of a piece of stonework from Nineveh belonging to the school. It was sold for £7m at Christie's, and the governors put a substantial part of this money aside for the purposes of charitable work.

In 1995, students from Canford visited an orphanage in India, a journey that now takes place annually for a fortnight at Easter. Each year, they take an active role in teaching and playing with the orphans, as well as helping to construct solar panels to provide cheap, sustainable energy.

Following the success of this project, Symonds and a colleague began looking in Kenya and Zimbabwe for a second project that the Canford students could work with.

Gilgil was chosen because "it's in a deprived area, but there was clear evidence that the people were doing a lot to help themselves with limited resources. In some lessons, three or four pupils were using the same exercise books. They had already built themselves one corrugated iron classroom, and we decided to help them build another. The plan is that we will return to Gilgil each June for the next six years, by which time the primary school will be complete."

In fact, the plans have become a little more ambitious, as the classrooms will now be made of stone, but there is plenty of goodwill, says Symonds.

The school governors have put some money towards the project, as have parents, but a great deal of effort has been made by the students themselves. Abigail Marseilles-Dickson is one such student. She became involved because she thought the project was worthwhile and would have long-lasting benefits.

Abigail is also enthusiastic about the pioneering aspect of this year's visit. "We are the first group of people to go out and start the partnership, making it something that we will remember for many different reasons, including the fact that we started off something which will continue after us."

All the students have raised money for the trip through pledges from former schools, friends and family. As a group they have run a tuck shop, held mufti days (when they could wear casual clothes in return for a pound, although donations were often more than this), and a duck race on the day of the school inter-house regatta. Abigail and a fellow volunteer, Louise Davidson, also arranged a fashion show in conjunction with local shops in Bournemouth, held on June 24.

Oxfam believes everyone can make a difference, and the students at Canford take pride in the fact that they, too, are helping to make the world a fairer place in a practical and enduring way.

fields.headline: Fear rules
fields.standfirst: The threat of violence is very real in too many schools.  Máire Tobin investigates a report which says that many secondary teachers in Birmingham are suffering unacceptable abuse
fields.trailText: The threat of violence is very real in too many schools. Máire Tobin investigates a report which says that many secondary teachers in Birmingham are suffering unacceptable abuse
fields.body:
"I was dismissing a class for lunch. They were all standing up behind their chairs and just about to leave. I was standing in front of a door with a glass window. A 15- or 16-year-old boy entered the room and wanted to put his bag in the room before lunch. I told him to wait until the class was out of the room.

"He was bigger and stronger than me. He pushed me out of the way and put his bag beside a desk; he was arrogant and rude to me. I wanted to have a word with him and asked him to stay behind after the class had left. He pushed me back and I hit the door and banged against the handle. I was lucky not to have gone through the glass."

This was just one of a catalogue of incidents reported in a survey that today reveals alarming levels of violence against teachers. Four out of ten Birmingham secondary school teachers who responded to a questionnaire said they had suffered physical and verbal abuse, nearly two-thirds of them at least once a year. The yob culture that has been so painfully on display at Euro 2000 football matches is growing and thriving in the classroom.

Equally worrying are complaints from staff that they are being left unprotected by their headteachers and that incidents are being hushed up to avoid bad publicity for the schools. The teacher who was slammed against the door continued: The boy "was put in isolation for the day and his parents were involved. They didn't seem that bothered, as he lied over what had happened and they chose to believe him rather than me."

One in 11 teachers said they had been threatened by a pupil with a weapon. Teenage boys between the ages of 14 and 15 are the main perpetrators of physical abuse.

Two-thirds of the abused teachers were women. An equal number of men and women completed the survey distributed by the National Union of Teachers to members at all the city's secondary schools. Seventy per cent of teachers who had been assaulted had more than five years' experience.

Response to the survey was comparatively small (116 usable replies) but the union is convinced they are typical. "Everyone is aware that there is a significant problem but we were genuinely shocked by the scale of it," said Nigel Baker, the health and safety officer of the union's Birmingham association. This problem is in no way unique to Birmingham, and if similar surveys were carried out in other parts of the country, the same sort of results would be produced.

He believes assaults are being under-reported, partly because teachers are afraid that they would be accused of being unable to control their classes if they admitted to such bad behaviour among their pupils.

"It is clear that in some schools, senior management appear not to take physical or verbal abuse seriously. There is a clear under-reporting of assaults by schools to their local education authority. No doubt one reason for this is the competitive climate schools are in, which means that, like teachers themselves, they are unwilling to admit to the scale of the problem, for fear that it will be used against them," Baker says.

Physical abuse for the purposes of the study was defined as "deliberate and inappropriate bodily contact such as pushing, pulling, grabbing, hitting and spitting with no regard to the physical well-being of the staff member".

In 17% of reported cases of deliberate assault, teachers said nothing at all had been done to discipline an offending pupil. A further one third received a verbal reprimand and/or detention, another third were excluded from certain lessons, but not excluded temporarily or permanently. Over half of the teachers surveyed, (56%), felt that the action taken to discipline such behaviour was ineffective.

"The lack of support from the heads of year, deputy heads and the headmaster add to the feeling that you are in a minority and fighting against the current trend," said one.

The physical abuse of teachers is an issue that is apparently ignored by many senior management teams within secondary schools. Only 20% of incidents formally reported were handled by the headteacher. "There should be 100% of headteachers involved in cases of physical abuse of teachers by pupils," said Baker.

One teacher commented: "I was appalled that management did not take it seriously and I was told to laugh it off." Another said: "I felt totally alone when I complained about being assaulted. I was disgusted that the parents were not involved and that I was not seen to be important."

Nearly 90% felt that ill-conceived government policies on exclusion were to blame and they also agreed that the loss of discipline was due to an erosion of the respect and authority of teachers, coupled with a lack of parental support in dealing with cases of bad behaviour. Placing highly disruptive pupils in mainstream schools was one of the main contributory factors.

"Some pupils should not be in mainstream schools for whatever reason. We are seen to be failing because they [the pupils] cannot cope with school life. You cannot accommodate such extreme cases of disruptive pupils."

The sense of frustration and demoralisation was obvious from the study, with 60% of teachers saying they wanted to leave the school they worked in. Half of all the teachers surveyed said they wanted to leave the profession because of the poor level of discipline in schools.

"From friends who have completed the course with me, many are leaving after just two years of teaching. The threat of disruption in class and the worry of physical and verbal abuse makes the job very stressful."

As from September 2000, schools will be fined £6,000 and also lose a grant of approximately £2,000 per pupil if a student is excluded. The financial incentive to keep highly disruptive pupils at school is huge, but supportive measures to deal with these pupils, such as the new learning support units, are not available in enough numbers.

"This makes me feel very sorry for the pupils who do wish to learn and have their education disrupted."

"The sooner a headteacher is taken to court for 'failure to provide a safe place to work' under the 1974 Health and Safety At Work Act, the better."

A Birmingham local education authority spokeswoman said: "We are, of course, extremely concerned at any instances where teachers' health and safety is under threat. All schools have clear policies on dealing with such events and Birmingham's millennium anti-bullying campaign is addressing issues of bullying against staff as well as pupils by providing additional resources and support to schools. We have not seen this particular research but would be very interested in having the opportunity to use it as we are continually striving to improve our support to schools and teachers."

Everyday acts of violence

I am a mainstream teacher and this 13- to 14-year-old boy was messing around in class with a dictaphone, passing it around his mates and distracting the class. I tried to carry on with the class and ignore him but he was still being disruptive, so I confiscated the dictaphone.

He came at me and cornered me in front of the class. He was verbally very aggressive and threatening. He tried to get it out of my hand by twisting my arm behind my back and prising open my fingers. He left marks on my arm and strained my fingers.

I managed to get out of the class and get help. He was taken out and permanently excluded from school.

Looking back, the management were sympathetic, but they did tell me that I shouldn't have confiscated the dictaphone.

I was writing something on the board in the middle of a lesson. Two pupils had stood up without my knowledge and immediately a fight broke out.

One of the boys then picked up the other and threw him across the room. He landed on me, pushing me against the board. This winded me and frightened me. The pupil that threw the boy at me was autistic.

He didn't set out to harm me deliberately but didn't fully realise how dangerous his actions could be. He was in a mixed-ability class and had learning difficulties. The pupils in the class with him also had behavioural difficulties.

I was in the corridor and saw a group of four girls make a mess in a classroom by throwing paper and rubbish around. I naturally asked them to tidy up their mess. They refused and were rude and arrogant, saying that I had no right to tell them what to do. They then deliberately pushed past me as a group and knocked me off my balance. I fell against the stairwell and injured my shoulder.

I passed on the information to more senior management but, as far as I know, nothing happened to the girls.

 Quotations in this article are not attributable because the questionnaire was conducted anonymously.

"From friends who have completed the course with me, many are leaving after just two years of teaching. The threat of disruption in class and the worry of physical and verbal abuse makes the job very stressful." As from September 2000, schools will be fined £6,000 and also lose a grant of approximately £2,000 per pupil if a student is excluded. The financial incentive to keep highly disruptive pupils at school is huge, but supportive measures to deal with these pupils, such as the new learning support units, are not available in enough numbers. "This makes me feel very sorry for the pupils who do wish to learn and have their education disrupted." "The sooner a headteacher is taken to court for 'failure to provide a safe place to work' under the 1974 Health and Safety At Work Act, the better." A Birmingham local education authority spokeswoman said: "We are, of course, extremely concerned at any instances where teachers' health and safety is under threat. All schools have clear policies on dealing with such events and Birmingham's millennium anti-bullying campaign is addressing issues of bullying against staff as well as pupils by providing additional resources and support to schools. We have not seen this particular research but would be very interested in having the opportunity to use it as we are continually striving to improve our support to schools and teachers." Everyday acts of violence I am a mainstream teacher and this 13- to 14-year-old boy was messing around in class with a dictaphone, passing it around his mates and distracting the class. I tried to carry on with the class and ignore him but he was still being disruptive, so I confiscated the dictaphone. He came at me and cornered me in front of the class. He was verbally very aggressive and threatening. He tried to get it out of my hand by twisting my arm behind my back and prising open my fingers. He left marks on my arm and strained my fingers. I managed to get out of the class and get help. He was taken out and permanently excluded from school. Looking back, the management were sympathetic, but they did tell me that I shouldn't have confiscated the dictaphone. I was writing something on the board in the middle of a lesson. Two pupils had stood up without my knowledge and immediately a fight broke out. One of the boys then picked up the other and threw him across the room. He landed on me, pushing me against the board. This winded me and frightened me. The pupil that threw the boy at me was autistic. He didn't set out to harm me deliberately but didn't fully realise how dangerous his actions could be. He was in a mixed-ability class and had learning difficulties. The pupils in the class with him also had behavioural difficulties. I was in the corridor and saw a group of four girls make a mess in a classroom by throwing paper and rubbish around. I naturally asked them to tidy up their mess. They refused and were rude and arrogant, saying that I had no right to tell them what to do. They then deliberately pushed past me as a group and knocked me off my balance. I fell against the stairwell and injured my shoulder. I passed on the information to more senior management but, as far as I know, nothing happened to the girls.  Quotations in this article are not attributable because the questionnaire was conducted anonymously.

webTitle: Scientists revel in a day of glory

fields.headline: Scientists revel in a day of glory
fields.standfirst:
New weapon in battle against cancer already shows startling success

The ethics of genetics: special report
fields.trailText: Scientists worldwide have a new weapon in the war against cancer with the long-awaited completion of the first draft of the "book of humanity", the complete text of human DNA, announced in London and Washington yesterday.
fields.body:
Scientists worldwide have a new weapon in the war against cancer with the long-awaited completion of the first draft of the "book of humanity", the complete text of human DNA, announced in London and Washington yesterday.

"It is now conceivable that our children and our children's children will know the term cancer only as a constellation of stars," President Clinton told Tony Blair in a joint announcement.

And Mr Blair called the completion of the human genome - 3bn chemical "letters" which spell out all the human genes - a "breakthrough that opens the way for massive advances." It was a day of glory for thousands of scientists who had worked on the project in Britain, France, Germany, Japan, China and the US.

And the news was greeted with delight by researchers everywhere.

"Today is the day in which the scientific community hands over its gift of the human genome sequence to humanity.

This is a gift that is very delicate, very fragile, very beautiful," said Mike Stratton, head of the cancer genome project at the Sanger Centre in Cambridge.

"With the handover of this fragile gift, we are also entrusting responsibility - responsibility to use it for the benefit of mankind, and not to misuse it."

Cancer experts have begun a complete catalogue of the DNA changes in cancer cells in the hope of totally new treatments and methods of prevention for one of the western world's biggest killers.

There could be 20 such genes in one cancer. There are 200 kinds of cancer. So far, researchers have counted about 100 genes with tiny mutations in their DNA.

"We have seen, in the last few months, the development of drugs targeted at abnormal genes and their proteins in cancer cells, and these drugs, some of them, have worked beyond our wildest expectations," said Dr Stratton, as British scientists passed a milestone in the understanding of the machinery of life. Cancer was the consummate disease of DNA, he said. From birth, the DNA in the 100 million million cells of any human were assaulted by chemicals, radiation and viruses.

The study of tumours had begun to reveal the genetic changes that turned cells cancerous. One dramatic advance was against chronic myeloid leukaemia, a slow-burning disease which can suddenly turn lethal.

It began with the disruption of the chromosomes which ended with two genes fusing together - and making an unusual protein which triggered the cancer.

Scientists identified a drug that would work against the protein, and began the usual "phase one" toxicity trials - on a group of very sick people for whom all other therapies had failed.

"To all our surprise and particularly theirs, 31 out of 31 people in this phase one trial went into remission," Dr Stratton said. "That is an extraordinary thing: all, in that first run, went into remission. So now, obviously, the drug is being taken through the other processes of trialling, rather quickly, one expects."

It will be years before the hard-won knowledge from the human genome project is translated into new, precise treatments tailored for both the disease and the patient.

But scientists were in no doubt of its ultimate potential.

It could lead to new treatments for a host of conditions, including child birth defects, skin diseases, muscular dystrophy, neurodegenerative diseases and cardiovascular conditions.

"A few months ago I compared the project to the invention of the wheel," said Dr Mike Dexter of the Wellcome Trust, which financed the British effort.

"On reflection it is more than that. I can well imagine technology making the wheel obsolete.

But this code is the essence of mankind, and as long as humans exist, this code is going to be important and will be used."

He spoke as American colleagues gathered for a joint declaration with the controversial Craig Venter, of Celera Genomics, who threatened to beat British and American government scientists to the prize, and who provoked a storm over questions of the ownership of the genome.

But he, too, saw ultimate victory over cancer. "Each day approximately 2,000 die in America from cancer," Dr Venter said.

"There's at least the potential to reduce the number of cancer deaths to zero during our lifetimes."

Dr Venter's entry into the field initially provoked furious exchanges, yesterday tactfully barely mentioned in the euphoria. But one of the giants of DNA, James Watson, who won the Nobel prize for deciphering the structure of DNA in 1953, writes in the Guardian today: "To our vast relief, the publicly supported effort received not less but more money. Our backers want to ensure that all the essential features of the human genome are available without cost to all the people of the world.

The events of the past few weeks have shown that those who work for the public good do not necessarily fall behind those driven by personal gain."

Useful links:

Human genome programme
Celera
GeneWatch UK: ethics and risks of genetic engineering
US national human genome research institute

fields.headline: Gene map benefits Oxford Biomedica
fields.standfirst: The ethics of genetics: special report
fields.trailText: The completion of the human genome project has triggered a blitz of scientific propaganda, as biotechnology companies try to join the vanguard of gene research.
fields.body:
The completion of the human genome project has triggered a blitz of scientific propaganda, as biotechnology companies try to join the vanguard of gene research.

Every drugs company has perfected a polished patter on the relevance of the new DNA blueprint to its business. All are hoping to benefit from a surge in interest from investors.

Oxford Biomedica can claim more relevance than most - it specialises in gene therapy. At a neurosciences conference in Brighton yesterday the company announced it had developed an efficient way of delivering genes to the brain, using a virus found in horses as a "transporter".

Gene therapy involves the use of genes to "reprogramme" cells that are malfunctioning. The use of a virus helps them spread through the body quickly.

Yesterday's breakthrough will be used to develop Oxford Biomedica's products for Parkinson's Disease, and could also lead to progress in treating Alzheimer's. The company's shares rose 3.5p to 59p.

Oxford Biomedica's chairman, Alan Kingsman, believes the completion of the genome project will help the company in the long term, because it will make genes easier to come by as targets for its new drug research. Furthermore, the company can tweak its existing gene research through reference to the completed genome map.

But the benefits to any company are long term. Chris Redhead, a biotech analyst at WestLB Panmure, says: "The human genome project will provide value eventually, but it's not going to be simple and it's not going to be fast."

The hype surrounding the genome project should help companies specialising in providing drug targets. There is also likely to be a shift in emphasis from genes to proteins - the body's by-products, which actually cause disease. Finally, patent experts - such as BTG - are likely to benefit from the inevitable ownership wrangles surrounding gene research.

The biotech sector ballooned when Celera announced it was 90% of the way towards mapping the human genome and share prices exploded. There is unlikely to be a repeat of this phenomenon, particularly as biotech shares are already, on average, up 100% over the past year.

Oxford Biomedica
Human genome programme
Celera
GeneWatch UK: ethics and risks of genetic engineering
US national human genome research institute
